DOC.HEAD: Pioneer of Modern Architecture Dead at 87
DOC.TEXT: William Muschenheim, a member of the group that helped launch the modern movement of architecture, has died at age 87. Muschenheim, a professor emeritus of architecture at the University of Michigan, died Thursday in Ann Arbor. The cause of death was not disclosed. His designs included the original facade of the New School for Social Research, the color scheme for the Chicago World's Fair of 1933, the Solomon Guggenheim Museum of Non-Objective Art and the Marine Transportation Building for the New York World's Fair in 1939. He was a member of CIAM, the French acronym for the International Congress of Modern Architects, which included Ludwig Mies van der Rohe, Walter Gropius and Le Corbusier and was instrumental in developing the modern movement in architecture. Muschenheim was a native of New York City, and his family owned the Hotel Astor there. He attended Williams College and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology before leaving for the Vienna Academy of Fine Arts to study with Peter Behrens, another pioneer of modern architecture. His student projects included a renovation of the Hotel Astor bar in the Bauhaus style. Muschenheim, whose books include ``Elements of the Art of Architecture'' and ``Why Architecture?'' joined the Michigan faculty in 1950 and retired in 1973. Survivors include his son, C. Arthur Muschenheim of London, and daughter Anneli Arms of New York City. Services are scheduled for Wednesday in the Auditorium, Art and Architecture Building on the Ann Arbor campus.

DOC.HEAD: Faced With Lingering Death, Some AIDS Patients Choose Suicide
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: They swallow deadly drugs, plunge out of windows, smash their cars and hang or shoot themselves at an alarming rate. And they do it because suicide seems better than the alternative: dying of AIDS. ``You have no control over this illness at all, so it gives me some kind of control when I can say I can end my life any time I want to,'' said Chuck Sporeman, a 43-year-old nurse who has AIDS. Sporeman tried to kill himself twice in December 1988, two months after his male companion of 13 years died of AIDS. He said he might try again when the disease leaves him unable to care for himself, but participation in a support group helps, at least for now. ``There are days where I wish I had done it, but there are other days when it's a beautiful day, the wind is blowing through the trees, I can go watch the waves crashing on the beach, and I'm glad I didn't do it,'' he said. The author of a 1988 Cornell University study estimates about 1,000 AIDS patients in the United States will kill themselves by 1991. The study found people with AIDS are 66 times more likely to commit suicide than the general population. ``It definitely happens all the time,'' said Andrew Weisser, spokesman for AIDS Project Los Angeles, a service agency where five of 2,100 AIDS-infected clients killed themselves in December. The relatively small number of AIDS-related suicides reported publicly ``is just the tip of the iceberg,'' Weisser said. ``There's no way for us to keep track,'' said Los Angeles County coroner's spokesman Bob Dambacher. ``If someone comes off a building, we don't know if they have AIDS. If they shoot themselves, we don't know.'' Such suicides graphically illustrate that mental health budget cuts and discrimination leave many AIDS patients without adequate counseling, Weisser asserts. Many AIDS patients who discuss suicide are ``calling out for help,'' he said. But hopelessness makes others kill themselves: _ A 28-year-old AIDS patient in San Diego drank all day, stole a car, swerved down the highway without headlights, then triggered a six-car accident that killed him and injured three others in April 1988. Paul James Curry ``was dying slow. I think he chose to die fast,'' a friend said. _ Two men who authorities said had AIDS tied themselves together, then jumped 35 floors off their New York apartment building in 1985. _ Philip Saylor, 40, took a revolver into Los Angeles' Cedars-Sinai Medical Center on Jan. 2, shot and killed his longtime companion, 35-year-old AIDS patient Steven Jenkins, then killed himself. Police said Saylor also was infected by the AIDS virus. After that tragedy, several experts said suicide can be a reasonable alternative if AIDS patients are thinking clearly and fully informed of all options. ``People have a right to kill themselves _ not early on when people first find they're infected, but when they have become sufficiently sick that the quality of their life is not satisfactory to them,'' said Dr. Neal Schram, a member of the California Medical Association's AIDS task force. Rabbi Allen Freehling, a member of the Los Angeles County Commission on AIDS, advises AIDS patients against killing themselves, saying suicide is a selfish act that can compound the grief of family and friends. ``In Ecclesiastes, it says there is a time to live and a time to die, and I don't think the author of that statement meant we should decide when that time is,'' Freehling said. A Cornell University study published this month found that people who have just learned they are infected by the AIDS virus but don't yet have symptoms are no more likely than other people to have suicidal thoughts _ if they receive proper counseling. Dr. Peter Marzuk, author of the earlier Cornell study, found patients face the greatest risks just after they are diagnosed, and again when AIDS' effects on the brain cause depression, delirium or other treatable psychiatric disorders. ``If you treat the depression, frequently these people will feel better and not feel driven to suicide,'' said Dr. Geoffrey Newstadt, a Cedars-Sinai psychiatrist. Marzuk's study, published in the Journal of the American Medical Association in 1988, found 12 suicides among 3,828 AIDS patients in New York City in 1985. He called it striking that three of them jumped from hospital windows _ an act repeated in 1986 by AIDS patients at hospitals in Eureka, Calif., and Dallas. A Cedars-Sinai AIDS patient jumped to his death a year ago, Newstadt said. Two other suicides in Marzuk's study had lovers who earlier died from AIDS, which Newstadt said can spur the depression that leads to suicide. Sporeman said he took care of his companion ``for the last year and a half of his life, and when he died I, being ill, saw no reason to go on. ... After the funeral, everybody goes back to their lives and you're left all alone.'' A study similar to Marzuk's found California men with AIDS are up to 21 times more likely than other men to kill themselves. The study, conducted by California's Department of Health Services, counted 13 AIDS-related suicides in 1986. Marzuk wrote that many AIDS-related suicides go uncounted because some people kill themselves without revealing they have the disease, while others might be cloaked as overdoses of prescribed medications or illicit drugs. Sporeman tried to inject a fatal air bubble and overdose of medicine in his first failed suicide attempt. Days later, he swallowed Valium and Percodan pills and downed alcohol as he walked around his house writing a will. A friend walked in and stopped him before he could swallow a fatal amount. Schram said it still is more common for AIDS patients to refuse heroic medical treatment, to let themselves die, than to commit suicide. There is ``a very thin line ... between maintaining a life and taking a life,'' Freehling said. That line can be hard to define, especially when AIDS patients often recover from repeated infections before they die. Some AIDS patients ask friends or lovers to help them commit suicide. In August, John Cleaves, 43, of San Diego was sentenced to 15 years to life in prison after being convicted of second-degree murder for strangling Dennis Eaton, 40. Cleaves contended he helped Eaton commit suicide. The development of AZT and other life-extending drugs may change the way AIDS is viewed from a fatal disease to a ``manageable chronic disease'' like some cancers. That could lower suicide rates, Schram said. AIDS patients have a right to decide to commit suicide, Newstadt said, but ``the problem is whether they have all of the information available to them about treatment possibilities.'' Of suicide, Sporeman said, ``Before the virus hits my brain or I'm unable to do things for myself, I want to be able to do it. I still have a plan to do it. ... Even if I don't do it, I feel I got control over the disease, because I can say, `Stop.'''

DOC.HEAD: Government Test Program Sets Standards for Condoms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Garage mechanics listen for pings. Piano tuners are alert for plunks. Donald E. Marlowe's job is to wait for the next POW! to shatter the silence of his laboratory. Marlowe is the government's chief condom tester, and the explosions come from an ``air burst'' test he is perfecting to measure sample condoms' resistance to pressure. Working in a low, nondescript building that the Food and Drug Administration shares with a furniture store in this Washington suburb, Marlowe demonstrates by slipping a latex condom onto a machine equipped with gauges, dials and the squiggly needle of an instrument that looks like a seismograph. Then he inflates the condom with air. It swells to the size of a good-sized watermelon before it bursts. The instruments record that it withstood 30 liters or about 7{ gallons of air and pressure of three-tenths of a pound per square inch, well above the government's exacting standard. ``Pretty tough,'' says Marlowe, a 49-year-old mechanical engineer who runs the division of mechanics and material science for the FDA's Center for Devices and Radiological Health. In another room, Marlowe takes a circular section cut from the middle of a condom, similar to a wide rubber band, and stretches it on a machine to test its tensile strength _ how far it will stretch before it snaps. Besides condoms, Marlowe's laboratory tests a wide variety of medical devices such as cardiac pacemakers, artificial hearts and valves, false eyes, syringes, pumps and bone, joint and ligament implants. Nearly four dozen of these prosthetic body parts are attached to ``Yorick,'' the FDA's bionic skeleton, which greets visitors to the laboratory where all the devices have been tested over the years. ``The FDA is responsible for the safety and effectiveness of medical devices, and condoms are a medical device,'' Marlowe said. Marlowe is accustomed to the snickers and jokes he sometimes hears about condoms. He chuckles indulgently about the time his staff, in a playful holiday mood, inflated some condoms with helium and tied them to the office Christmas tree. ``They looked great,'' he said. But Marlowe says that with widespread public concern over the AIDS epidemic and former Surgeon General C. Everett Koop's highly publicized campaign to promote safer sex, condoms are no laughing matter. Since the early 1960s, FDA agents at a Winchester, Mass., laboratory north of Boston have been conducting random, unannounced tests of sample condoms from domestic and foreign manufacturers for possible water leakage. During the year ended in April 1988, the FDA tested 115,000 condoms for possible pinholes or tears in this way, resulting in rejection of more than 30 million imported condoms as defective and the recall of 3 million domestic condoms from store shelves. Marlowe said his laboratory's air burst and tensile strength tests for condoms form the basis for an industrywide testing standard that was first published in 1973 and was revised most recently in November. That standard is recognized voluntarily by manufacturers, the government and consumer interests, including the U.S. Agency for International Development, which supplies condoms for Third World population control projects. Compliance is determined during the FDA's regular ``quality assurance'' inspections of manufacturers. ``Someone new coming into the lab gets over the bathroom humor about condoms very quickly,'' Marlowe said. ``This is serious business.''

DOC.HEAD: World's Last Wilderness To Be Set Aside as Nature Reserve
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: A cold, windswept plain in Tibet populated with scores of birds, plants and animals found nowhere else on Earth has been proposed as the world's largest nature reserve. The Chang Tang Reserve, named from the Tibetan words for ``northern plain,'' would encompass an area the size of California. The proposed territory covers one-sixth of the Tibet Autonomous Region and adjoining parts of the Chinese provinces of Qinghai and Xinjiang, said George Schaller, an American biologist who has explored the region and helped negotiate an agreement signed just days ago. ``It's one of the last, almost unexplored places on the face of the Earth,'' said Schaller, of Wildlife Conservation International in New York. ``It survives intact almost as it was 100 years ago.'' Schaller, one of the world's leading wildlife biologists, has done pioneering studies on gorillas, pandas, snow leopards and other endangered animals. He is one of the very few Westerners to have entered the Chang Tang region. Few local people have been there, either. Despite its size, it has a human population of no more than several hundred wandering herdsmen who live there for only a few months each year. When he returned from Chang Tang in late January, he brought with him an agreement with the Tibetan Environmental Protection Agency that outlines the steps to be taken to establish the reserve. An area of 100,000 square miles, about the size of Colorado, will be set aside in Tibet. The Tibetan EPA will coordinate the effort, with funds from Wildlife Conservation International and Tibetan and national agencies. Proposed additions in adjoining provinces would bring the size of the reserve to about 150,000 square miles, an area the size of California. ``We want to, in the next few years, find out what's there and the areas of particular importance,'' Schaller said. He plans to return in July. The research will be conducted with the Tibet Institute of Plateau Biology. The agreement calls the area ``a unique animal and plant community which includes such spectacular creatures as wild yak, Tibetan wild ass, Tibetan wild sheep, Tibetan gazelle, Tibetan antelope and Tibetan brown bear, all of which occur only on the Tibetan plateau.'' When asked to describe the region, he paused, searching for comparisons to convey the vastness and austere beauty of an area unlike any other. It has ``the aura of the Serengeti'' in East Africa, he said. ``You travel and travel toward a distant horizon, and the world seems to expand in front of you.'' The reserve is a high-altitude steppe at an elevation of about 3 miles. It is covered with scrub grasses no more than 6 inches high, lakes too salty to drink from, and jagged, inhospitable mountains. Winter temperatures can drop to 40 or 50 degrees below zero. Snow can fall any day of the year. ``And the winds,'' Schaller said. ``Oh, how the winds can howl across there.'' Four hundred species of plants have been found on the plateau, along with 60 species of birds. Wild yak gather in herds of 100 or 150. ``It's a real desert area, but it has oases around which animals congregate'' by the thousands, he said. Access to the reserve is normally by way of Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, a week's drive south of the proposed reserve. ``I've gone in from the north by camel caravan, but you cross such desolate country, it's difficult,'' Schaller said. The trip from Lhasa isn't a simple excursion either. ``You need two cars and a truck to carry gas,'' he said. Because of the need to carry gas, expeditions normally last no more than three months, he said. ``My preference would be to just have a herd of yak animals and live in there for a few years,'' he said. ``But politically that's not feasible.'' Schaller is willing, but ``most of the local people have families and they don't want to be out,'' he said. In an area so remote, is the establishment of a nature reserve really necessary? ``There is no such thing as a remote area any more,'' Schaller said. ``It's known there are minerals there. Near there oil has been discovered.'' Recalling the bison that once roamed the American plains in uncounted numbers, he said, ``They destroyed the bison in 15 years.''

DOC.HEAD: Color & Romance Pep Up Men's Clothing for Winter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The only common thread weaving through news about menswear for next winter is that guys will still be wearing pants. And even then, the trousers displayed at shows ending Monday ranged from fairly baggy to cigarette-style, with or without cuffs. Besides classic blazer jackets with vents, toppers are usually hooded toggle-buttoned duffel coats or puffy parkas. Otherwise, there's nearly as much romance and color to seduce male dandies as you see in women's styles, from brocade to rhinestone embroidery touches. The emphasis at Hermes was on incomparable silkscarf touches in linings on dress tails or bathrobe loungewear. The house's famed leather goods looked softer than ever in jodphur styles. Welsh designer Richard James went all-out for fantasy gear: bold tartan combinations of bermuda shorts, ties, jackets and sequined waistcoats worn with argyle socks or sweaters. His sequined-snowflake pastel velvet jogging outfits were adorable. Balmain's offerings by Patrick Aubert included a range of delectable colors and casual styles based on suits and separates in all ranges of chocolate brown, plum, cinnamon and curry or mustard. The cashmere blazers in everything from robin's egg blue to dusty rose and rust worn with paisley vests looked great for casual wear teamed with charcoal or blue denim jeans. The Lanvin message was dubbed ``a new language of color'' by Patrick Lavoix. Besides some sharp pinstripe or herringbone suits in soft wools, there were color combinations like burgundy, violet and rust shades with a dash of pine green, or mixes of greenish gray, chartreuse, cassis, teal blue and raspberry in an outfit. Lavoix's splendid touches of brocade vests with black tuxedos and lounging outfits in copper brocade would pep up any conservative's wardrobe. Jean-Charles de Castelbajac's selections ranged from fringed blanket lumberjack looks to startle Tonto right through soft plaid pants sporting peplum wraps and trains. The epicene fashions that a lady might covet also included full-skirted loden coats for a citified Henry David Thoreau returning to nature. Claude Montana's clothes were often minimalist styles in petrol blues, tobacco, sand shades in big duster-coats over casual, tieless gabardine suits. More fun for sportswear would be the brightly colored blazers with dark pants. Montana's evening wear would best be worn by the ``leather-bar'' set. Zombie-like, the models clomped around in all manner of nailhead-studded black leather blousons with narrow pants, plus some weird visored stiffened nylon-string caps Jean-Paul Gaultier put on a rousing show of fun featuring red-nosed cartoon characters, the Gallic version of the Three Stooges. They sometimes sported candleabra headgear sprouting shaving brushes instead of candles or big egret feathers. Gaultier also threw in some real clothes, notably well-cut brown and blue blazers and hooded duffels in ethnic-patterned fabrics. Yohji Yamamoto, the Japanese advocate of black, went in for a lot more color this time in patchwork jackets teaming checks, glen plaids, chevron and tweeds. Mossy green or brown shirts were in, ties were out. Issey Miyake put on a show of low-keyed practical clothes featuring plenty of puffy quilted windbreakers in ``wet'' or ``dry'' surface fabrics over corduroy pants and ground-grippers. The black evening wear featuring spencers or priests' collar jackets emerged from a hole in the floor on models carrying roses in a tango-rhythmed tribute to ``the dead and the dying,'' presumably a reference to victims of AIDS. Catherine Hamnett, English queen of laid-back styles for men and women, came up with a good siena-brown redingote with velvet collar as well as rust, mustard, caramel belted polo coats. The evening wear was a sparkly fireworks show based on black dressy fabrics with red sequin and crystal trim _ the glitziest number in an all-sequined bluejean-suit look with bomber jacket. The Yves Saint Laurent show by designer Bernard Sanz offered true originality in wearable classics updated with new color schemes and light, soft fabrics. His shades of silvery gray and creamy white should please anyone from Minneapolis to Montreal. The handsome toggle-buttoned duffel coats with knit caps topped jersey pants tucked into heavy cable socks or corduroy bicycle knickers with black-laced beige suede high-top shoes. The new fox or wolf-collared panther-spotted windbreakers with contrasting quilted satin linings looked handsome over tweed jackets, button-down corduroy shirts and lean pants. They turned up in various shades of tobacco, curry and old gold, with flowered or fruit ties and long fringed silk scarfs adding a festive touch.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Immigration Wave Boosts Israeli Spirit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A massive influx of Soviet Jews is reawakening a sense of national pride among Israelis, who are volunteering to help the newcomers and even furnishing whole apartments for them. The outpouring of good will has surprised government officials and immigration activists who just weeks ago were having trouble shaking Israelis out of their attitude of suspicion toward new immigrants. ``It's as though a revolution has struck Israeli society. In many places we have more volunteers ready to help the immigrants than we have immigrants,'' said Yuri Stern, a Russian immigrant and an adviser to Parliament's Committee on Immigration Absorption. ``For the first time in many years, Israelis are seizing this chance to fulfill their destiny and their major reason for being,'' said Stern, referring to Israel's founding as a homeland for all Jews in 1948. The dream of ``ingathering'' the exiles was popularized by Israel's first prime minister, David Ben-Gurion, who spoke of ``aliyah,'' a biblical word for ``moving up'' to the Holy Land, as a top national priority along with building an army. As the immigrant flow rises, Israelis also are realizing the numbers of Jews in their country is being significantly enhanced _ a welcome prospect with figures showing the Arab population growing faster than the Jewish population. ``The demographic issue bothered Israeli society in a way that many people just submerged, and now they see another half-million Jews may arrive. It's a historic development for us,'' said Michael Kleiner, a member of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc who chairs Parliament's Immigration Committee. Kleiner said the immigration wave also provided a psychological lift after more than two years of the Palestinian uprising that has divided Israelis and damaged the country's image abroad. ``I don't remember this rise in spirits since the Six Day War'' of 1967, when Israel defeated three Arab armies, Kleiner said. The influx began last year when 12,000 Soviets arrived, more than five times the total in 1988. The pace quickened in January with 4,800 arrivals, and the government predicts up to 100,000 Soviets will immigrate by year's end. In the next decade, officials say, 500,000 Soviet Jews could settle in Israel because of liberalized Kremlin exit policies, growing unrest in the Soviet Union and tighter U.S. visa restrictions. With the Israeli government too financially strapped to handle the rush of arrivals, at least 50 voluntary organizations are working nationwide, along with dozens of neighborhood councils, to encourage Israelis to ``adopt'' Soviet families. Thousands of individual citizens also have organized projects. In Jerusalem's Gilo neighborhood, for example, Meir and Rachel Monsonego helped furnish an apartment across the hall when immigrants Victor and Katya Savitsky moved in. ``We need these immigrants and we want them to stay, so we have to help,'' said Meir Monsonego, an electric company worker who emigrated from Morocco at the age of 10. The Savitskys, who have an infant and an 8-year-old daughter, Lena, arrived with only an old green trunk full of clothes. Victor, 40, an engineer and translator of scientific documents, said he left Moscow because he feared growing anti-Semitism. Savitsky said he considered trying to join relatives in the United States. Now, he said, he would prefer to land a job in Israel. As his 11-month-old daughter Sophya crawled on the floor, Savitsky gestured toward gifts from neighbors: a crib and a child's bed, a new gas range, an electric heater and a living room armchair. ``I like the openness of people that I have found here. It's an important thing, especially when you are new,'' Savitsky said. Across town in Jerusalem's Neve Yaacov suburb, retired traffic safety official Tuviah Diamant took Asya Eisenstadt, an economist from Minsk, to Israel's Bank Leumi to try to get her a job despite her broken Hebrew. ``We need to encourage as many immigrants as possible,'' he told the bank manager, who said he would consider the application. Elitzur Mordechai, a social worker who is organizing volunteers in Jerusalem's East Talpiot quarter, said many Israelis empathized with the newcomers, who must deal with red tape and infighting among government agencies. This week, their plight was worsened by a walkout of 350 immigration employees in a labor dispute. ``We get involved emotionally when we see people put in unpleasant circumstances arriving at empty apartments,'' Mordechai said. Contrasting with the warm welcome from most Israelis is lingering resentment among many Sephardi Jews, those from Arab and Asian countries. They claim the newcomers are better treated than their relatives were during the 1950s wave of immigration. They worry that Soviet immigrants will be given jobs and welfare funds that would otherwise go to Sephardis. A typical complaint came from Jerusalem shopkeeper Nahum Cohen, whose parents were from Syria. He went into a tirade in his dusty clothing store as he heard Shamir quoted by the radio as saying the Russians ``can live anywhere they choose.'' ``I'm glad they're coming to fill the country with Jews. But why do the Russians get to live in the big cities, while many of our families were forced to help settle the Negev desert? This is discrimination,'' Cohen said.

DOC.HEAD: Royal Navy Taking Women to Sea in Warships
DOC.TEXT: Women will be at sea in British warships by the end of this year, ending a longstanding ban on women in combat roles because there is a shortage of male recruits, the government says. Women will also be eligible to join the Royal Marines and fly Navy aircraft but will be barred from submarines, where privacy cannot be provided in cramped conditions, the defense ministry said in Monday's announcement. The ministry said ships will be modified to allow women to live in them and aircraft carriers will be among the first to have women in their crews. It said women will initially be employed as radio and radar operators and in engineering work on aircraft. Archibald Hamilton, armed forces minister, told the House of Commons that the Admiralty was unanimous in the decision and expected that women would be quickly accepted after initial opposition from some sailors _ and their wives. The navy, army and air force have recruited women for many years but not for combat roles and the army and air force will continue that ban. The ministry said the difference is in the nature of naval operations and the fact that combat at sea is different to that on land or in the air. The Dutch navy has had women among its crews for several years. A few women with a taste for the rough life joined the Royal Navy disguised as men in the 18th century days of Adm. Horatio Nelson and several served at the battle of Trafalgar in 1805. Navy records indicate that when discovered, some of the women were allowed to stay on board as long as they continued to wear men's clothes.

DOC.HEAD: Lebanon's Christians Have Long History of Feuds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: The battle between rebel Gen. Michel Aoun and militia chief Samir Geagea is one of the bloodiest episodes in the long power struggle among Maronite Catholics, Lebanon's dominant Christian sect. Since the Lebanese civil war began in April 1975, the Christians have sought to present a united front against Moslems and leftists, who have had support from Syria, Iran and Libya. Disputes among Moslems factions frequently turn into armed confrontations, but the Christians usually have been able to avoid open war among themselves. Lebanon's Maronites are the only Christians to hold power in the Middle East. Maronites have dominated the army, government and judiciary since independence from France in 1943, and before Aoun, the military generally stayed out of the civil war. Its first serious involvement came last year when Aoun, then army commander, went to war with Syrian troops in Lebanon and fought sporadic actions against Geagea's powerful Lebanese Forces, the main Christian militia. President Amin Gemayel appointed Aoun interim prime minister in September 1988, when his six-year term ended with Parliament unable to agree on a successor, and the general considers himself the only legitimate authority in Lebonon. He does not recognize Elias Hrawi, a fellow Maronite who was elected president in November and fired him as army commander. The Christian power struggle has centered on the three most powerful Maronite dynasties: Gemayels, Chamouns and Franjiehs. Each family had its private army, lucrative interests and political influence, and each produced presidents of Lebanon. By unwritten agreement since independence, Lebanon's president has been a Maronite, the prime minister a Sunni Moslem and the speaker of Parliament a Shiite Moslem. Rivalries between the Christian clans has claimed hundreds of lives in the last 15 years. The right-wing Phalangists of the late Pierre Gemayel fought the Tigers militia of former President Camille Chamoun in February 1976, 10 months after the civil war began. As the war dragged on, the Gemayels tried to become supreme among the Maronites. Gemayel's charismatic youngest son, Bashir, emerged as their military leader and in 1978 he began trying to eliminate his rivals. His first target was the Franjiehs, who had allied themselves with the Syrians and had a fiefdom in north Lebanon centered on the mountain town of Zghorta. Scores of militiamen were killed in shootouts. On June 13, Bashir Gemayel sent 100 men to attack former President Suleiman Franjieh's summer palace at Ehden, 65 miles north of Beirut. The assault was led by Samir Geagea, a young former medical student and policeman's son who had impressed Bashir. The raiders killed Franjieh's oldest son Tony; his wife, Vera; their 3-year-old daughter, Jehane, and 30 bodyguards. Tony Franjieh was his father's heir apparent, a member of Parliament and commander of the clan's militia _ the Marada, or Giants. In February 1980 a car bomb killed Bashir Gemayel's daughter, Maya, and seven Phalangists. More more than 300 Phalangists were killed in the months that followed. By 1980, Bashir had merged the Phalange militia and other Christian groups into the Lebanese Forces and taken over interests that produced an estimated $100 million a year. On July 7, his militia defeated Chamoun's Tigers, a force of 2,000 men, in one of the bloodiest showdowns in the Christian enclave north and east of Beirut. Gemayel's fighters showed no mercy. In one Chamounist coastal resort, they cut power to the elevators and worked their way through the building, hurling people from the upper floors and shooting at them as they fell to their deaths. Police said more than 300 people were slain. Chamoun's son Dany claimed the total was 530. Bashir Gemayel was elected president in September 1982, after the Israeli invasion of Lebanon, and Moslems appeared ready to deal with him. He was killed by a bomb at Phalange headquarters nine days before inauguration and his brother, Amin, became president instead. After Bashir's death, Phalangist militiamen slaughtered hundreds of Palestinians in Beirut's Sabra and Chatilla refugee camps. In January 1986, Geagea teamed up with Amin Gemayel to oust the militia commander, Elie Hobeika, who had signed a treaty with Moslem militia chieftains arranged by Syria. More than 350 people were killed. A year ago, Aoun attacked the Lebanese forces to curb Geagea's growing power. At least 82 people were killed in three days of fighting in Christian east Beirut. Aoun won the battle but could not crush the Lebanese forces, and the ultimate result was the battle that began Jan. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Brumley To Become Moscow Bureau Chief
DOC.TEXT: Bryan Brumley, an Associated Press newsman who has worked in Moscow, Warsaw, Tokyo and Washington, will move to the AP's Moscow bureau in April and become the next bureau chief later in the year. The appointment was announced Monday by AP President Louis D. Boccardi. Brumley will succeed Michael Putzel. Putzel, who is completing a three-year assignment as Moscow bureau chief, will return to Washington, where he last served as White House correspondent. Brumley, 37, currently covers national security issues for the AP in Washington. He is a native of Fort Worth, Texas, and a graduate of the University of Texas, where he earned a degree in history, and studied Russian in Moscow and Leningrad. He has continued Russian area studies at Georgetown University. Brumley joined the AP in Washington in 1977. He transferred to the Foreign Desk in New York in 1979 and was assigned to Tokyo the following year. He transferred to Moscow in 1981 and was named correspondent in Warsaw, Poland, in 1982. Brumley returned to New York two years later, working on the World Services desk and in the New York bureau before transferring to Washington in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Former China Institute President Dies in Arizona
DOC.TEXT: Paul Chih Meng, former president of the China Institute in America, has died at the age of 100. Meng, who died Sunday, lived in this retirement community about two years after spending much of his life in New York City. Meng was born in Beijing, and was a descendant of Mencius, the founder of neo-Confucianism. He moved to the United States in the fall of 1919 after his release from prison for revolting against pro-Japan Chinese officials. He entered Columbia University, and earned a master's degree. In 1930, Meng was appointed director of the China Institute in New York. After the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941, Meng helped create a special fund to aid Chinese students stranded in the United States. He also worked with the State Department to create scholarship and training grants for students. Meng received an honorary doctoral degree from the University of Southern California in 1946. He retired from the institute in 1967. He continued to work until a stroke forced him to curtail his activities. He is survived by his wife, Huan-Shou; a daughter, a son and a grandchild. A memorial service for Meng is scheduled for Wednesday at the insititute.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Budget Worries Tank Plant Workers
With PM-Bush's Military, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: At the Beer Barrel Saloon, the talk was uncharacteristically sober. No Super Bowl reminiscing. No dreaming of spring fishing. Patrons talked of tanks and President Bush. Bush's proposal last week to end orders for the Lima-built M-1 tanks was a direct hit on their jobs. They work at the Lima Army Tank Plant, and his plan could put them and thousands of others out of work. ``I got this bad feeling that the plant is going to close for good,'' said Pat Sample, a 31-year-old welder who has worked at the northwestern Ohio plant since 1982. ``A lot of people feel the same way.'' Sample's friend Wayne Thomas shook his head, saying: ``It doesn't make sense. We make the best damn tanks in the world, and now the government says it doesn't want them.'' In the president's 1991 budget proposal, the plant would close along with a sister General Dynamics Corp. tank plant in Warren, Mich. Some believe the Lima factory, Allen County's largest employer, will never reopen after its scheduled March 1993 closing; others are more optimistic, saying the factory will keep operating _ even if on a smaller scale. ``I think what our workers have to remember is that this is just a proposal. It's not the bottom line and Congress hasn't acted on it yet,'' said Darrell Cole, president of United Auto Workers union Local 2075, which represents 1,800 production and maintenance workers at the plant. ``I think there are some people around in Congress that think we need some tanks.'' More than 13,000 Ohio workers depend on the plant for their jobs, including 2,600 employed by General Dynamics and 11,000 by suppliers. U.S. Rep. Michael Oxley, a Republican whose district includes Lima, has promised to urge fellow House members to modify the proposal. General Dynamics also promises to lobby against the proposal. Oxley said tank production should not be reduced when the Soviet Union's tanks outnumber the United States by 3-1. He also said one option to keep the Lima plant operating was to export tanks. Army spokesman Lt. Col. Dick Bridges said plans call for the factory to be idle until the military begins production of its next generation of the Army's main battle tank and other heavy vehicles. The starting date probably won't be before 1994. Bridges said the proposed Pentagon budget of $303 billion provides for production of 163 M-1A1 tanks and 62 M-1A2 tanks. He said the Lima plant, now in M-1A1 production, would be closed after completing production of the tanks in the 1991 budget. This city of 50,000, once a manufacturing hub carved out in the middle of rich farm land, has lost thousands of manufacturing jobs in recent years. Many of the laid off workers found jobs at the plant. Mayor David Berger said closing the plant would be devastating. ``The community would be really hurt,'' he said. ``Those are very high-paying positions, and to replace those would be very difficult.'' A plant closing, though, is not without precedent. It was opened in 1942 by United Motors Service, a General Motors Corp. division. During Word War II, it handled nearly every type of vehicle in the Amry's motorized fleet, including amphibious landing craft, cargo carriers and tanks. But after the Korean War, its importance declined, and in 1959, it closed. It didn't reopen until 1976, with the production of the M-1 tank; the Army spent $40 million in plant renovations. Chrysler Corp. ran the plant until 1982, when it sold its defense subsidiary to General Dynamics, which renamed it the Lima Army Tank Center. General Dynamics' four-year $3.5 billion contract with the Army to produce 3,299 M-1 tanks is in its final year. The 67-ton tank has a top speed of 45 mph and is considered the world's most advanced battle tank. Some don't see the closing as all bad. ``I hate to see it happen,'' said Don Downhour, 72, a production control worker at a Westinghouse plant before he retired. ``It will hurt Lima, but we don't need tanks if we're going to have peace, and that's what we've been praying for.''

DOC.HEAD: Few Tangible Reforms Since Bloody Coup Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Two months after mutineers nearly toppled President Corazon Aquino, there have been few signs of steps to combat the social, economic and political problems that contributed to the coup attempt. Instead, most efforts have been directed at tracking down those behind the bloody Dec. 1-9 uprising and at presenting a facade of normalcy to lure back foreign investors and tourists. Bold words about swift punishment for ``enemies of the people'' and a ``new beginning'' have bogged down. Rumors of a new coup attempt fill the capital's newspapers despite the arrests of several key conspirators. Mrs. Aquino's declaration of a 60-day national state of emergency has made little difference, except to allow the state to set price controls on rice and other essentials and to assume operation of some transport companies. The pattern is similar to the government's response to the August 1987 coup attempt. Then, Mrs. Aquino declared herself a ``committee of one'' to ride herd over a bloated, inefficient bureaucracy. A few months later, it was business as usual: Garbage went uncollected, telephones broke down and transport deteriorated. ``The political situation remains unsettled,'' U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Carl Ford told the House subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific last week. ``Many wonder whether the government can recover from the blow sufficiently to restore popular confidence and make lasting strides toward stability.'' Some observers fear the military has become so politicized that Mrs. Aquino can do little to end the coup attempts, which have plagued her since she took power in the February 1986 uprising against Ferdinand Marcos. ``What can Mrs. Aquino do to stop more coups? Nothing,'' wrote Teodore Locsin Jr., publisher of the Philippine Daily Globe and Mrs. Aquino's sometimes speechwriter. That presents a formidable challenge to President Bush, who is committed to supporting Mrs. Aquino and ordered U.S. warplanes to help crush the December coup. Since the coup attempt, in which 113 people were killed and more than 600 injured, an appearance of normalcy has returned. Most of the nighttime roadblocks near the presidential palace have been removed. There is no evidence of large-scale flight of capital. But the peso is weakening against the dollar. Inflation reached 14 percent in December and is expected to remain in double-digits this year. Private economists predict economic growth will slow to between 4 percent and 5 percent from 5.5 percent last year. During the coup attempt, rebel leaders cited a failure of leadership, corruption, inefficiency, rising prices and deteriorating infrastructure as reasons for removing Mrs. Aquino. Mrs. Aquino never publicly acknowledged any validity to rebels' demands and instead branded them ``power-grabbers'' and ``mad dogs'' seeking to restore a Marcos-style dictatorship. Three weeks later, however, she revamped her Cabinet, replacing secretaries of transport, agriculture, agrarian reform and other departments which had come under the sharpest public criticism. But personnel shifts have not been matched by dramatic changes in policy. In some cases, stopgap measures to correct one problem exacerbated others. For example, in the weeks before the coup attempt, Manila was plagued by frequent electric power outages, which the National Power Corporation blamed on the palace's failure to approve purchase of new generating equipment. During the coup attempt, the outages ceased, and Christmas lights returned to public streets. Later, the government acknowledged that it increased power output by diverting drinking water to hydroelectric projects. Now, Manila faces a critical water shortage. Corruption remains endemic. During testimony in Washington last week, U.S. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State David Lambertson said: ``Corruption remains a real problem in the Philippines and its corrosive effects hamper government operations.'' Critics blame much of the government's inefficiency on a bureaucratic presidential staff that fails to coordinate and prioritize policy. Cabinet members and department heads are retained or fired because of loyalty to Mrs. Aquino, critics say. Miriam Defensor Santiago, who was removed as agrarian reform secretary in December, complained that weekly Cabinet meetings had degenerated into fruitless debating seminars. ``What happened is that it became a workshop, a seminar, where everyone could speak off the cuff on subjects where their knowledge was only skin deep,'' Mrs. Santiago said. Complaints persist that the government is unable to use foreign aid effectively. Elliot Richardson, President Bush's special representative to the international Philippine aid plan, said recently the government must demonstrate it can spend money effectively if it expects Congress to approve $200 million in aid. Most changes in government policy must be approved by the unwieldy bicameral Congress, established after Mrs. Aquino took power. Even the state of emergency had to be ratified by Congress, which rejected administration requests for curbs on strikes and other tough measures. Blas Ople, an opposition politician and member of the 1986 Constitutional Commission, said the framers of the charter should have forged a more streamlined, single chamber. Some observers believe no reforms will satisfy dissidents in the military, deeply politicized during Marcos' eight years of martial law. Politicization deepened in 1986 when dissident officers mutinied against Marcos, triggering the ``people power'' revolution which toppled his administration. ``We opened a Pandora's box when we admired and lionized rebel soldiers (in 1986),'' said Brig. Gen. Rodolfo Biazon, who played a key role in crushing the December coup. Military sources claim opposition to Mrs. Aquino is broad-based in the 160,000-member armed forces and that many units are ready to strike again.

DOC.HEAD: Threats Remain Following Gandhi's Fall From Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Rajiv Gandhi lost the prime ministry and most of his 1,800 security guards after national elections, but death threats from Sikh extremists remain as he moves from his government compound to a smaller home. Spike-pointed fences, metal detectors and watch towers are being installed outside Gandhi's new three-bedroom bungalow to protect him from the Sikhs, who assassinated his mother, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. Some say he faces another threat at his new address _ ghosts. Three former officials, including Gandhi's younger brother, Sanjay, died after moving into the 30-year-old house. Previous occupants or their servants lit candles every evening under a massive banyan tree in a Hindu ceremony to try to drive out evil spirits. ``I personally do not believe that this house is haunted, but I am told that there is something,'' said Krishna Kant Tiwari, its last occupant. ``I thought it proper that I should tell Mr. Gandhi about it. But our leader does not believe in ghosts, demons or stuff like haunted houses.'' Tiwari was Gandhi's minister of information and broadcasting and lost his seat in Parliament in the November elections. Former Prime Minister Lal Bahadur Shastri, who died in office in 1965, once lived there. A senior government adviser died after moving to the house. Sanjay Gandhi had his office at the home when he was killed stunt-flying his light plane in 1980. Although none of the three died in the house, the ghost stories persisted and the house remained unoccupied until Tiwari arrived in 1985. Tiwari's wife continued the custom of lighting a candle under the banyan tree and often summoned priests to perfom ``pujas,'' or religious ceremonies. Hindus believe ghosts are scared of fire, and the flame was meant as an evocation of the Hindu fire god, Agni. Since losing his job to V.P. Singh in November's election, Gandhi has stayed in the prime minister's compound while his new home was being renovated. In moving to the bungalow, Gandhi, his wife, Sonia, and their two children are losing most of their 1,800 security guards. The number of guards assigned to the new residence has not been disclosed for security reasons. The Times of India said Sunday that the opposition Congress Party leader would now have about 125 security men, while the Sunday Observer, without giving numbers, claimed the new contingent of bodyguards would be one-sixth the size of the old group. The new government says the 45-year-old Gandhi, a former airline pilot, will continue to be adequately protected. But threats remain from Sikh separatists, who Gandhi, like his mother, sought to quell by expelling them from their faith's holiest shrine, the Golden Temple in the northern city of Amritsar. Gandhi took office on Oct. 31, 1984, the day his mother was assassinated. While in office, his entourage included decoy cars and ambulances carrying people with the same blood type as Gandhi, should he need it. Under the security network, which cost $176 million annually, flights were diverted whenever Gandhi was in the air. ``We even protected Mr. Gandhi from possible Stinger missile attack threats. Will this government do it?'' asked Palaniappam Chidambaram, Gandhi's former internal security minister. ``Let there be no doubt whatsoever that Mr. Gandhi is, and will continue to be, the target of terrorist groups.'' According to a well-placed source, secret service agents foiled at least four assassination plots against Gandhi after he became prime minister. The only publicly known attempt against Gandhi came in 1986 when a lone gunman penetrated his security cordon at a public memorial and fired at him from a crude 12-gauge shotgun. Gandhi was not hit, but two other people were wounded, The gunman was captured, and his trial is still underway. ``Threats develop overnight, but do not recede overnight,'' said Chidambram. ``And in the case of Mr Gandhi there is no sign that it will ever recede.''

DOC.HEAD: Conspicuous Consumption the Rule in Cash-Rich Hong Kong
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Walk into any 7-Eleven store in this British colony, look past the Slurpee machine to the liquor selection and start counting; chances are up to a dozen brands of French cognac will be on display. Welcome to Hong Kong, where prosperity and an obsession with status blend to create what may be the world's capital of conspicuous consumption. Cognac flows like water, luxury cars jam the streets, pricy portable telephones are the rage and droves of people spend small fortunes on flashy wristwatches. ``There's a lot of ostentatious display among Hong Kong people ... because the achievement of wealth is such a driving force in people's lives,'' explains S.K. Cheong, head of marketing for Television Broadcasts Ltd., the territory's No. 1 television station. A recent international survey conducted by the marketing firm Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide found that nearly half of Hong Kong people say owning expensive cars and jewelry are important goals. Only one-third of Japanese and one-quarter of Americans surveyed felt the same way. Here are the stats that tell the story: _About 12 percent of the private cars on Hong Kong roads are Mercedes-Benz, which cost from nearly $40,000 to more than three times that amount, according to C.P. Moore, managing director of the local dealership. ``As far as we know, that is the highest penetration on Earth'' for Mercedes, he said. Nearly 1,000 Rolls Royce luxury automobiles, which can cost almost $400,000, cruise the local streets, giving this tiny British colony of 5.7 million people the ``highest concentration of Rolls Royces in the world,'' said Russell Blythe, sales and marketing manager of the Hong Kong dealer. _Nearly 50 brands of wristwatches, most of them among the priciest on the market, were advertised on Hong Kong's four television channels last year. Bulgari, an exclusive Italian manufacturer of jewelry, has two stores in Hong Kong and eight for the rest of the world. The most popular Bulgari watches cost about $4,500 but are often out of stock here. _About 100 fur retailers are listed in the 1990 telephone book of this sub-tropical city, whose climatic claim to fame is stifling heat and humidity for much of the year. _About 70,000 handheld portable telephones, which generally cost $1,500 or more, have been sold in Hong Kong, although pay phones and community phones are ubiquitous. _Per capita consumption of cognac is widely believed to be the highest in the world, with 357,000 cases of brandy entering the colony last year, or slightly more than one bottle per person age 20 or older. Shelves of neighborhood food stands often are stocked with bottles priced at $200. In explaining such sales, local analysts note that the rapid growth of Hong Kong's export-led economy in the past decade made millionaires of many local entrepreneurs and left countless other people with money to spend. The low business and personal tax rates in the colony have ensured a high level of disposable income. But the thirst for status, or ``face,'' among the local Chinese appears to be the main driving force behind the colony's conspicuous consumption. ``When they have accumulated some wealth they like to spend it on visible things to show off,'' says Joseph Wan, finance director for Dickson Concepts Ltd., which has recorded 50 percent compound annual growth for the past five years by selling expensive name brands in Hong Kong and elsewhere in the region. ``It's an affluent city, everybody wants respect,'' agrees James J.S. Wong, host of the popular late-night talk show ``No Restrictions Tonight.'' Cheong, the television marketing manager, believes social pressure is intense to acquire possessions that advertise one's wealth. He acknowledged considering buying a wristwatch for several thousand dollars because of peer pressure. Still, the local demand for status-enhancing products may not be limitless. Sales of some luxury goods fell after Chinese troops ruthlessly quashed the pro-democracy movement in Beijing, and the long-term health of the market is unclear with Hong Kong being handed over to Communist China in 1997. Although Beijing has guaranteed that Hong Kong can maintain its freewheeling capitalist ways until the middle of the 21st century, many local residents are skeptical of such promises. But for now, capitalism and conspicuous consumption remain very much alive in the territory. ``I see it as a beauty of Hong Kong rather than a minus,'' said Wong. ``You work hard and you make your fortune, and now you're allowed to show that. ``It's another form of freedom.''

DOC.HEAD: Adjusting the Census: Politics vs. Statistics?
DOC.TEXT: After the forms are filled in and the computers are whirring away, the time will come for one of the most controversial political decisions ever for the U.S. Census _ whether to adjust the results to make up for undercounting in some areas. None of the 20 prior U.S. censuses has managed to count everybody and no one expects this national head count to be perfect either. But this year, for the first time, some statisticians believe they can significantly improve the results by adjusting the final numbers. And since the final figures are used to distribute billions of dollars in federal funds _ and seats in the House of Representatives _ forces on both sides of the issue are already at war. A Census Bureau analysis estimated that the 1980 national head count missed more than 3 million people, or 1.4 percent of the population. It wouldn't make much difference if that were spread out evenly, but it isn't. Minorities and poor people living in large cities are missed more often than others. It's harder to count Hispanics too, especially those who are here illegally. Men are missed more often than women; young people more than the elderly; and overall, young black men are missed most often. New York and a group of other large cities, contending the undercount cheated them of money and representation, sued for an adjustment in the 1980 census. The government responded that it was unable to improve the count, and the courts rejected the suit. But in the meantime, statisticians worked out methods they believe can make the necessary adjustments and improve the census. Their plan would use an extensive post-census survey in selected areas to check on how many people were missed. By comparing that survey with the census for the same regions they could estimate the undercount. The estimate then could be used to adjust the figures for all similar areas. Enough surveys would allow adjustment of the whole census, statisticians contend. But in 1987, the Commerce Department announced there would be no adjustment in 1990. Department officials contended the methods were not proven and that changing the numbers would shake public confidence in the figures. Since the blacks and other minorities most often missed are mostly Democrats, there was an outcry that the decision was a crass political move by the Reagan administration. Barbara A. Bailer, a top Census official, resigned over the action, saying the Census bureau hadn't been consulted by the Commerce Department. And New York City, New York state, California, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston, Dade County, Fla., and several civil rights groups filed another lawsuit. That one was settled with an agreement that the government would reconsider adjustment and would publish criteria for deciding whether to adjust the figures. The final decision on adjustment is to be made by July 15, 1991 _ 15 months after the April 1 official count. But those backing an adjustment say the decision has already been made. The guidelines suggest changing the count only if it can be shown that the results would be more accurate on both a national and local level, and discourage adjustment if it would result in confusion, disrupt the political process or undermine public confidence in the census numbers. The proposed guidelines ``so stack the deck against the possibility of correction that their adoption will be tantamount to a decision not to correct the differential undercount,'' charged New York Attorney General Robert Abrams. Michael R. Darby, Commerce undersecretary for economic affairs, said the department hopes to take such an accurate census that adjustment won't be needed. But if adjustment has to be considered, he said, the guidelines are still under development and can be modified. Observed Rep. William R. Thomas, R-Calif.: ``The census is a political act and there are winners and losers. The losers say `count differently,' and the winners say `leave it alone.''' Meanwhile, the Census Bureau says it is hiring 315,000 temporary workers, in addition to its usual staff, to track down people who don't mail back the census forms they will receive in late March. In April and May 200,000 census workers will go into neighborhoods, small towns and across rural America to interview people. Another 115,000 workers will remain in offices tabulating information and contacting people by phone, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Found in Paper Sack in Hospital Parking Lot
DOC.TEXT: A 7-pound baby boy was found in a paper bag in a hospital parking lot by a driver who had steered around the sack. ``Baby Doe,'' 1 to 2 days old, was doing well Sunday at Southwest Washington Medical Center. Vicky Morrow was taking her mother to the hospital for a checkup Saturday evening when she spotted the bag. She said she avoided running it over because she thought it might contain glass or nails and damage her tires. After she got out of the car, she said, she heard the baby crying. The baby, wrapped in a towel, was taken to the emergency room and was found to be in good condition without any apparent ill effects from the cool temperatures, which were in the 40s, said nursing supervisor Libby Sturtevant. Sheriff's deputies have npt determined who abandoned the infant.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Aviator's Scarf Spacebound on Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: Two generations of aviation history will be linked April 19 when a scarf once worn by Amelia Earhart rockets into space aboard the space shuttle Discovery, Purdue University officials say. The scarf was presented Saturday to astronauts Jerry L. Ross and Donald E. Williams, both alumni of Purdue, where Earhart trained for the 1937 around-the-world flight during which she disappeared over the Pacific. Ross and Williams will take the scarf to the Johnson Space Center in Houston and give it to fellow astronaut and Purdue alumni Loren Shriver, who will command the shuttle mission. The square brown, gold and orange silk scarf is part of a collection of Earhart memorabilia at Purdue, where she was a counselor to female students from 1935-37. ``When Amelia Earhart made her flights, it was a breakthrough in aviation at the time,'' said Helen Q. Schroyer, a Purdue librarian who has cared the memorabilia. ``Amelia Earhart and our astronauts share that pioneering spirit.'' The shuttle flight will deploy the Hubble space telescope.

DOC.HEAD: Winner of Costa Rica's Presidential Election Plans To Look Inward
With AM-Costa Rica
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Rafael Angel Calderon, the driven son of a discredited former president, plans to focus his energies on ``improving social justice'' in his country. Calderon, who founded his Social Christian party, defeated Carlos Manue Castillo of the incumbent National Liberation Party in Sunday's election. He will succeed President Oscar Arias, who could not succeed himself. Calderon, 40, is a clear supporter of Washington's policy in Latin America. He backs U.S. aid to help El Salvador fight its leftist guerrilla insurgency and visited Panama to congratulate President Guillermo Endara shortly after the U.S. invasion that toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. But focusing on Costa Rica's domestic problems may affect the dynamics of the Central American peace process, which was driven by Arias' activist foreign policy. ``I will support the peace process, but I believe the main duty of a Costa Rican president is to deal with Costa Rica's problems. I will let my foreign minister focus on foreign policy,'' Calderon said at a news conference Friday. Calderon's campaign culminated a long effort to restore the memory of his father, Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia, who also became president at age 40 and erved from 1940 to 1944. However, he was exiled after he tried to nullify the results of the 1948 vote. Calderon, whose full name in Spanish style is Rafael Angel Calderon Fournier, is familiarly known as ``Junior.'' During the campaign, he agreed that the economy had improved under two National Liberation governments, but that was not the problem in his view. ``A social breach is opening in this country between rich and poor,'' he said. Calderon campaigned on a populist platform that drew comparisons to his father's social reforms, which included establishment of social security. He promised a housing program for the poor and alarmed some businessmen by saying he would require large businesses to establish profit-sharing plans. But he also promised to reduce government deficit spending, and it was not clear how he would manage both. His father became an ogre of Costa Rican democracy by attempting to overturn the results of the 1948 election. After a 40-day revolution, the army was abolished and Calderon's father was sent into exile. Calderon himself was born in Nicaragua on March 14, 1949, and spent much of his childhood in Mexico City. He eventually became a lawyer, but he started working in his father's old party, the Calderon Republicans, by the age of 16. At 21, he became director of Social Security; at 25, he was a National Assembly delegate and at 29, he became foreign minister. Calderon first ran for president in 1982 for a coalition headed by the Republicans, drawing 33 percent of the vote. He put some distance between himself and his father's legacy by founding the Social Christian Unity party in 1983, and in 1986 he made a strong losing race against Arias. This time he ran a careful campaign, trying to take advantage of his father's history as a reformer without raising the specter of 1948. Calderon said repeatedly that he planned to focus on Costa Rica's problems, not the problem of peace in Central America. That stood as an implicit criticism of Arias, who won the Nobel Prize in 1987 for his efforts to obtain regional agreements to bring peace to El Salvador and Nicaragua. Calderon is seen as likely to maintain close relations with Salvador's President Alfredo Cristiani, Guatemala's Vinicio Cerezo and Rafael Callejas of Honduras. Arias, trying to present himself as an honest broker, was careful to avoid the appearance of ganging up on Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega's Sandinistas. Calderon also supports the creation of a permanent 400-man special police force to deal with emergency situations, including border incidents. The proposal is somewhat controversial since Costa Rica has no army and only lightly armed police because of his own father's actions. Calderon, a devout Roman Catholic, married Gloria Bejarano de Calderon, a native of Mexico, in 1972. They have four children, Rafael Angel, Gloria, Gabriela and Marco Antonio.

DOC.HEAD: Two Members of LL Cool J's Entourage Found Innocent of Sex Assault
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 4th graf
DOC.TEXT: A singer and a technician in the rap group LL Cool J were acquitted of sexually assaulting a 15-year-old girl after a concert last August. A Hennepin County jury returned the verdict Sunday after deliberating since Friday. Singer David James Parker, 26, whose stage name is Busy Bee, and technician Gary Chris Saunders, 27, both of New York City, had been charged with first-degree criminal sexual assault. The victim, now 16, testified that Parker and Saunders forced her to perform oral sex on them while six to 10 other men watched and encouraged the assault in a bathroom of a room in L'Hotel Sofitel. At a separate trial in December, a jury convicted LL Cool J's bodyguard, Christopher Tsipouras, 22, of Union, N.J., of raping the girl alone shortly before the others arrived. He was sentenced to 10 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Found Early Sunday in Parked School Bus
DOC.TEXT: A kindergarten pupil who fell asleep on the way home from school was hospitalized with frostbite after spending nearly two nights in a school bus waiting for help, authorities said. Angela Terrell was in fair condition Sunday night at Children's Mercy Hospital, where she was recovering from frostbite to her hands, toes and legs, police said. The child boarded the Mayflower school bus Friday for Ashland Elementary School in midtown Kansas City, police said. When the girl did not return Friday afternoon, her mother filed a missing person report with police, who began a search. Police found the girl early Sunday in the Mayflower school bus parking lot. Temperatures fell to 24 degrees Saturday night. The bus driver was fired for failing to inspect the bus before leaving the route, said Kyle Martin, spokesman for Mayflower Contract Services.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Democrats Seek Definition Through Confrontation
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats, frustrated that President Bush is winning high approval ratings without addressing what they see as the hard problems of governing, are ready for an election-year session with a sharp partisan edge. Bush's State of the Union speech last week crystallized the feelings of many on Capitol Hill who saw it as a glowing vision of America without any substantive support. The budget Bush sent to Congress two days earlier largely ignored areas like education, health care and the environment, they said. And for a Democratic Party that has lost five of the last six presidential elections, the frustration is beginning to boil over. ``Apparently we're not getting our message across to people who consider themselves to be Democrats,'' said Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif. ``We have to sharpen the message.'' One way to do that, according to a growing number of House Democrats, is to be more willing to take Bush on directly rather than seeking compromise and accommodation. Use Democratic power in Congress to send the president popular legislation, and let him veto it if he disagrees, the reasoning goes. That will draw sharper ideological lines between the parties and more clearly tell voters what Democrats stand for. The subject was a frequent topic at a private retreat last week attended by about 160 members of the House Democratic Caucus. The two-day ``issues conference'' in suburban Columbia, Md., was a chance for lawmakers to listen to pollsters talk about voters' wants and fears and to talk to each other about how to get the party back on the track to the White House. ``We think there's a growing anxiety about our drifting'' as a nation, said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., ``our drifting toward a lower standard of living, our drifting toward less competence in education in science and mathematics, our growing problems in international competition ... Americans want something better than that.'' It's clear that Bush is personally popular, Foley said. ``But we do have a difference over the emphasis we should be giving to some of these problems, and we're going to try to speak about those more clearly and more dramatically in the days ahead ... Where we have disagreements, the American people expect us to raise our voices and take our stand.'' Democrats at the conference took broad philosophical looks at topics like the role of government, economic opportunity and the role of the United States in the world. Members came up with a series of ``bold ideas'' for party initiatives that will continue to be refined, said caucus Chairman Steny Hoyer, D-Md., adding that most address voters' concerns about future security. ``People think they're doing pretty well, but they're concerned about their children. They're not as optimistic as they were,'' Hoyer said. The better Democrats address those fears, ``the better we're going to do electorally,'' he said. Hoyer acknowledged that Democrats must overcome lingering perceptions that they are softer than Republicans on national defense and crime. ``We want to make sure America stays strong. We haven't conveyed that as well as we should have,'' he said. It remained unclear which issues Democrats will choose for confrontations with the White House _ and where the party could find the cohesion to make such an attack work. The proposal by Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., to cut the Social Security payroll tax has divided the party. Moynihan contends Republican administrations have been using surplus funds from the tax to mask the size of the budget deficit instead of putting the money aside for future Social Security payments. There was no consensus among Democrats at the retreat, and Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., conceded it was hard to find quick agreement in such a large group. ``This proposal is very far-reaching in its implications. We don't think it's a trivial matter. We're going to take our time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Slovenian Communists Make Historic Split From National Party
DOC.TEXT: Slovenia's liberal Communists have broken with the national party over its resistance to swift democratic change, further eroding the authority of the institution that has ruled Yugoslavia since 1945. Slovenia's determination to chart its own course raises the possibility of the disintegration of the loose Yugoslav federation, which is riven by disputes arising from ethnic tensions and economic troubles. The dispute over the pace of reform has led to the outbreak of a virtual trade war between the relatively affluent northern republic of Slovenia and archrival Serbia, the largest and most populous of Yugoslavia's six republics. Last month, Slovenia's Communists stormed out of a national party congress dominated by hard-liners led by Serbia. Yugoslavs increasingly criticize the apparent inability of the party's fractious regional leaderships to take steps to deal with the worst economic and political crisis under Communist rule. The break from the national party by the Slovenian party is the first such rift in the 45-year rule of the Communists, whose authority is in decline. By contrast, the authority of federal premier Ante Markovic and his government, which is undertaking a radical economic reform program, is rising. In Sunday's emergency meeting, the Slovenian party also changed its name and called for the release of all political prisoners, an end to all political trials and immediate talks between Yugoslav Communists and leaders of newly formed opposition parties. It demanded that opposition political parties be legalized throughout Yugoslavia. Slovenia's Communist Party president, Ciril Ribicic, said the new party is not seeking secession from Yugoslavia but rather the establishment of a Yugoslav confederation that restricts central authority. ``This is the end of the League of Communists of Yugoslavia, in which Slovenian Communists had the status of an unequal minority,'' said Ribicic, using the formal name of the national party. The national party ``doesn't exist any more for us,'' said Petar Bekes, another Slovenian party leader. Slovenian Communists, aware of rising criticism of Communism in their Westward-looking region, have moved quickly in the past three years to create a more democratic political system in the republic. They have scheduled multiparty elections for April and, at last month's national party congress, told those resisting reform that the Communist Party risks a hasty demise if it does not address the people's democratic yearnings. The Slovenes have also criticize Serbia for its handling of unrest in the southern province of Kosovo, where at least 25 ethnic Albanian protesters have been killed in clashes with police since Jan. 24. The Albanians, the ethnic majority in Kosovo, are demanding more say in how their province is governed. The Slovenian reforms have been criticized harshly in Serbia, where the ruling Communist hard-liners demand continued national Communist dominance. Last month's national party congress was indefinitely adjourned, but Slovenian leaders said Sunday they are not returning. ``We do not want to be a part of an old-style dogmatic organization such as Yugoslavia's League of Communists,'' Bekes told reporters. He said, however, that the Slovenian Communists ``will remain open for cooperation with all democratic-orientated forces'' in other Yugoslav republics. He said Slovenia from now on will have no representatives in the national Communist leadership, but is open to form a coalition with the federal leadership on the national level. The strains between Serbia and Slovenia have led in recent weeks to a virtual trade war. On Sunday, the state news agency Tanjug said the governments of the republics would enter negotiations to try and end their dispute. Yugoslavia's Communists were the first to break with the Soviet-led Communist bloc in 1948. But the country has been slower in adopting democratic reforms than other East European countries because of its deep ethnic and economic divisions. Yugoslavia consists of six republics and two autonomous provinces, each with its own government and party structure. The decentralized system of government and collective federal presidency were devised in 1974 to prevent one republic from gaining sway over the others, but has resulted in an ineffective government by compromise. The federal government is generally responsible for economic policy while the collective presidency, which appoints the premier, dictates defense and foreign policy. But the bulk of political influence in the country has traditionally been concentrated in the Communist Party. The Slovenian Communist party, which was formally known as League of Communists of Slovania, changed its name to ``LCS-The Party for Democratic Renewal.'' Its platform will be similar to Western European social democratic parties, Bekes said.

DOC.HEAD: Durenberger Scheduled to Face Ethics Committee This Week
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger goes before the ethics committee this week to explain his book contract and real estate deal, making him the first in a long list of lawmakers facing scrutiny this year by fellow senators. Durenberger's case, while less publicized than those of five senators who received contributions from savings and loan owner Charles Keating, has led to public disapproval in polls back home in Minnesota and newspaper editorial calls for him to resign. ``There's no question that the issue has filtered down to the grassroots level, but I also think it's still in the questioning stage,'' says Rep. Vin Weber, a fellow Minnesota Republican. ``I didn't have a lot of people damning Dave Durenberger. But I did have a lot of people asking me about Dave.'' Durenberger, a 55-year-old political moderate, denies any intentional wrongdoing in a case that involves a book contract he is accused of using to launder speaking fees; numerous lobbyist-paid trips to Boston to visit a marriage counselor; and a system under which he charged the government for staying in a Minneapolis condominium of which he was part owner. He says he has given no thought to resigning the seat he won for a third term a little more than a year ago. Still, he has apologized to voters for ``lapses of judgment'' and repaid the Senate $11,000 last month after the Rules Committee said he was not entitled to reimbursements for daily expenses while using the condo during congressional recesses. After Durenberger appears before the panel, the committee must decide whether to issue a statement of possible violations, similar to an indictment. That would trigger an investigation similar to a trial in which the committee would decide whether violations of ethical standards occurred. If violations are found, the committee could recommend disciplinary actions ranging from a reprimand to expulsion. Aside from Durenberger, the ethics committee has a busy work load. Also under scrutiny are five senators whose campaigns and political causes received $1.3 million from S&L owner Keating, his relatives and employees. The five are accused of improperly intervening with federal banking regulators on behalf of Keating, whose Lincoln S&L now ranks as the biggest thrift failure in the nation, estimated to cost taxpayers up to $2 billion. The senators are John McCain, R-Ariz.; Democratic Whip Alan Cranston of California; Donald Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the Banking Committee; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and John Glenn, D-Ohio. In a separate matter, the role of Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., in several housing deals also is being examined. The House ethics committee also has several cases under review. Durenberger's staff has refused to discuss the senator's expected appearance on Thursday. He has turned down requests for interviews since telling a newspaper last month that unreleased depositions tend to support allegations that he used the book deal to launder speaking fees. The Ethics Committee hired a special counsel in August to investigate allegations that Durenberger made $100,000 in violation of Senate honoraria limits through a contract to promote two books written under his name. The Rules Committee concluded that Durenberger was not entitled to expense money for staying in the Minneapolis condo. He has reimbursed the money, but committee members said other, unspecified aspects of the deal also need to be examined by the ethics committee. Several newspapers in and out of Minnesota _ including the Mankato (Minn.) Free Press and the Boston Herald _ have called for Durenberger to resign and polls show Minnesotans are losing faith in him. More than 70 percent of Minnesota adults want Durenberger to resign if the committee finds significant wrongdoing, according to two statewide polls published last week. The case has been costly to Durenberger financially as well as politically.
