In addition to the $11,000 he repaid the Senate, his campaign treasury last year paid $160,059 in legal fees, and he still has another $85,847 in unpaid bills from his lawyer, according to his 1989 campaign finance report.

DOC.HEAD: Bird Count to Determine Effects of Coastal Development
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Virginia Beach in last graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Booming development along the South Carolina coast has made worried scientists count bills. Nobody knows for sure what toll development has taken on bird populations along the state's 200-mile coastline, but researchers suspect an 80 percent, 10-year decline for one kind _ a little gray and white shore bird called the sanderling. The sanderling, which runs with abandon toward water only to retreat from rushing waves, is being counted by volunteers for a consortium of academics and state officials. Scientists suspect South Carolina coast's, with its wealth of estuaries and marshland, is an important resting place for some migratory birds that spend summers in the arctic and winter in the tropics. ``But they haven't been able to document it yet,'' said John Tibbets of the South Carolina Sea Grant Consortium. ``They haven't been able to get hard numbers.'' About 60 volunteers, with more to be hired, have been counting birds along the coast for two years. Their census should be complete in 1991. A similar census is under way in North Carolina. The results of both counts will provide a better picture of bird migration patterns and be the basis for future surveys to determine if populations of certain bird species are declining. The census also will allow researchers determine the impact of Hurricane Hugo on shore bird populations. The September storm inundated Marsh Island, for instance. The island is an important nesting area for egrets, herons and terns at the Cape Romain National Wildlife Refuge north of Charleston. ``The storm leveled all the tall dunes and most birds will be at risk for flooding in the spring tides,'' said Thomas Murphy of the South Carolina Department of Wildlife and Marine Resources. ``The pelicans will do all right but it may push other birds' nests out to areas where they will be flooded.'' The census also will pinpoint key nesting areas for coastal bird colonies. Atlases will be compiled to help regulatory agencies make sure such areas are protected. That, in turn, should help prevent some species from becoming endangered, Murphy said. About 250 colonies that include perhaps hundreds of thousands of wading and sea birds are spread over the state's coast, Murphy said. He would not venture a more specific estimate of bird populations until the census is complete. ``A lot of times for nine months of the year there is nothing there,'' Murphy said. ``Then you suddenly might have thousands of birds on a two-acre pond.'' Scientists are concerned about development encroaching on colonies. While the birds will adapt, ``if they have to go through that every three years or so because of development, they (colonies) will not be successful,'' Murphy said. Volunteers usually go by boat to remote areas and count around the time of high tide because birds congregate on sand banks and oyster banks left uncovered by the tide. ``They move around a lot and it's difficult to do the actual counting. They are so mobile and so fast you have to count them in that very narrow window,'' said Virginia Beach, a consortium spokeswoman.

DOC.HEAD: Calderon Winner In Costa Rica Presidential Vote
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs with Castillo's concession speech, updated election results; EDITS thruout to tighten, conform; no pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SJO2,3,4
DOC.TEXT: Rafael Angel Calderon, the son of an exiled president, won Sunday's presidential election, defeating the governing party's candidate to succeed Oscar Arias, architect of Central America's peace process. ``I feel very proud of my country tonight. This is a victory for all of you, the people of Costa Rica,'' Calderon, a strong supporter of U.S. policy in the region, said in a statement at his Social Christian party headquarters. Calderon was leading Carlos Manuel Castillo by 178,571 votes to 169,352, according to official returns representing about 20 percent of the vote. The count was suspended for the night and was to resume at noon Monday. ``I accept the verdict of the people. Today we have elected liberty and democracy to the presidency of Costa Rica,'' Castillo said in a concession statement at the National Liberation party's election headquarters. Most of the tabulated returns came from Castillo's stronghold of San Jose, and Calderon was expected to expand his lead when the votes from his rural strongholds started coming in. More than 80 percent of the nation's 1.7 million registered voters were expected to turn out. Calderon will take office May 8 for a four-year term. Arias, who won a Nobel Peace Prize in 1987 for his efforts to bring peace to Central America, cannot succeed himself. Calderon's victory marked the 10th straight peaceful election in Costa Rica since 1948, when Calderon's father, Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia, was president and tried to nullify the result when his party lost. ``My sympathy goes out to my opponent, Mr. Castillo, and his followers. I know what they are going through. I went through it four years ago,'' said Calderon, 40, who made losing presidential bids in 1982 and 1986. He asked his followers to celebrate without gloating or rancor and called on ``those who did not vote for me to join us and fight for a better future for Costa Rica.'' Party faithful were out in force, waving flags and honking horns in rhythm. Buses took thousands to the polls, where crowds of teen-agers decked out in colorful T-shirts guided voters to their precincts. Some who celebrated Saturday night were lined up at 5 a.m. when the polls opened. Police blocked streets near hospitals to hold down the sound of a festival that jammed streets of the capital throughout the day and continued after the polls closed. The fiesta continued into the night for Calderon's supporters. Both major candidates ran populist campaigns aimed at the poor in this country of 2.9 million. The campaign was devoid of specifics, however. Castillo was hurt by disclosures about drug trafficking and corruption, but in keeping with the tradition of Costa Rican politics, Calderon did not press those issues as hard as he might have. Calderon founded the Social Christian party in part to shed the legacy of his father. But the president-elect still calls his father, who served as president from 1940 to 1944, the greatest Costa Rican president of this century. The elder Calderon was exiled after he tried to nullify the 1948 election results, an incident that led to the abolition of Costa Rica's army. Calderon has said he supports Arias' peace efforts but won't try to imitate them, and will focus on domestic issues and ``improving social justice.'' Calderon, whose father founded Costa Rica's social security system, has promised a new housing program for the poor while at the same time saying he would reduce the government's deficit spending. He also has proposed requiring large companies to establish profit-sharing plans, something that has made some businessmen nervous. Voters also elected 57 national assembly delegates and filled 525 municipal posts. Prisoners, each escorted by a guard, were permitted to vote for the first time in Costa Rican history. ``It's a step towards the perfection of Costa Rican democracy,'' said human rights advocate Nancy Hernandez. In an exercise to reinforce the understanding of and commitment to democracy, more than 9,500 children under age 12 went to their own polling places in a mock election and Castillo won, taking 4,885 votes, or 50.6 percent, to 4,693, or 48.6 percent, for Calderon. The voting took place only in San Jose, where the incumbent party is strong. Joao Baena Soares, secretary general of the Organization of American States, praised Costa Rica's democratic tradition but refused to compare it to Nicaragua, where a controversial campaign winds up on Feb. 25. He noted, however, that the OAS sent only four observers, including himself, to Costa Rica. On election day in Nicaragua there will be 400 OAS observers, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Budget: Some Blanks, Some Clues About the Future
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf to clarify time reference.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's new defense budget doesn't offer a long-range vision for the Pentagon in a time of revolutionary change, but it gives some short-term clues about how this commander-in-chief wants the military to prepare for the years to come. Bush said his $292.1 billion defense budget for 1991 offers a chance to ``restructure America's defenses'' in the wake of Europe's revolutionary changes, and he made headlines with last week's proposal to strip hundreds of thousands of U.S. and Soviet troops from the European continent. But the budget proposal also reveals a conservative, take-it-slow approach in many areas. The 1991 plan takes only tentative steps into a new era with a modest troop reduction of 38,000 in the coming year, cutbacks in about 20 minor conventional weapon programs, and continued funding for several futuristic weapons systems from the Reagan administration, such as the Strategic Defense Initiative. Dramatic change is difficult to achieve in one year, Pentagon officials say, given the long lead time required to adjust high-tech weapons programs and to reduce the military force of 2.1 million. ``We are prepared to cut the defense budget, but please let us do it in an orderly fashion,'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told the Senate Armed Services Committee last week. Cheney, appearing Sunday on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation'' program, said it ``makes no sense'' to cut major weapons programs now because ``we have to deal with Soviet military capabilities and not just intentions.'' ``There is still enormous nuclear capability'' and the Soviets have not shown they are prepared to change that, Cheney said. But Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press'' that continued spending for the MX missile was unnecessary. ``I don't think there's any chance that the administration's proposal to fund both (the MX and Midgetman) will be enacted,'' he said. The budget opts for continued modernization of the nation's strategic nuclear forces, including funds for more B-2 stealth bombers, MX missiles, the Midgetman missile, a Trident submarine and Trident missiles. The cuts in conventional weapons came more easily, the secretary said, because fewer such arms will be needed as the military force is reduced. The Army has argued that in an era of lessened superpower conflict in Europe, it now must prepare for Third World, low-intensity conflicts that require a lighter, more flexible force, as demonstrated in the Panama invasion. As a result, the Army procurement budget was cut by $4 billion from last year, but its research and development programs grew by $1 billion, in the interest of developing such things as a light tank. The announced base closures were designed to accommodate those decisions, said one Army general involved in the planning. ``We closed a number of ammunition depots and such because we just don't need that much ammunition,'' said the general, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Army is bearing the brunt of the force cutback with a 17,000 reduction, while the Air Force would be cut by 15,000 and the Navy by 6,000 men and women. The Marine Corps was spared any major personnel cuts. By most accounts, it is a better paid, better prepared and more heavily armed military force, one that Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, warned Congress last week must not be slashed willy-nilly amid the calls for foreign-based troop withdrawals and tight budgets. ``You'll start to break the great force we've put together in the past 10 years,'' Powell warned. Even if Bush's call to draw U.S. troop levels down to 225,000 in Europe is agreed upon, it would take place over a span of one to two years, Cheney told lawmakers. In the budget, none of the Air Force's major programs _ such as the B-2 stealth bomber or the MX missile system _ were impaired. However, the service will retire 14 1950-era B-52 conventional bombers based on Guam, the only such unit based outside the continental United States. Despite headlines over the decision to mothball two World War II-era battleships, the Navy eluded some of the major cuts aimed at the other services. But Cheney told reporters that even the service's 14 aircraft carriers are not sacrosanct in an era of declining budgets. The Navy took a major cut in research and development funds, due in part to Cheney's decision to cancel the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft. Congress expressed some impatience with Cheney's lack of information on long-range Pentagon plans for troop cuts and weapons programs, with Senate Armed Services Committee chairman Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., complaining of ``a number of blanks in the budget.'' Cheney promised to provide more information when he releases his five-year plan in April. ``The fact of the matter is, this is a dynamic world we live in ... We have not made final decisions in many areas because you can't,'' Cheney said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Backs Tax Subsidy for Corn-Based Fuel Enhancer
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is moving ahead with a controversial plan to allow a new corn-based octane enhancer to qualify for a 60-cents-a-gallon tax subsidy for alcohol fuels even though it will cost the Treasury an estimated $192 million in lost revenue over the next three years. In addition, administration officials acknowledged last week that the planned subsidy _ sought primarily by corn growers and the growing alcohol fuel industry _ likely will be held to be in violation of international trade agreements as an illegal subsidy. Nonetheless, Assistant Treasury Secretary Kenneth W. Gideon told the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee his department plans to make the lead substitute, ethyl tertiary butyl ether or ETBE, eligible for the tax credit ``in the near future.'' Although the ETBE technically is a compound of ethanol and petroleum-based isobutylene and not a mixture of alcohol and gasoline as required by the 1980 law, Gideon said the Treasury ``did not believe Congress ... chose to use the word `mixture' in its narrow technical sense.'' Expanding the credit to cover ETBE has won the support of 75 senators. However, it has raised the ire of the fossil fuels industry, which has a competing product, and several tax writers in the House. Rep. Frank Guarini, D-N.J., cited administration estimates that the ETBE tax credit will cost $2 billion over the next 10 years if Congress votes to continue the alcohol fuel subsidies, which now are set to expire in 1993. ``Without consulting Congress, you decided (something) that is going to cost an additional $2 billion,'' he said. ``Joe Sixpack or the fellows working in the steel mills in Ohio are now going to have to pay that $2 billion.''

Rep. Jim Jontz, D-Ind., says he is optimistic about the prospects for including his sustainable agriculture proposal in the 1990 farm bill. The Jontz legislation, which would create a new voluntary option in the farm program, encourages producers to reduce their use of manufactured chemicals and fertilizers by instilling greater flexibility into federal farm programs. ``Regrettably, present farm policies, particularly the base acreage requirements, force producers to plant the maximum amount of program acreage annually,'' Jontz said. ``This inflexibility hurts the environment by requiring greater use of manufactured chemicals and fertilizers.'' The Jontz bill has about 20 co-sponsors and is the vehicle in the House for getting language on sustainable agriculture into law this year. In the Senate, similar legislation is pending and lawmakers there have been vocal about the need for flexibility in the upcoming farm bill. On Friday, Sen. Robert Kerrey, D-Neb., told the National Grain Trade Council that ``flexibility is more than this year's catchword. ... It must be central to our farm bill deliberations.'' ``What a cruel paradox it would be if Congress didn't give farmers the flexibility they need to rotate crops and reduce chemical use, but instead saddled them with new regulations intended to force a reduction in the chemicals they apply,'' said Kerrey.

The Federal Agriculture Mortgage Corp. has announced publication of its securities guide, enabling potential borrowers, loan originators, poolers, underwriters and investors to familiarize themselves with the program and begin to participate. The sale and pooling of qualified loans can begin as soon as Farmer Mac certifies eligible poolers, said Farmer Mac President Henry Edelman. Farmer Mac was established by Congress in 1987 to create a secondary market for agricultural real estate. The securities guide can be obtained by writing Farmer Mac, Suite 200, 1667 K St., NW, Washington, D.C., 20006. The guide costs $250.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Bus Attacked In Egypt; At Eight Reported Killed, 17 Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with one graf to UPDATE with higher death toll of nine, SUBS grafs 15-17 with 3 grafs to CONFORM; pickup 18th graf pvs, `Baruch Binah,...'
DOC.TEXT: Masked guerrillas armed with guns and grenades attacked a bus carrying 31 Israeli tourists on a desert road to Cairo Sunday, killing at least nine people and wounding 17, officials and news reports said. At least two Egyptians on board the bus were among those shot, according to the reports. An unidentified man telephoned the Cairo bureau of a Western news agency and said the attack was to punish President Hosni Mubarak and security officials for alleged torture in Egyptian prisons. It was the worst attack on Israelis in Egypt since 1985 and the deadliest single act of terror in the nation since Moslem extremists killed President Anwar Sadat and seven others with him on a parade viewing stand on Oct. 6, 1981. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, speaking in a telephone interview with Israel TV, said the attack ``proves that hostility towards Israel still exists and runs amok in the region.'' Mubarak telephone Shamir and issued a statement that said he regretted ``the monstrous aggression against Israeli tourists.'' He said the attack was aimed at thwarting efforts for Middle East peace, said the government-run Middle East News Agency, or MENA. Egypt, the only Arab country to have peace with Israel, has been mediating efforts to get talks started between Israeli officials and representatives of Palestinians who have waged a 2-year-old uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The bus was carrying the Israelis to Cairo from Rafeh, a divided town on the Egypt-Israel border in the Sinai Peninsula, when it was attacked near the Suez Canal town of Ismailiya, 40 miles from the capital, said a statement issued by the Egyptian government. Two men in a white Peugeot station wagon stopped the bus, got out of the car and opened fire with machine guns, then hurled four hand grenades before fleeing. Two grenades exploded, said the statement carried by MENA. The government account was similar to that of a witness, Miriam Kadmon, who was quoted by Israel army radio. She said the driver of the car signaled the bus to stop and that the attackers smashed the car's rear window and opened fire. An Egyptian on the bus began screaming, jumped out of the vehicle and was shot dead, she said. ``Everyone saw his death in front of his eyes. ... It seemed like an eternity, but in fact it lasted for several minutes only,'' said another survivor, Dr. Yigal Barak, who spoke on army radio in a telephone interview from an Ismailiya hospital. ``Then there was a total quiet, and only screams were heard,'' he said. ``Bodies were scattered everywhere.'' The government statement said eight people were killed and 17 wounded. It said the dead, taken to hospitals in Cairo and Ismailiya, included three women. Israel radio said a ninth person died early Monday and put the number of wounded at 18. MENA issued a partial list of the wounded, including 13 Israelis and Egyptian tour guide Wadia Gamil Sorial, 27. Unconfirmed reports said the tour guide and the bus driver, also an Egyptian, were killed. The total number of Egyptians aboard was not known, but reports indicated there may have been as many as four. Baruch Binah, a spokesman for Israel's Foreign Ministry, said he could not provide a final casualty figure because the process of gathering information was ``so slow as to be almost painful.'' The gunmen spoke Arabic with non-Egyptian accents, the Egyptian government statement said, suggesting they were either Palestinian or from other Arab countries. Israel's armed forces radio said a caller speaking to a Western news agency in Cairo claimed responsibility on behalf of the Organization for the Defense of Oppressed in Egyptian Prisons, a previously unknown group. MENA said Egypt's interior minister, Abdel-Halim Mousa, who is in charge of police, rushed to the scene with other senior security officials. Israel television said Israeli armed forces prepared a special plane to evacuate the wounded from Cairo. Mubarak telephoned Shamir to express condolences to families of the victims. Mubarak ``stressed that nothing should ever obstruct the peace process but (this incident) should be an incentive for going ahead ... to reach a final settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict,'' MENA said. In Washington, State Department spokesman George Malleck said, ``This horrible act of terrorism is to be condemned by civilized people everywhere'' and called it and ``attempt by the enemies of peace to halt efforts at reconciliation and dialogue.'' He said the U.S. Embassy was in contact with Egyptian authorities and offered medical assistance. Israel army radio said the bus belonged to an Egyptian tourist company identified as Santa Maria. The tour was organized by Ofakim, an Israeli tourist company. Albert Levy, an Ofakim manager, said the Israelis had begun an eight-day tour of Egypt. He said 12 members of the group were residents of Mevasseret-Ziyyon, a suburb of Jerusalem. Egypt and Israel signed a U.S.-mediated peace treaty in 1979. There have been several incidents of violence against Israeli diplomats or tourists in Egypt. On Aug. 20, 1985, an Israeli diplomat was fatally shot in Cairo while three Israeli Embassy employees were on their way to work. The diplomat's wife and another woman were also wounded in the attack. On Oct. 6, 1985 an Egyptian policeman opened automatic gunfire on Israeli tourists in the Sinai Peninsula resort of Ras Burka, 28 miles south of the border checkpoint of Taba, killing seven people. The policeman also shot his commanding officer in the incident. On July 6, a Palestinian shouting ``the glory of Allah'' grabbed the steering wheel and forced an Israeli bus over a cliff eight miles west of Jerusalem, killing 14 people when the bus exploded in flames.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 37,631.41, down 18.74 points, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Pit Bulls the Subject of New Legal Dogfight
DOC.TEXT: The gruesome death of an elderly woman after an attack by two pit bull terriers has revived a legal dogfight between pet owners and authorities over the regulation of vicious canines. The issue centers on whether cities should pass ordinances specifically citing pit bulls _ a breed the American Kennel Club says does not exist among its 141 registered varieties. Animal control officers and politicians have adopted an I-know-one-when-I-see-one stance, and insist the dogs that fit the general pit bull description are more vicious than others and need to be regulated more closely. Both sides have had victories. Last year, the kennel club successfully challenged a New York City law requiring that pit bulls be neutered, tattooed with a registration number, and leashed, muzzled or confined at all times. But an Overland Park, Kan., law requiring the dogs to wear muzzles when out of their homes or kennels survived a lawsuit by pit bull owners that went to the U.S. Supreme Court, which declined to review the case. In Florida's Dade County, pit bull owners must pay a $50 registration and keep the dogs indoors or locked in a cage or a 6-foot-high pen. Outside, the dogs must be leashed and muzzled. After an attack in the Happy Valley, Ore., pit bull owners managed to block an ordinance that would have had the animals and other vicious dogs put to death or removed from the Portland-area city. In California, a law took effect in January establishing a uniform system of review, hearing and punishment for owners of vicious dogs. But the law also bans counties and cities from enacting their own regulations ``if they are specific to breed.'' Focusing on any one breed ``is cutesy, shortcut politics'' aimed at getting maximum attention, said Alan J. Stern, American Kennel Club vice president. ``You make a dog vicious. You beat it, deny it affection, apply electric shock, put down its food dish and take it away,'' said Stern. ``These dogs are bad because of bad people.'' He said 21 states and 183 cities have bans that do not mention specific breeds. But Los Angeles Animal Control Lt. Michael Burns, who is overseeing the investigation of the dog-mauling death of 70-year-old Marjee Lilly, said there are enough specifics about pit bulls to adopt a law regulating them. ``This is the year of the pit bull ban,'' he said. He said arguments by opponents of pit bull bans about the absence of genetic differences between breeds fall down in the reality of backyard breeding used to produce dogs that most people accept as pit bulls. ``You have a dog that has aggressive tendencies enhanced through constant and incestuous breeding,'' Burns said. ``If there are some recessive genes on the aggressive or psychotic side, they will make themselves manifest.'' Mrs. Lilly, of San Diego, was visiting her grandson at his home and was attacked by his two dogs when she tried to feed them. The 4-foot-11 inch, 130-pound woman was alone at the time and was mauled by the dogs for a half hour. She died Jan. 17, one day after the attack. Her death prompted Gov. George Deukmejian to say he would consider legislation restricting the ownership of pit bulls. Such legislation would override the current law he signed. But Stern said the dogs that attacked Mrs. Lilly were mixed-breed boxers. He called the immediate identification as pit bulls typical of the trend by police, animal control officers and the media to write off all vicious dogs as pit bulls. ``Pit bulls have been identified at one time or another as 27 different breeds,'' he said. ``It's a handle. If there's a dog attack, then it's a pit bull.'' Pit bull is generally applied to Staffordshire bull terriers, the American Staffordshire terrier, the American pit bull terrier and sometimes the bull terrier. Bred for dog fighting, they have a powerful chest, neck and jaw muscles. And those are the features that backyard buyers of pit bulls are most interested in, said Burns. He said a dog generically called a pit bull can be bought for around $15 to $30 in Los Angeles. ``It just has to have the characteristics you talk about when you are describing a fighting dog,'' he said. And they are different, Burns insisted. ``There's an absence of the normal sounds a dog makes when it attacks,'' said Burns, who trained sentry dogs for the military. ``It's almost a workmanlike way they hold on in an attack. It's a persistence I haven't seen in any other breed.''

DOC.HEAD: Group Doesn't Want Soviet Sister City
DOC.TEXT: A group of people in this southern Oregon community are saying ``nyet'' to establishing a sister city with the Soviet town of Rubtsovsk. ``While we feel profound sympathy for the subjugated people of the U.S.S.R., as well as the peoples of the 49 Communist-dominated nations of the world, we feel no sisterly kinship with the city of Rubtsovsk,'' a petition being circulated states. The petition goes on to say that sister city projects are ``a danger to America's national security and a terrible insult and discouragement to oppressed people who live under the Communist yoke.'' Gedney Webb, who drafted the petition, says those who sign it are opposed to any formal relations with a ``totalitarian regime.'' Cindy Patterson, who has visited Rubtsovsk in central Siberia and who has been active in the sister city campaign, said the opposition group is ignoring the future. ``I really look at this from the aspect of securing a safe future for my children,'' said Patterson. She said establishing ties with Soviet cities has improved relations at a personal level, avoiding much of the political friction created by the differing systems. Webb plans to present his petition to the City Council on Wednesday, when it considers the sister-city proposal.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: Letting your spouse's words go in one ear and out the other may indicate a happy marriage, research suggests. Laura L. Stafford, an assistant professor of communication at Ohio State University, said her study showed that strangers recall more of their conversations than married couples. ``It appears obvious that at the early stage of a relationship you are listening closely to what a person is saying and forming impressions and evaluations _ asking yourself, `Do I like this person?''' Ms. Stafford said recently. ``By the time you are in a stable marriage, you are no longer forming impressions and evaluations of your spouse _ not on a routine basis, anyway. So you don't recall as much detail from a conversation.'' Ms. Stafford has conducted studies concerning the ability to recall conversations. One study concluded that married couples remembered the general topic of their discussion, but strangers recalled more detail. ``Happy couples may be talking for the sake of talking. You don't really know what you talked about with your wife, but you know you had a good talk,'' Ms. Stafford said. Unhappy couples may recall more from their conversations because they are re-evaluating the relationship.

The popularity of what 100 years ago was a protein substitute for the toothless has spread into the nation's most-popular sandwich filler, consumed by an estimated 40 million Americans in an average day. Peanut butter _ conceived by an anonymous St. Louis physician in 1890 as a soft edible for his toothless patients _ turns 100 this year. The Peanut Advisory Board has designated March 1 as National Peanut Butter Day, and has planned centenary celebrations throughout the year. ``It has the staying power that doesn't exist in many products in America,'' said Mitch Head, the group's executive director. ``It has survived all the food fads in America from tofu to sushi.'' The secret to peanut butter's popularity? It's inexpensive, convenient and relatively healthy. Americans consumed a record 800 million pounds of it last year, or about 3.3 pounds apiece.

DOC.HEAD: Banks, Other Lenders Seek To Reduce Loan Defaults
DOC.TEXT: Banks and other lenders in three years doubled the money recovered from delinquent student loan borrowers by using aggressive tactics that included garnishing lottery winnings and putting liens on real estate, a study shows. Lenders in the Guaranteed Student Loan Program ``introduced innovative procedures to forestall default'' and increase recoveries from $200 million in fiscal year 1986 to more than $400 million in fiscal year 1989, Pelavin Associates, a Washington, D.C. research firm, said Sunday. Pelavin conducted three national studies on the GSL program for a consortium of guarantee agencies in Colorado, Massachusetts, Tennessee, Texas and Washington state. The program, created by Congress in 1965, has made higher education possible for more than 20 million Americans. Government student loan programs have been harshly criticized in recent years because of spiralling default rates, mainly among trade and vocational schools. The GSL program, administered by 56 guarantee agencies that protect private lenders against losses from loan defaults, had $51.6 billion in student loans entering repayment status in fiscal year 1988. The federal government is the ultimate guarantor of the loans. According to the new studies, eighteen guarantee agencies improved their recovery rates by more than 10 percent and 22 agencies saw improvements between 5 percent and 10 percent.
DOC.HEAD: Future Workers Will Need Communications, Math, Reading Skills
DOC.TEXT: A study says jobs for the unskilled and poorly educated are disappearing, and future employment will require, if not higher education, at least good communications skills and basic ability in math and reading. Radical changes are occurring in the size and composition of the work force that will affect the nation for decades to come, even as U.S. businesses confront the challenge of foreign competition and new technology, reports the private Population Reference Bureau. The study, ``America in the 21st Century: Human Resource Development,'' says the 1990s provide a window of opportunity for facing the nation's human and workplace problems _ problems which, if ignored, could produce dire consequences. ``The 1990s provides a unique opportunity for addressing human resource needs. If we postpone the choice at hand, demographic factors in the years ahead could push us to the edge of a formidable crisis,'' conclude the authors of the study, Carol J. De Vita and William P. O'Hare. The nation is in transition from an industrial to a service economy, which means most new jobs will require education and skills, the authors say. Managerial, professional and technical jobs will have the highest rates of growth in the years ahead, while the greatest number of new jobs are expected to be in retail sales, office workers, cleaners and waiters and waitresses.
DOC.HEAD: Some 9.7 million People Jailed in Year Ending June 1988
DOC.TEXT: About 9.7 million people were jailed in the United States during the year that ended June 30, 1988, the Justice Department says. During the same year, some 9.6 million people were released from jail, said the Office of Justice Statistics study released Sunday. Both numbers represented increases of 20 percent over 1983 figures, it said. The average jail stay was three days, with 39 percent of inmates spending one day or less behind bars, 23 percent spending two to four days and 10 percent spending five to seven days, according to the study. About 3 percent served more than six months and 1 percent spent more than a year behind bars. On June 30, 1988, the jail population totaled 343,569, or 144 of every 100,000 Americans, the study said. That rate was 47 percent higher than the 98 per 100,000 five years earlier. The study focused on local jails, defined as locally administered confinement facilities holding people awaiting trial or sentenced to terms usually of a year or less. About 51 percent of the people in jail had not been convicted of any crime when they were incarcerated, while 49 percent had been convicted, the same level as in 1983, the study found. The census did not include facilities in Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Rhode Island and Vermont that combine jails with prisons, which are state or federal institutions.

DOC.HEAD: Silly Putty Stretches Into Its 40th Year
LaserPhoto PX2
DOC.TEXT: Forty years after a copy writer for a small advertising agency took a taffy-like substance invented by accident and called it Silly Putty, the toy in the plastic egg is still making an impression. Binney & Smith Inc., Silly Putty's maker, sells more than 3 million eggs a year of the bounceable, moldable, stretchable toy capable of lifting images from newspapers. And this spring, the Easton-based company plans to add four fluorescent colors of Silly Putty to the pinkish silicone rubber. These colors mark the first change in the product since Peter C. Hodgson borrowed $147 in 1950 to market a researcher's failed attempt at making synthetic rubber during World War II. ``Dads and moms may get a little jealous because they didn't have these things, but maybe their kids will share,'' said Dennis Malloy, Binney & Smith's director of business development. The privately held company, which also makes Crayola crayons and Liquitex fine arts products, bought the rights to Silly Putty in 1977, a year after Hodgson's death. Hodgson's son, Peter Jr., said Silly Putty's simplicity has allowed it to stretch over two generations. ``It demands something of people so it animates you,'' said Hodgson, a professor of Russian literature at the University of California, Los Angeles. ``It really is what it says it is: a liquid solid,'' he said. ``It's just a paradox, a kind of puzzle, an enigma you can hold in your hand.'' The elder Hodgson, who envisioned Silly Putty as a therapeutic diversion for adults, began the business in a converted barn in North Branford, Conn., and shipped the product to retailers in pasteboard egg crates. Since then, more than 200 million eggs of Silly Putty _ more than 3,000 tons _ have been sold. Silly Putty, which has survived copycats such as Nutty Putty and Goofy Goo, has been pressed into service in some unusual ways. The elder Hodgson gave Apollo 8 astronauts Silly Putty in sterling silver eggs for their 1968 trip to the moon, and they used it to keep tools from floating away in weightlessness. Athletes squeeze it to strengthen their hands, and physical therapists recommend it for patients recovering from hand or wrist injuries. And New York City artist George Horner uses Silly Putty in his work, which sells for as much as $5,000. ``I do consider myself a serious artist even though I work with Silly Putty,'' said Horner, whose works inside Silly Putty-filled frames address topics such as homelessness and AIDS. ``I sort of like to fool people's expectations.'' Malloy said he expects Silly Putty to continue to thrive _ even in the age of the video game. ``I think a parent is ecstatic when a child requests a toy that costs a buck and a half,'' he said. According to Malloy, baby boomers' children have hatched a Silly Putty sales increase of 15 percent to 17 percent during the last four years. He said he expects sales to grow by 25 percent to 30 percent this year as children collect the new blue, green, yellow and magenta colors scheduled to reach retail stores' shelves in May. But Larry Carlat, editor of Toy & Hobby World, said he didn't think children would collect the different colors. ``Silly Putty is more of a one-trick pony,'' he said. At the modern plant in northeastern Pennsylvania, Binney & Smith makes an average of 300 pounds a day of Silly Putty, about 12,000 eggs a day. To make Silly Putty, silicone rubber is first swirled in 225-pound blobs with ingredients to keep it from puddling. After the pink goo _ warm from the stirring _ is poured from the vat designed to mix mortar, it is cut up into chunks resembling oversized loaves of homemade bread. These are then fed through a machine designed for cutting taffy. Rows of Silly Putty drop onto a conveyer, and workers place the 13.3-gram disks resembling chopped hot dogs into red plastic eggs. Malloy said he expected the old-fashioned pink putty to continue to sell well despite the bright colors and other innovations on the drawing board. ``This isn't the last you'll see of new things in Silly Putty,'' he promised.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Nikkei Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with market closing
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose moderately against the Japanese yen Monday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange inched down. The dollar closed at 145.60 yen, up 0.65 yen from Friday's close of 144.95 yen. After opening at 145.59 yen, it moved in a range of 145.40-145.60 yen. Currency dealers said the dollar's firmness carried over from its strong showing in New York on Friday, where it closed at 145.50 yen. They said investors bought the currency in New York after the release of a better-than-expected U.S. Labor Department report which showed the nation's unemployment rate holding steady at 5.3 percent in January. Economists say a steady jobless rate will keep the U.S. Federal Reserve Board, the U.S. central bank, from easing interest rates. Higher interest rates tend to support a country's currency. Dealers also said uncertainty over the situation in the Soviet Union should keep participants from taking large positions Monday despite bullish sentiment for the West German mark. ``Now the market is looking to whether Soviet Leader (Mikhail) Gorbachev's position will be consolidated'' in the meeting of the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee scheduled for Monday and Tuesday, a Bank of Tokyo dealer said. The Tokyo market has fluctuated erratically in past weeks on rumors that Gorbachev may be resigning from his position as secretary general of the Soviet Communist Party. Monday's exchange activity elsewhere is likely to be centered on cross trading between the West German mark and the dollar as has often been the case in recent weeks, said the dealer who, spoke anonymously. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 443.73 points Friday, fell back 18.74 points, or 0.05 percent, to close at 37,631.41 yen. Securities dealers said the benchmark index opened bullish, but uncertainty about the direction of currency rates and falling government bond rates sidelined investors, causing large-capital issues to lose ground.

DOC.HEAD: Oregon Gun Law Supported by NRA
DOC.TEXT: Gun regulations have come to Oregon in the form of a delicately balanced law that the National Rifle Association endorses. The bill, which took effect Jan. 1, imposes stricter requirements for gun ownership but gives urban-area residents greater access to concealed handguns. ``I think it's a huge step for public safety. And I think it can show other legislators they can work with the NRA,'' said House Speaker Vera Katz, chief architect of the first major addition to Oregon's gun laws in at least 20 years. Katz began work on the law after an Oregon man sprayed a Stockton, Calif., schoolyard with bullets from a semiautomatic rifle and two handguns in early 1989. Patrick Purdy killed five children and wounded 30 people before fatally shooting himself. Purdy bought the AK-47 assault rifle at a gun shop in the town of Sandy, about 30 miles east of Portland. In a state where the NRA claims 62,000 members, Katz proceeded cautiously, bringing together key lawmakers, police officials and gun lobbyists for a series of closed-door meetings that eventually spawned a bill. Banning the sale or possession of semiautomatics or any other kind of gun never was on the agenda because of the NRA's lobbying power, she said. Oregonians have a state constitutional right to bear arms for their own defense, and the state Supreme Court has ruled residents are entitled to possess billy clubs and switchblade knives. Katz said she focused instead on having enough safeguards to keep guns out of the hands of people who shouldn't have them. The result, Katz said, is one of the most comprehensive gun laws in the nation. For handgun purchases, the law extends the presale waiting period from five to 15 days and requires fingerprinting. Buyers of any gun must furnish two pieces of identification, including at least one with a photograph. People prohibited from possessing guns include convicted felons or people convicted of violent misdemeanors during the previous four years or who have been declared by courts to be dangerous because of mental illness. Purchases of rifles or shotguns carry no waiting period. But if a background check later shows the buyer was ineligible, police are required to confiscate the gun. But the law also took away much of the discretion given to county sheriffs to deny permits for concealing weapons. Sheriffs who once had sole discretion over such permits now are required to issue them to applicants that meet the law's criteria and complete a handgun safety program. That change was expected to spark a brisk business in those permits in urban areas, where few had been issued. In one recent year, Multnomah County, the state's most populous with 560,000 people, had issued 14 permits. Some sparsely settled counties in eastern Oregon issued hundreds a year. Gun lobbyists said they support the new law. ``I'm still encouraged,'' said John Nichols, director of the Oregon State Rifle & Pistol Association, the state affiliate of the NRA. And NRA member Tex Shively, who said he lobbied against gun control bills during 24 Legislative sessions, is willing to give it a chance. ``Too many people have guns out there,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Five Children, One Man Killed in Fiery Accident
DOC.TEXT: A four-wheel-drive vehicle skidded on an icy bridge, overturned and burst into flames, killing six people, including five siblings, but the driver and the children's mother were able to survive. The group was going from New York state to Texas because the children's 18-year-old sister was in the hospital there, Highway Patrol Sgt. Vern Reynolds. The accident occurred around 7:30 a.m. Sunday as the truck was heading west over an ice-covered bridge on Interstate 44 near this southwest Missouri town, according to Highway Patrol Trooper Leslie Crowe. The driver, Howard Bouchard, 38, of Denton, escaped by kicking out a window, and pulled his girlfriend, 38-year-old Marcella England, from the front seat of the burning truck, authorities said. A bystander held him back when he tried to rescue the others, police said. The dead included sisters Edna England, 16, Clara, 14, Ella, 12, and Virginia, and their 10-year-old brother, Virgil. Also killed was another passenger, Arthur Brown, 20, of Watertown. The children's mother and Bouchard were treated for burns at a Springfield hospital and released.

DOC.HEAD: Calderon Celebrates Victory; Costa Rica Celebrates Democracy
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Rafael Angel Calderon and thousands of chanting, honking supporters celebrated victory today as Costa Rica embarked on its second century as Central America's most stable democracy. ``Today we have elected liberty and democracy to the presidency of Costa Rica,'' said Calderon's main opponent, Carlos Manuel Castillo, in a graceful concession statement Sunday night. Castillo was the governing party's candidate to succeed Nobel laureate Oscar Arias, the architect and prime mover of Central America's peace process. Arias was barred from running for re-election. ``I feel very proud of my country tonight. This is a victory for all of you, the people of Costa Rica,'' said Calderon at his Social Christian party's campaign headquarters. The 40-year-old Calderon, who was born in Nicaragua after his father was sent into exile, had tears of joy in his eyes as he entered a San Jose hotel to the cheers of a flag-waving crowd. Calderon, a strong supporter of U.S. policy in the region, was leading Castillo by 178,571 to 169,352, according to official returns representing about 20 percent of Sunday's vote. Unofficial returns showed a much wider victory margin for Calderon with twice as many votes counted. Calderon was also predicting his party would win 33 of 57 National Assembly seats. Voters also filled 525 municipal posts. The official count was suspended and was to resume this afternoon. Castillo was breaking even in his National Liberation party stronghold of San Jose, while Calderon was sweeping most of the countryside. Five minor parties were not a factor in the outcome. Both major candidates ran populist campaigns aimed at the poor in this country of 2.9 million people. The campaign was devoid of specifics, however. Calderon made a trip to Panama shortly after the U.S. invasion in December and supports Salvadoran president Alfredo Cristiani in his U.S.-backed fight against leftist guerrillas. However, he has expressed disappointment at U.S. aid to Costa Rica, set at about $90 million for 1990 and due to fall about 30 percent in 1991. ``Just because we are a democracy does not mean we don't need help,'' he said. Costa Rica celebrated 100 years of democracy in October. Calderon's victory marks the 10th straight peaceful election in Costa Rica since 1948. Calderon founded the Social Christian party in part to shed the legacy of his father, Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia, who was exiled in 1948 for trying to nullify the presidential vote that year. Calderon, who made losing presidential bids in 1982 and 1986, asked his followers to celebrate without gloating or rancor and called on ``those who did not vote for me to join us and fight for a better future for Costa Rica.'' Thousands of voters had been celebrating a civic fiesta in the streets throughout Sunday, and the celebration then continued for Calderon's supporters. Cars with red-and-blue flags raced through the streets early today honking to the rhythm of Calderon's name. Calderon said he owed his victory to party organization and the fact that National Liberation had won the last two elections. ``Costa Ricans don't like one party to dominate,'' said Calderon. He will take office May 8 for a four-year term. Calderon has said he supports Arias' peace efforts but won't try to imitate them and will focus on domestic issues and ``improving social justice.'' Calderon has promised a new housing program for the poor, while saying he would also reduce the government's deficit spending. He has also proposed requiring large companies to establish profit-sharing plans, something that has made some businessmen nervous. He inherits control of a country with a $5.5 billion debt _ more than the annual Gross National Product of goods and services. But Arias, with help from President Bush, has arranged a debt relief package and the economy is improving, although a precipitous drop in coffee prices has hurt income from the nation's largest export.

DOC.HEAD: Robin Williams Presents NYC with Check for Homeless
DOC.TEXT: ``This is tortilla money from Manuel Noriega,'' Robin Williams told Mayor David Dinkins as he presented the city with a $227,000 check for the homeless from Comic Relief. ``This is from Leona Helmsley's legal fund,'' he said Sunday as he signed over the check at St. Vincent's Medical Center. ``For once, a check that is not in the mail,'' Dinkins replied Sunday The money comes from the $9 million that have been raised by Comic Relief, the HBO telethon that featured Williams, Whoopi Goldberg, Billy Crystal and other top comedians. Comic Relief has donated funds to help the homeless in 23 cities. It has given New York $580,000, which was administered through St. Vincent's and the United Hospital Fund to pay for the medical care of more than 15,000 homeless people. The charity's president, Bob Zmuda, said Comic Relief planned to hold its next telethon May 12 at Radio City Music Hall. Tickets go on sale Feb. 25. ``It's good to see that, hey, maybe in a little way, it's helping,'' Zmuda said. HBO picks up the telethon's operating costs, so all the money raised goes to the program, Zmuda said.

DOC.HEAD: Most of Territory Without Water After Storm Passes
DOC.TEXT: At least two-thirds of this U.S. territory's 38,000 residents were without water because a power outage caused by Hurricane Ofa. The remaining third get their water from village catchment systems, but some of them may have been muddied by the rains that accompanied the weekend storm. Disrupted communications prevented reports from Western Samoa, a country with 160,000 people between American Samoa and the storm track. High waves forced the evacuation of about 200 American Samoa residents, territorial Gov. Peter T. Coleman said Sunday in Honolulu, where he was attending a conference. They were given temporary shelter in a school near Pago Pago. He said 10 to 20 people suffered cuts from flying debris, ``but no fatalities, so we're very fortunate in that.'' Members of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers were to arrive today from Honolulu to assess damage. As of Sunday, the center of the storm, was 350 miles east-southeast of American Samoa, moving to the southeast at 15 mph, according to the Navy in Honolulu. Winds were 120 mph, with gusts 150 mph. The storm had sustained winds of 132 mph when it passed the islands. Winds tore the roof off a hangar Pago Pago International Airport and forced the airport's closure Saturday. It reopened Sunday for daytime flights, but remained closed at night because of the power outage, said Francesca Bozem, a Coast Guard spokeswoman in Honolulu.

DOC.HEAD: Barthelemy Re-Elected; Mintz Pledges Support
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Sidney Barthelemy and his defeated challenger, Donald Mintz, called for a united effort to move the city forward following an election decided along racial lines. Barthelemy, 47, who is black, overcame a strong challenge from fellow Democrat Mintz, 46, who is white. Complete but unofficial returns gave Barthelemy 79,995 votes, or 55 percent, to 65,047, or 44 percent, for Mintz. Two other candidates split the rest of the vote. Pollsters said Barthelemy got about 85 percent of the black vote and Mintz got 75 to 80 percent of the white vote in Saturday's election. ``Let all New Orleanians come together _ all of us, rich and poor, black and white ... and let us move into the 1990s and create and build a New Orleans like no one has ever seen,'' Barthelemy said. ``Together we will make New Orleans the greatest city in America.'' Mintz, who resigned as head of the city's dock board to make his first try for office, said he would work to help the mayor. ``Because we have, perhaps, elevated campaign practices to a new level in this city, I ask you to join with me today in pledging support for the mayor and the new administration ... because we believe in a better New Orleans,'' Mintz said. Barthelemy and Mintz said repeatedly during the campaign that race should be irrelevant, and accused each other of exploiting it as an issue. ``I think it has been a little divisive, and I'm sorry it developed that way,'' Barthelemy said. Nearly 62 percent of the city's 237,000 registered voters turned out. It was Barthelemy's sixth victory since 1974, when he won an interim election and became the first black state Senator since Reconstruction. He was elected again to the Senate and twice to the City Council, where he was the first black ever elected as an at-large councilman. Barthelemy's campaign speeches focused on ending unemployment; Mintz said the mayor's predictions were pie-in-the-sky, and that he could do better. But there was never much interest in employment or other substantial issues, including the city's high crime rate and the candidates' political experience and competence. ``The city of New Orleans has a little growing to do.... People have to start putting race behind us,'' said U.S. Rep. Bob Livingston, a Republican who represents Metairie. ``We have to start looking at the credentials of the candidate. And I think if they'd done that, Donnie would definitely be the next mayor.'' But Moon Landrieu, the city's last white mayor, said he felt that Barthelemy's extensive political background and Mintz' lack of political experience were the telling factors. ``I don't think it's a question of color so much as who is this person and what are his programs ... and talents or abilities?'' said Landrieu.

DOC.HEAD: Palauans Vote on New Political Status with U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Voters in this tiny, remote Western Pacific archipelago cast ballots Tuesday on whether to accept self-government or continue as the world's last trusteeship. Palau's constitution mandates at least 75 percent approval must be given to a proposed Compact of Free Association with the United States, worth nearly $500 million in financial assistance. President Ngiratkel Etpison, who has spent most of the past five weeks campaigning for the measure, believes the pact will be ratified. It will be the seventh vote in as many years on the agreement that has become U.S. law and awaits only Palau's ratification before being put into effect. In the previous plebiscites, the agreement has been approved ranging from 61.4 percent in the first vote in 1983 to 73 percent in 1987. The U.S. Department of Interior, which administers Palau's affairs, has indicated it will strengthen its presence here if the pact is rejected. ``However, this is not to say that there will not be another act of self-determination by Palau's people at some future date if the plebiscite fails,'' said Sam McPhetres, who is representing the department with a United Nations team sent here to observe voting proceedures. Palau is the last of 11 territories under the U.N. trusteeship system formed in 1947. The other territories have achieved independence or self-government. An estimated 15,000 people live on eight of its 200 islands, most in Koror, the provisional capital. The total land area is nearly 200 square miles. The United States captured the volcanic islands about 500 miles east of the Philippine island of Mindanao in 1944 from Japanese military forces. Under the compact, the United States would not be able to test, store or dispose of nuclear or other unconventional weapons in Palau. However, the agreement gives the U.S. permission to use Palau's airport, harbor and other lands for military purposes. Under the trusteeship, the United States is not restricted in any of those activities. While there is no organized opposition in Tuesday's vote, there are small factions who could send the compact to defeat, officials said. On Sunday, 602 Palauans living on Guam voted as did 424 at Saipan in the Northern Mariana Islands. Palauans living in Hawaii, Oregon and California also voted on Sunday. Yoich Kohama, Palau Election Commission chairman, said it may be Friday before the unofficial outcome is known.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Figure Resigns From Romania's Government
DOC.TEXT: A leading figure in the revolutionary government has quit, suggesting discord in its highest echelons, and criticized the leadership for campaign efforts that try to undermine the opposition. Silviu Brucan, a former Communist who became the leading foreign affairs specialist in the new regime, announced his resignation Sunday from the National Salvation Front in a letter to the national news agency Rompres. Three days earlier, the front agreed to share power with opposition parties in a new Council of National Unity until elections set for May 20. The front took control during the bloody December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceaucescu, who was executed Christmas day after a summary trial. In making his announcement, Brucan said he considered his mission fulfilled and that he believed all those who fought in revolution ``share my conviction that a strong opposition is absolutely essential to a real democracy'' in Romania. However, Brucan himself had been a target of opposition criticism. It was he who announced that the front, contrary to its initial pronouncements, would field candidates in the elections. Bowing to public pressure, the front last week agreed to share power with the opposition until the elections and split into two groups _ one to govern, the other to contest the elections. After his ouster, Brucan quickly became the National Salvation Front's ideological beacon and was one its most outspoken figures. He is a former ambassador to Washington and one-time editor of the Communist Party daily Scinteia who first openly criticized Ceausescu after force was used to put down labor unrest in Brasov in 1987. ``Today, Feb. 4, I took the decision to retire from the leadership of the National Salvation Front because I consider my mission fulfilled,'' Brucan said in his letter. He said he was worried about several ``weak points of our new political life,'' including a certain apathy and a focus in the election campaign on adversaries rather than policies. The stress on trying to undermine the opposition rather than to debate how best to solve Romania's many problems ``threatens to reduce the contest to the lowest electoral traditions before World War II,'' he said. In the 1930s, Romania's pre-war democracy became increasingly autocratic, with political parties being formally banned in 1938. Brucan said he worried that one of the key figures helping to form public opinion in Romania was formerly in charge of two propaganda offices ``that were constantly promulgating Ceausescu's cult'' and was a member of the Communist Party's now defunct Central Committee. He did not identify the man. But Stelian Tanase, spokesman for the group for Social Dialogue, told The Associated Press he believes Brucan resigned because of a misunderstanding within the front. He said this centered on ``the rupture'' between intellectuals who demonstrated against the front's power and the front's ruling council, which organized a counter, pro-front demonstration a week ago, using Communist methods such as trucking workers in from factories. ``Brucan's theory is that intellectuals are a progressive force and the anti-intellectual demonstrations were maneuvered by the front, so these are the probable dissensions that appeared in the council's top leadership,'' Tanase said. Brucan's departure follows the resignation last week of the front's interim vice president, Dumitru Mazilu, a prominent government critic during Ceausescu's last years although reportedly once a colonel of the Securitate secret police. Mazilu accused the revolutionary government of using ``Stalinistic methods.'' Brucan, 73, offered his help to the front in the future but said he wanted ``to get back to my writing desk and do research on social and political issues.'' Romanian television said the front would present its electoral platform this week. It also said the proposed electoral law, under debate by all parties, will be published this week. More than 200 people demonstrated outside the television station Sunday, protesting what they said was biased coverage slanted against the opposition. ``Has the TV been free after the revolution?'' asked Dumitru Juga, head of a new union of 1,200 radio and television workers. ``No!'' the crowd shouted. Some waved placards demanding, ``Down with censorship on TV,'' ``Down with the Ceausescu-ists from TV'' and ``Don't lie to the people with TV.'' More than a dozen armored personnel carriers surrounded the station, the scene of the heaviest fighting during the revolution.

DOC.HEAD: Meditation Lengthens Lives of Elderly, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: Elderly people who learned Transcendental Meditation were more likely than their peers to still be living three years later, in what experts call the first study to directly link meditation to longer life. Transcendental Meditation proved more effective than two other techniques for longevity, lowering blood pressure and improving on several measures of mental functioning, researchers said. The study results are ``rather dramatic ... I think it's very impressive,'' said psychologist Arthur Aron of the University of California, Santa Cruz. Two other psychologists who study meditation said they suspect the outcome was due to factors other than Transcendental Meditation itself. They also suggested that other techniques might do as well or better. The Harvard University study is presented in December's Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, published by the American Psychological Association. The study included 73 volunteers, with an average age of 81, from eight homes for the elderly. They were assigned randomly to learn Transcendental Meditation, another technique called mindfulness training, a simple relaxation program, or no training at all. Three years later, the 20 taught Transcendental Meditation were still alive. Survival rates in the other groups were 88 percent, 65 percent and 77 percent, respectively. Transcendental Meditation, or TM, induces a ``a distinctively deep state of rest'' while the mind is alert but ``in a very settled, quiet state,'' said co-author Charles Alexander, now an associate professor of psychology at Maharishi International University in Fairfield, Iowa. Students there practice TM as part of the curriculum, Alexander said. The ``mindfulness training'' in the study was not the Buddhist technique of the same name. Instead, it was designed to stimulate creation of ideas or new perspectives, through a verbal exercise and a challenge to think about topics in new and creative ways. Each technique was practiced for 20 minutes twice daily with the eyes closed during the 12-week experiment. Alexander attributed the findings to TM's combination of high wakefulness, which he said combats atrophy of the mind and so the body, and deep restfulness, which he said releases stress from the nervous system and leads to reduced ``wear and tear'' on mind and body. He said the study suggests TM should be combined with standard Western medicine, not replace it. Some other meditation researchers suggested different explanations for the outcome. For example, Michael Maliszewski, director of behavioral medicine at the Diamond Headache Clinic in Chicago, said TM instructors may have differed from the instructors of the other techniques in terms of motivation or other factors that could have given their teachings more impact. The TM group had fewer dropouts than the other groups, he noted. He also said he suspected that Chinese Taoist meditative techniques, which he said were designed to increase longevity, might do so better than TM did. Taoism has not been studied experimentally so far, he said. Alexander replied that a survey covering most dropouts found their decision had nothing to do with the quality of the instructors. He also said other studies have found TM superior to alternative techniques in improving aspects of physical and mental health, even though the commitment of the instructors of other techniques was presumeably as high as that of the TM instructors.

DOC.HEAD: Wiesel Dedicates Grim Reminder of Death Camps
DOC.TEXT: A dramatic new Holocaust memorial drew thousands of people who came to its dedication to remember and in some cases, bear witness. The memorial, dominated by a 42-foot-tall bronze hand with sculptured, suffering figures climbing it, is for a tragedy ``beyond words and beyond imagination, but not beyond memory,'' said Elie Wiesel, the Holocaust survivor, author and professor honored with the 1986 Nobel Peace Prize. ``Not to remember means to betray them all,'' he said at Sunday's dedication. ``Not to remember means to kill the victim a second time. Not to remember means to become an accomplice of the enemy.'' Nearly 3,000 chairs in an outdoor ampitheater at the memorial were filled more than an hour before Sunday's dedication ceremonies, and thousands more stood. Wiesel said not just the past, but the present, with anti-Semitism revitalized in some countries, shows the need for ``these sanctuaries of memory.'' The ceremonies had many in tears in this city, where thousands of Eastern European Jews moved after World War II. ``I can't stop crying,'' said Miriam Feigenblat of suburban Hallandale. She showed the number 56035 on her arm from the Auschwitz death camp, and said she lost her parents, three sisters and other family members. ``We are the witnesses.'' ``It's the greatest thing to happen in Florida,'' said Jacob Kreitzna, who survived other death camps. Pointing solemnly to his number, he said: ``It's very important to remember.'' Helen Fagin, a retired University of Miami professor of Judaic studies who survived a concentration camp but lost her parents at Treblinka, initiated the project five years ago. From teaching, she saw, students knew little about the Holocaust, and she was alarmed by historical revisionists who contended the genocidal ``Final Solution'' of Adolf Hitler never happened. ``More and more survivors are leaving us,'' she said in an interview. ``We as witnesses are going to soon disappear.'' During trips to Washington, D.C., she was impressed by the Vietnam Memorial and the Lincoln Memorial. A small group here, led by automobile dealer and Philadelphia Eagles football team owner Norman Braman, began a drive that gained donated land from the city of Miami Beach and raised nearly $3 million for the memorial. Kenneth Treister, a Miami Beach resident and architect-sculptor, traveled to Israel and studied Holocaust memorials and records before conceiving the memorial here. There is a reflecting pool in the front of the ampitheater, and a semi-circular black granite wall frames its back. A tunnel walkway leading to the sculpture has 47 photographs showing scenes from the Holocaust _ victims digging their own mass graves before their executions, people being packed into railroad cars for the camps, emaciated camp prisoners, a small boy raising his hands in surrender to Nazi soldiers. The tunnel passes an eternal flame and turns, with walls carrying the names of the death camps and listing the names of victims. At the end of the tunnel, a sculptured small girl weeps and beckons, leading to the hand, with figures climbing it, reaching for help or for each other. About 5,000 names of the estimated 6 million Holocaust victims are inscribed in the memorial, and more will be continually added as they are received, organizers said. ``The Nazis tried to dehumanize them. They took away their names and gave them numbers,'' Braman said. ``We're giving them back their names.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``The vehicle became like hell at once, there were shots from every direction, grenades were thrown inside the bus and everything was covered with smoke. There was a terrible fear and the feeling of helplessness. Nobody could protect us, nobody carried any weapons.'' _ Dr. Yigal Barak, a survivor of Sunday's machine gun and grenade attack on a bus of Israeli tourists in Egypt.

``I hate to see it happen. It will hurt Lima, but we don't need tanks if we're going to have peace, and that's what we've been praying for.'' _ Don Downhour, 72, on President Bush's proposal to end orders for the M-1 tanks built in Lima, Ohio.

``The way it must be done is we must generate the programs in which the people, the customers turn away from the drugs, not us turning the drugs away from customers.'' _ former President Reagan, insisting the nation's drug problems can be overcome this decade.

DOC.HEAD: 3-Day-Old Baby Kidnapped From NYC Hospital Found Safe
DOC.TEXT: A newborn and his mother were reunited after a bloodhound named Sherlock led police to the abductor, a woman who was depressed over her own recent miscarriage, authorities said. Maria Quinones was arrested at Sunday afternoon when police saw her walking the baby in Brooklyn, said Sgt. Nick Vreeland, a police spokesman. Police said she kidnapped Steven Earl Pender from St. John's Hospital on Saturday afternoon. The 3-day-old boy was found unharmed and returned to the hospital, and Quinones was charged with kidnapping, authorities said. ``I hugged him. I squeezed him. I'm just happy he's back,'' said the child's mother, Cathy Pender, 18. Quinones was about seven months pregnant when she had a miscarriage two weeks ago, Vreeland said. ``That more or less caused her to do it,'' he said. Police got help in looking for Quinones and the baby from the bloodhound, who picked up her scent from the baby's clothing and a piece of a chair that Quinones sat in at the hospital Saturday. Sgt. Kevin Bacon said officers went to the neighborhood where Quinones was arrested because the dog indicated that the woman had been there earlier. On Saturday afternoon, Quinones was seen talking to new mothers, including Ms. Pender, on the eighth floor nursery of the hospital. She apparently was able to enter the maternity section by convincing employees she had been discharged from the hospital and had come to feed her son. Ms. Pender said she never had met Quinones until the woman approached her in the hospital and asked her to point out her son. ``She came over and just started talking. She acted friendly,'' Ms. Pender said. ``She said, ``He's so adorable, he's so adorable,''' Ms. Pender recalled. Quinones later asked nurses for Ms. Pender's son, saying she was the child's mother, said police Sgt. Mary Wrensen. The nurse ``asked for some ID and she was in the course of trying to verify who this woman was, got distracted to do something else and when she turned around and realized, the woman was gone with the baby,'' said hospital administrator William F. Green. The nurse who gave the baby to Quinones has been relieved of her duties pending an investigation, Green said.

DOC.HEAD: McMartin Defendants: Justice System Harmed Them, Children
DOC.TEXT: Raymond Buckey promised to ``fight to my last breath'' to prove his innocence in a retrial on child molestation charges scheduled for next month. In his first extensive remarks since his acquittal on dozens of child molestation counts, Buckey called the trial a miscarriage of justice that destroyed his life and left children in torment. ``I saw what the system did. I saw how it treated children. I saw how it treated adults. It doesn't work very well,'' Buckey said in a Jan. 28 interview broadcast Sunday night on CBS's ``60 Minutes.'' ``It's a very safe side to be on, saying, `Gee, these poor children went through hell,''' he said. ``And they did go through hell, but I'm not the cause of their hell, neither is my mother. Nothing that happened at that preschool is the cause of their hell. The cause of their hell is the product of the adults who took on this case and made it what it is.'' On Jan. 18, a Superior Court jury acquitted Buckey, 31, and his mother, Peggy McMartin Buckey, 63, of 52 molestation counts stemming from alleged attacks on pupils at their now-closed McMartin Pre-School in Manhattan Beach. Jurors deadlocked on 13 other counts against Buckey. Last week, after a vociferous campaign by McMartin parents that included television talk show appearances, Los Angeles County District Attorney Ira Reiner decided to retry Buckey on the 13 counts. ``I don't want to go through another McMartin trial,'' Buckey said, ``but I will because I know I'm innocent. I'll fight to my last breath to get vindicated in the system in some way, because there's no end to what they've done to me.'' The trial was the longest and costliest criminal proceeding in U.S. history. Buckey spent five years in jail and his mother nearly two before they were released on bail. On the CBS-TV program, Reiner was asked if, in retrospect, he felt Buckey and his mother should have been jailed for as long as they were. ``In retrospect? Who can tell in retrospect?'' Reiner replied. Mrs. Buckey, who also was interviewed, said she expected the jurors to acquit her, but Buckey said he was unsure. ``I couldn't believe that they'd buy this whole case, but I knew they were looking for something,'' he said. ``And I just hoped to God that there weren't 12 people who were blind enough to buy this witch hunt.'' Jurors told reporters after the verdict that they felt some children had been molested, but that there was insufficient evidence that Buckey was the attacker. ``God knows all of us are innocent, and I can't convince other people, but God knows it,'' Mrs. Buckey said.

DOC.HEAD: Cosmonauts Ride Space Motorcycle For Second Time
DOC.TEXT: Soviet cosmonauts left the Mir orbital station on Monday for high-flying acrobatics on a space motorcycle designed to rescue spacemen in distress and repair satellites. Cosmonauts Alexander Viktorenko and Alexander Serebrov, who have been aboard the Mir complex for nearly five months, emerged from Mir for a second test of the motorcycle, officially known as the Cosmonaut Movement System, the official news agency Tass said. The space motorcycle, which more closely resembles a floating armchair, was ridden for the first time Thursday by Serebrov, the mission's flight engineer, who piloted the device about 100 feet from the giant Mir space station. During Thursday's test, the cycle was tethered to Mir. Official media did not say if the tether was in place today and television pictures were not detailed enough to determine. Today's test was carried out by Viktorenko, who was scheduled to put the motorcycle through a series of pirouettes to test the craft's maneuverability and technical performance, Radio Moscow said. The testing of the space motorcycle was the fifth time the two comsonauts have left the spaceship to work in open space since they boarded Mir in September. Viktorenko and Serebrov are scheduled to be replaced later this month by another crew.

DOC.HEAD: Home Affordability Gap Still Growing, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: Home buyers last year waited longer to buy their dream house because prices rose faster than their incomes, the 14th straight year the gap has widened, a study found. The Chicago Title & Trust Co. said its annual survey of home buyers in 18 urban areas showed that the majority of 1989 home buyers were two-income couples who saved for an average of 2.9 years _ the longest period in the survey's 14-year history _ before having enough money for a down payment. The study ``documents that working couples have been the major factor influencing home affordability in this decade,'' said John Pfister, Chicago Title vice president in charge of marketing research. The study, the only national home buyers survey embracing all types of home sales throughout the year, was based on telephone interviews of more than 1,500 people, according to Chicago Title, the country's largest title-insurance company. Nationally, the median home price _ which historically reflects a price that most closely parallels what most people would pay _ rose 6.4 percent last year to $129,800, while the median household income of 1989 home buyers rose 6.3 percent to $58,700, the survey found. The median home price is the midpoint with an equal number of homes selling for more and less. The gap was smaller than in recent years, but when considered with the gaps since the first Chicago Trust survey in 1976, the difference between income gains and home-price increases grew a total of 6.5 percent over 14 years. ``Those buying houses today have noticeably fewer discretionary dollars to spend on things other than housing than their counterparts did 13 years ago,'' Pfister said. Chicago Title said 79.3 percent of all 1989 home buyers were two-income families compared with 73.3 percent in 1988 and 53.1 percent in 1976. Among first-time home buyers, 86.8 percent were two-income families, compared with 85.5 percent in 1988 and 64 percent in 1976. The segment of first-time home buyers purchasing newly constructed homes dropped to 17 percent from 23 percent in 1988, while the number buying existing single-family homes rose to 83 percent from 77 percent. ``What this tends to suggest is that the first-time buyers, in general, were increasingly priced out of the new home market last year and opted for older, less expensive houses instead,'' Pfister said. San Francisco remained the most expensive metropolitan housing market in 1989, the survey found, with a median home price of $199,900, up 11.2 percent from 1988. At the low end, the median home price in Cleveland last year was $75,800, down 1.3 percent from 1988. The median home price in Memphis jumped 18.1 percent last year to $92,000, while the median price of a home in New York City fell 13.7 percent to $166,200.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran President Attracts Protesters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates thruout with scuffle, remarks from Cristiani.
