DOC.TEXT: Secret Service agents and police removed several demonstrators who tried to block a limousine waiting for El Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani outside a Harvard University gym. About 20 demonstrators, some chanting, ``Cristiani you can't hide, we charge you with genocide,'' were sitting in front of the limousine Sunday afternoon when authorities picked them up and moved them to the sidewalk, the student newspaper Harvard Crimson reported today. It was not known if Cristiani, who had come to watch his son play squash, was in the limousine during the demonstration, the newspaper said. No arrests were made and no one appeared to have been injured in the brief scuffle. Cristiani's son, Alex, plays for the Princeton squash team. Harvard won the match 5-4. The El Salvadoran president told a Crimson reporter inside the gym that the demonstration was ``normal. It's a free country. They're allowed to do that.'' He said he was in the United States to visit the United Nations. Peter Costa, a spokesman for Harvard, said Cristiani was in town for ``a private, family visit,'' and was not on official business with the university. About 60 demonstrators opposed to El Salvadoran military policies gathered outside the gym early Sunday afternoon to protest Cristiani's presence.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Student Gets 10 Years For Visiting North Korea
DOC.TEXT: A woman college student nicknamed ``the flower of unification'' was convicted and sentenced to 10 years in prison today for illegally visiting communist North Korea. Im Su-kyong, 21, is the first South Korean student to be sentenced for going to the north. As the sentence was handed down, Ms. Im and a Roman Catholic priest on trial with her, stood in prison garb and shouted ``Wake up judges who ignore unification!'' Some 30 radical students and Catholic priests in the gallery at the Seoul District Criminal Court yelled ``Release them!'' and the courtroom proceedings were temporarily halted until order was restored. The Rev. Moon Gyu-hyon, 41, who accompanied the 21-year-old Ms. Im across the border on Aug. 15 was given eight years in prison. He said he went to the north to accompany her home because she was Catholic and needed support. Attorneys for the defendants said they would appeal. On hearing news of the verdict, students at two Seoul universities held rallies demanding Ms. Im's release. ``Release Im _ Flower of Unification'' shouted students at Sogang University. Presiding Judge Hwang Sang-hyun found the pair guilty of making an illegal visit to the communist north, of acting under instruction from North Korea, of contacting, communicating and rendering voluntary support to the enemy north and of benefitting the north militarily. He said that when the two returned to the south they were under instruction from North Korea to continue their anti-U.S., anti-government struggle. Ms. Im and Moon said their trips to the north last summer were in support of unification of the peninsula, divided into the communist north and capitalist south in 1945. The Seoul government forbids unauthorized trips to North Korea as a violation of national security laws and maintains dialogue on unification must be conducted through official channels. In October, a dissident clergyman was sentenced to 10 years in prison for visiting North Korean leaders to discuss unification. Ms. Im said her trip to a July 1-8 international youth festival in Pyongyang had the support of radical students and dissidents demanding unification. She appeared on North Korean television, gave interviews and was treated as a heroine by North Korean officials. In the south, radicals nicknamed her ``flower of unification.'' After her arrest, they staged violent protests demanding her release. Radical protests have dwindled in recent months due to lack of support. The trial was marred by frequent outbursts, with members of the gallery throwing paper airplanes and paper flowers at the judge. Radicals, dissidents and North Korea demand the ouster of 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea, claiming their presence hinders dialogue on unification. The Seoul government says the North wants to communize and unify the peninsula by force.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Budget Proposal Won't Solve Veterans' Problems, Groups Say
DOC.TEXT: Veterans' organizations today said the proposed 1991 budget for veterans' programs should be boosted by $1.1 billion, adding the current plan will not solve such basic problems as delays in handling benefit claims. The proposal by AMVETS, Disabled American Veterans, Paralyzed Veterans of America and the Veterans of Foreign Wars said the Veterans' Administration needs $1.1 billion more than the $30.9 billion sought by the Bush administration. ``There are no grandiose concepts in this independent budget,'' said Frank Morrone, a health policy consultant to the paralyzed veterans' group. Combined, the groups claim to represent 3 million of the nation's 27 million veterans. The groups want a shift in some spending priorities within the VA, including the addition of $1.2 billion for medical care over the Bush administration's request for $12.2 billion. Though the highest administration request in years, the Bush proposal for health care just meets ``the bare minimum,'' said Morrone. ``VA is not getting its fair share of federal dollars in terms of health care,'' said Morrone, citing 4 percent growth in veterans' health spending between 1985 and 1989, compared with nearly 7 percent for Medicare and 11 percent for Medicaid. Research dollars are decreasing, he said. Another chief concern of the groups was the handling of claims. According to the groups, the underfunding of the veterans' benefits administration has caused a 650,000-case backlog in compensation and pension claims. The backlog was at 167,000 cases as recently as 1987, they said. As a result of underfunding, veterans wait six months for benefits, applicants for vocational rehabilitation wait 100 days to be interviewed, almost 2 million veterans a year can't get through to the VA because of busy lines and long waits on hold, and home loans are being defaulted on unnecessarily, they say. The groups say 734 additional employees are needed at a cost of $25 million for general operating expenses, the category that covers benefits work. The four veterans' groups, like other critics of the VA budget, blame short staffing in the loan program for a large number of defaults that is leading the administration to propose eliminating a centerpiece housing benefit. For the first time, the Bush administration proposed last week a mandatory 4 percent down payment on VA loan amounts over $25,000. The veterans' groups, offering their fourth ``independent budget,'' say they are motivated by a ``final loss of confidence in the Office of Management and Budget's intention or ability to objectively address veterans' issues.''

DOC.HEAD: Warmer East of Rockies; Rain in Northwest
DOC.TEXT: High pressure from Kansas to New England spawned sunny skies and milder weather today as the weekend storm that dumped freezing rain and snow on the East Coast moved out to the Atlantic. Clouds and cooler temperatures were due today in the Great Lakes, Texas and the Southeast. The Pacific Northwest looked for rain near the coast and snow in the Cascade Mountains today. Fog was expected in the South and in the valleys of California. Four tornadoes touched down in central Alabama on Sunday, flinging tractor-trailer rigs across a highway near Birmingham and splintering buildings in St. Clair County, but no deaths or serious injuries were reported. About 150 homes and 15 businesses were reported damaged at Fultondale, north of Birmingham. By Sunday, the second winter storm in four days left Portland, Maine, beneath 16 inches of fresh weekend snow. Concord, N.H., and Syracuse, N.Y., received a foot of new snow, while Montpelier, Vt., got 10 inches and Bangor, Maine, 9 inches. Up to 6 inches of snow covered the Mohawk Valley and northern parts of the Susquehanna and Catskill areas of New York state early today. Sunny skies, high clouds and moderate to light winds spawned spring-like temperatures Sunday in the upper Midwest and Southeast. Record highs for the date included: International Falls and St. Cloud, Minn., 47; Devils Lake, N.D., 51; Jamestown, N.D. 54; Sioux Falls, S.D. 57; and Cape Hatteras, N.C., 71. Three Florida cities shared the nation's warmest readings on Sunday: it was 87 in Daytona Beach, Melbourne and West Palm Beach. Marie 24 cloudy; San Antonio 34 fair. _WEST: Albuquerque 29 fair; Anchorage 0 partly cloudy; Boise 22 fair; Casper 24 partly cloudy; Fairbanks 37 fog; Great Falls 26 windy; Honolulu 72 fair; Las Vegas 38 fair; Los Angeles 51 fair; Medford 31 cloudy; Pendleton 39 cloudy; Phoenix 49 partly cloudy; Portland, Ore., 42 rain; Reno 20 fair; Salt Lake City 30 cloudy; San Diego 45 fair; San Francisco 45 cloudy; Seattle 42 rain; Spokane 30 cloudy. _INTERNATIONAL: Calgary 19 partly cloudy; Montreal 1 partly cloudy; Ottawa 1 foggy; Regina 12 fair; Toronto 12 partly cloudy; Winnipeg 10 cloudy; Mexico City 46; Acapulco 75 fair; Merida 73 cloudy; Nassau 72; San Juan 68.

DOC.HEAD: Writers Applaud Rushdie's Defense, But Moslems are Unpersuaded
DOC.TEXT: Author Salman Rushdie's detailed defense of ``The Satanic Verses'' is winning plaudits from fellow writers but has failed to placate British Moslems who say the novel is blasphemous. Several writers said Rushdie's 7,000-word essay was a brilliant defense of free speech. But Moslems said it would not break the deadlock over the novel, and one reiterated that the death sentence passed on Rushdie by the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini remained in force. Rushdie's essay, published in The Independent on Sunday, was his first detailed comment on the furor aroused by ``The Satanic Verses'' since Khomeini's edict forced him into hiding a year ago. Rushdie, 42, wrote of the pain of being cut off from society; the irony of being condemned by Moslems for a novel that sought to highlight their plight as immigrants in the West; and the anger he feels that the Labor Party, which he has always supported, failed to back him. The Bombay-born Briton said his novel sought to create a literary language for ``formerly colonized, still-disadvantaged peoples,'' those like himself who straddle different cultures _ ``a love-song to our mongrel selves.'' ``To be rejected and reviled by, so to speak, one's own characters is a shocking and painful experience for any writer,'' he wrote. ``I recognize that many Moslems have felt shocked and pained too. Perhaps a way forward might be found through the mutual recognition of that mutual pain. Let us attempt to believe in each other's good faith.'' Shabbir Akhtar, a British Moslem, welcomed Rushdie's decision to publish the essay, calling it ``thoughtful and unexpected.'' But he said the novel remained a ``calculated attempt to vilify and slander (the Prophet) Mohammed.'' Akhtar is a member of the mosque council in Bradford, the heavily Moslem-populated city in northern England where anti-Rushdie sentiment runs high. Writing today in The Independent, sister of the paper that published Rushdie's essay, Akhtar urged Rushdie to ``engage in a dialogue'' with those he has offended. He said Islam was a merciful religion, and ``the magnanimity which has been denied to both parties may yet seek an occasion.'' But he regretted Rushdie's insistence that a paperback edition be published, saying it would ``fuel extremism in the Moslem camp. There may even be acts of political terrorism. It will be seen as a further provocation...'' Rushdie's publisher, Viking Penguin, says ``no firm date'' has been set for issuing a paperback. Liaqat Hussain, general secretary of the Council of Mosques in Bradford, urged Rushdie to ``be brave enough to face the world for his principles.'' Another British Moslem leader, Sayed Abdul Quddus, said: ``The death sentence still stands on Salman Rushdie. It has been passed by Islamic law.'' Novelist Penelope Lively, one of several writers who praised Rushdie's essay, called it ``dignified and moving. I think, sadly, it points up the basic confrontation; here is a novelist trying to explain his purpose to fundamentalists who cannot, or will not, understand what fiction is or does.'' Writer Michael Ignatieff said the essay would be regarded as ``one of the great classical defenses of the novelist's art in this country.'' In his essay, Rushdie says the sequences most objected to by his Moslem critics are actually attempts to express the pain of people when their faith is stretched to breaking point _ ``to portray a soul in crisis, to show how the loss of God can destroy a man's life.'' But he says the passage involving Mohammed with three pagan, female deities _ an episode that particularly incensed Moslems _ was designed in part to ask ``awkward questions'' about Islam's attitude to women. In introducing a character named Mahound, a medieval European term of abuse for Mohammed, Rushdie said he was turning an insult into a term of ethnic pride; ``The purpose is not to suggest that the Koran (the Moslem holy book) is written by the devil; it is to attempt the sort of act of affirmation that, in the United States, transformed the word Black from the standard term of racist abuse into a `beautiful' expression of cultural pride.'' To Moslems who accuse him of turning against the faith into which he was born, he replied: ``To put it as simply as possible: I am not a Moslem. It feels bizarre, and wholly inappropriate, to be described as some sort of heretic after having lived my life as a secular, pluralist, eclectic man.'' Responding to those who claim he deliberately set out to provoke Moslems, he likened himself to rape victims who are accused of having ``asked for it.'' In a separate interview with the Independent on Sunday, Rushdie said he has been reading Moby Dick, Ulysses, Tristram Shandy and great free-speech defenders like Rousseau, Diderot and Voltaire, and watching TV soap operas. He added: ``Having had a lot of late nights by myself I've also become an addict of American football'' _ one of the newer features of British television.

DOC.HEAD: Campaign Mailers Attack Anti-War Activist
DOC.TEXT: Ron Kovic, the disabled Vietnam veteran whose story is portrayed in the hit movie ``Born on the Fourth of July,'' has not declared his candidacy, but Rep. Robert K. Dornan is taking no chances. The Republican congressman already is on the offensive against Kovic in mailings that portray the veteran as a draft card-burning ultraliberal. Dornan sent out 20,000 fund-raising letters that reproduce an old newspaper photograph apparently showing Kovic burning a draft card. The letters, received Saturday by contributors, called Kovic the favorite of the ``ultra-liberal ... Hollywood left.'' Kovic, whose transformation from patriotic Marine to war opponent is recounted in the movie, said Sunday he would announce later this month whether he will run as a Democrat in Dornan's 38th Congressional District. He called Dornan's letter a ``hatred campaign,'' and a desperation move that will backfire. ``It's the false patriots who always attack the real heroes,'' said Kovic, who received the Purple Heart and is paralyzed from the chest down from a combat wound. While not stating he would run against Dornan, Kovic said his ``time of dedicated service to my country has come again,'' and that he was confident of victory if he does run. Dornan's letter asks for immediate campaign contributions of $100 or $150 and mentions the less savory aspects of Kovic's life, as recounted in the motion picture. ``The movie shows Kovic in a panic and mistakenly shooting his corporal to death in Vietnam, visiting prostitutes, abusing drugs and alcohol and cruelly insulting his parents,'' a postscript said. ``And this is a person the liberals want in the U.S. Congress. No way.'' The letter said Kovic is ``fast becoming one of the liberals' best hopes for 1990. And he will have access to hundreds of thousands of dollars from the Hollywood left and liberals across the country.'' Kovic has said Tom Cruise, who played him in the film, will walk precincts if Kovic decides to run. ``I can't waste any time in case this guy is serious,'' Dornan said Saturday. ``He's threatening to bring Tom Cruise and Jane Fonda and (Pentagon papers defendant) Daniel Ellsberg to town. If he's going to bring in these big guns, I've got to start building up my war chest.''

DOC.HEAD: Young Cancer Patient Realizes Dream
DOC.TEXT: For a 9-year-old English boy who is terminally ill with cancer, the looming silver-blue pickup truck with 5-foot wheels was a dream come true. ``There it is, Mom,'' cried Ray Joseph ``R.J.'' Bush, of West Croydon Surrey, England, as he pointed toward ``Big Foot,'' a customized truck. ``There it is.'' Seeing his mechanized hero for the first time was a dream come true for R.J., who suffers from rhabdomyosarcoma, a rare and fatal cancer which afflicts muscle fibers in children. With the aid of several British actors who perform in a BBC sitcom, R.J's parents, Ray and Josephine Bush, raised about $8,150 for a trip to Denver to see Bigfoot in the Coors Extra Gold Motor Spectacular Sunday at the Denver Coliseum. The Bushes arrived Saturday and were to return to England Monday. ``About 12 weeks ago, they said R.J. had a month or so to live,'' said his 42-year-old father, who quit his job in a florist shop to help care for the boy. ``Getting him here, being able to see Bigfoot, has helped keep him going.'' R.J., who was diagnosed with rhabdomyosarcoma about 16 months ago, has been a devoted fan of the modified Ford pickup since he first saw it on cable television several years ago. The youth's eyes grew even wider as he sat next to Bigfoot and received a few souvenirs from driver Ron Bachmann. ``How ya doin,' buddy?'' said Bachmann, who handed over a Bigfoot poster, a license plate, balloons and a miniature satin jacket with an embroidered Bigfoot patch. ``It's a little bewildering for him,'' said his mother as R.J., who is quiet and shy, reacted with tears to the Earth-shaking rumbling of engines throughout the Coliseum. ``I don't think he even believes that we were ever going to bring him here for this.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Los Angeles-dated 5th item in rdp to CORRECT in 2nd graf that judge's decision reached last month sted two months ago.
DOC.TEXT: Eddie Murphy and his assistants ran up $5 million in expenses during the making of the movie ``Coming to America,'' which has made no profit despite $350 million in ticket sales, according to studio records. Last month, Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist Art Buchwald and producer Alain Bernheim won a lawsuit against Paramount Pictures in which they said the studio took the concept for the 1988 movie from an idea by Buchwald. Paramount was ordered to pay Buchwald and Bernheim 19 percent of the movie's net profits. A financial audit is scheduled during a forthcoming phase of the trial to determine how much money Buchwald and Bernheim should receive. The financial documents released to the Los Angeles Times by court order Saturday were sealed during the trial at Paramount's request, but studio officials had testified that the movie was still in the red. The amount of money Paramount absorbed during the making of the movie could become an issue in the accounting phase of the suit. According to the documents, weekly charges to production made on Murphy's behalf included: $4,920 for a limousine and driver kept on call around the clock, $2,200 for a special motor home for Murphy, $1,592 to the motor home's driver, $1,500 for a personal trainer and $650 for a valet. None of those expenses came out of Murphy's $8 million salary, his 15 percent share of the film's gross receipts, his own travel and hotel expenses or his $5,000-a-week living allowance, according to the documents.

DOC.HEAD: Tutu: Havard Should Divest Until South African Changes Are Made
DOC.TEXT: Archbishop Desmond Tutu, who is a member of Harvard University's governing board, urged the school to withdraw its money from South Africa until promised changes are made there. Tutu told reporters Sunday that he had asked the 30-member Board of Overseers to sell off $139 million in investments in companies that do business in South Africa. The money could be reinvested once it becomes clear that reforms promised by President F.W. de Klerk will take place, Tutu said. The Board of Overseers, to which the Anglican archbishop was elected last June, had met earlier in the day in a closed session. The board planned to further consider the divestment issue at a later meeting. Last week, de Klerk said he would release jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and lift government bans on 30 outlawed opposition groups. Tutu, who won the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize for his anti-apartheid efforts, praised de Klerk for his announcement, but said actual advancements would be decided by the South African Parliament. ``We'd like to see these things immediately, but let's be realistic. The parliamentary session has just begun,'' he said. ``If (de Klerk) is playing games, they would be very odd games and the world would know how to act.'' When asked why he was in Massachusetts rather than in South Africa at such a critical time, Tutu said, ``Harvard is Harvard. The things that Harvard does and does not do have an impact far beyond what you would expect from an educational institution.'' Tutu ran for the Harvard board on an anti-apartheid slate and was elected last June, along with Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole and actor John Lithgow.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Attack Israeli Tourists In Bus; Kill Nine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to CORRECT death toll, edits to conform; picks up 21st pvs: The tour ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY11
DOC.TEXT: Two masked men ambushed a busload of Israeli tourists on an isolated desert road and opened fire with machine guns and hand grenades, killing at least nine Israelis and wounding 20, officials said. An Egyptian tour guide also was wounded in Sunday's attack. The bus was carrying 31 Israelis, the guide and an Egyptian driver to Cairo from Rafeh, a divided town on the Egypt-Israel border in the Sinai Peninsula. It was attacked near the Suez Canal town of Ismailiya, 40 miles from the capital, the Egyptian government said. Two men in a white Peugeot station wagon stopped the bus, got out of the car and opened fire with machine guns, said the government statement. It said they hurled four hand grenades, two of which exploded. ``The vehicle became like hell at once, there were shots from every direction, grenades were thrown inside the bus and everything was covered with smoke,'' said Dr. Yigal Barak, a survivor who spoke on army radio in a telephone interview from an Ismailiya hospital. Barak, who was not injured, said the attack lasted several minutes as many passengers lay flat on the floor. He said he could not see the attackers but could hear they fired both from outside and from the open doors of the bus. ``There was a terrible fear and the feeling of helplessness,'' said Barak. ``Nobody could protect us, nobody carried any weapons.'' It was the worst attack on Israelis in Egypt since 1985 and the deadliest single act of terror in Egypt since Moslem extremists killed President Anwar Sadat and seven others with him on a parade viewing stand on Oct. 6, 1981. The gunmen spoke Arabic with non-Egyptian accents, the Egyptian government statement said, suggesting they were either Palestinian or from other Arab countries. An unidentified man telephoned the Cairo bureau of a Western news agency and said the attack was in retaliation for alleged torture in Egyptian prisons. The caller claimed responsibility on behalf of the Organization for the Defense of Oppressed in Egyptian Prisons, a previously unknown group. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, speaking in a telephone interview with Israel TV, said it ``proves that hostility towards Israel still exists and runs amok in the region.'' President Hosni Mubarak telephoned Shamir and issued a statement calling the attack ``monstrous.'' He said it was aimed at thwarting efforts for Middle East peace, said the government-run Middle East News Agency. A witness, Miriam Kadmon, was quoted by Israel army radio as saying the car's driver signaled the bus to stop and the attackers then opened fire. An Egyptian, screaming, jumped out of the vehicle and was shot to death, she said. Rivka Betzer, another survivor, said that during the attack the gunmen told Egyptian hitchikers aboard the bus to get off and that one or two Israelis apparently got off with them and escaped. Israeli Embassy spokeswoman Doreet Shavit said today that nine Israelis were killed and 20 Israelis wounded. Egyptian officials said the Egyptian tour guide was hurt but the driver was not. Israeli officials in Jerusalem said earlier that a 10th Israeli died of wounds on a flight back to Israel, but a military official later corrected that report, saying no one died in flight. It was unclear if the witness who claimed an Egyptian ran off the bus and was killed was referring to a hitchhiker or if she was in error. Egyptian officials did not mention any deaths among hitchhikers. Ms. Shavit said Israel sent three medical teams to Cairo aboard a C-130 transport. Three of the wounded flew home overnight, and the others were being flown back today. MENA quoted an unidentified senior security official as saying police found the Peugeot station wagon on Cairo's northern outskirts early today. He said some bullet casings were found inside the vehicle, which is owned by an Egyptian who rents it to tourist agencies. The official said authorities had found clues as to the identity of the attackers, but did not elaborate. Authorities tightened security in Cairo's southern suburb of Maadi, where many Israeli diplomats live. Police threw up barricades and checked cars in the suburb, where Egyptian gunmen attacked Israeli diplomats in 1984 and 1985. The bus belonged to an Egyptian tourist company called Santa Maria Tours. The tour was organized by Ofakim, an Israeli tourist company. Albert Levy, an Ofakim manager, said the Israelis had begun an eight-day tour of Egypt. He said 12 members of the group lives in Mevasseret-Ziyyon, a Jerusalem suburb. Mubarak telephoned Shamir to express condolences to families of the victims. Mubarak ``stressed that nothing should ever obstruct the peace process but (this incident) should be an incentive for going ahead ... to reach a final settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict,'' MENA said. Egypt, the only Arab country to have peace with Israel, has been mediating efforts to get talks started between Israeli officials and representatives of Palestinians who have waged a 2-year-old uprising against Israeli rule of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. In Washington, State Department spokesman George Malleck said the attack represented an ``attempt by the enemies of peace to halt efforts at reconciliation and dialogue.'' Egypt and Israel signed a U.S.-mediated peace treaty in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Israel: Attack Designed To Harm Peace With Egypt, Peace Moves
With PM-Israelis Attacked, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT death toll to nine sted 10; pickup graf 4 pvs `It came...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli leaders said today an attack on a busload of Israeli tourists in Egypt was designed to harm Israel's peaceful relations with the Arab country and ruin chances for peace talks with the Palestinians. Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin said, ``There is no doubt that those who carried it out planned it in advance in order to harm the Israelis, harm Israel's ties with Egypt and maybe harm the chances of achieving peace in the region.'' Some officials said Sunday's attack, which claimed nine lives, seemed timed to coincide with a sensitive moment in Middle East peace efforts. It came two days before a crucial meeting was scheduled by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc, at which Shamir was expected to defend his Middle East peace plan against assaults by influential party hawks. Shamir's plan calls for Palestinian elections in the occupied territories as a first step toward peace. The hawks say the plan, which has been approved by Israel's coalition government, could lead to a Palestinian state. After the bus attack, Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, Shamir's chief opponent, announced on Israel army radio that the Likud session would be delayed to an unspecified date. Shamir said today before the postponement ``it is clear we don't think now about internal struggle and about settling accounts.'' If Shamir manages to overcome his party's hawks, the next step would be a Washington meeting urged by U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III with Israel's and Egypt's foreign ministers to set the stage for the first Israeli-Palestinian dialogue. But the emotional climate surrounding the bus attack could strengthen the hand of Likud's hard-liners. The hawks, who fear Shamir's plan could give the PLO a role in negotiations, blamed Egypt's links with the group for the attack. ``We should not accept any expressions of sorrow any more. The Egyptians have to prove they are disassociated only by one way _ a total rejection of the PLO,'' Yehoshua Matza, a Likud legislator, said on Israel army radio Sunday. Sharon said: ``There are those who believe that Egypt is an important contributor to peace, but I say that Egypt does not contribute to peace.... The positions of Egypt and the PLO are one.'' Ehud Olmert, Likud's Cabinet minister in charge of Arab affairs, said that ``diplomatic links with Egypt are important'' but suggested Israelis should stop visiting Egypt. Last year, about 90,000 Israelis visited Egypt, according to Israeli reports. In 1986, Israeli tourism to Egypt came to a virtual halt for a year following the Oct. 6, 1985 attack in which an Egyptian policeman shot and killed seven Israeli tourists in the Sinai peninsula. Other Likud officials, including some of Shamir's supporters, were more cautious about blaming Egypt, the only Arab country that has made peace with Israel. ``I hope it would not influence the relations between Israel and Egypt,'' Foreign Minister Moshe Arens said. Finance Minister Shimon Peres of the left-of-center Labor Party, Shamir's rival and coalition partner, said Israel should pursue its peace plan regardless of the attack. ``It's clear to me that those who fired wanted to hurt that process,'' Peres said. ``Of course, such an attack does not help the peace process, but it should not be stopped by several mad terrorists.'' The leftist Peace Now group issued a statement calling on Jews and Arabs to ``act together to stop a crazy minority ready to spill blood in order to stop the peace process.'' Faisal Husseni, a leading pro-PLO activist, condemned the attack. He told The Associated Press in a telephone interview that such violence ``comes from groups who are fed by the stubbon Israeli position'' in the peace process.

DOC.HEAD: Life as a President's Child Isn't Easy, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 4th graf pvs, ``Being related xxx to CORRECT problem to problems
DOC.TEXT: An unusual study of presidents' children concludes that having a father in the White House brings ``more problems than opportunity.'' ``Almost any enterprise is criticized,'' says the report on ``All the Presidents' Children'' commissioned by George Bush's eldest son, George W. Bush, while his father was still president-elect. Douglas Wead reviewed the lives of presidential offspring from John Adams to Ronald Reagan and concluded that history ``should be a sobering warning to any new arrivals'' at the White House. ``Being related to a president may bring more problems than opportunity,'' Wead cautioned in his 44-page treatise, excerpts from which appear in the latest issue of U.S. News & World Report. ``If (an enterprise is) successful, it's assumed that it is because of the relationship. If not, the public assumes the son or daughter is lazy or incompetent,'' Wead reported. Wead ``found a consistent pattern of trouble for the sons and daughters of presidents,'' the magazine reported. ``There were higher-than-average rates of divorce, alcoholism and accidental death; a wide variety of scandals over real or perceived conflicts of interest, and constant frustration over lack of independence.'' Some presidential offspring became prominent in their own right: John Quincy Adams became president himself, and Theodore Roosevelt's four sons were war heroes. Others met tragedy during their father's term: Calvin Coolidge Jr. died of blood poisoning after a freak accident on the White House tennis court; Abraham Lincoln's son, Willie, died of pneumonia in his father's arms. The magazine ran the excerpts as part of a story looking at how the five Bush children are faring under the spotlight. George Walker Bush, 43, last year became a part owner and managing partner of the Texas Rangers baseball team. He also ruled out a race for governor of Texas. Another son, Neil, 35, a Denver oil executive, is currently under investigation by federal bank regulators as a former member of the board of directors of a major bank that collapsed, Silverado Banking, Savings & Loan Association. The Silverado bailout is expected to cost taxpayers $1 billion. The magazine reports that when Neil called his father recently to say he wanted to fight the Silverado charges rather than accept a negotiated settlement, the president told him, ``Don't worry about me. Don't worry about the presidency. Do what's best for Neil Bush.'' Daughter Dorothy LeBlond, 30, a tourism official for the state of Maine, recently filed for divorce from her husband of seven years. Jeb Bush, 36, is a Miami real estate developer active in state GOP politics. Marvin, 33, is a business entrepreneur who lives just across the Potomac in Alexandria, Va. Marvin, who had part of his colon removed in 1986, has been a prominent supporter of the National Foundation for Ileitis and Colitis. Wead spelled out some of the pitfalls of White House kinship for the Bush children. ``Try something great and (you) appear grandiose and presumptuous. Try to lead a quiet, normal life and (you) appear lazy or unambitious. Try something artistic and (you will) offend those who believe in `causes,''' Wead said. ``The presidential child in business faces the pressure of enormous scrutiny. Two things the media and the public won't allow? Success or failure. Keep the business mediocre, maintain a personal low profile and you will be left alone,'' said Wead, a White House liaison to conservative groups.

DOC.HEAD: Precede PAARL
Ministers: Segregated Neighborhoods, Schools To Stay
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout with officials saying white schools and neighborhoods will remain, Mandela associate demanding release of all ANC prisoners; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The government remains committed to segregated neighborhoods and public schools despite President F.W. de Klerk's announcement of major political reforms, two Cabinet ministers said today. ``Black people should be running their own education and white people should be running their own education,'' said Stoffel van der Merwe, the white official who oversees education for blacks. Otherwise, he said, there will be ``tremendous chaos.'' Herman Kriel, minister of planning and provincial affairs, said the government has no plans to repeal the Group Areas Act, which mandates racial segregation of residential areas. ``We cannot allow the minorities that live here to be swamped by majority decisions,'' he said. ``We believe community life is a right.'' The two ministers spoke at briefings for journalists covering the start of Parliament. On Friday, in a historic speech opening the session, de Klerk lifted bans on the African National Congress and other militant opposition groups, declared a moratorium on executions, eased restrictions on the media, and pledged to free ANC leader Nelson Mandela soon. De Klerk said his intention was to draw black leaders into negotiations on a constitution that would extend political rights to the black majority. He said Sunday the government would implement major constitutional changes only after white voters were allowed to convey their views. Mandela's wife, Winnie, visited her husband Sunday and said later that the white-led government still must be pressured into further reforms before Mandela can go free. She said those conditions include lifting the 3{-year-old state of emergency, and she appealed for renewed pressure on authorities to lift it. ``Unfortunately, the obstacles that were in the way, which prevented his release on Friday, still exist,'' Mrs. Mandela said after the four-hour visit at the Victor Verster prison farm. ``It ... doesn't depend on him when he will be released,'' she said. But in answer to repeated questions about the obstacles, she said Mandela still demands the complete lifting of the state of emergency. Dullah Omar, an anti-apartheid lawyer who accompanied Mrs. Mandela, said Mandela also demands that the government free all jailed members of his African National Congress, including those convicted of violent acts. De Klerk offered to free prisoners convicted of belonging to the ANC, but not those convicted of terrorism or murder. Under the emergency regulations that remain in effect, the government can detain anyone for up to six months without charge. Police have wide powers to ban meetings or speeches and restrict televison or photo coverage of their own actions in dealing with unrest. Van der Merwe said today that the government was ready to open negotiations promptly and contended that some anti-apartheid groups were looking for excuses not to talk. The ANC has said it will enter negotiations only if Mandela and other political prisoners were freed, the state of emergency was lifted, outlawed opposition groups were legalized, executions were halted, and troops were removed from black townships. To a large extent, these conditions have now been met. De Klerk has expressed a desire to meet the remaining conditions soon. De Klerk issued a statement through government-run radio Sunday night responding to comments from ANC officials that the guerrilla campaign would continue. If that happened, de Klerk was quoted as saying, ``The world would turn against them.'' Mandela, 71, was jailed in 1962 and is serving a life sentence for helping to plan the start of the ANC's sabotage and bombing campaign against the government. Mrs. Mandela said her husband was preparing a reaction to de Klerk's speech, but she didn't know when it would be made public because ``he remains a prisoner.'' On her return to Johannesburg, she said the document being prepared by her husband would indicate the circumstances under which he would be released and would indicate when his release is expected. De Klerk has said people imprisoned only for membership in outlawed organizations or non-violent support of such groups, would be freed. Those convicted of violent crimes, including participation in the ANC's bombing campaign that killed 40 people and injured 680 over the past three years, would not be freed. In Pretoria Sunday, assailants shot out windows at the British Embassy. A day earlier, right-wing graffiti was spray-painted on the building. No one was injured and no one claimed responsibility for the incidents, which may have been in retaliation for Britain's endorsement of de Klerk's reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Plane Found in Pasture; Dead Include Candidate's Children
DOC.TEXT: A woman feeding cattle in a pasture 100 yards from her home found a plane that had crashed four days earlier. All four people aboard were dead, including two teen-age children of a congressional candidate. The pilot and a newspaper publisher also were among the dead recovered Sunday. The four had been on a campaign swing Wednesday with state Rep. Bill Brewster, who was kicking off his campaign for Congress. Police said the crash victims probably died instantly when the plane, bound for Ardmore, buried its nose in a pasture in Coal County shortly after taking off from nearby McAlester in stormy weather. ``We believe it crashed within 30 minutes of departure, but that won't be known for a while,'' Highway Patrol Lt. Mike Grimes said. ``We're basing that estimate on the distance the plane was from its departure point.'' The victims were Kecia Brewster, 16, and Kent Brewster, 13, who had accompanied their father on his campaign for the 3rd District congressional seat; Herb Pate, 32, publisher of The Madill Record; and pilot Jack Kirkpatrick, 43, of Broken Arrow. Brewster and his wife were in another plane because he was heading to Oklahoma City to attend a legislative session while the children were heading home to Marietta, near Ardmore. A third plane carrying Brewster's other daughter and campaign workers landed safely at Ardmore. The crash site was about 7 miles north of Coalgate in southeastern Oklahoma, roughly halfway between McAlester and Ardmore. Grimes said the cause of the crash was not known. The National Transportation Safety Board will investigate. Freda Rogers, who lives about 100 yards from the crash site, was feeding cattle on her property about 4 p.m. Sunday when she saw something shiny, Highway Patrol Lt. Stewart Meyer said. Ms. Rogers called Coal County Sheriff Joe Stone, who confirmed the plane was the missing aircraft, Meyer said. About 60 aircraft had been used in an extensive search that began early Thursday but was hampered by fog and rain. The bad weather forced searchers to stay on the ground much of the time, covering the 80 miles between McAlester and Ardmore on foot, horseback and in four-wheel-drive vehicles. ``It was a long, tough road and we're just sorry the way it turned out,'' said Lt. Carolyn Wrobleski, spokeswoman for the Civil Air Patrol in Ardmore.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing Whites Vow To Fight Reforms
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: An attack on the British Embassy has increased fears that white extremists may begin lashing out in anger at the sweeping political changes proposed by President F.W. de Klerk. Assailants shot out windows at the embassy in Pretoria on Sunday, a day after right-wing graffiti was spray-painted on the building. The graffiti said: ``The Struggle Begins _ Order of the Boer (Afrikaner) People.'' Police said they have never heard of the group but are investigating. ``It is suspected that the attack by the right wing might have come about because we, the British government, have emphasized our support for the decisions announced by President de Klerk,'' embassy spokesman John Sawyer said today. De Klerk, in a speech Friday, legalized or lifted restrictions on more than 60 anti-apartheid groups, including the African National Congress, and promised to release jailed ANC leader Nelson Mandela. Right-wing whites accused the president of capitulating to the country's black majority and have vowed to resist the changes. Robert von Tonder, leader of a group that seeks a whites-only homeland, said de Klerk's changes could lead to the formation of an underground guerrilla movement for whites. Several other right-wing groups have said repeatedly they will take up arms if they believe the government has abandoned white privilege. The pro-apartheid Conservative Party, which won 31 percent of the white vote in last year's elections, is planning a major rally Feb. 15 in Pretoria, the capital, to protest against the ``revolutionary left-wing announcements'' by de Klerk. Most right-wing whites are Afrikaners. Primarily of Dutch descent, they began settling in South Africa more than 300 years ago and now account for about 3 million of the country's 5 million whites. In school they are taught that their role as rulers was ordained by God. Until several years ago, the main Afrikaner church taught that the foundations of apartheid were found in the Bible. De Klerk's legalization of the ANC has outraged many right-wingers, who for years have been told by the government that the black guerrilla movement was Communist-controlled terrorist group. Several recent incidents suggest a growing militancy among right-wing groups. _ Police Brig. Floris Mostert said in court last month that authorities had uncovered the existence of ``a secret organization ... with members from all levels of society, which strives to terrorize left-wing radicals with the aid of violence and intimidation.'' He declined to elaborate. _ Police in December announced the arrest of five men suspected of planning attacks against de Klerk and other government leaders as well as anti-apartheid activists. The men allegedly broke away from the neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement because they felt the group was not taking decisive measures to oppose de Klerk's reforms. _ Right-wing whites continue to champion the cause of Barend Strydom, a self-professed white supremacist who shot dead seven blacks and an Indian in Pretoria in 1988. Supporters held a service in November to commemorate the first anniversary of the shooting. Strydom is on Death Row for the killings. _ The mayor of Welkom, a conservative mining town, was tarred and feathered last year after he granted permission for a multi-racial running race.

DOC.HEAD: Constitutional Amendment Gives Party its Power Base
With PM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Article 6 of the Soviet Constitution, which makes the Communist Party the ``leading and guiding force of Soviet society,'' is the key to the party's exclusive hold on political power. It is part of the Constitution adopted Oct. 7, 1977, by a special session of the Supreme Soviet under the leadership of the late Leonid I. Brezhnev. It has been interpreted as ruling out the creation of competing political parties. The Article says: ``The leading and guiding force of Soviet society and the nucleus of its political system, of all state organizations and public organizations, is the Communist Party of the Soviet Union. The C.P.S.U. exists for the people and serves the people. ``The Communist Party, armed with Marxism-Leninism, determines the general perspectives of the development of society and the course of the home and foreign policy of the U.S.S.R., directs the great constructive work of the Soviet people, and imparts a planned, systematic and theoretically substantiated character to their struggle for the victory of communism. ``All party organizations shall function within the framework of the Constitution of the U.S.S.R.''

DOC.HEAD: HUD Insured Luxury Building's Mortgage
DOC.TEXT: The owners of a luxury apartment building got special treatment from the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development after hiring two former HUD officials as consultants, according to a report published today. Local HUD officials agreed to insure a $41 million mortgage for an apartment building on the fashionable East Side of Manhattan even though it was already under construction, New York Newsday reported. HUD usually requires application for mortgage insurance before construction starts. The building's owners eventually withdrew their HUD application and obtained the mortgage insurance elsewhere, Newsday said. At the time of the application for the government insurance, HUD was told that one-bedroom apartments at the building, called ``the Colorado,'' would rent for $2,200 a month. The newspaper said the two consultants to the Colorado's owners were Alexander Naclerio, former housing director for HUD's New York region, and Lance Wilson, a former executive assistant to Samuel R. Pierce Jr., then secretary of HUD. Naclerio and Wilson were paid $25,000 each, according to one of the owners, Norman Segal. Naclerio's attorney, Raymond B. Grunewald, said his client had been hired by the owners to work on other projects but may have helped process the Colorado's application to HUD. A lawyer for Wilson, Raymond Banoun, said that since the Colorado later went elsewhere for mortgage insurance, ``I don't see how there can be any suggestion that there's anything improper.''

DOC.HEAD: Warner Announces For Re-Election
DOC.TEXT: Sen. John Warner, R-Va., announced today he will seek re-election to a third term. Warner, 62, was elected to the Senate in 1978 after serving as undersecretary of the Navy, secretary of the Navy and head of the American Revolution Bicentennial Administration. He told a news conference he believes ``seniority in Congress means an ever more experienced, ever stronger voice for Virginia.'' He said he has raised about $750,000 for his re-election effort. Asked how he felt about having no announced competition as yet from the Democratic Party, Warner said he hoped that reflected people's satisfaction with his work. ``Should there not be an opponent, I would accept that, not in a boastful way, but with humility, and go right on and campaign,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Troops Force Rival Units From Key Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with seven grafs to UPDATE with new cease-fire collapsing; picks up 6th pvs, `A police...'
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's troops drove a rival Christian militia from a key coastal town north of Beirut today and prepared for a final assault to dislodge the militia from the capital, police said. Police said 64 more people were killed and 95 wounded in both Christian and Moslem neighborhoods since Sunday. The latest casualties raised the toll to at least 274 people killed and 1,030 wounded in the week-old fighting between Aoun's forces and the Christian militia of Samir Geagea. The factions are battling for control of the Christian enclave. In Beirut, already devastated by fighting between the Christian factions, a four-hour gun battle broke out Sunday between rival Shiite Moslem factions in the southern slums. Police said four people were killed and seven wounded before Syrian troops moved in to separate the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, and the Syrian-allied Amal militia. A committee representing Maronite Catholic Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir called a cease-fire for 2:15 p.m. today, the seventh in a week of fighting between the Christian forces. But the Lebanese Forces charged in a communique that Aoun's forces mounted a large-scale attack on the militia's strongholds in east Beirut's Ein Rummaneh district ``at the very moment the cease-fire was slated to start. Pitched battles are raging.'' Earlier today, Aoun began to regroup armored forces at the northern and northeastern entrances to Beirut's eastern Christian sector after helicopter-borne paratroopers seized the strategic coastal town of Dbaye in close-quarter combat Sunday, authorities said. A police spokesman said Aoun's soldiers, mostly trained by U.S. Marines, ``are mopping up Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen from a few remaining pockets of resistance in Dbaye before turning to the Beirut battle.'' The latest casualties included 59 fighters killed and 70 wounded in the battle for Dbaye. Dbaye's capture was Aoun's first meaningful victory in the showdown for mastery of Lebanon's Christian enclave. Shelling duels slackened at dawn, allowing tens of thousands of residents to venture out from basements and underground bomb shelters for the first time in six days to take stock of the destruction. However, the civil defense department said fire brigades had no water to battle fires raging out of control because all pumping stations had been knocked out of action. ``I am stunned,'' said Youssef Khazen, 35, whose electrical tool shop in east Beirut's residential district of Ashrafiyeh was gutted. ``You cannot believe what those monsters have done to us. They simply ruined us. Ashrafiyeh looks like it was struck by a hurricane,'' Khazen told The Associated Press by telephone. A Lebanese Forces statement today conceded the loss of Dbaye, saying the 80-man militia garrison, which was outnumbered and outgunned, made a ``tactical retreat of 200 meters.'' Dbaye, five miles north of Beirut, sits at a strategic traffic junction of the coastal highway that links Beirut and north Lebanon. The road has been closed since the outbreak of the fighting. It also has a harbor that would enable Aoun's forces to disrupt maritime supplies to Geagea's command headquarters in east Beirut. Lebanese Forces defenders had held off repeated tank attacks in east Beirut by Aoun's forces. ``They might not be able to hold longer. The general is now in a stronger position,'' said the police spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing regulations. Both Aoun and Geagea are Maronite Catholics, the dominant Christian sect. The general, appointed head of an interim military cabinet in September 1988 by outgoing President Amin Gemayel, considers himself the sole legitimate authority in Lebanon. Geagea has been the Christians' standard bearer in the nearly 15-year-old civil war against the Moslems. Aoun has 20,000 troops. Geagea's heavily armed militia has 6,000 fighters and 30,000 reservists. Aoun's inability to crush Geagea has led to speculation that he risks being ousted by his troops if he does not deliver a quick victory. At least 1,000 of his fighters have defected, 600 to the Lebanese Forces and 400 to Gen. Emile Lahoud, the army commander named by Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi, military sources reported. Hrawi, another Maronite, was elected by Parliament Nov. 24 with a mandate to oversee a peace plan brokered by the Arab League in October. He fired Aoun as interim prime minister and army commander, but Aoun refused to quit. Aoun rejected the peace accord because it fails to guarantee the withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops from Lebanon. Aoun considers the Syrians, who entered Lebanon in 1976 under an Arab League peacekeeping mandate, to be an army of occupation. In Damascus, Syria, U.S. Ambassador Edward Djerjian today blamed Aoun's ``personal quest for power'' for the Christian battles. ``Aoun should step aside and all parties, including the Lebanese armed forces, should support President Elias Hrawi now in urgent work for restoring legal authority,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Dolls May Be Overrated in Child Abuse Cases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 21st graf pvs, `In California ...' to UPDATE with prosecutors deciding to retry Raymond Buckey.
DOC.TEXT: The 5-year-old girl tossed her hair, twisted around in the chair, rolled her head, raised her arms, stood up and sat down again, all the while dutifully answering questions from the nice lady with the rag doll. A camera rolled behind a two-way mirror as the two went through a delicate procedure that has become vital in prosecution of child abuse cases. The lady told the girl that sometimes unpleasant things happen to little children and maybe they could talk about it. She pulled out a clothed, rag doll with hair of yarn _ and anatomical details such as breasts and genitals. Together, the child and interviewer pointed to the different body parts. No, no one had ever touched her there, said the child, pointing. She was sure. Despite physical evidence of abuse, the little girl wasn't talking that day. In recent years, the use of anatomical dolls has grown as more child abuse cases are prosecuted. But a new study shows that the dolls' effectiveness in aiding a child's memory may be overrated. ``These dolls have become very popular because some psychologists believe they do something magical, eliciting information they otherwise couldn't get at,'' said Bruce Forman, a University of Miami psychologist. ``But our findings indicate that's probably not so.'' Anatomical dolls became available in the late 1970s and early 1980s and now are common in social workers' and prosecutors' offices and police agencies. The dolls, costing up to $75, have evolved from crude, unclothed figures to less-threatening, more realistic ones with underwear and bright clothes. Experts agree that the dolls can help some children tell what happened to them, especially those who are very young or are embarrassed to talk about the incident. But the evidence is less clear in terms of what interview tool helps get the best information from an abused child and what is normal behavior. ``Clinically, many believe the dolls have a place in evaluating suspected abused kids that cannot be taken over by another tool,'' said Mark Everson, a psychologist and co-director of the clinical research program on childhood maltreatment at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. In a study of whether dolls' anatomical explicitness would lead a non-abused child to act out in a sexually suggestive manner, Everson found that 6 percent of more than 200 children aged 2-5 showed fairly clear sexual acts with the dolls during an interview, even when there was no history of abuse. In the Miami study, 45 children, aged 8 and 9, viewed a 12-minute film often used in sexual-abuse awareness programs. One group later told what they remembered verbally, another by drawing pictures and a third with the dolls. ``We found no significant difference in accuracy or completeness of information recalled,'' Forman said. The results of the study will be published in the journal ``Social Behavior and Personality.'' In another study, of 32 girls aged 5-8, the Miami researchers found that abused girls showed somewhat more aggression and sexual play with the dolls if an observer was not in the room than did non-abused girls. With an adult in the room, there was little difference between the two groups, Forman said. However, not all of the abused girls showed increased agression and sexual play, indicating a need for more research on what is normal behavior, he said. ``From our work, we know that children who have not been abused display some curiosity about sexual body parts, and that's normal and healthy when it appears at the appropriate age.'' It is important, he added, that aggression shown by a child doesn't necessarily imply a history of sexual abuse. ``We've only scratched the surface of how children react. There are still a lot of questions,'' he said. Although much has been made of the potential for over-interpretation of children's interaction with anatomical dolls, they have become an integral part of child-abuse investigations and the prosecution of mass child abuse cases. Videotaped interviews of children with the dolls was among evidence used to convict Frank Fuster Escalona in 1985 in one of Florida's most notorious cases, involving the abuse of children at a baby-sitting service in Dade County. The story was retold recently in the TV movie ``Unspeakable Acts.'' Fuster is serving six consecutive life sentences. His wife, Ileana, was also convicted in the so-called Country Walk case, which involved allegations of nude sex games and satanic animal sacrifices. She served about four years of a 10-year sentence and was deported to her native Honduras. Among defense criticisms was that children had been manipulated during the interviews and that using the dolls was inappropriate, said John Hogan, lead prosecutor. ``Obviously the jury didn't put much credence in that.'' In California, defense attorneys also made an issue of how children were interviewed in the McMartin preschool molestation case. Peggy McMartin Buckey was cleared and son Raymond Buckey was acquitted on most charges last month in the alleged molestation of 11 children at the now-defunct school in Manhattan Beach, a suburb of Los Angeles. Prosecutors last week said they will retry Raymond Buckey on the 13 counts on which the jury deadlocked. Mary Emmons, executive director of Children's Institute International, where the children were interviewed, said defense attorneys were just doing their job in attacking the methods. ``For the most part, the methods used by mental health professionals are well-stablished clinical methods designed to aid children in telling what may or may not have happened,'' she said. Others in the field echo that sentiment. ``I have seen some criticism of use of the dolls ... and frankly it all gets blown out of proportion,'' said Patricia Toth, of the National Center for Prosecution of Child Abuse, a nonprofit group based in Alexandria, Va. ``People latch onto the dolls as if they're responsible for conviction of innocent people,'' Toth said. ``I truly don't think they have the impact people attach to them. Dolls in and of themselves don't make the case.'' At the Children's Center in Miami, run by the Dade State Attorney's Office, dolls play a prominent role in interviews. They are primarily used for showing exactly what happened after a child has already talked about an incident, said Teresa Pooler, an assistant state attorney and director of the center. The center, founded in December 1986 after the Country Walk case, has about 18 dolls in adult, child and toddler size. The females have vaginas and breasts and the males have penises. An average of 70 children are interviewed a month. ``We use the dolls for demonstrative purposes, not for diagnosis as to whether something in fact occurred,'' said Pooler, adding children often have different names for body parts and difficulty with spatial relationships. ``I think anything that can be used to elicit a statement from a child is a positive thing,'' she said, ``provided it's used properly.''

DOC.HEAD: Doctors: May Be Years Before They Know How Lung Assist Device Performs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with girl still in critical condition this morning.
DOC.TEXT: Doctors at a hospital where the world's first implant of a lung assist device has taken place say it may be years before they can assess its potential. Last week, a 16-year-old girl became the first human recipient of the IntraVascular Oxygenator, known as IVOX. The girl, whose name was not released. remained in critical condition at LDS Hospital early today. Dr. Alan Morris, director of pulmonary research, and Dr. Terry Clemmer, director of critical-care medicine, said it may be months or even years before they can assess the medical significance of IVOX, which has received approval by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for up to 10 experimental implants. IVOX is an inch-wide bundle of plastic fibers that mimic the lung's task of supplying oxygen to the body. It was implanted during a two-hour operation Friday. It was unclear how long doctors hope to keep the device in the patient. In September, guidelines approved by the Food and Drug Administration limited implants to seven days in people with acute respiratory failure who have little or no chance of survival. However, hospital spokesman Tim Madden said Sunday the seven days is considered to be a ``rough guideline'' by doctors. ``It's not hard and fast, although there is a limit they think they can use it for, and that is about a week,'' he said. Hospital officials have released little information about the operation, or the patient's status. Madden said he was unable to discuss how doctors would decide when to remove the device. ``That would get into an area I just can't,'' he said. IVOX's developer, Dr. J.D. Mortensen of Salt Lake City, says while it cannot be called an artificial lung, it represents an important step toward eventual development of one. Implantation involves insertion of the device via the neck or groin into the inferior vena cava, the large vein that brings blood to the heart. Two tubes the diameter of a soda straw are attached to the IVOX bundle _ consisting of 900-1,200 hollow, porous fibers each about the diameter of a human hair. One delivers oxygen to the body from an oxygen system or tank, the other removes carbon dioxide, a waste product of breathing. Mortensen said the initial FDA-approved human experiments will involve only patients with acute lung disease, such as pneumonia or smoke inhalation, not long-term, chronic disorders such as cystic fibrosis or emphysema. The only alternative for people with acute lung failure is an extra corporeal oxygenator, a large machine that requires pumping the blood outside the body.

DOC.HEAD: 11 Union Members Arrested In Occupation of UMW Office
DOC.TEXT: Eleven United Mine Workers members on strike for more than five years were arrested today on charges of breaking into the UMW District 30 office in a protest of termination of their strike benefits. Members of UMW Local 2492 in Phelps, near Pikeville in the coalfields of eastern Kentucky, remained outside the office afterward, continuing the protest. The 90-member local has been striking McCoy-Caney Coal Co., now called Colonial Coal Co., near Phelps since 1984 when the company refused to sign the 1984 Bituminous Coal Operators' Association contract, the national contract with the UMW. The miners received their last strike benefit check on Dec. 15, and their health benefits could end within 30 days, said Hilman Dotson, president of Local 2492. Dotson was one of those charged with breaking into the UMW district office early today in an attempt to bring attention to their plight. Police went to the office about 12:45 a.m. EST to investigate a reported break-in and arrested the men on third-degree burglary charges, according to police records. The men were released after each posted $5,000 bond. The miners returned to the office parking lot after their release and were joined by about 30 other union members about 5 a.m., Dotson said. ``We're going to protest at the office until we get our checks back,'' said Dotson, who pledged that the protest would be peaceful. Dotson said they were losing their strike benefits because the union's international leadership determined there was no movement in contract talks. The frustrated miners also picketed outside the UMW office on Dec. 18. A sign on one of the miners' trucks mentioned UMW Vice President Cecil Roberts and a union occupation of a coal processing plant in Virginia last summer. ``If Cecil Roberts can occupy _ he taught us this tactic _ so can we,'' it said. Dotson said Leonard Fleming, co-administrator of District 30, spoke with the men today and promised to present their concerns to the international union. One of the miners, Homer Estep, said he has had a tough time feeding his family since his strike benefits were cut off. ``I'm living now on $92 a month and there's four of us at home,'' he said. ``It's pretty bad when you get up in the morning and you only have a piece of bologna to give the boys for breakfast.'' Telephone calls to the district office went unanswered this morning. In Washington, UMW staff member Bill Banig said he had not been aware of the situation and declined to comment.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Adds Opposition Members To Government
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's Parliament today added eight members of pro-democracy groups to Communist Premier Hans Modrow's government, giving the opposition seats in the Cabinet for the first time in the country's 40-year history. The Communists now hold less than half of the 36 Cabinet seats. Also today, Parliament banned the ultra-right Republican Party of West Germany from operating in East Germany. The party had been hoping to attract major voter support during upcoming elections. On Sunday, the Communist Party changed its name and promised to hand over $600 million in assets to the government in an attempt to refurbish its image before the elections. The first free balloting in the country's history is set for March 18. In an address to Parliament, Modrow said today that German reunification is inevitable, although many obstacles need to be overcome because the two German nations have vastly different legal and financial structures. He said his proposal last week that a united Germany be neutral was not meant to be the final word on the matter. ``I never believed that all points of my proposals would be accepted by everyone,'' he said. The United States and other NATO countries insist that a united Germany be a part of the Western alliance. West Germany has said that while it seeks German unity, it will not leave NATO. ``I made my proposals (on unification) ... to create conditions for the inevitable process of unification of the German states,'' Modrow said. Modrow asked West Germany to provide immediate, short-term financial assistance to help stabilize East Germany's flagging economy, which has been further worsened by strikes and an exodus of more than 50,000 East Germans to West Germany this year. The Communists are widely blamed for the nation's economic problems. Modrow told Parliament that East Germany needs a government of ``national responsibiity'' to lead it away from the brink of economic disaster and toward the free elections, which were made possible by a pro-democracy revolution last year that ousted hard-line Communist Party chief Erich Honecker. Following Modrow's address, Parliament approved his recommendations that the eight opposition officials be added to his Cabinet. The Communist Party now holds 17 of 36 seats in the new government. Besides those given to the pro-democracy forces, the other seats are held by parties once aligned with the Communists. The eight newly appointed opposition officials are Tatjana Boehm of the Independent Women's Association, Rainer Eppelmann of Democratic Awakening, Sebastian Pflugbeil of New Forum, Matthias Platzek of the Greens Party, Gerd Poppe from the Initiative for Peace and Human Rights, Wolfgang Ullmann from Democracy Now, Klaus Schlueter of the Green League, and Walter Romberg of the Social Democrats. Earlier today, both opposition leaders and the Communists discouraged West German politicians from stumping for East German candidates. At round-table negotiations, 10 of the 22 participants said West German politicians should not be invited to be guest speakers at election rallies. Former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt already has led a campaign rally for the East German Social Democrats, and had planned further appearances. Chancellor Helmut Kohl also has said he is planning to stump for candidates. The Communists especially have objected to the plans, saying such appearances amount to unfair interference in East German affairs. Parliament today barred the Republicans, neo-Nazi groups and other right-wing extremists from trying to spread their doctrines and beliefs in East Germany. A resolution said ``immediate measures are needed for the protection of the state and its citizens'' because of the activities of neo-Nazis and Republicans. It said there recently have been threats of ``violent acts'' that ``seriously threatened the process of renewal'' in East Germany. The Republicans are a legal party in West Germany, and during the past year they have been able to win seats in a number of state legislatures and local governing bodies. On Sunday, Communist leaders changed the party's name to the Party of Democratic Socialism. It previously had been known as the Socialist Unity Party of Germany. The party said it would hand over the $600 million from its private reserves because the ``country's economic situation requires such support,'' the government news agency ADN reported. ADN said the money came from party dues and party-owned businesses such as printing operations. It did not say what the party's total reserves are.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Eliminating $50 and $75 Savings Bonds from Payroll Plans
DOC.TEXT: The Treasury Department said today that beginning next Oct. 1, it will not issue $50 and $75 Series EE savings bonds through payroll savings plans, making $100 bonds the minimum denomination for plan participants. ``This step is one of several initiatives that will assure the long-term strength of the savings bonds program by reducing administrative costs,'' Richard L. Gregg, commissioner of the public debt, said in a statement. The change does not affect over-the-counter sales at financial institutions where $50 and $75 bonds will still be available. The Treasury said employees who currently buy $50 and $75 bonds will not be required to complete new bond authorizations. Instead, current allotments will automatically be applied to the purchase of $100 bonds. The Treasury began phasing out $50 and $75 bonds from payroll savings in February 1988 by no longer offering them to new enrollees. Payroll savings allows employees to buy savings bonds on the installment plan through regular payments withheld from their paychecks. Bonds are issued when the price of a bond is accumulated.

DOC.HEAD: Family Slain And Bodies Burned On Farm
DOC.TEXT: Capital murder charges have been filed against two men suspected in the slayings of a couple and their two children, who were each shot more than once and their bodies left in their burning home. Anthony Carr, 24, of Clarksdale and Robert Simon Jr. 26, of Memphis, Tenn., were arrested Saturday in Clarksdale, said Highway Patrol Lt. Kenny Dickerson. The victims, Carl Webster Parker, 58, his wife, Bobbie Jo, 45, and their children, Charlotte Jo, 9, and Gregory, 12, apparently walked in on a burglary Friday night at their home in Quitman County, about 15 miles from Clarksdale in the northwestern part of the state, police said. All were shot between two and four times at close range, said Quitman County Coroner J.W. Jenkins. ``They were all shot in the back,'' Jenkins said. ``There were two different guns used.'' ``The little girl also was raped,'' he said. ``It looked like she had broken loose and tried to run.'' The girl was shot three times in the back and once in the right hip, he said. The Lambert Volunteer Fire Department received a call late Friday that the Parkers' home was burning, said Assistant Fire Chief Chris Dancy. Investigators said they suspect the fire was set to cover the killings. Firefighters pulled the bodies of Parker and the two children from a rear room before flames gutted the house, Dancy said. ``All three were within 5 feet of each other,'' Jenkins said. ``We didn't know they'd been shot. We figured they died from smoke inhalation,'' Dancy said. After the fire was extinguished, Mrs. Parker's body was found in a back bedroom. Parker's pickup was found abandoned in Clarksdale early Saturday, Dickerson said. The family was returning home from a Bible study class at Riverside Baptist Church in Clarksdale at the time of the slayings, the pastor there said.

DOC.HEAD: Ethnic Albanians Mourn 25 Killed, Leaders See No Hope For Dialogue
With PM-Yugoslavia
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic Albanians today mourned 25 activists killed in clashes with police, and leaders of both the Albanian majority and Slav minority said they see no hope of talks to end the ethnic violence. Several thousand ethnic Albanians assembled in the center of this provincial capital for a moment of silence called by newly formed opposition groups. At 2 p.m., car horns sounded throughout the city and pedestrians stopped on sidewalks, raising their hands in the ``V'' for victory sign. Planes flew overhead and riot police stood by, but did not interfere. As the moment ended people applauded, then returned to their daily routine. ``We are not terrorists, we're just paying homage. We didn't kill anybody. We want every nation to live in equality and freedom,'' one ethnic Albanian participant said. In their quest for more autonomy, the ethnic Albanians have taken up calls sounded elsewhere in Eastern Europe for multiparty democracy, free elections and the release of political prisoners. Throughout the countryside today, cars stopped on roads, people filled village streets and workers put down their tools in fields and factories to observe the moment of silence. On a hillside outside Pristina, 200 mourners stood silently at the grave of one of the 25 demonstrators who have been killed in clashes with police since Jan. 24. A security forces helicopter hovered overhead. On Friday, federal authorities brought at least a temporary halt to the killing. They sent army tanks into Kosovo and staged a show of force with military jets flying low over Pristina and other cities. But leaders of both Kosovo's ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of the province's 1.9 million inhabitants, and its Slav minority of Serbs and Montenegrins said today there was little hope for a peaceful resolution. ``The peace is just a cover,'' said Bogdan Kecman, leader of the Serb minority group Bozur. ``Inside, war is raging.'' Ethnic Albanian leader Ibrahim Rugova, a writer who chairs the newly formed Democratic Union of Kosovo, echoed Kecman's pessimism. The ethnic Albanians have been seeking more autonomy since Serbia, the Yugoslav republic that administers Kosovo, last year imposed greater control over the province's police, judiciary and schools. The Serb minority says the move was necessary to protect Slavs in Kosovo from alleged harassment by ethnic Albanians that is driving them out of the region, the cradle of Serbian culture. ``There cannot be any talks with Albanian nationalists,'' Kecman told The Associated Press. The Serbs allege that the ethnic Albanians seek union with neighboring Communist Albania. Also today, the trial of Kosovo's former leader, Azem Vllasi, and 14 other ethnic Albanians resumed in Titova Mitrovica, north of Pristina. Vllasi, a political archrival of Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic, and the others are accused of ``counter-revolutionary activities'' and of inciting last year's unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Asks Party Leaders to End Communist Monopoly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with more Gorbachev acknowledging parties can be formed at some stage; picks up 19th pvs: Earlier last ... ^LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told the Communist Party leadership today that the time has come to loosen the party's iron grip on power and compete with others for the right to rule the Soviet Union. His landmark speech to the party's Central Committee came a day after perhaps the largest protest in Moscow since the Bolshevik revolution. At least 200,000 impassioned citizens marched to the Kremlin, demanding that the party embrace reform and end exclusive control of the government. At the opening session of a pivotal two-day Central Committee meeting, Gorbachev made essentially the same proposal. The party ``intends to struggle for the role of ruling party, but do it strictly in the framework of the democratic process, rejecting any kind of legal or political advantage,'' Gorbachev told the policy-making body. The party will ``present its own program, put it out for discussion, cooperate with other public-political forces,'' the Soviet leader said in remarks distributed by the Tass news agency. The meeting comes at a time of growing dissatisfaction with the Communist leadership by the populace plagued by chronic shortages and ethnic unrest. The Tass news agency reported that Gorbachev urged the party to move up the next Communist Party congress, theoretically the party's highest-ranking body, to late June. Presumably it would be to allow him to choose a new Central Committee and further advance radical reforms in the party. The 251-member Central Committee, despite extensive changes made by Gorbachev in recent years, is still regarded by reformers as a bastion of party conservatives who worry that Gorbachev's reforms are leading the country to economic collapse and ethnic strife. The proposed changes by Gorbachev would meet some of the demands of the reformers who rallied an estimated 200,000 people just outside the Kremlin on Sunday. One of their leaders, Communist reformer Boris N. Yeltsin, said the Central Committee's plenary meeting represented the party's ``last chance.'' Tass said Yeltsin, who remains a Central Committee member despite his populist campaign against party privilege, was one of those who spoke after Gorbachev during the opening session of the Central Committee meeting.
