Gorbachev's statement to Central Committee meeting, which had been anticipated for weeks and expected to turn into a battle between conservatives and reformers, pushed the party toward elimination of its constitutionally guaranteed position as the ``leading and guiding force'' of Soviet society. The former Soviet satellites of Eastern Europe abd party leaders in the Soviet Baltic republics already have given up their exclusive right to power. The political reforms through which he has strengthened the government at the expense of the party apparatus ``have been accompanied by a growth in political pluralism,'' Gorbachev said. ``This process can lead to the creation of parties at some stage.'' Gorbachev declared that the party now was ``ready to act taking into account these new circumstances, cooperate and carry out a dialogue with all organizations that stand on constitutional grounds, and the social structure established in it.'' Earlier last week, Gorbachev denied a U.S. broadcast report that he was considering stepping down as party chief but remaining president. In such a scenario, Gorbachev would continue to run the country with the decison-making power once concentrated in the party transferred to legislative bodies. Some demonstrators on Sunday carried signs warning Communist officials who resist change to ``Remember Romania,'' where Communist dicatator Nicolae Ceausescu was toppled in a bloody December revolution. Others called for the ruling party Politburo to resign. It served notice on the Central Committee that a disgruntled populace expects radical changes. The people are angered by the dismal state of the economy, which has wrought worsening consumer shortages, and they resent that many Communist officials exploit their power and enjoy comforts and goods denied the populace. A wall of protesters 60 wide and more than a half-mile long had marched from Gorky Park, through some of Moscow's widest streets, to a rally at the steps of the Moscow Hotel across from Red Square. They demanded that the Communist Party give up its constitutionally guaranteed monopoly on political power. ``We need a free society, with a free economy ... a society of free people,'' declared economist Gavriil Popov. The crowd waved huge white-red-and-blue flags of pre-revolutionary Russia. ``Long live the beginning of the peaceful, non-violent revolution of February 1990!'' historian Yuri Afanasiev told the cheering crowd. The rally united reformers from the People's Front organizations of Moscow and Russia, the Association of Moscow Voters, the Memorial group dedicated to remembering the victims of Stalin, and other reformers. It marked another step in a rapid solidification of the reformers' movement. The Radio Moscow news service, Interfax, also said Gorbachev was planning structural reforms that would reduce the size of the Central Committee and possibly eliminate the Politburo. He also was expected to give tacit approval to the concept of private property. However, he cautioned that a retooled political system could not be considered a solution for all the country's problems. The Soviet Union is the last Warsaw Pact country where the Communists still have a guaranteed lock on power. However, in the country's Baltic republics, the party already has given up its claim to exclusive power and many small, local parties are forming to compete in local elections scheduled for later this month. Many Moscow observers expected the Central Committee meeting to develop into a pitched battled between reformers who want quicker change and conservatives who feel that reforms are wrecking the economy and causing ethnic strife. The two-day Central Committee meeting is likely to be the last before local elections. Most of the voting is scheduled to take place in the next six weeks. Many prominent local party officials were embarrassed by defeat in the last national elections in March.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Killer Charged With Killing Girlfriend, Taking Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Police said...', to CORRECT time of shooting to 11:20 a.m. sted p.m.
DOC.TEXT: A convicted killer was arrested after he shot his girlfriend to death, drove to a restaurant with police in pursuit and took nine people hostage for up to 6{ hours, police said. The hostages were all freed unharmed. Fred Goodine Jr. was being held at the Pickens County Law Enforcement Center pending a bond hearing later today on charges of murder and kidnapping, sheriff's department officials said. Police said Goodine, 47, shot his girlfriend at about 11:20 a.m. Sunday. The woman, 40-year-old Mary Williams of Central, died an hour and a half later. Shortly after the shooting, Goodine was spotted driving through Clemson. Police gave chase because his car matched the description given for the suspect in Ms. Williams' shooting. He pulled up to the Shoney's restaurant on U.S. 123 and went inside, officials said. Workers there said he was a regular customer. Dennis McDill, a waiter at Shoney's, said the restaurant had a lunchtime crowd of about 75 to 100 people when the hostage incident began. Police Chief Johnson Link said Goodine took nine hostages. One of the hostages, waitress Lori Hockman, said they were held in the kitchen, and both gunman and hostages remained calm. ``He wasn't pointing the gun at anyone. I don't think he was really threatening anyone at that point,'' she said. ``He seemed like he was reasonable, but I'm sure that he probably feels trapped.'' When she and another woman began crying, the gunman let them go, she said. The others were released unharmed one at a time over the next few hours. Only a manager remained when Goodine surrendered about 6:15 p.m., officials said. Earlier in the day, said Goodine's wife, Betty, he was ``talking sort of weird'' and mentioned she might soon need a black coat. Mrs. Goodine said she knew of her husband's girlfriend but held no animosity toward her. ``I'm not the kind of person who hates,'' she said. ``If I'm serving God, then I can't hate someone.'' The couple married when both were 15, she said. Court records show that Goodine was charged with murder in 1982 for the shooting death of Barbara J. Henderson, 41, whom he was dating. He was convicted on a lesser voluntary manslaughter charge in 1983, and served part of a five-year prison sentence.

DOC.HEAD: RCA Fined $2.5 Million in Pentagon Contractors Probe
DOC.TEXT: RCA Corp. pleaded guilty in federal court today to two felony charges and was fined $2.5 million as part of the continuing probe of contractors who acquired and passed along secret Defense Department plans for weapons systems. One former and one current RCA employee also entered guilty pleas to charges of illegally conveying government property. The government told U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris that in the years 1978-1985, RCA acquired copies of a wide range of Department of Defense documents dealing with program objectives, internal decisions and budget estimates. ``Both counts of the information to which RCA plead guilty concrned RCA's unauthorized acquisition of secret editions of the Department of Defense's five-year defense program,'' said the U.S. attorney's office. One count charged that RCA, through former employee Leonard Kampf, gave others within the company a copy of the five-year program for 1985. The other count made a similar charge for 1986, involving Ronald Stevens. Stevens, 49, manager of marketing services at RCA's Aerospace and Defense Division at Cherry Hill, N.J. and Kampf, 69, former manager of marketing information and communications in Cherry Hill, face possible sentences of up to 10 years in prison and fines of $10,000. As part of their plea agreement, the two agreed to cooperate with the investigation. Stevens has been suspended from his duties, said George Jamison, a spokesman for General Electric Co., which purchased RCA in 1986. RCA agreed to enter the guilty plea when it learned the two planned to plead guilty to charges of conveying government documents without proper authority, according to a statement from GE. ``This unfortunate chapter in RCA history is now closed,'' GE said in a statement. The settlement is the second in three months. The Boeing Co. recently paid $5.2 million to settle civil and criminal charges involving similar violations.

DOC.HEAD: Latest Developments in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Here in brief are the latest developments in Eastern Europe:
DOC.HEAD: SOVIET UNION:
DOC.TEXT: At the opening of a two-day Central Committee meeting, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev tells the Communist Party leadership that the time has come to loosen the party's iron grip on power and allow other parties to seek control of the government. His speech today came a day after perhaps the largest protest in Moscow since the Bolshevik revolution. At least 200,000 impassioned citizens paraded through the streets to the Kremlin, demanding that the party embrace reform and end exclusive control of the government.
DOC.HEAD: YUGOSLAVIA:
DOC.TEXT: Liberal Communists in the republic of Slovenia break away from the national Communist Party and declare that they no longer recognize the institution that has ruled Yugoslavia since World War II. The move follows disputes over the pace of democratic reform and a virtual trade war between the relatively affluent republic of Slovenia and archrival Serbia, the largest and most populous of Yugoslavia's six republics.
DOC.HEAD: EAST GERMANY:
DOC.TEXT: WEST BERLIN _ Parliament adds eight members of pro-democracy groups to Communist Premier Hans Modrow's government, giving the opposition seats in the Cabinet for the first time in the country's 40-year history. The Communists now hold less than half of the 36 Cabinet seats. Also, Parliament bans the ultra-right Republican Party of West Germany from operating in East Germany. The party had been hoping to attract major voter support during upcoming elections.
DOC.HEAD: ROMANIA:
DOC.TEXT: A former Communist who was the top foreign affairs expert in Romania's revolutionary government resigned, saying he had completed his mission of pointing the country toward democratic elections. Silviu Brucan also said he was worried about several ``weak points of our new political life,'' including a apathy and a focus in campaigning for the May 20 elections on adversaries rather than policies.
DOC.HEAD: ALBANIA
DOC.TEXT: Albania's hard-line Communist leadership plans to introduce some reforms as part of a cautious move away from total control of society, Albania's state ATA news agency reported. At a Jan. 22-23 meeting, the party's Central Committee reaffirmed its claim to power but agreed to give state enterprises more decision-making authority, permit dual candidacies for some posts and tie wages more closely to production.

DOC.HEAD: Cholera Outbreak Kills 12
DOC.TEXT: An outbreak of cholera has killed 12 people and forced 91 to seek treatment at hospitals, the Health Ministry said Monday. Health Minister Mavis Muyundu ordered restrictions on public gatherings including funerals, weddings and sporting events to halt the spread of cholera from the western suburbs and central areas of the capital of Lusaka. Street vendors were prohibited from selling food, and residents were advised to boil drinking water, she said. Ten treatment centers were set up in the city, and authorities were ordered to ensure the bodies of cholera victims were buried within hours of death. The government postponed Wednesday's start of a national convention of the ruling United National Independence Party because of the outbreak. It was delayed until Feb. 12. Cholera is an intestinal disease spread mainly by poor hygiene and sanitation.

DOC.HEAD: Dim Future for $1 Billion Test Reactor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `The 8-year-old...', to CORRECT that reactor did not play role in space program but supporters had hoped it would. Picks up 4th graf, `The department...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Bush's Military, Bjt
LaserPhoto YAK1
DOC.TEXT: It is the federal government's newest nuclear reactor, a gleaming showcase amid aging Cold War-era plants. And it is about to be closed. The Department of Energy, in a cost-cutting move, announced last week it will shut the Hanford nuclear reservation's Fast Flux Test Facility. The 8-year-old test reactor, largest of its kind, never had a permanent mission. Supporters hoped to win the assignment of producing plutonium for the space program. Instead of using the reactor here, DOE will rely on reactors more than 30 years old at the Savannah River project near Aiken, S.C. The department says that project costs far less to maintain and operate than the $1 billion Flux. Savannah River has been shut down because of safety problems, however, and Hanford's supporters say it's hypocritical for the department, supposedly committed to safety, to cast its fate with the South Carolina project. ``This is a reactor that meets every standard, and they don't want to pay for it,'' said Rep. Sid Morrison, R-Wash., who is leading a fight in Congress to restore operating funds for one of the biggest employers in his district. Flux is the only defense reactor that meets federal standards for commercial nuclear plants, said Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash. And it has an operating record commercial reactors would envy, running 98 percent of the time it was supposed to in 1986, the Energy Department said. But the department, facing billions of dollars in replacement costs from decades of mismanaging its reactor complexes here, in South Carolina, in Colorado and elsewhere, decided to shut Flux during the next four years. That will cost 1,000 jobs at Hanford, which lost 2,000 jobs during the past two years when plutonium production for nuclear weapons ended. ``Unfortunately the message people get out of this is they may be praised for their work ethics and attitudes, but the jobs will go somewhere else that is cheaper,'' Morrison said. Built as a prototype for the Clinch River breeder reactor program, Flux began life in 1982 without a permanent mission when Congress decided to kill that expensive experiment to design a reactor that could generate and burn its own plutonium. But the Hanford test reactor was started up and has been performing experiments on the durability of reactor parts and fuel, producing radioactive isotopes for medicine, and carrying out other functions. ``Fast flux'' refers to the speed of neutrons on the reactor core during the fission process. The neutrons are not slowed down as in conventional reactors, which makes the production of nuclear fuel quicker. Lacking a permanent mission, the test reactor faced annual funding battles. But last year Energy Secretary James Watkins offered encouragement that production of plutonium-238 for the nation's space reactor program would be transferred from Savannah River to Hanford, after extensive modifications. But a budget analysis prepared for the department showed that modifying and operating the Hanford reactor for plutonium production would cost more than $1 billion through fiscal 1995 versus $172 million at Savannah River. In addition, the department said once Savannah River's reactors are restarted, they would be the only ones able to produce plutonium in the early 1990s in time to meet National Aeronautics and Space Administration and Pentagon needs. Hanford supporters say the Energy Department's budget concerns did not factor in the costs of writing off the $1 billion investment in Flux. It also didn't take into account that the Savannah River plants will have to be replaced soon anyway _ if restarted at all. The Flux shutdown is scheduled to begin in April and conclude by fiscal 1994, at a cost estimated at $275 million. Though members of the state's congressional delegation unanimously promised to fight the shutdown, some conceded privately that they face an uphill battle. For one thing, the Savannah River plants are much cheaper to operate. For another, the Energy Department cushioned the blow to Hanford by boosting the site's total budget request by $217 million, to a record $1.2 billion, and adding 300 jobs to a workforce of more than 13,000. Most of the increases will go toward the 30-year cleanup of the nuclear wastes at the department's most polluted site. But Morrison argues that cleanup funds are owed because of past federal abuses of the environment. Hanford was created as part of the Manhattan Project to beat Nazi Germany to the atomic bomb during World War II, and residents are proud of their history of making something useful for the nation, Morrison said. ``We want to produce something,'' Morrison said. ``That's born in us.''

DOC.HEAD: Key Lawmaker Promises Probe of Pentagon Supply Stockpiles
DOC.TEXT: The senior Republican on the Senate Armed Services Committee said today his panel will look into a report that the Pentagon has stockpiled $30 billion worth of unnecessary supplies and equipment. Sen. John Warner of Virginia said that he and Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., the Armed Services Committee chairman, ``will go to work on the problem,'' described in a Senate Budget Committee staff report disclosed over the weekend. Warner, however, said he did not believe the value of unnecessary supplies was as high as $30 billion, saying he thought it was more like $10 billion. He said he based the lower estimate on discussions he had with an assistant secretary of defense, whom he did not identify. The report said that the Defense Department has roughly $100 billion in supplies and equipment stockpiled at various installations and that as much as $30 billion worth of the material is going to waste. ``They have a 13,000-year supply of a particular part for an F-14 fighter aircraft,'' Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., chairman of the Budget Committee, said today. ``There are a number of other instances similar to that.'' The Budget Committee's findings were based in part by staff aides' visits to military bases around the country and on interviews with Pentagon officials. The committee staff found, among other things, that there was a glut of supplies and that in many instances equipment was stored in the open and was deteriorating. The report's release came as Congress is beginning to weigh the Bush administration's proposed $295 billion budget for fiscal 1991, which begins next Oct. 1. Appearing on NBC-TV's ``Today,'' show, Sasser said, ``The Pentagon has over $100 billion in spare parts. About $30 billion of those spare parts would be characterized as excess, as not needed.'' The senator said the excess supplies included, among other things, ``a female dress shirt that was prepared and tailored for the military. And this is a result of a study that cost $3.2 million. ``They studied the number of sizes they needed and they concluded 40 sizes of the shirt weren't enough so they went up to 120 sizes,'' Sasser said. ``Now, $3 million of these shirts are still gathering dust in Pentagon warehouses and now they've shifted over to a different shirt style entirely.'' ``So this is an example of the kind of problems we have in Pentagon procurement practices,'' he said. Sasser also said the Defense Department has spent over $700 million in the past six to eight years for additional warehouse space. ``And now with the troops on the verge of returning from Europe, we're going to have just a glut of material that we're going to have to store or deal with some way,'' he said. ``So I predict we're going to see war surplus stores bulging at the seams again just as they did after World War II.''

DOC.HEAD: Closing Arguments in Trial of Reputed Mob Boss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE with defense summation; pick up 9th graf pvs, `The principal ...
DOC.TEXT: A defense lawyer today asked the jury hearing John Gotti's assault trail to acquit the reputed mob boss, charging that prosecutors suffered from a ``disease'' that compelled them to chase Gotti. Gerald Shargel said there was absolutely no proof that Gotti, 49, and a reputed mob associate, Anthony Guerrieri, 61, had ordered the revenge shooting of John F. O'Connor, the former vice president of Carpenters' Union Local 608. Shargel ridiculed the prosecution's two key pieces of evidence _ testimony of convict James McElroy and audio tapes secretly recorded in 1986 at Gotti's Queens hangout and in the visiting room at the Rikers Island jail. ``When the smoke clears, you will realize one thing _ that there is no proof, let alone proof beyond a reasonable doubt, that John Gotti and Anthony Guerrieri had John O'Connor shot,'' Shargel said. He said prosecutors are afflicted with an illness _ ``a disease that will cause them to do anything to get John Gotti.'' Gotti is reputed to be the boss of the Gambino crime family. McElroy, a member of a criminal gang called the Westies who is serving a 60-year prison sentence, testified that he went to the funeral of a reputed Gambino underboss, Frank DeCicco, and was introduced as the Westie who was going to ``whack'' O'Connor. ``James McElroy is saying what he knows the prosecutors want to hear,'' Shargel said. The tapes in question were difficult to hear and the defense pointed out that transcripts of the same conversations used in a federal court trial differed from transcripts used in this trial, in state court. ``You've seen time and again that they misinterpreted on the tapes,'' Shargel said. ``They (prosecutors) know full well that the tapes don't prove the case.'' A second defense lawyer, Bruce Cutler, and Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky also were scheduled to give summations today. The jury could get the case Tuesday. The prosecution maintains the defendants had Westies gang members shoot O'Connor in retaliation for vandalism at a restaurant that which is controlled by an alleged Gotti associate, Philip Modica. O'Connor allegedly had the restaurant trashed because construction there was done by non-union workers. The prosecution's summation was expected to focus on testimony by McElroy, who said he was part of the group of Westies gang members who shot O'Connor as a favor to Gotti. The defense maintains McElroy is not credible because he testified that prosecutors said his cooperation in the case could help his girlfriend, who faces drug charges. The principal evidence against Gotti was a series of secretly recorded tapes. In one, Gotti allegedly told an associate, ``We're gonna, gonna bust him up.'' The defense maintains this section of the tape is largely inaudible and that the transcription by law enforcement officials is inaccurate. Although jurors will be allowed to hear the tapes during their deliberations, Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin said he was not sure he would allow them access to the transcripts. The state Supreme Court jury has been sequestered in a hotel. O'Connor, who was shot in the buttocks May 7, 1986, appeared as a surprise witness for the defense. He admitted that the union was plagued by intercine troubles and said it was possible that someone within the union could have arranged to have him shot. He said he saw the gunman but was unable to identify him from photographs of suspects. O'Connor faces charges in a 127-count indictment with extortion, perjury, larceny and labor racketeering.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak Enovy to Washington Appointed
DOC.TEXT: Rita Klimova, a former teacher and dissident, was appointed ambassador to the United States by President Vaclav Havel on Monday, the CTK news agency reported. The appointment comes on the eve of Havel's visit to the United States, where he is scheduled to meet with President Bush on Feb. 20. Ms. Klimova, 58, was a political economics teacher at the Charles University in Prague before she was dismissed for her political views after the 1968 Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia. She then worked as a translator for underground publications and became known as ``the voice of the revolution'' for having interpreted for Havel at news conferences during Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution in November. Ms. Klimova spent her childhood in the United States with her parents, who fled Czechoslovakia before World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Concerned Over Signs of Corrosion in Trans-Alaska Pipeline
DOC.TEXT: Corrosion caused by the failure of controversial protective coating and tape wraps has weakened parts of the 800-mile crude oil Trans-Alaska pipeline, triggering a federal probe, according to a published report. Alyeska Pipeline Service Co., the oil industry consortium that operates the pipeline, has already started making repairs on the line, the Los Angeles Times reported Sunday. Alyeska officials maintain the corrosion poses no immediate danger to its operations or to the environment. The pipeline carries crude oil from Alaska's North Slope to Valdez, where the crude is transferred to tankers for shipment to refineries. If left unchecked, corrosion could eventually weaken the half-inch-thick steel wall of the pipe, which is pressurized and could rupture, conceivably spawning an oil spill requiring a costly pipeline shutdown. ``We have sufficient early warning in this case,'' said Bill Howitt, Alyeska's manager for engineering. ``We don't have pipeline integrity problems.'' But Jack Overly, western regional division chief for the federal Office of Pipeline Safety, said: ``The extent of it (corrosion) we don't know, but it's big enough that it could affect the integrity of the pipeline.'' Alyeska may have violated federal safety regulations by failing to adequately maintain portions of its systems designed to retard corrosion, according to Office of Pipeline Safety staff reports, the newspaper said. The Office of Pipeline Safety, part of the Department of Transportation, could decide by spring whether to cite Alyeska for violating federal guidelines, the story said. Pipeline inspection reports show that safeguards against corrosion often were incomplete or faulty to begin with, the Times reported. Before pipeline operations began in 1977, preparations for laboratory tests of corrosion were set up at the National Bureau of Standards. But those tests were never conducted, the newspaper said, adding that most of the corrosion was caused by the failure of a protective coating and tape wraps, which many critics earlier had warned were flawed. Alyeska has said repairs on weakened portions of the line can be completed without disrupting oil flow for more than 2{ days over the next 18 months. Until repairs can be completed, pressure in the line has been reduced by 20 percent in key locations. The pipeline rehabilitation plan could cost operators $1.5 billion over the next five years, and under a complex formula used to determine royalties paid to Alaska, the state could lose $22 million this year alone, said Alaska Attorney General Douglas B. Baily. Federal inspectors also blamed corrosion in storage tank bottoms at the Valdez terminal on salty sand used as landfill beneath the tanks. Alyeska officials, however, maintain that the tanks were constructed on an asphalt base.

DOC.HEAD: Student Who Visited North Korea Gets 10 Years
DOC.TEXT: Im Su-kyong, a college student known to her supporters as the ``flower of unification,'' was convicted Monday of illegally visiting North Korea and sentenced to 10 years in prison. She was the first student sentenced to prison for visiting the communist nation. As the three-judge court declared them guilty, Miss Im and a dissident Roman Catholic priest on trial with her shouted: ``Wake up, judges who ignore unification!'' The priest, the Rev. Moon Gyu-hyon, 41, was sentenced to eight years for visiting North Korea. He went there to accompany Miss Im home. Both the defense and prosecution said they would appeal. The prosecution had sought 15 years in prison for Miss Im and 10 for Moon. About 30 radical students and Catholic priests raised clenched fists and shouted ``Release them!'' from the gllery of the Seoul District Criminal Court. The Rev. Moon Jung-hyon, a Catholic priest who is Moon's older brother, was expelled from the court after violating several orders to keep quiet. ``Is this a fair trial?'' he shouted as guards escorted him awat. A few hundred students protest rallies at Sogang and Hankook universities in Seoul, but did not confront police and dispersed voluntarily after less than two hours. Presiding Judge Hwang Sang-hyun pronounced Miss Im and Moon guilty of traveling to North Korea last summer in violation of national security laws. He said they had instructions from North Korea to foment protests against the United States and the South Korean government when they returned to Seoul through the border village of Panmunjom on Aug. 15. ``These days, war is a total war which involves politics, economics and other help'' the judge said. ``By providing the North with information regarding South Korean dissidents and opposition and other matters, they helped the North militarily.'' Miss Im testified that her trip July 1-8 to a world youth festival in North Korea was intended to promote Korean unification, but the judge said it benefited only North Korea, which he said was bent on making South Korea communist. South Koreans are not allowed to visit North Korea without government approval. The two Koreas were created when the peninsula was divided in 1945, at the end of World War II, and fought a war in 1950-53. A dissident clergyman, the Rev. Moon Ik-hwan, was sentenced to 10 years in prison in October for visiting North Korean leaders early in 1989 without government approval. In the verdict Monday, Hwang said the defendants never criticized North Korea while there, but spoke against South Korea and the United States. A North Korean film shown on South Korean television last year showed them denouncing the government in Seoul as a ``lackey of the U.S. imperialists.'' Radical students, dissidents and North Korea demand withdrawal of the 43,000 U.S. troops stationed in South Korea. The radicals are a small, vocal minority among South Korea's 42 million people and have lost public support largely because of their violent tactics and extreme views. In another legal action Monday, a Seoul appeals court accepted a defense argument and released dissident leader Lee Bu-young on a stay of a one-year sentence imposed by a lower court. Lee, a leader of South Korea's largest dissident group, the United National Democratic Movement, was arrested in April 1989 on charges of organizing illegal anti-government rallies.

DOC.HEAD: Former HUD Official Refuses to Testify
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Updates throughout with Hamernick taking 5th, Crawford saying OMB shares in responsibility for HUD scandal; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A former HUD official invoked his constitutional rights and refused to testify before a House panel today as it reopened its investigation into alleged widespread abuses in federal housing programs. James Hamernick, former director of the office of insured multifamily housing, became the fifth former official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development to refuse to testify before congressional investigators. Hamernick cited Fifth Amendment protections against self-incrimination in refusing to testify. Rep. Tom Lantos, chairman of the House Government Operations subcommittee on housing, said he had decided to resume a HUD probe despite Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's decision Thursday to seek appointment of a special prosecutor to investigate former Secretary Sam Pierce and other former top housing officials. That appointment by a federal court is now automatic under the law. Pierce is among the other former officials from the Reagan administration who have refused to testify. ``As has happened in the past, most notably in the Watergate investigation ... and the Iran-Contra investigation ... there is occasionally a compelling need for simultaneous parallel investigations by Congress and by law enforcement,'' Lantos said, explaining his decision to proceed further after holding more than 20 hearings last year. ``The subcommittee is duty-bound to proceed with its investigation of abuses at HUD,'' he said. ``This is particularly true since in recent weeks the subcommittee staff has uncovered a good deal of relevant new information.'' He declined to say what that information was. Hamernick refused to answer when Lantos asked him what HUD programs he discussed when he was entertained by Lance Wilson, a former top aid to Pierce who later became a housing consultant with the Wall Street firm of Paine Webber. Wilson reported spending more than $2,000 in that job on meals and other entertainment for Hamernick in expense accounts filed with his employer. Hamernick invoked a House rule allowing subpoenaed witnesses to ban cameras and recording equipment from his appearance. The subcommittee questioned Carol Crawford, former associate director of the Office of Management and Budget in the Reagan administration, who acknowledged that OMB shared some responsibility for what Lantos said was gross mismanagement at HUD during those years. ``I would say we have to accept a certain amount of responsibility,'' she said. Lantos said he had postponed the scheduled appearance of one principle witness, former HUD assistant secretary for housing Thomas Demery, who first appeared before the panel in May 1989. Demery's attorney, Jerris Leonard, said he was told over the weekend that Lantos decided he ``wanted to discuss with the independent counsel the question of whether or not Mr. Demery should appear because he is at least a witness into the investigation of Mr. Pierce's activities.'' Stuart Weisberg, the panel's chief counsel, said Demery would have been questioned about Pierce. He said Lantos postponed Demery's testimony until an independent counsel is named and they can discuss Demery's appearance. Lantos said new information caused him to change his mind since last fall, when he told reporters it was time to turn the case over to the courts and end the congressional probe of alleged fraud, mismanagement and influence-peddling at HUD during the Reagan years. Lantos said he was pleased with Thornburgh's application for a special counsel but ``I disagree with him on the scope'' of the counsel's investigation. Congressional investigators are interested in Pierce's assertion at a voluntary appearance last spring that he took no direct role in contract awards, a point disputed in subsequent testimony by other former HUD officials. Additional witnesses, including HUD inspector general Paul Adams, are set to appear before the panel on Tuesday, and Lantos said ``a number of additional hearings'' were being scheduled. Thornburgh sought an investigation of Pierce and others in the awarding of grants under HUD's section 8 moderate rehabilitation program, which provided subsidies for developers to do moderate amounts of renovation to housing for low-income people.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Says Covenant House Apparently Used Dead Son's ID
DOC.TEXT: The Covenant House runaway shelter apparently used the birth and baptismal certificates of a child who died at age 10 to provide a new identity for a former male prostitute, the child's mother said today. Betty Anne Warner said by phone from her home in Jamestown, N.Y., that she and her husband knew nothing of the alleged use of their son's identity until they learned of it from a reporter last week. They since have been interviewed by a New York City prosecutor, she said. ``When I first heard it, I thought it was a joke,'' Ms. Warner said. ``I thought, oh golly, what's happening in this cruel world?'' The Warners' son, Timothy, died of leukemia in 1980 at age 10. The Rev. Bruce Ritter, Covenant House's founder, has said he gave the name Timothy Warner to Kevin Kite, a former male prostitute, to protect him from enemies. Kite alleged in December that Ritter gave him money, housing and gifts in trade for sex, and Manhattan prosecutors have said they are investigating Covenant House finances. Ritter has denied Kite's charges and Kite's father has described him as an emotionally troubled liar. The New York Post, reporting on the Warners in today's edition, noted that Ritter said in a December newspaper column that he gave Kite ``the name of Timothy Warner on a new birth certificate so that he could get his life started again.'' Moreover, Kite has said that Covenant House officials gave him birth and baptismal certificates in Timothy Warner's name, and told him Warner was a child from Jamestown who died of cancer at age 10, the Post reported. Jamestown is about 300 miles northwest of New York City. It was unclear how Covenant House may have obtained Timothy Warner's birth and baptism records. Mrs. Warner said she has the originals. Stanley Arkin, Ritter's lawyer, said he did not know if Timothy Warner's records were used, but maintained that it is legal to use such records so long as they are not used for illegal purposes. While Ritter has acknowledged providing Kite with the name of Timothy Warner, ``I don't know that Father Ritter has any knowledge where that name came from or anything like that,'' Arkin said. Mrs. Warner said she and her husband, Terry, learned of the matter in a call from a New York Times reporter. They called an FBI agent and discussed it with him, then were called by a Manhattan assistant district attorney last week, she said. Gerald McKelvey, spokesman for the Manhattan prosecutors' office, declined to comment in the case. Covenant House's spokesman did not return a call. ``I am mad to think that somebody got a hold of these two documents and did use them,'' Mrs. Warner said in a telephone interview. ``The poor kid's dead. He suffered so. I wish he was still here. And here's somebody going around using his name. I don't think it's fair.''

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge On Trial Charged With Misuse of Office; Wiretap Use Allowed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with trial beginning, judge allows use of wiretaps as evidence; pick up 5th graf, `Aguilar, a ...
DOC.TEXT: The trial of U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar, charged with using his office to do favors for convicted felons, began today after a ruling that allows the prosecution to use wiretape evidence. Prosecutors are relying heavily on court-approved wiretaps from late 1987 and early 1988 to provide evidence that Aguilar tried to influence the outcomes of cases by approaching two fellow judges and assisting in criminal appeals. In today's ruling just before jury selection began, U.S. District Judge Louis Bechtle said wiretaps on Aguilar's co-defendants in September and October 1987 were valid. Those taps were the basis for court-approved monitoring of Aguilar's telephones beginning in January 1988. Besides the wiretap ruling, Bechtle denied motions by Aguilar's co-defendants for separate trials. Aguilar, 58, is charged with eight felonies, including the first racketeering charge against a federal judge. He faces up to 55 years in prison if convicted. His co-defendants are Rudy Tham, 66, a former Teamster leader and convicted embezzler, and Abe Chapman, 83, a self-styled former mobster who is related to Aguilar by marriage. Aguilar, a 1980 appointee of President Carter, is the fourth federal judge indicted during the last decade. Harry Claiborne of Nevada, Alcee Hastings of Florida and Walter Nixon of Mississippi were all later impeached and removed from office by Congress, although Hastings was acquitted of the criminal charge against him. None of the charges in a June grand jury indictment against Aguilar relate to cases in his court. He is accused of obstructing justice by trying to use his office to benefit friends and acquaintances. Other allegations say he approached two other federal judges to seek favorable treatment for Tham and Ronald Cloud, a former Aguilar law client who was convicted of bank fraud; of trying to help Tham get a new trial while Tham arranged a job for Aguilar's brother; and of tipping Chapman that his phone was being tapped. Aguilar also is accused of helping his former secretary, Vera Hoff, remain a fugitive in Mexico, where she fled after being convicted of tax evasion. The judge is additionally charged with lying to the FBI and advising one of Tham's lawyers to lie to the grand jury. Several of the accusations are combined in a charge that Aguilar used his office as a ``racketeering enterprise'' _ in the words of one prosecution brief, that he ``infiltrated'' the court and ``perverted its functioning to the benefit of criminal elements.'' Defense lawyers have suggested that Aguilar had made some mistakes in judgment out of loyalty, but have said the government's motives are political. Before Bechtle imposed a gag order in the case, Aguilar's lawyers repeatedly called the charges political _ ``an attempt to wipe out a frequent, vocal opponent of the conservative doctrines of the Reagan and Bush administrations,'' as attorney Patrick Hallinan put it. Since his appointment, Aguilar has curbed immigration raids on factories and restricted aerial surveillance of marijuana fields and prohibited the government from blocking a homosexual's entrance into the country. One of 11 children of poor Mexican immigrants, Aguilar worked his way through college and law school, and practiced law in San Jose for 19 years before then-Gov. Edmund Brown Jr. appointed him to the Superior Court in 1979. After his federal appointment the next year, one of his first acts was to swear in his father as a U.S. citizen.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Hails Moscow Rally, Reserves Appraisal Of Party Developments
DOC.TEXT: Developments

The Bush administration said today a massive rally in Moscow demanding that the Communist party surrender some powers was ``a measure of the new oppenness in the Soviet system.'' With Secretary of State James A. Baker III due in the Soviet capital for talks beginning Wednesday night, the administration refrained from assessing prospects for change in the Communist Party, which is holding its Central Committee meting. But Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, praised the demonstration Sunday that drew some 100,000 people to the Kremlin walls to demand that the party surrender its monopoly of power over the life of the nation. ``Yesterday marked the largest demonstration in Soviet history,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``It is a measure of the new openness in the Soviet system that Soviet people felt free enough to march for the rights for greater political participation in the political process.'' Her statement added: ``Our dream for all people, including the Soviet people, is political pluralism and free market economies.'' As for the party proceedings specifically, Ms. Tutwiler said at this point there was only speculation, which she did not discuss. Baker was due to leave tonight for Czechoslovakia for a 27-hour visit that will include a meeting with President Vaclav Havel and a foreign policy speech endorsing a 35-nation summit meeting next year to ease tensions in Europe. He will hold talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze in Moscow Wednesday evening through Saturday, when Baker also is scheduled to make an unprecedented appearance before the International Affairs Committee of the Soviet parliament. Baker will meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday. In testifying last week before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Baker endorsed ``the reformers'' in Eastern Europe and said he would offer technical cooperation and trade benefits to the Soviets if their human rights record continued to show improvement. But he also stressed the issue was not ``whether or not President Gorbachev will or will not succeed.'' Baker said, ``the issue ought to be whether or not we can take advantage of the fact that he is there now reforming things and ... lock in agreements that are mutually advantageous, that are good from the standpoint of the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: BBC Pips to Keep Time to One 1,000th of a Second
DOC.TEXT: The pips and peeps of BBC radio became a shade more precise Monday after the corporation moved its timekeeping operations from the countryside to its London headquarters. Not that radio listeners were likely to notice; the difference is that inaccuracies will be only one 1,000th of a second instead of five 1,000ths, the BBC said. BBC newscasts, recognizable worldwide by their hourly ``pip pip pip pip pip peep,'' have been getting the time from the Royal Greenwich Observatory since 1924. But that service ended with Monday's 1 p.m. (8 a.m. EST) time signal, and the BBC's own equipment, installed in a basement at its London headquarters, took over. The BBC started broadcasting its time checks 66 years ago, relying on data from the original observatory in the London suburb of Greenwich. In 1957, the observatory moved to Herstmonceux, south of London, and started using atomic clocks. But even these could not prevent occasional inaccuracies as the signal traveled from Herstmonceux to London. Now that the pips come directly from the BBC, the time should be accurate to within one 1,000th of a second, said Simon Shute, engineering manager at BBC radio.

DOC.TEXT: Two Waco television news anchors who were reported missing last week and then turned up together in New Mexico have resigned from the television station. The KWTX-TV anchors, Wendy Sheldon and Mike Reeder, resigned Friday during their first meeting with station executives since they left in January, said Virgil Teter, the station's vice president for news. Ms. Sheldon's husband, Jan Rigby, reported her missing Jan. 26, when she didn't show up for work. Rigby is production manager at the station. Ms. Sheldon anchored weekday newscasts. Former TV star Gary Coleman has sued his mother, claiming malicious prosecution in her unsuccessful attempt to place him and his multimillion-dollar estate under conservatorship. Coleman, who starred on the sitcom ``Diff'rent Strokes,'' is seeking $25,000 in costs incurred to fight the conservatorship action filed by his mother, Edmonia Sue Coleman, said his attorney, Barry E. Mallen. The lawsuit filed Friday also seeks exemplary dathe tumor, was cheered Sunday by a visit from Braxton, a former North Dakota State University football player. Darren's father, Michael Arneson, said his son's meeting with Braxton was a wish come true. Darren's other dream is to play one-on-one with Jordan, who sent him a letter and an autographed poster. After surgery, radiation treatments and chemotherapy, Darren's doctors say they find no sign of the tumor. He will now begin physical and speech therapy. Braxton gave Darren an autographed Bronco T-shirt. ``You feel happy someone wants to meet you, but it's sad to see someone going through all that pain,'' Braxton said.

Actor Tom Hanks will play Sherman McCoy in the movie adaptation of Tom Wolfe's novel ``Bonfire of the Vanities,'' a satirical look at New York's social hierarchy at the end of the 20th century. The Warner Bros. cast also includes Bruce Willis as journalist Peter Fallow and Melanie Griffith as the McCoy's extramarital girlfriend, Maria. The industry newspaper Daily Variety said Monday that Elizabeth Perkins was negotiating to play the part of Hanks' wife, Judy. The pairing would be their first since ``Big.'' The movie begins filming April 17 with five weeks of location shooting in New York City, followed by two weeks in Los Angeles and six weeks on a sound stage at The Burbank Studios. The movie is set for Christmas release.

DOC.HEAD: Dentist Cleared of Sex Attacks; Judge Cites `Fantasy' Theory
DOC.TEXT: A dentist was acquitted Monday of indecently assaulting seven women patients after a judge ruled that a sedative administered to them could have caused sexual fantasies. Neil Larah, 32, was accused of fondling six of the women in his office and sexually assaulting another after following her home. But the judge, Sir Derek Hodgson, ordered the jury to acquit him after hearing evidence from a leading anesthetist, Thomas Healey of Manchester University, that the sedative Valium, injected as a relaxant, could have caused the women to believe in ``unreal experiences.'' The judge said he did not doubt the women were telling what they believed to be the truth. ``The danger is not that they are lying or exaggerating, but that they are mistaken ... that their recollection, honestly believed in, is of an unreal and not a real experience,'' he said. ``It is also clear there is a mounting body of evidence that patients under sedation from this class of drugs do sometimes experience sexual or erotic fantasies,'' he said. The Lancet, a respected British medical weekly, reported last month on research suggesting some drugs administered by dentists could induce sexual fantasies.

DOC.HEAD: Research Finds Teenage Girls Having Sex Sooner
DOC.TEXT: America's teen-age girls seem to be having sex sooner, according to early reports from a federal survey of childbearing and sexual practices. A 1988 survey of young women 15 to 19 found that 54 percent had had intercourse at least once, according to researchers with the National Center for Health Statistics. That compares to 47 percent in a similar survey in 1982. ``A larger percentage of teen-agers (are) initiating sexual intercourse at younger ages than in 1982,'' the Atlanta-based Centers for Disease Control said in its report this week, commenting on the NCHS research. ``That's a fair conclusion to draw from this,'' said Dr. William Pratt, chief of the NCHS' Family Growth Survey Branch in Hyattsville, Md. ``We're quite sure it's real.'' And while sexual activity was somewhat more widespread among young black women than their white counterparts, the increase from 1982 to 1988 apparently was fueled by increased sexual activity among whites. For example, among 15-year-olds, 18 percent of whites had had sex in the 1982 survey, rising to 29 percent in 1988, Pratt said. Among blacks, the results actually fell slightly, from 28 percent to 26. For 16-year-olds, the results rose from 29 percent to 32 among whites, while the percentage for blacks rose from 42 to 46. For whites at 17, the percentage rose from 40 to 46; for blacks, the jump was from 55 to 69. For whites at 18, the increase was from 55 percent to 67; for blacks, the percentage fell from 77 to 69. And for 19-year-olds, the results rose from 69 percent to 81 among whites, while the percentage for blacks dropped slightly, from 82 percent to 81. Those year-by-year findings may be skewed by ``sampling variability,'' Pratt said; the smaller survey samples are more prone to statistical quirks. Small jumps in the white population have more influence on the total because of the greater number of whites. Racial breakdowns on the total survey are not yet available. Still, Pratt said, the pattern is clear. ``All that change was due to ... the changing behavior of white teen-agers,'' he said. ``Black teens were, statistically speaking, unchanged.'' The NCHS' Family Growth Survey questioned 8,450 young women, representing a national sample. Interviews were conducted one-on-one in the participants' homes. NCHS plans further reports on the findings.

DOC.HEAD: US Calls Attack on Israeli Tourists `Outrageous'
With AM-Bus Attack
DOC.TEXT: The terrorist attack in Egypt that killed nine Israeli tourists is an ``outrageous act'' designed to halt efforts toward reconciliation and dialogue between Arabs and Israelis, the State Department said Monday. President Bush called Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to express his sorrow and Secretary of State James A. Baker III relayed a similar message in calls to the Israeli and Egyptian foreign ministers, department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. ``This outrageous act of terrorism is to be condemned by civilized people everywhere,'' she said. ``Our sympathy goes out to the family and friends of all those killed and injured in this tragic incident.'' She added: ``Whoever did this is an enemy of peace. This is an obvious attempt to halt efforts at reconciliation and dialogue. It points out the need for all people to rededicate themselves to the pursuit of peace and not allow the perpetrators of such outrages to triumph.'' Of the 31 Israelis aboard the bus, at least nine were killed and 20 were wounded. The bus was attacked near the Suez Canal town of Ismailiya, 40 miles from the capital.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Invites Congo President for Visit
DOC.TEXT: President Bush has invited President Denis Sassou-Nguesso of the Congo to Washington on Feb. 12 for a state visit, the White House announced Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Border Guards Open Fire on Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Indian border guards opened fire on Pakistani protesters who swarmed into Indian territory in the northern state of Jammu-Kashmir on Monday, officials said. At least 10 people were believed injured in the shooting, the government's chief spokesman said; Pakistani officials said one protester was killed and 13 others were shot in the legs. The episode occurred near Ranbirsinghpura in Jammu region, 310 miles north of New Delhi, said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. The demonstrators who shouted anti-India slogans were protesting a recent Indian government crackdown on Moslem separatists in the Kashmir region of Jammu-Kashmir, said a Pakistani police official in Sialkot, about three miles from the border. The Indian spokesman said about 4,000 demonstrators gathered on the Pakistani side and tried to cross the border. ``Despite efforts by the Pakistani rangers, some people crossed over and the Indian security forces had to fire to control the situation.'' He said without elaborating. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said Pakistan's top diplomat in India, Rashid Babar, was summoned to the Foreign Office and was told of India's ``concern and deep regret'' at the ``unprovoked incident.'' The Pakistan government did not immediately react to the incident. In Jammu, a senior official of the Indian Border Security Force, which guards the area, said the trouble started around noon when about 500 people gathered near the border and shouted ``provocative slogans.'' He said the commander of the Border Security Force outpost then called Pakistani officers into the Indian territory to discuss the situation, following which the Pakistani forces dispersed the crowd. But the crowd regrouped and despite the Pakistani guards, many swarmed across the border, he said. Pakistan's official TV said there were about 30,000 demonstrators. The intrusion was an apparent fallout of a strike Monday in major Pakistani cities to support the Kashmiri secession. At least 76 people have been killed in Kashmir since Jan. 20 in clashes between curfew-breaking protesters and security forces. India accuses Pakistan of aiding the militants with a view to annexing Kashmir, a predominantly Moslem region claimed by Pakistan. The charge is routinely denied, but Pakistan says it supports the separatism, calling it a movement for self-determination. Jammu-Kashmir is part of a larger Kashmir that was divided into Indian and Pakistani territories after a war in 1948. A United Nations monitored cease-fire line separates the smaller slice of Pakistan Kashmir from the Indian state. Another war in 1965 over the territory has not changed the situation. India and Pakistan were formed by the division on religous lines of the Indian subcontinent when it gained independence from Britain in 1947. Pakistan claimed Jammu-Kashmir because of its dominant Moslem population. About 64 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 5 million people are Moslem, making it the only Moslem dominated state among predominantly Hindu India's 25 states.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Congratulates Costa Rican Victor
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration congratulated Rafael Angel Calderon on Monday on his election as president of Costa Rica, saying the United States looks forward to working with his government in a ``close and friendly atmosphere.'' ``We are pleased that the oldest democracy in Central America has once again conductd free and fair elections,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. ``This is a testament to the political traditions of the Costa Rican people and an indication of the direction in which our hemisphere is headed.'' The 40-year-old Calderon is a strong supporter of U.S. policy in Central America. He succeeds Oscar Arias, the prime mover of the region's peace process, who was barred from seeking re-election. ``The United States looks forward to working with his administration in the continued close and friendly atmosphere which has marked the relationship between our two countries,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Census Launches Publicity Campaign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS pvs 2nd graf bgng, Census Day, to restore dropped verb.
DOC.TEXT: They're going into churches and schools. They're advertising in foreign languages and dialects. They've hired professional athletes in Chicago and a former gang member in Los Angeles. The Census Bureau is going all out to count you. Census Day is April 1, the day every 10 years when the government takes a snapshot of the American public. To make sure everyone is included in the picture, no fewer than five advertising agencies and businesses across the country have been enlisted to spread the word. Serving as publicity ``ambassadors'' will be the 50 state titleholders from the Miss American pageant. ``Participation is one of the most important activities each one of us can do as citizens,'' said Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, who joined Miss America Debbye Turner in completing sample census forms at a news conference Monday. Mosbacher said a good turnout also saves the government some money. More than 100 million census forms will be mailed March 23, with a request that they be completed and sent back after April 1. People who don't return their forms will be contacted personally. Mosbacher estimated that every 1 percent increase in mail responses saves the government $10 million. Reaching some Americans is no easy task, however, and special efforts are being made to track them down. Brenda August, a census field coordinator in Los Angeles, said a former gang member has been hired to work with census enumerators to try to ease distrust of government officials in gang territories. Census workers won't be accompanied by police, but will receive safety training, travel in groups and wear special vests to identify themselves, she said. Widely known athletes, including members of the White Sox baseball team, will be used to count people in Chicago, said regional census director Stan Moore. Enumerators are being hired from among residents of public housing projects. Census volunteers will go into local churches and schools to promote participation, officials said. The Ad Council, a public service arm of the advertising industry, will conduct a national publicity campaign. Ads will appear on the Goodyear blimp and be mailed by J.C. Penney and Sears, Roebuck and Co. Space will be set aside in many 7-Eleven stores for census workers to answer customers' questions. The ad campaign's theme is ``Answer the Census: It Counts For More Than You Think.'' Ads will stress the importance of census data in determining the location of new public facilities, apportioning state legislatures and allocating federal funds to localities. Special advertising appeals will be aimed at blacks, Hispanics, Asians, American Indians and native Alaskans. The Asian ads, available in English, Vietnamese, Korean, Chinese and Japanese, feature an abacus with the theme, ``Any Way We Add It _ It Makes Good Sense to Answer the Census.'' A big selling point in the Hispanic ads, which will be published in Mexican, Cuban and Puerto Rican dialects as well as English, is that census answers are confidential. Census Director Barbara E. Bryant said records are kept secret for 72 years and information about individuals is not given to any government or private group.

DOC.HEAD: US Urges Angola To Halt Military Offensive
DOC.TEXT: The State Department urged the Angolan government Monday to halt its military offensive against U.S.-backed rebel forces and open negotiations on ending the conflict. The military attempts to crush the UNITA rebels ``are futile and make it increasingly difficult to reach the negotiated settlement necessary to conclude this tragic conflict,'' said department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler. She reaffirmed Washington's willingness to assist the warring factions and the chief outside mediator, Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko, in a search for peace. The heaviest fighting has been around the rebel-held town of Mavinga, where Ms. Tutwiler said government air strikes are continuing. The leftist government's main foreign supporter is the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Illinois Domestic Dispute Leaves Four Dead, One Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with identity of victims; police now unsure about allegation of psychiatric history, other detail. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A man killed his two adult sons and a girlfriend of one of them and stabbed his wife before taking his own life this morning as police attempted to negotiate with him by telephone, police said. Lt. Steve Rathbun of the Will County sheriff's office identified the gunman as James W. Breen, 47. His victims were identified as his sons James M. Breen, 27, and Eric T. Breen, 20, and a girlfriend of Eric's, Victoria Pasinski, 18, of Lockport. Breen's wife, Virginia, 48, was taken to a hospital for treatment of stab wounds. ``At 2:50 this morning we received a call of a domestic disturbance'' in the Phelan Acres subdivision in Wilmington Township, about 15 miles south of Joliet, Rathbun said. When police arrived, he said, they found a wounded woman who told them the gunman had already shot some people and was still in the house. Another spokesman for the sheriff's department, who asked not to be identified, said the elder Breen talked on and off with police negotiators by telephone until about 5:30 a.m., when the negotiator reported hearing what sounded like a gunshot. Police entered the house at 6:05 a.m. and found the gunman and three other bodies, the spokesman said. The elder Breen was found lying in the bathroom, a gun and a portable telephone next to him, the spokesman said. Two other bodies were found in a bedroom, and a fourth in the living room of the one-story frame house, the spokesman said. It was not immediately clear how the victims died but it appeared they had died at least two hours before Breen killed himself, the spokesman said. ``With the amount of blood around, there must have been some kind of struggle,'' he said. Mrs. Breen was taken to St. Joseph's Medical Center in Joliet, Rathbun said. Hospital spokeswoman Jean Slater said the victim was in stable condition. She declined to release additional information. Rathbun said the elder Breen ``had some contact with police in last few weeks,'' but he backed away from an earlier statement that the man had been treated for psychiatric problems in the past, saying police were unsure about it. Joliet is about 40 miles southwest of Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Volunteers Paint Anti-Drug Crusader's Home
DOC.TEXT: A volunteer work crew made up of recovering drug addicts gave a fresh coat of paint to the home of anti-drug crusader C.W. Roddy. They also covered up bullet holes in the home of the 60-year-old woman, who was wounded when a hail of bullets was fired into her house on New Year's Day. Roddy has complained for two years to police, city and county authorities about drug activities in her neighborhood. She supplied the paint Sunday for the crew of 13, all from a Veterans Administration drug recovery program in nearby Menlo Park. She also bought doughnuts and coffee for the workers. ``If I could, I'd jump up to the sky,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Governor Appoints Cuban Study Commission
DOC.TEXT: A new commission has been asked to figure out what would happen to Florida if Cuba's Communist regime lost power, Gov. Bob Martinez said Monday. Martinez said he has no information that change is imminent, but he believes the state should be ready in case Fidel Castro, in power since 1959, follows other Communist leaders out of power. ``It's pretty hard to believe that he can continue to get support from a system that no longer exists,'' Martinez said, referring to the reforms in the Socialist bloc countries that have helped sustain Cuba's struggling economy. The governor added that it would be ``bad planning'' for Florida not to prepare for Cuba after Communism. There are an estimated 700,000 Cubans in the Miami area. The 14-member commission will be chaired by Jorge Mas Canosa, a prominent Cuban-American businessman and leader of the influential Cuban American National Foundation lobbying group.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Conspirator In Nuke Plant Sabotage Changes Plea
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of conspiring to destroy power lines leading to nuclear facilities in three states has decided to change his innocent plea, federal officials said Monday. A change-of-plea hearing for Mark Baker, 37, of Prescott, has been scheduled for Tuesday before U.S. District Judge Robert C. Broomfield, a court clerk said. Steve Mitchell, an assistant U.S. attorney, declined to say whether Baker had entered into a plea agreement. Court records indicate Broomfield vacated a suppression-of-evidence motion that had been scheduled for hearing Monday. Baker is one of four defendants in the case, all of whom are members of Earth First!, a radical environmental organization founded by co-defendant David Foreman, 42, of Tucson. Baker, Foreman, Mark Davis, 39, of Prescott, and Margaret Millett, 35, also of Prescott, face counts of conspiracy to sabotage federal facilities. The alleged targets were the Palo Verde and Diablo Canyon nuclear powerplants in Arizona and California, respectively, and the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant near Denver.

Greene said he would consult with all sides to set an appropriate place and a date for the testimony ``prior to the start of trial,'' which is scheduled to begin Feb. 20. DOC.HEAD: Former President Skeptical on Cold War's End
DOC.TEXT: On the eve of his 79th birthday and a year after leaving the White House, former President Ronald Reagan says the Cold War isn't over despite events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. In an exclusive interview Friday, Reagan focused on such topics as the American hostages in Lebanon, Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and his private life in his beloved California. He declined to discuss aspects of the Iran-Contra scandal other than his concern for the hostages, citing pending litigation. ``I think we see something on the horizon,'' Reagan said when asked if the Cold War was over. ``But we also have to remember this is the work of a man who can be dismissed by the Communist Party if they see their way clear to do it. ``We have to know that permanent changes have been made before we can say everything is in the clear and the Cold War is over. ... But we have to make sure that the deeds are permanent.'' Nevertheless, Reagan said the choice of Gorbachev as Time magazine's ``Man of the Decade'' was appropriate. Some conservatives have argued that Reagan should have been chosen. ``As a matter of fact, I have to think anything that will help Gorbachev succeed in the changes he's trying to make in the Soviet Union then, well, fine,'' Reagan said. He added that he has always expected internal opposition to Gorbachev. ``I knew his opposition wouldn't come from the people, it would come from that fixed bureaucracy,'' he said, adding, ``As I describe it, the Russian Revolution simply wiped out an inherited aristocracy and has replaced it with an inherited bureaucracy.'' Reagan, who celebrates his birthday on Tuesday, began the interview by pointing to the Pacific Ocean and Channel Islands visible from his 34th-floor office in Century City, a high-rise business district. He marveled at the view. ``I've always said that a Californian who is forced to live away from California lives in a state of perpetual homesickness,'' he said, adding, ``It isn't a place, it's a way of life.'' Age hasn't diminished Reagan's love of a self-deprecating joke. ``I prefer to think of it as the 40th anniversary of my 39th birthday,'' Reagan quipped. Reagan keeps in shape by pumping iron daily in his basement gym and trimming trees with a chain saw during his monthly visits to his Santa Barbara County ranch. He also remains active on the ``mashed potato'' speaking circuit, delivering speeches on issues he cares about, such as a balanced budget amendment and line-item veto power for the president in dealing with budget issues. Reagan's hair has grown back _ still black but with a more pronounced touch of gray _ since brain surgery last year following a throw from a horse in Mexico. He's riding again on his trips to the ranch. The former president proudly reported that he and wife Nancy now own the $2.5 million home in the exclusive Bel-Air community that was first purchased by friends for the couple's return to California. ``It's ours and we enjoy it very much. We are very fond of it,'' Reagan said. There was a twinkle in his blue eyes as he told of the first time he saw the house _ from the floor of a sedan _ while he was still president. ``If I went any place the press would have been in attendance and we didn't want that publicity at the time,'' he said. It was Mrs. Reagan who persuaded him to sneak up to the house. ``She said if I was willing to get down on the floor of the car and go there the press wouldn't be following or any photographers or anything, so I did. I didn't get up until we were in the driveway,'' Reagan said.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor In Hazelwood Trial Said He Was at Bar for 7 Hours Before Trip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with quotes rrom prosecutor's opening statement, Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Superior Court...'.
DOC.TEXT: For seven hours before he boarded the Exxon Valdez for its disastrous trip, former tanker skipper Joseph Hazelwood sat in a bar drinking vodka, a prosecutor told the Superior Court jury today in his opening statement. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole maintained that Hazelwood was noticeably intoxicated when he returned to his ship after a day ashore in Valdez. He also maintained it was the captain's sole responsibility to ensure that the tanker arrived safely at its destination. ``This catastrophe represents the largest U.S. oil spill,'' Cole told the jurors who listened attentively to his outline of the case he would present against Hazelwood. ``It left in its wake a path of destruction and death. It removed a part of Prince William Sound that will never be replaced.'' As Hazelwood sat a few feet away stroking his beard, Cole directed blame at the captain. ``Joseph Hazelwood, the captain of the Exxon Valdez, was in charge and responsible for that tanker's safety,'' he said. ``He was in charge and responsible for the tanker's cargo.'' ``Because of circumstances surrounding his failure to perform his responsiblity on that evening, he has been charged with four crimes,'' the prosecutor said. The swearing-in of jurors today and beginning of opening statements came nearly a year after the tanker ran aground and spilled about 11 million gallons of North Slope crude oil into Prince William Sound. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone warned jurors that the Hazelwood case is of interest to many people and will atrract wide media coverage. He instructed them to ignore reports on the case and told them ``it's important you decide this case solely on what you see and hear in this courtroom and not on anything you hear outside.'' Johnstone instructed the jurors briefly in the rules of evidence, telling them they would be the sole judges of the credibility of witnesses who come forward to describe the disastrous accident and the events that followed. Hazelwood's attorney, Dick Madson, lost a bid to bar the prosecution from mentioning Hazelwood's blood-alcohol level in opening statements. He contended it might not be admissible evidence and should not be mentioned now. But the judge said it was likely to be the subject of testimony and give the prosecution the go-ahead. The captain's blood alcohol reading 10{ hours after the accident was .061, which Madson said was below state limits but above Coast Guard limits for operating a vessel. The jurors, 12 regular members and three alternates, were selected last week from among more than 60 candidates who were screened through questions about exposure to pretrial publicity and other factors that could lead to bias in the trial. Hazelwood was not on the bridge of the 987-foot tanker when it struck Bligh Reef. Part of the defense involves his contention that he left sound orders for crew members and cannot be held criminally responsible for the way they did their jobs. The Exxon Valdez was under the control of Third Mate Gregory Cousins when it ran aground early the morning of March 24 after leaving designated shipping lanes. Cousins is among more than 100 potential witnesses in Hazelwood's trial on a felony charge of criminal mischief and on misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. If convicted of all charges, Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., would face up to seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Preparations for the trial took months. Originally scheduled for Valdez, the port from which the tanker sailed on March 24 with its cargo of California-bound oil, the trial was moved to Anchorage in an effort to obtain an impartial jury.
