DOC.HEAD: Jean Galloway Bissell, Who Sat on Federal Appeals Court, Dead at 53
DOC.TEXT: Jean Galloway Bissell, a judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, has died of cancer. She was 53. Mrs. Bissell, who was appointed to the court by President Reagan in 1984, died Sunday at Sibley Memorial Hospital in Washington, D.C. Prior to that appointment, Mrs. Bissell was vice chairman and senior vice president of South Carolina National Corp. and practiced corporate law in Greenville. A Due West native, she lived in Washington, where the federal circuit court is located. She is survived by her husband, Gregg; a stepson, a sister, and a brother.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Cautions Against Global Warming Meaures that Burden Industry
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 3 grafs new to raise reaction; subs pvs graf 23, Bush also, to include Jewish leaders' request. Editing to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush cautioned an international gathering of scientists today against seeking solutions to global warming that would burden major industries. In a speech one environmentalist called a ``gross disappointment,'' Bush said he is convening a meeting at the White House this spring of top environmentalists, economists and ecologists to grapple with the issue. He promised U.S. support for ``aggressive and thoughtful action'' to solve problems caused by global warming. But he sounded a note of caution against scientists and environmentalists who believe the warming of the Earth's atmosphere is already serious enough to warrant severe anti-pollution controls. ``Wherever possible we believe that market mechanism should be applied and that our policies must be consistent with economic growth and free market principles in all countries,'' Bush said in his address before the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a United Nations-sponsored group opening a three-day meeting at Georgetown University. Environmentalists from the United States and Europe were quick to criticize Bush for not making a clear commitment for immediate action aimed at dealing with global warming. ``It was a gross disappointment. There was more talk in the speech about economics than about the environment,'' said Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club. Stewart Boyle of the Association for the Conservation of Energy in Great Britain said Bush's remarks demonstrated ``a leadership crisis'' on the global warming issue at the White House. ``About the only thing we can say about it is he turned up'' at the conference, said Boyle. The cross-section of environmentalists are attending the conference as observers. They said they would have liked to have seen Bush present specific U.S. commitments toward energy conservation and specific goals on reductions in carbon dioxide pollution, which is the major contributor to global warming. Global warming is the gradual increase in the Earth's temperature due to buildup of heat-trapping gases emitted into the atmosphere by burning oil and gas. In his speech, Bush said, ``We all know that human activities are changing the atmosphere in unexpected and in unprecedented ways.'' He said ``some may be tempted to exploit legitimate concerns for political positioning.'' ``Where politics and opinion have outpaced the science, we are accelerating our support of the technology to bridge that gap,'' Bush said. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu reportedly ordered changes in the text to mute U.S. concerns about global warming. Sununu acknowledged Sunday he made some changes, but said they were simply to make the speech ``reflective'' of administration policy. Sununu also criticized ``faceless'' environmental bureaucrats he said want to force Americans to give up their cars. ``If we hope to promote environmental protection and growth around the world it will be important not to work in conflict, but with our industrial sectors,'' Bush told the scientists. ``You're called upon to deliver recommendations which strike a difficult and yet critical international bargain, a convergence between global environmental policies and global economic policies, a bargain where both perspectives benefit and neither is compromised,'' Bush told the scientists. The speech drew restrained applause from several hundred delegates. ``There was no step forward in his speech,'' remarked Brooks Yeager of the National Audubon Society. Later, at the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater asserted scientists disagree on the issue of global warming and ``the people who think this is a problem that needs to be solved today don't understand it. They're wrong.'' Fitzwater was asked if Bush had changed his position since the 1988 presidential campaign. During the campaign, Bush said he would convene a global conference on the environment in his first year in office on global warming and other environmental problems, and that it was time to act on these problems. ``If that's true, then he has changed his view. I don't know if he said those words during the campaign, but if so, he's changed his mind,'' Fitzwater said. In a major speech on enviornmental policy in Michigan on Aug. 31, 1988, Bush said that ``those who think we're powerless to do anything about the `greenhouse effect' are forgetting abvout the `White House effect.' As president, I intend to do something about it.'' Bush also greeted the president-elect of Uruguay, Luis Alberto Lacalle. He also met with a delegation of 24 U.S. Jewish leaders, who urged him to prod Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to speak out against rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. Sununu, speaking on ABC's ``This Week with David Brinkley,'' said Sunday the speech would focus ``on our commitment to deal with the international environmental issues in such a way that we don't end up not being able to use our coal, oil and natural gas resources.'' ``There's a little tendency by some of the faceless bureaucrats on the environmental side to try to create a policy in this country that cuts off our use of coal, oil and natural gas,'' said Sununu, a nuclear engineer by training. ``I don't think that's what this country wants. I don't think America wants not to be able to use their automobiles,'' said the former governor of New Hampshire, who has clashed with Environmental Protection Agency head William K. Reilly on this and other issues. White House officials said the president is seeking to underscore environmental steps he is taking, including: _A proposal to spend $1 billion in fiscal year 1991, an increase of 57 percent, for global change research. _Plans to spend $175 million to plant 1 billion trees annually for a decade. _Major revisions in the Clean Air Act to attack smog and other pollution, still pending in Congress.

Greene rejected a suggestion by Reagan's lawyers that the former president be permitted to give written answers to written questions from Poindexter. A videotaped deposition ``will preserve the flexibility and spontaneity that are essential to the effective examination of a witness,'' said the judge. Reagan also was ordered to turn over by the end of today 33 diary entries to Poindexter. The Justice Department on Friday asked for a delay in the deadline, but the judge rejected the request today. ``Such a delay is out of the question'' in view of the fact that the trial is scheduled to start in two weeks, said the judge. The Justice Department's motion ``is nothing more than an attempt to delay into the indefinite future compliance with'' Greene's orders, said the judge.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Judge Orders Reagan to Give Videotaped Testimony
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; expands on judge's refusing delay in turning over diaries further background; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge today ordered former President Reagan to give a videotaped deposition in the Iran-Contra trial of John Poindexter and renewed his ruling that Reagan must immediately turn over 33 diary entries to his former national security adviser. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene gave Reagan and President Bush until Friday to invoke executive privilege as part of any attempt to avoid testimony by the former president. Today was also the deadline for Reagan to turn over 33 of his diary entries to Poindexter, and Greene said he would not permit a delay. Nominees Breeze Through Hearings
DOC.TEXT: Two Bush administration energy nominees breezed through Senate confirmation hearings Monday although one is under heavy attack from Nevada's two senators over the choice of their state to host a nuclear waste dump. The Senate Energy Committee's chairman, Sen. J. Bennett Johnston, D-La., used the occasion to declare he will not allow Nevada to ``defeat politically'' Congress' choice three years ago of Yucca Mountain as the site for an underground high-level radioactive waste repository. Nevade senators Harry Reid and Richard H. Bryan, both Democrats, want President Bush to withdraw his nomination of John W. Bartlett, a chemical and nuclear engineer, to head the program after the Energy Department sued the state last month over its denial of environmental permits to study the site. However, Bartlett, a former nuclear waste specialist at Battelle Pacific Northwest Laboratories in Richland, Wash., received nothing but support Monday from Johnston and the committee's ranking Republican, Sen. James McClure of Idaho. ``The attitude of some people in the past has been to take the path of least resistance ... to let the program drift,'' said Johnston. ``I would hope Nevade would recognize that ... it is a scientific challenge ... and one that cannot be defeated on a political basis.'' Bartlett came under attack from Reid and Bryan after writing a technical paper last year asserting that scientific research alone cannot provide the proof that Yucca Mountain will be an absolutely safe geological barrier around the radioactive wastes for 10,000 years. ``I do not apologize for that,'' Bartlett said Monday. ``In the face of imperfect information, it's a very common situation that rules are developed using good information and sound judgment.'' Reid has accused Bartlett of wanting ``to rush full speed ahead on the nuke dump regardless of the scientific consequences.'' Johnston, however, complained Monday that the Energy Department is moving too slowly, citing a decision in November to delay until 1993 the drilling of a 1,200-foot test shaft at the site and to postpone from the year 2003 to 2010 that target date for completing and opening the dump. ``We're spending hundreds of millions of dollars year after year and there's not even a shaft ..., just paper studies,'' he said. ``Some people claim that's bureaucracy at its best. I think it's a waste. At the rate we're going it will be the 22nd Century before we get it done.'' The committee spent only 20 minutes questioning Robert H. Gentile, a former Ohio coal operator, to head the Energy Department's fossil fuels program. Gentile, who headed the Interior Department's Office of Surface Mining in the last year of the Reagan administration and is a champion of a $6 billion government-industry program for developing clean-coal technologies, was Bush's second choice for the job. Coal state lawmakers, led by Senate Appropriations Committee Chairman Robert C. Byrd, D-W.Va., had objected to the nomination of Michael McElwrath, a friend of Bush with a background in the oil and gas business, for the post. Both nominations could be voted on by the committee as early as Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Justices Ask for $1.7 Million More for High Court
DOC.TEXT: Congress was asked Monday to approve a $1.7 million spending increase for the Supreme Court for the next fiscal year, which would bring the court's annual budget to $19.2 million. Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and Antonin Scalia made the request to a House appropriations subcommittee. O'Connor said most of the proposed increase is for higher pay and benefits for the justices and the court's staff. The court is not adding any staff or new programs, she said. As of Feb. 1, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's annual pay was increased $9,000 to $124,000. The salary for the eight associate justices rose $8,600 to $118,600. Next Jan. 1, Rehnquist's salary will be raised to $155,000, and the associate justices will be paid $148,300. The court's budget request includes $100,000 to begin upgrading computers.

DOC.HEAD: China Buys More Subsidized Wheat
DOC.TEXT: China has bought an additional 299,150 metric tons of U.S. wheat under a price-subsidy program, the Agriculture Department said Monday. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said four private exporting companies made the deals under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is schedfuled for April and May, he said. The sales were part of 1 million tons authorized for sale to China under the program Dec. 5. A previous allocation of 2 million tons made last Feb. 27 had been exhausted, except for 10,000 tons. With the latest EEP approvals, China has only 1,050 tons remaining to be used under the current authorization. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The latest sales would be about 11 million bushels. At current prices, estimated by USDA at around $3.60 per bushel, the wheat would have a farm value of around $39 million. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $10.28 per ton, or about 28 cents per bushel. The subsidized sales were handled by Louis Dreyfus Corp., 70,000 tons; Continental Grain Co., 84,150; Cargill Inc., 100,000, and J. Aron & Co., 45,000. With the latest sales, China has bought about 5.7 million tons of U.S. wheat for delivery in the 1989-90 marketing year, which began June 1, much of it without subsidies. In 1988-89, China bought more than 8 million tons of U.S. wheat, all of it under the EEP program.

DOC.HEAD: Something Fishy Going on 'Round Here
DOC.TEXT: Even in New York, where a new scam comes along about as often as a puff of pollution from New Jersey, this is one for the books: They're scalping lox. More precisely, well-to-do customers are paying as much as $20 for tickets to get to the fish counter at Zabar's. Zabar's is a gourmet food market on Manhattan's Upper West Side, but that is an understatement; Zabar's is a kind of secular cathedral to New Yorkers who want the most wonderful whitefish, the cream of caviars, the best bagels. On Saturday and Sunday mornings and on holidays, 100 people or more line up outside. When the doors open at 8 a.m. they make tracks for the dispenser that spins out numbered tickets _ first come, first served. But not always. Zabar's officials say they have learned that some of the early birds are ``phantom shoppers.'' They grab several numbers and then go outside and sell them to other shoppers who want to jump the line. ``Some people pay $20 for a number,'' said Kenneth Kuss, head man at the fish counter. ``But I can understand it. I have customers who come in here regularly and, what with sturgeon and caviar, spend maybe $500. They don't care about an extra 20 bucks if it'll save them an hour's wait.'' An hour's wait is not unusual, says Murray Klein, one of Zabar's owners. Sometimes, it stretches to two hours. On weekends, ``These are big customers _ sometimes they tie up a clerk for 10 minutes. An hour is nothing.'' Klein says a look at the limousines parked outside attests to the wealth of some customers; they can easily afford to pay $20 to the scalpers. ``Time means a lot to them. I guess they go play golf or meet someone,'' Klein said. Occasionally, police ticket cars that are double-parked outside, and Klein tries to warn his customers. ``Some of the people wouldn't go out,'' he said, preferring to risk a $40 ticket rather than lose their places in line. ``So for these people, $20 is cheap,'' Klein said. Police say selling anything fraudulently in a public place at an inflated price is a misdemeanor, punishable by fines and up to a year in jail. But no one has been busted for the Zabar's scam _ yet. Klein says he's keeping an eye out for scalpers, and will stop them if he can. ``It's not fair to the people who do stand in line,'' he says.

DOC.HEAD: Fifth Former Official Refuses to Testify at HUD Scandal Hearings
DOC.TEXT: A former official of the Reagan administration's Department of Housing and Urban Development refused to testify Monday before a congressional panel that resumed its hearings on the HUD scandals. James Hamernick, former director of HUD's office of insured multi-family housing development, became the fifth former housing official from the Reagan administration, including former HUD Secretary Samuel Pierce, to refuse to testify on grounds of self-incrimination. Hamernick had been questioned about his dealings with another former HUD official, Lance Wilson, an aide to Pierce who quit to become a housing consultant for a Wall Street investment firm. In that position, Wilson wined and dined Hamernick. Hamernick appeared before the House Government Operations subcommittee on employment and housing, whose investigation last year prompted Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to ask a federal court recently to name a special prosecutor to investigate Pierce and other top officials. Rep. Tom Lantos, D-Calif., the subcommittee chairman, said last fall he was ready to end the hearings and turn the HUD scandal over to the courts. But he changed his mind and said he would continue the House hearings while a special prosecutor _ yet to be named _ conducts a parallel investigation. Lantos asserted that ``there are still ... many unanswered questions'' in the HUD scandal, which involves allegations of gross mismanagement, influence-peddling, political favoritism and fraud. ``The subcommittee is duty-bound to proceed with its investigation of abuses at HUD,'' he said. ``This is particularly true since in recent weeks the subcommittee staff has uncovered a good deal of relevant, new information.'' He refused to say what that information was. Lantos cancelled the scheduled appearance Monday of a key witness, Thomas Demery, a former assistant secretary for housing who has been cooperating with investigators. Demery was prepared to testify about his involvement with Pierce in administering the scandal-plagued Section 8 moderate rehabilitation program, which provided subsidies to developers to fix up low-income housing. Lantos said he would meet with a special prosecutor before calling Demery to testify. Hamernick also invoked a House rule allowing subpoenaed witnesses to ban cameras and recording equipment at a hearing. Congressional investigators say that after Wilson left his job as Pierce's aide, he reported spending more than $2,000 on meals and other amenities _ including a limousine _ for Hamernick in expense accounts filed with his employer, Paine Webber. Congressional investigators, speaking on condition of anonymity, said that Wilson and not Hamernick was the real object of the panel's line of inquiry. The subcommittee also questioned Carol Crawford, former associate director of the Office of Management and Budget in the Reagan administration, who said ``we have to accept a certain amount of responsibility'' for what Lantos called gross mismanagement at HUD during those years. Ms. Crawford underwent a sometimes contentious questioning by the panel, when Lantos and another member, Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., complaining that her lengthy replies did not answer the questions. ``You are really wasting the committee's time,'' Lantos told her at one point. She denied Lantos' suggestion that OMB received lists of projects _ and the developers pushing for them _ which HUD had selected for assistance under the urban development action grant program. She said she did not recall seeing such lists, and said she had met or talked with Pierce ``not more than half a dozen'' times. Except for her office's concern that former HUD assistant secretary June Koch was spending too much time on a building trade exhibition in the Soviet Union, Ms. Crawford said she was unaware of other management problems that have since been uncovered at HUD. The committee said last fall that Ms. Koch's involvement in the Soviet project after she left HUD and joined a private company appeared to violate ethics laws.

DOC.HEAD: Buh Will Push Funds for Weapons Research
DOC.TEXT: President Bush still considers the Soviet challenge ``very much real'' and during his upcoming three-day Western trip will defend his budget proposal to continue to pump billions of dollars into nuclear-weapons programs, his spokesman said Monday. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush's trip to California, Nebraska and Ohio, which begins Tuesday, will focus on defense issues. ``The president thinks it's important to talk to the American people about the changes that we're seeing'' in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, Ftizwater said. In a series of speeches and stops at militry installations, the president will argue for his proposal to close or change dozens of military installations while continuing to commit resources to nuclear weapons programs. Despite the reduction of East-West tensions over the past year, ``the Soviet challenge remains very much real,'' Fitzwater said. ``There have been reductions in troop strength; there are promises of other reductions that we haven't seen. But this is not a time to lay down our arms.'' Bush's first stop Tuesday will be the Army's National Training Center at Fort Irwin in Barstow, Calif., where he will view combat exercises. On Wednesday, he will tour the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Livermore, Calif., where extensive research is underway on the administration's Strategic Defense Initiative. Bush will also give a ``broad-based discussion of defense policy'' in a speech Wednesday to the Commonwealth Club in San Francisco, Fitzwater said. On Thursday, he will visit Strategic Air Command headquarters in Omaha, Neb. ``The president will stress his continued support for strategic modernization. Despite the lessening of tensions in many areas of the world, the United States must continue to maintain a robust and credible nulcear deterrent,'' Fitzwater said. Asked whether the president saw any irony in beginning his visit in California, the state that would be hardest hit by base-closings in his budget, the spokesman said: ``This trip represents several aspects of the changing world we find. One is the ability to make reductions in U.S. forces, to close down some bases that are obsolete and aren't needed.'' ``The fact that some of those are in California simply points out the changing nature of the defense situation,'' Fitzwater said. The administration has called for the closure or realignment of more than 72 military installations and has called for ending operations at 12 U.S. installations overseas. Democrats in Congress have complained that the administration's budget calls for continued high-levels of financing for sophisticated strategic systems while making deep cuts at U.S. bases, most of them in Democratic districts. The spending plan sent to Congress Jan. 29 seeks total military spending of $303.3 billion. That's about 2 percent, or $3.1 billion, less than this year's Pentagon budget, after inflation. However, the budget calls for about a 6 percent increase, after inflation, in key weapons production activities, plus a 19 percent jump in spending authority for development of a new generation of reactors to make weapons materials.

DOC.HEAD: Bright and Brief
DOC.TEXT: OK, here's the challenge: Screw a lid onto a glass jar. If that sounds simple, you'll never win the eighth annual Rube Goldberg competition at Purdue University, which aims to turn the easiest tasks into amazingly complicated ones. In the spirit of Rube Goldberg, the cartoonist who specialized in drawing complicated machines that performed mundane tasks, this year's teams must use at least 25 steps to affix a two-piece lid onto a pint-sized Ball canning jar. The lid has to be tight enough so that the jar can be turned upside down without spilling. The task must be accomplished in five minutes or less. Winners of the Feb. 17 campus contest will compete against winners from other colleges and universities on March 17 at Purdue. David Oliver, student chairman of the competition, said he expected four to six teams at each level. Past challenges have included sharpening a pencil and preparing an egg for frying. ``It's a unique competition in that people, mainly technology and engineering students, have taken principles of science and engineering and turned them inside out, finding complex ways to do simple tasks,'' Oliver said.

A man appeared in a village court Monday with a rooster tucked under his arm and told the judge the bird was the only legal counsel he could afford. The judge cried fowl. David Ashley was charged last month with raising poultry without a permit, but his case was postponed until he could got a lawyer. When Ashley appeared in court with the rooster, village Justice Gordon Tetor told him to get rid of the bird. ``It was the only legal counsel I could afford,'' Ashley told the judge. ``I don't think he could speak,'' Tetor said. ``Sure they can, they speak to me all the time,'' Ashley said. After removing the chicken, Ashley told the judge he couldn't afford a lawyer. He also told Tetor he would represent himself but wasn't ready to go trial. Tetor adjourned the case until March 5. Ashley and his wife, Lynda, have about 20 chickens at their home that they say are pets for their two children. Mrs. Ashley spent 10 days in jail in October after refusing to seek a permit or get rid of the chickens. The Ashleys applied for a permit in November but the village board turned them down and gave them 10 days to remove the chickens. David Ashley was charged after the couple failed to remove the birds.

DOC.HEAD: Third Grader Suspended for Bringing Billy Beer to Show-and-Tell
DOC.TEXT: A third-grade student who took an unopened can of beer considered a collectors' item to ``show-and-tell'' at school was suspended for three days, an action that the girl's mother said Monday was ridiculous. ``I am furious,'' said Melissa Woodfin, whose 8-year-old daughter, Haley, also must undergo counseling for illegal possession of an alcoholic beverage for taking a can of Billy Beer to show her classmates last week at Skipwith Elementary School. ``My daughter has been treated unfairly,'' Mrs. Woodfin said. ``She has lost three days of school with no right to make up the work, according to the policy.'' Mrs. Woodfin said her daughter removed the can of beer from a display case at home. The beer, no longer made, was named for President Carter's late brother, and unopened cans are considered collector's items. ``She took it for show and tell,'' Mrs. Woodfin said. ``She didn't run into a closet and pop it open.'' In addition to the suspension from the school in suburban Henrico County, police were notified that Haley had possessed an alcoholic beverage illegally. School officials said the steps were taken under a strict drug and substance abuse policy to which any child is subject if caught in possession of drugs or alcohol, regardless of age. ``Suspending young people is not what we are about,'' said Henrico School Superintendent William C. Bosher Jr. ``But we want to help young people understand that alcohol and drugs are not appropriate.'' ``I have no problem with them having a policy, but you can't treat a third-grader the way you would a teen-ager,'' Mrs. Woodfin said. Bosher acknowledged that the suspension of an elementary school pupil was unusual. He said suspension is a way to get the attention of parents and bring parents, educators and the pupil together to discuss a potential problem. Haley was back in school Monday after serving her suspension. Mrs. Woodfin said she was awaiting word from police about what legal steps would be taken. Sgt. James Price said the girl would be referred to juvenile intake proceedings, ``which is nothing more than a counseling session.'' Mrs. Woodfin said police returned the can of Billy Beer and it is back in the display case, where it will remain.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Mixed in Monday's Auction
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $7.7 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.83 percent, up from 7.77 percent last week. An additional $7.6 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.72 percent, down from 7.73 percent last week. The rates for three-month bills were the highest since they sold for 7.88 percent Sept. 5, 1989. Three-month bills also sold for 7.83 percent Oct. 2. Rates for six-month bills were the lowest since they averaged 7.58 percent Jan. 22. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.10 percent for three-month bills, with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,802.10, and 8.15 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,609.70. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable-rate mortgages, rose to 8.09 percent last week, up from 8.01 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Panama's Archbishop Requests U.S. Aid After Invasion
DOC.TEXT: Fearing that his country may be forgotten now that deposed dictator Manuel Noriega is in U.S. custody, Panama's Archbishop said Monday that the future of the Central American nation depends on economic assistance from Washington. Monsignor Marcus Antonio McGrath, who just returned from a trip to Washington to request aid, met with South Florida church leaders at the Miami Archdiocese to discuss the Catholic Church's role in Panama's restructuring. ``There is hope and joy now in Panama,'' McGrath said. ``We (the church) have to be more careful in our judgment and look beyond the immediate moment.'' Noriega surrendered to U.S. troops on Jan. 4 after the military invasion of Panama on Dec. 20. McGrath said the church never supported the invasion. ``We were against the invasion, against any solution that would involve violence because violence breeds violence,'' he said. ``It could have left in its wake many years of guerilla warfare in Panama.'' The Archbishop wants the U.S. government to do several things to help his country get back on its feet. He said unemployment is about 32 percent and there are 14,000 people homeless. ``Not a penny has come in almost two months,'' he said, referring to a $1 billion aid package proposed by President Bush. ``All has been promised but nothing is being done about it.'' McGrath also said he wants the U.S. troops that arrived in late December to be pulled out immediately. ``The extra troops should leave as soon as possible, so the new government can take over,'' he said. The fledgling new government should be allowed to make all decisions concerning Panama and the military should let it test its wings, he said. ``We need to develop a new generation of leaders,'' McGrath said of President Guillermo Endara and his leaders. ``They are honest, dedicated and well-intentioned and will make a lot of mistakes, but I think it will work out.''

DOC.HEAD: Price Waterhouse Selected to Measure the Mail
DOC.TEXT: Price Waterhouse, the folks who certify Academy Awards winners, soon will be monitoring the efficiency of the postal system. The U.S. Postal Service announced Monday it has hired the accounting firm to begin measuring its performance in delivering the mail. ``Our efforts to improve and enhance mail service must begin with an accurate assessment of that service as our customers see it,'' Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank said in a statement. The decision to award the three-year, $23.4 million contract to Price Waterhouse was made in Los Angeles, where the Postal Service board of governors is holding its monthly meeting. Frank had announced earlier that an independent test of mail performance would be conducted and the results made public. Price Waterhouse will begin monitoring mail delivery this spring and go into high gear next year. Details of making the results public were not disclosed. The contract calls for Price Waterhouse to mail letters within and between 86 cities, and to keep records of when each item was mailed and received. The company will calculate the percentage of mail delivered overnight and by the second and third days, and how that compares with Postal Service delivery standards. The tests will involve more than 1 million letters sent annually to households and businesses that will use a toll-free telephone number to report when the letters arrive.

DOC.HEAD: Productivity Posts Slowest Gain Since 1982; Labor Costs Escalate
DOC.TEXT: American workers' productivity rose just 0.9 percent last year _ their worst showing since the 1981-82 recession _ while hourly labor costs sped upward, the government said Monday. The Labor Department said that the 0.9 percent increase in non-farm productivity _ defined as output per hour of work _ was less than half the 2 percent gain recorded in 1988. While blaming part of last year's poor performance on an overall slowdown in economic growth, analysts worried that the combination of weak productivity growth and rising labor costs would further weaken America's ability to compete internationally. ``That's a recipe for trouble,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Co. ``It's very distressing ... it's symptomatic of an economy that is near the end of expansion.'' The report showed that while productivity was slumping, hourly labor costs _ a major inflation measure for businesses _ escalated significantly, jumping by 5.5 percent, up from 4.7 percent in 1988 and the biggest increase since 1982. ``Labor cost increases are probably the scariest part of the report,'' said David Wyss, chief economist at DRI-McGraw Hill. For the October-through-December quarter, non-farm productivity rose a barely perceptible 0.2 percent, the report said. Hourly labor costs rose at an annual rate of 6.9 percent in the fourth quarter. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater pinned the slight productivity increase on the overall slowdown of the economy. The pace of economic expansion, as measured by the gross national product, grew by a rate of 0.5 percent in the final three months of 1989, the slowest growth for any quarter since 1986. ``The small productivity gains last year probably reflect the transition to a more moderate pace of economic growth rather than a general weakening in productivity,'' Fitzwater said. ``Productivity gains often fall off sharply when output growth slows.'' Output in the non-farm sector was up 3.3 percent in 1989 while the number of hours worked rose by 2.4 percent, giving the 0.9 percent increase in productivity. The report was certain to revive the debate over America's lagging productivity. Since the end of the 1981-82 recession, productivity growth has averaged 1.8 percent a year. While a slight improvement over the 1.2 percent average growth rate in the 1970s, it was still far below the 3.3 percent rate of increase posted in the two decades following World War II, when American workers enjoyed healthy wage gains and a rising standard of living. Increasing productivity is considered basic to boosting living standards because it allows businesses to pay workers more as their output rises without risking higher inflation. In addition to the large hike in hourly compensation, the report showed that unit labor costs, another key determinant of future price inflation, shot up 4.6 percent for the year, compared with a 2.7 increase in 1988. Unit labor costs reflect changes in compensation as well as changes in productivity. ``Productivity gains have been anemic for several years. It means that our standard of living isn't increasing anymore,'' said Michael Evans, head of a Washington forecasting firm. However, Robert Dederick, chief economist for the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago, said productivity growth has been slow, in part because the labor market has been growing rapidly in the 1980s, absorbing record numbers of unskilled workers. ``There's sort of a knee-jerk reaction that this is a negative, and I'm not sure I agree with that,'' he said, adding that it would be worrisome only if productivity failed to rebound in the 1990s as the workforce matures and gains job skills. Analysts were cheered by the report's findings on manufacturing productivity, which continued to show better gains than the rest of the economy. Manufacturers reported a 2.8 percent productivity gain in 1989, close to the 2.7 percent gain of 1988. Manufacturing output rose 3.7 percent last year, down from the 6.1 percent increase of 1988.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Financing Water Quality Improvements in 28 States
DOC.TEXT: An additional $11.9 million is being provided by the Agriculture Department this year to help carry out special water quality projects in 28 states, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter announced Monday. The projects are in addition to 37 announced on Jan. 25 and are ``part of USDA's accelerated effort'' in support of President Bush's water quality initiative, he said. The projects were authorized and funded under the Agricultural Conservation Program, which for many years has provided federal cost-sharing and other assistance for watershed improvements. Yeutter said the goal of the special projects is to solve problems caused by agricultural pollution of ground and surface water from animal waste, fertilizers, pesticides and sediment. The areas targeted for the assistance include: Alabama _ Big Prairie Creek. Arkansas _ Beaver Lake. Delaware _ Nanticoke. Georgia _ Piedmont. Illinois _ Cedar Lake. Indiana _ LaGrange County Lake Enhancement. Iowa _ Corydon Lake. Kansas _ Miola Lake. Kentucky _ Mammoth Cave area. Louisiana _ Tangipahoa River. Maine _ Kenduskeag Stream; 25-mile River. Maryland _ Bohemia-Sassafrass rivers; Chincoteague and Sinepuxent systems. Massachusssetts _ Lower Deerfield River. Michigan _ Clam River. Mississippi _ Tenn-Tom. Nebraska _ Quad County; Southern Nuckolls. New York _ Cattaraugus Creek; Multi-County Chesapeake Bay-Susquehanna River. North Dakota _ Renwick. Ohio _ Clark Lake; Upper Darby; Upper Vermillion. Oregon _ Coquille River; Nestucca River. Penneyslvania _ Potomac-Juniata. Rhode Island _ Narragansett Bay. South Carolina _ Clarendon-Sumter; Greenwood-McCormick. Tennessee _ Lick and Limestone creeks; Upper Duck River. Vermont _ Lower Lake Champlain. Virginia _ Lower Nottaway and Blackwater rivers; Rockingham County. Washington _ Kamm Creek; South Fork of the Palouse River. Wisconsin _ Lake Neshonoc-Little La Crosse River.

DOC.HEAD: Serbian President Throws Fuel on Ethnic Fire
DOC.TEXT: The Serbian president Monday threatened to send hundreds of thousands of Serbs to take over the province of Kosovo, the scene of a fierce ethnic feud. Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic, who backs the minority Serbs, also accused two rival republics of aiding ethnic Albanians in the strife-torn province. The Serbian republic has administrative control of the Kosovo, where 90 percent of the population is ethnic Albanian. On Monday, Milosevic called for ``hundreds of thousands'' of Serbian settlers to move to Kosovo to aid their countrymen. ``Every man in Serbia is ready to head for Kosovo if the terror is continued there,'' Milosevic added. At least 25 ethnic Albanians have died since Jan. 24, when the latest wave of unrest broke out. Albanians in Kosovo oppose control of their province by Serbia, which considers Kosovo the cradle of Serbian culture. The ethnic and political divisions are part of a larger tapestry of conflict that threatens to dismember this diverse nation that once was held together by the dominating presence of Josip Broz Tito, who died in 1980. The Communist Party in the relatively liberal Slovenian republic on Sunday voted to break away from the national party, pushing the nation closer to dissolution. Yugoslavia consists of six republics and two autonomous provinces, each with its own government and party structure. Serbia is dominated by hard-line Communists. Slovenia and Croatia are reform oriented and have backed the ethnic Albanians in their conflict with Serbia. Albanians are demanding free elections and an end to emergency restrictions in place in the province for the past 12 months and the release of jailed ethnic Albanian political activists. Serbia's leadership showed little sign of compromise Monday. ``Those who support ... terror in Kosovo are lashing out at Serbia and Yugoslavia,'' Milosevic said in comments carried by the state Tanjug news agency. ``Every Serbian citizen feels fury in his heart because of the support for terror from Slovenia and Croatia.'' But Tanjug also reported that Serbia had decided to end a two-month economic boycott of Slovenia, which was imposed Dec. 1 after Slovenian authorities banned a planned rally of Serbs protesting Slovenian support for Kosovo Albanians. It gave no explanation. The provincial capital, Pristina, was the scene of a brief rally on Monday, with several thousand Kosovo Albanians assembling to observe a minute of silence for the dead. As the hour struck, car horns sounded through the city, and pedestrians stopped on sidewalks, hands raised and fingers spread in the victory sign. Riot police stood by. As the minute ended, there was applause before participants returned to their daily routine. Thousands again gathered in Pristina at 7 p.m. for a march by candlelight. Except for occasional shouts of ``Long live democracy, long live freedom,'' the protest was eerily silent. Federal authorities brought at least a temporary halt to the violence Friday by sending tanks into the province and ordering military jets to fly low over Pristina and other cities. But leaders of both Kosovo's 1.6 million ethnic Albanians and of the Slav minority of Serbs and Montenegrins expressed pessimism about the chances of peace in the long term. Bogdan Kecman, leader of the Slav minority group Bozur described the calm in Kosovo as temporary. ``The peace is just a cover,'' he asserted. ``Inside, war is raging.'' Albanians continued to hold wildcat strikes in the province.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0726, AM-Student Loans transmitted Feb. 4 under a Washington dateline, may wish to use the following story
DOC.TEXT: An Associated Press story transmitted Feb. 4 may have left unclear the role played by banks and other lenders in pursuing delinquent borrowers under the Guaranteed Student Loan Program. The loan program is administered by 56 guarantee agencies that protect private lenders against losses from loan defaults. If a borrower defaults and the lender is unable to collect, the account is turned over to one of these special agencies, which in turn goes after the delinquent funds. The guarantors collected more than $400 million in fiscal 1989, in part by garnishing lottery winnings, refusing professional licenses and putting liens on real estate.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Heads For Moscow Talks As Administration Supports Demonstrators
With AM-Soviet-Party Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration voiced support Monday for pro-democracy demonstrators in Moscow and for political pluralism as Secretary of State James A. Baker III headed for wide-ranging talks in the Soviet capital. While refraining from any direct appraisal of the power shifts contemplated by the Central Committee of the Communist Party, the State Department said the demonstrators who called on the party to relinquish some of its powers were asserting a right to participate in the nation's political process. With Baker due in Moscow for talks beginning Wednesday night, administration officials shied away from making any judgments about the party's deliberations, which began on Monday with a call from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for a loosening of control. His landmark speech followed perhaps the largest protest in Moscow since the Bolshevik revolution. At least 200,000 impassioned citizens marched to the Kremlin on Sunday, demanding that the party embrace reform and end its exclusive control of the government. Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, called the turnout ``a measure of the new openness in the Soviet system'' and said the Soviet people ``felt free enough to march for the rights of greater political participation in the political process.'' She added: ``Our dream for all people, including the Soviet people, is political pluralism and free market economies.'' Similarly, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said: ``We welcome political pluralism, but it's difficult to say exactly what the demonstrations yesterday meant. But there, again, we aren't going to offer any comment that might be disruptive in terms of the (Communist Party) plenum that they're just starting today.'' Asked about a potential change in the Soviet Constitution, ending the party's iron grip on power, Fitzwater said: ``That's an internal matter. We will not comment on it.'' Baker headed first for Shannon Airport in Ireland and a meeting with Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France while his plane is being refueled. The meeting follows talks in the last two weeks with two other European foreign ministers, Douglas Hurd of Britain and Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany. The idea is to compare notes among the allies before Baker's talks with Gorbachev and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, talks held in the shadow of burgeoning sentiment for Germany reunification. The United States insists that a united Germany must remain in NATO. Last week, Shevardnadze proposed that the issue be put to a international referendum while Gorbachev cautioned that ``forcing passions and simplified approaches to the problem could be pernicious.'' West Germany Chancellor Helmut Kohl immediately rejected the referendum idea. Before going to Moscow, Baker is paying a 27-hour visit to Czechoslovakia, where a Velvet Revolution smoothly transferred power last year from a hard-line government to reformers headed by playwright Vaclav Havel. Baker will meet with Havel on Tuesday and make a speech Wednesday supporting Gorbachev's call for a 35-nation European summit meeting to lessen tensions in Europe. He will hold talks with Shevardnadze in Moscow Wednesday evening through Saturday, when Baker will make an unprecedented appearance before the Soviet parliament's International Affairs Committee to answer questions. Baker will meet with Gorbachev on Friday. In testifying last week before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Baker endorsed the reformers in Eastern Europe and said he would offer technical cooperation and trade benefits to the Soviets if their human rights record continued to show improvement. The issue is not ``whether or not President Gorbachev will or will not succeed,'' Baker said. ``The issue ought to be whether or not we can take advantage of the fact that he is there now reforming things and ... lock in agreements that are mutually advantageous.'' Baker's initial purpose in scheduling the Moscow talks was to prepare for the summit meeting President Bush will hold with Gorbachev in Washington in June, a meeting aimed at signing a new treaty that would sharply reduce each side's arsenals of long-range missiles and bombers. Regional issues are also on Baker's agenda. The United States and the Soviet Union have been aiding opposite sides in the civil war in Angola. Both sides support the principle of a negotiated settlement, but the Bush administration has charged that peace prospects were set back in December by a major government offensive in southeast Angola. In Afghanistan, an 11-year-old war rages on between the Soviet-backed Marxist government and U.S.-armed guerrillas even though the Red Army concluded its occupation of the country last February. The future of President Najib is central to a solution. ``Our goal continues to be a transfer of power from the Najib regime to a broadly representative government,'' State Department spokeswoman Tutwiler said, adding: ``Our policy has not changed. We have consistently said we support the Afghan resistance and Najib must go.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0688, AM-SAfrica-Jackson, transmitted Jan. 8 under a Washington dateline, are asked to use the following story
DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press erroneously reported Jan. 8 that Jesse Jackson, who will be granted a visa to South Africa, had never before been allowed to visit that country. Jackson visited South Africa in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Destroying Brazilian Wildlife Preserve
DOC.TEXT: Firemen fought a blaze Monday that has burned 40 percent of the Poco das Antas Wildlife Reserve in southeastern Brazil, which shelters the last 250 golden lion marmosets in the world, officials reported. Thousands of the small, goldish-maned monkeys, also called tamarins, once lived along the 3,000 miles of Brazil's coastline. The number of golden lion marmosets fell to about 70 in the early 1970s, but the cat-sized monkeys have made a comeback at Poco das Antas, which has financial support from the Smithonian Institution, World Wildlife Fund and Canadian government. Rare sloths, alligators, monkeys and jaguars also live at Poco das Antas, which means ``watering hole of the tapirs'' in Portuguese. ``We won't know if any of the tamarins perished as a result of the fire until the situation is under control, but I fear the worst,'' said Vicente Moreira Conti, acting superintendent of the Rio office of Brazil's federal environmental protection agency. He said more than 100 firemen and volunteers were trying to control the blaze at the the 12,300-acre reserve 80 miles northeast of Rio, but faced serious obstacles. ``The reserve's terrain is composed of very dry, tall grass that is extremely combustible, and the fire is located in a part of the reserve to which there is only difficult access,'' Conti said. ``The fire is nearly impossible to put out.'' Firemen carried only limited supplies of water in portable tanks and were trying to smother the blaze with rubber mats, he said. ``What we really need is a few days of heavy rain, but unfortunately that's not in the forecast,'' Conti said. ``We expect to have the fire under control within the next 48 hours but there could be a great deal more damage.'' The fire started Saturday, probably spontaneously, he said. It is summer in Brazil and temperatures have been around 100 degrees for weeks.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0654 to clear header
Excerpts of Gorbachev Speech to Central Committee
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are excerpts from the text of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's report to the Communist Party Central Committee meeting Monday. The English translation was provided by Tass, the official Soviet news agency: Comrades, I think you will agree that we have gathered for a very important plenary meeting, a meeting that Communists and all society have been waiting for with immense interest and impatience. The Central Committee has received thousands of letters with suggestions and wishes from party members and non-party people, from party organizations and committees, from work collectives, factory workers and farmers, intellectuals, scientists, veterans and youth. Telegrams continue to pour in. You, too, have seen rallies and meetings at which the most vital problems were discussed often from various positions, in an acute and interested way. Their participants also wanted to make their viewpoint known to the party Central Committee. All this combined is a phenomenon that reflects profound changes that have already occurred and are occurring in our society along the tracks of perestroika and in conditions of democratization and glasnost. The main thing that now worries Communists and all citizens of the country is the fate of perestroika, the fate of the country and the role of the Soviet Communist Party at the current, probably most crucial, stage of revolutionary transformation. Society wants to know the party's position, and this determines the entire significance of our plenum.

Having assessed the entire situation and examined petitions from Communists and party organizations, the Politburo submits the following proposal for your consideration: to hold the 28th Communist Party congress late in June-early in July this year. We are convinced that the proposal will be approved at this plenum. The congress should be preceded, in our view, with a full report-and-election campaign in all links of the party with a broad debate on the platform and the draft new rules of the Soviet Communist Party. Overdue personnel issues will be resolved and new elected party bodies will be formed. ... At this plenum we are to adopt the Central Committee's draft platform for the congress. In a month or, better, three weeks from now _ not later _ we will probably have to gather again for a plenary meeting to consider the draft new rules and have them published for public discussion.

The Soviet Communist Party initiated perestroika and generated its concept and policy. Profound revolutionary changes encompassing all spheres of life and all sections of the population have been launched on this basis in the country. This has paved the way for renewing society and tapping socialism's potential. The party has succeeded in expressing in theory and policy the country's acute needs and realities of present-day world development. Rapid changes, unusual in scope and originality, are taking place within the framework of perestroika. This makes ever new demands on state and public institutes and, of course, on the Soviet Communist Party. As a matter of fact, we have approached the moment when the party should enrich its policy with due account for changes that have already occurred during perestroika and problems that have recently emerged. Any delay threatens a lag and the loss of the initiative, which would, in turn, inevitably affect the party itself and the future of its revolutionary undertakings.

Of no less importance is the understanding of the fact _ which is the other aspect of the problem that also demands the bringing forward of the congress _ is that the party will only be able to fulfill the mission of political vanguard if it drastically restructures itself, masters the art of political work in the present-day conditions and succeeds in cooperating with all forces committed to perestroika. The crux of the party's renewal is the need to get rid of everything that tied it to the authoritarian-bureaucratic system, a system that left its mark not only on methods of work and interrelationships within the party, but also on ideology, ways of thinking and notions of socialism. The platform says: our ideal is a humane, democratic socialism. Expressing the interests of the working class and all working people and relying on the great legacy of Marx, Engels and Lenin, the Soviet Communist Party is creatively developing socialist ideals to match present-day realities and with due account for the entire experience of the twentieth century. The platform states clearly what we should abandon. We should abandon the ideological dogmatism that became ingrained during past decades, outdated stereotypes in domestic policy and outmoded views on the world revolutionary process and world development as a whole. We should abandon everything that led to the isolation of socialist countries from the mainstream of world civilization. We should abandon the understanding of progress as a permanent confrontation with a socially different world.

The party in a renewing society can exist and play its role as vanguard only as a democratically recognized force. This means that its status should not be imposed through constitutional endorsement. The Soviet Communist Party, it goes without saying, intends to struggle for the status of the ruling party. But it will do so strictly within the framework of the democratic process b giving up any legal and political advantages, offering its program and defending it in discussions, cooperating with other social and political forces, always working amidst the masses, living by their interests and their needs. The extensive democratization currently under way in our society is being accompanied by mounting political pluralism. Various social and political organizations and movements emerge. This process may lead at a certain stage to the establishment of parties. The Soviet Communist Party is prepared to act with due account for these new circumstances, cooperate and conduct a dialogue with all organizations committed to the Soviet constitution and the social system endorsed in this constitution. At the same time we openly state that at this crucial period the Soviet Communist Party is able to play the consolidating, integrating role and ensure progress of perestroika for the benefit of the entire nation.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says Global Warming Response Mustn't Hurt Economic Growth
DOC.TEXT: President Bush called Monday for balancing economic and environmental concerns when dealing with global warming, prompting environmentalists to accuse him of siding with industry and avoiding a pressing world problem. Bush, speaking to an international conference on the threat of a world ``greenhouse'' effect, said ``our policies must be consistent with economic growth.'' And he suggested that in some areas of the debate ``politics and opinion have outpaced the science.'' Environmentalists at the conference suggested the problem was not scientific but a lack of U.S. leadership in dealing with the issue. One participant called Bush's comments ``a gross disappointment.'' On Capitol Hill, Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., a frequent critic of Bush's stand on global warming, said the president was ``moving as slow as molasses'' on the issue when many scientists already are convinced decisive action is needed. But the president, addressing the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, said nations must strike a bargain between curbing pollution that is causing a warming of the earth and maintaining economic growth. Arguing that key scientific questions have yet to be answered, Bush suggested it was too early to unleash an action plan aimed at specific pollution reductions as many environmentalists _ and some European countries _ have said is required. Later at the White House, presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Bush does not believe it is ``time for a call to arms'' on the global warming issue, but ``time for a call to research and to find out more about it.'' ``Our goal continues to be matching policy commitments to emerging scientific knowledge _ and a reconciling of environmental protection to the continued benefits of economic development,'' said Bush. The remarks brought a subdued reaction from many of the participants at the international conference sponsored by the United Nations and attended by representatives from some 60 nations. Delegates from some European countries, including Norway, Denmark and Sweden, have argued that enough scientific knowledge has been accumulated to warrant a commitment from industrial nations to at least stabilize carbon dioxide pollution at current levels over the next decade. Scientists are concerned that the accumulation of manmade pollutants, largely carbon dioxide from the burning of fossil fuels, is creating a serious global problem. Like a greenhouse, the pollution traps heat and reflects it back to earth, causing a warming of the globe. While there is little dispute that greenhouse gases are increasing, there remains disagreement within the scientific community as to how severe the warming will become and what effect it might have on the earth. If the pollutants are left unchecked, many scientists expect the earth's temperature to rise by 4 to 9 degrees by the middle of the next century, perhaps causing coastal flooding and droughts in interior regions. On the other hand, reducing greenhouse gases would require major shifts from the use of coal, oil and natural gas, which are mainstays for a broad range of industries. Industrial leaders have raised concerns that if pollution controls are imposed too quickly, there could be severe economic disruption. Daniel Becker of the Sierra Club, said of Bush's speech, ``It was a gross disappointment. There was more talk in the speech about economics than about the environment.'' Stewart Boyle of the Association for the Conservation of Energy in Great Britain said Bush's remarks demonstrated ``a leadership crisis'' on the global warming issue at the White House. ``About the only thing we can say about it is he turned up'' at the conference, said Boyle. In his speech, Bush said he is determined to ``produce policies that work'' and suggested some of his critics ``may be tempted to exploit legitimate concerns for political positioning.'' Bush's address became a focus of controversy even before the conference opened when White House Chief of Staff John Sununu was reported to have ordered changes in the text to mute U.S. concerns about global warming. Sununu acknowledged making changes, but said the final version reflected the views of the president. During a campaign appearance in Michigan on Aug. 31, 1988, then-candidate Bush endorsed unilateral action to deal with greenhouse pollution, declaring: ``Those who think we're powerless to do anything about the greenhouse effect are forgetting the White House effect.'' He continued in his campaign remarks: ``As president I intend to do something about it. In my first year in office I will convene a global conference on the environment at the White House. ... We will talk about global warming ... and we will act.'' No such conference has been held, although Bush on Monday announced he is calling a meeting at the White House this spring to bring together top environmentalists, economists and ecologists to grapple with the global warming issue.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Urges Immediate Aid
DOC.TEXT: Panama's former president, expressing support for President Bush's proposed $1 billion economic aid package, said Monday his country needs immediate economic help to rebound from the Noriega era. ``Panamanians want to do the job, but to be successful, we need your economic support over the next two years to recover from the devastation of Panama's economy,'' Nicolas Ardito Barletta told the international economic policy and trade subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. Barletta, an economist who served as Panama's president for 11 months in 1984-1985, said Panama's economy is ``highly depressed.'' Barletta, now a consultant in Panama, was ousted as president by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, overthrown in the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion. Among the problems Panama faces are: unemployment of 25 percent; loss of $600 million in business inventories to looting after the invasion; an external debt $1 billion in arrears and a heavy physical damage to public facilities. Bush has proposed a economic package of $1 billion in aid for Panama. Rep. Sam Gejdenson, D-Conn., chairman of the trade panel, questioned the amount of the Bush package. ``This country is going to have to help,'' he said. ``Perhaps not the $1 billion that the president has proposed but certainly a good deal.'' Gedjenson said much of Panama's economic damage stems from the ``two years of U.S. economic sanctions'' and the large-scale military operation to dislodge Noriega. Barletta stressed the need to act swiftly. ``A delay in support will prolong stagnation and create despair,'' he said. As the economy begins to recover, with public works projects to employ people and credit programs to revive trade, the private sector will proceed with ``sustainable growth,'' he said. On a positive note, Barletta said the dissolution of the Panamania Defense Forces, which Noriega headed, will save the country roughly $70 million annually. The military will be replaced by a newly trained police force.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Questions Stockpile Allegations but Concedes Foul-Ups
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, responding to charges the Pentagon has stockpiled $30 billion worth of unneeded supplies and equipment, questioned the figure Monday but said a ``fouled up'' acquisition system contributed to excess. Cheney disputed the Senate Budget Committee's findings that as much as $30 billion worth of material is going to waste in a $103 billion inventory and said the Pentagon is taking steps to improve the system. ``They have a 13,000-year supply of a particular part for an F-14 fighter aircraft,'' said Sen. James Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat and chairman of the Budget Committee. ``There are a number of other instances similar to that.'' The committee's findings were based in part on staff aides' visits to military bases around the country and on interviews with Pentagon officials. Cheney, testifying before the panel on his $292.1 billion military budget request, said there is a debate over the amount of excess inventory, ``but a lot of that has to do with the way the system works. The system is fouled up.'' ``If the system is not very efficient or if there's long lead time between when you order something and you actually get it, what you're going to do is order enough so that you can rat-hole whatever extra you need,'' Cheney said. The defense secretary said among the changes under way is having the Army and Air Force adopt the Navy system that reduces the overall demand for spare parts by 20 percent. ``An individual will know what it costs him up front to order a part. It won't be a freebie. It will come out of his budget,'' Cheney said. The report said among the excess supplies was a female dress shirt in 126 sizes. The Army wanted to add 100 more sizes to the 58 sizes of the long-sleeved dress shirt in then had its inventory, but after warnings from the Defense Logistics Agency that the total was unnecessary, settled for adding 68 sizes. More than 200,000 of the shirts, priced at $14 apiece, are in the Army inventory, far in excess for the 86,000 women in the active service. ``We're moving in the direction of using commercial specifications to reduce the total number of clothing sizes,'' Cheney said. ``The clothing purchases have been out of control in a sense.'' The committee staff found, among other things, that there was a glut of supplies and that in many instances equipment was stored in the open and was deteriorating. The Defense Department has spent over $700 million in the last six to eight years for additional warehouse space, the report said. Sasser said that with past Pentagon efforts to improve management, Congress ``runs into the same procedures, the same cast of characters ... (and) when it bubbles to the surface, there's embarrassment.'' ``In the final analysis, we're going to have to institute some kind of incentives,'' he said. Cheney and the Pentagon also were criticized by Democrats on the committee for a military spending plan for fiscal 1991 that moves ahead several big-ticket projects, such as the B-2 stealth bomber and the Strategic Defense Initiative. Democrats believe that revolutionary changes in Eastern Europe and the lessening Soviet threat to the West should be reflected in the U.S. defense budget. ``Why are we going forward and spending these very large sums of money on things like the B-2, the rail-mobile MX (nuclear missile)?'' Sasser asked Cheney. ``Why don't we wait and see what kind of world we're going to be living in?'' The Bush administration's proposed defense budget calls for $5.5 billion for five B-2 stealth bombers and an increase of nearly $1 billion for a total of $4.5 billion for SDI, popularly known as Star Wars. Cheney said the Pentagon is studying the programs and will decide at a later date whether to scale them back. The defense secretary said it was unlikely he would cancel the B-2 program, but changes are possible in plans for a 132-aircraft fleet at a cost of $70 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets With President-Elect Of Uruguay
DOC.TEXT: President Bush met Monday with President-elect Luis Alberto LaCalle of Uruguay and discussed debt, investment, trade and the fight against narcotics traffickers, the White House said. The two leaders met for about 40 minutes in the Oval Office. A White House statement said Bush expressed support for LaCalle's plans to reform Uruguay's economy and said the United States would work closely with Uruguay toward this goal. The two leaders also said that a mutual legal assistance treaty between the two nations would be beneficial.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Joel Fluellen Died after Long Hollywood Career
DOC.TEXT: Actor Joel Fluellen, who protested black stereotyping in Hollywood and played the brother in ``The Jackie Robinson Story,'' has died. He was 81. Los Angeles County coroner's spokesman Bob Dambacher said Monday an autopsy showed Fluellen committed suicide and died from a gunshot wound to the head. Police found his body Friday at his Los Angeles home. Along with a string of movie and television credits, Fluellen played an instrumental role in fighting black discrimination in Hollywood during the 1940s and 1950s. Fluellen introduced resolutions to the Screen Actors Guild asking the group to ``use all its powers to oppose discrimination'' against blacks in the industry. His proposals were turned down, but 23 years later SAG formed its Ethnic Equal Opportunity Committee. The Louisiana-raised actor came to Hollywood around 1940 after appearing on the New York stage. Fluellen played the brother in the 1950 movie, ``The Jackie Robinson Story.'' His other movie credits include ``The Great White Hope,'' ``The Learning Tree'' and ``Run Silent, Run Deep.'' He also appeared in the television series ``Hill Street Blues.'' Funeral services were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Savage Storm Caused $670 Million Damage, 23 Dead
DOC.TEXT: The violent winds that killed 23 people this weekend in northern and western France caused at least $670 million damage, insurers said Monday. Tens of thousands of citizens are expected to make claims this week for homes, cars or businesses damaged by the windstorm, the Center of Insurance Information and Documentation reported. The state electricity company, Electricite de France, meanwhile reported that about 200,000 homes remained without power Monday as crews tried to restore lines toppled by falling trees. No total figure for downed trees was estimated by authorities, but at least 2,500 fell in the famed Bois de Boulogne and Bois de Vincennes in Paris, police said. Another 600 came down on the grounds of Versailles, with some striking buildings at Marie-Antoinette's mock Norman hamlet. The grounds will remain closed this week, authorities said. Thousands of acres of forests were damaged by the winds, whose top speed reached 104 mph at the Pointe de Raz in far western France. The death toll of 23 made the storm the worst to strike France in 20 years, authorities said. The winds occurred nine days after a similar storm raged across southern Britain, much of northern France and six European countries, leaving more than 61 dead and causing hundreds of millions of dollars in damage.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Holds First Hearings on Tax-Cut Plan
DOC.NOTE: EDs: First 8 grafs new with testimony; picks up pvs graf 6, The Social
DOC.TEXT: Senate tax writers spared no rhetoric Monday in criticizing the use of surplus Social Security taxes to hide the size of the federal deficit, but they and their expert witnesses disagreed on what to do about it. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., whose bill to cut Social Security taxes by up to $300 a year for higher-income workers set off the debate, said it is thievery to use those taxes for other purposes. Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., termed it looting. Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., called it embezzlement but said Moynihan's proposed remedy is worse _ a ``sugar coating hides a twin toxic menace: poison that will bankrupt Social Security and burden the many to the benefit of the few.'' Two former government officials who are among the foremost authorities on the pension system offered conflicting advice as the Senate Finance Committee held the first congressional hearing on whether Social Security taxes should be cut to keep surpluses out of government hands. Robert J. Myers, who helped create the system in 1934 and was its chief actuary for 23 years, endorsed the tax reduction. ``The time has arrived when the financing of the Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance program should be rationalized, stabilized and made crystal clear by going to a pay-as-you-go basis, as proposed by Senator Moynihan,'' Myers said. Robert M. Ball, Social Security commissioner from 1962 to 1973, said nothing justifies an immediate reduction in payroll taxes. If Congress decides to eliminate Social Security surpluses, the money should be transferred into the Medicare hospitalization fund, which also is financed through payroll taxes, he said. The Bush administration vigorously opposes the tax cut as a threat to Social Security benefits and an opening for increases in other taxes. Nevertheless, Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn S. King told the hearing, ``the administration is open to every reasonable alternative'' so long as any change does not upset ``the sound financial footing ... of the last seven years.'' Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas and chairman of the Finance Committee, sought to reassure future beneficiaries. ``Today, the Social Security system is sound. That's my No. 1 priority, the No. 1 priority of this committee,'' Bentsen said. The Social Security tax on 132 million workers and their employers is bringing in $1 billion a week more than is being paid out in benefits. This surplus is invested, by law, in federal securities and the money mixed with other federal revenues to finance general government programs. Moynihan and some other Democrats find that galling for two reasons. First, they say, it requires lower- and middle-income workers to pay an unfair share of the cost of government. Unlike the income tax, the Social Security tax rate is the same for rich and poor and it applies from the first dollar earned; the tax ends once income passes $51,300. Second, Democrats say, President Bush and his predecessor, Ronald Reagan, have been able to run on pledges not to increase income taxes because they knew the mounting Social Security surplus would hide the true size of the deficit in other government acounts. This is thievery, Moynihan says, and the only solution is to put Social Security on a pay-as-you-go basis, eliminating the surplus. Moynihan's bill would repeal the tax increase that on Jan. 1 boosted the rate for employees and employers to 7.65 percent of the first $51,300 of wages; that would drop the rate back to 7.51 percent. Next Jan. 1, the rate would be cut to 6.55 percent, where it would remain until 2011. Starting in 2012, when the post-World War II generation begins retiring, the tax rate would resume a gradual increase, peaking at 8.1 percent in 2045. Bush told a news conference last month that Moynihan's bill is ``a disguise for increased taxes around the corner.'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady called the proposal ``goofy'' and ``the height of folly.'' The administration has acknowledged that it is unfair to future retirees to use Social Security surpluses for other purposes. However, the president's solution is to do nothing about it until the federal budget is balanced and then to use surplus Social Security taxes only for debt reduction.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson, Thatcher, Argue About South Africa Sanctions
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Jesse Jackson, the black U.S. civil rights leader, argued about sanctions against South Africa during a a 90-minute meeting Monday, but smiled for photographers afterward. Mrs. Thatcher gave Jackson a message for jailed black leader Nelson Mandela saying many hopes rest with him, said a spokesman at her official residence, 10 Downing Street, who asked that his name not be used. Jackson is on his way to South Africa. ``We agreed to disagree,'' Jackson told reporters, referring to Mrs. Thatcher's opposition to sanctions. He added, ``I feel we have a better feel for each other.'' Jackson said Mrs. Thatcher expressed belief that President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa was committed to reforms he announced Friday, which include legalizing the African National Congress guerrilla movement and the speedy release of Mandela, an ANC leader when he went to jail nearly 28 years ago. ``She happens to believe for the most part that the courageous steps taken by Mr. de Klerk will continue,'' Jackson said. ``I believe they will continue with encouragement, with stimulation to go forward, with deterrence to go backwards, with economic incentives if and when apartheid is dismantled.'' Both Jackson and the Thatcher spokesman said the unexpectedly long meeting was friendly, and Jackson promised to telephone with a report on his South African visit. ``The prime minister asked Mr. Jackson to give Mr. Mandela a message,'' said the British spokesman: ``Tell Mr. Mandela how many hopes ride on him for the future of his country.'' Jackson flew to Zambia on Monday night, and goes to South Africa on Wednesday for his first visit in more than a decade. He has been refused a visa since 1979. ``We committed ourselves to remain in dialogue as both of us search in our own way for a new South Africa and a new equation,'' Jackson said of the meeting with Mrs. Thatcher. At a news conference held for him earlier Monday by three black members of the House of Commons, Jackson said: ``Sanctions and apartheid should end on the same day, and it ought to be soon. Even Mr. de Klerk did not make ending sanctions a precondition for negotiations'' with black leaders. Jackson urged white South Africans, outnumbered by blacks 5 to 1, not to fear losing power. ``There has been no evidence of any kind of retaliatory schemes by blacks against whites once they become involved politically,'' he said. ``The quest must be for a non-racial state where all can share power and responsibility.'' Mrs. Thatcher been criticized by opposition parties and anti-apartheid groups in Britain for lifting restrictions on academic and cultural contacts immediately after de Klerk announced the reforms Friday. Jackson was invited to South Africa by Walter Sisulu, an African National Council leader freed last year, and the South African Council of Churches.

DOC.HEAD: More Precipitation Scattered Over West
DOC.TEXT: Rain and snow was scattered over the West on Monday, while parts of Minnesota warmed to record highs in the 40s. A winter storm warning was in effect into the night over the Washington Cascades and Olympics. At midday, snow was scattered over the Idaho Panhandle and western Washington, from south-central Oregon into north-central California, and over northwestern New Mexico. Generally light rain extended along much of the northern half of the Pacific Coast. And a thundershower produced small hail during the early afternoon at Hoquiam, Wash. Snow fell during the night from Sunday into Monday over north-central Arizona, leaving 6 inches of new snow at Flagstaff, 5 inches at Sunset Crater National Monument, 3{ inches at Walnut Canyon National Monument and a little more than an inch at Munds Park.
