That made a total of 15 inches of snow on the ground at Flagstaff Airport, the National Weather Service said. In Minnesota, Minneapolis-St. Paul reached a record high of 46 degrees. Farther north, on the shore of Lake Superior, Duluth reached a record 43 degrees. Duluth's normal high for Feb. 5 is 19 degrees. Elsewhere, however, more severe winter temperatures are firmly in place in the interior of Alaska. For the 11th day in a row, early morning temperatures Monday were in the 30-below-zero to 50-below-zero range and the cold is expected to continue until the middle of the month, the weather service said. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EST ranged from 10 degrees above zero at Caribou, Maine, to 74 at Harlingen, Texas. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 23 below zero at Houlton, Maine.

DOC.HEAD: Failed Wrapping May Have Cause Oil Pipeline Corrosion
DOC.TEXT: Improperly installed protective wrapping may have caused most of the corrosion threatening the trans-Alaska oil pipeline, and repairs may cost nearly $1 billion over the next five years, officials say. ``Whether it will affect the integrity of the pipeline remains yet to be seen,'' said Jack Overly, western regional division chief for the federal Office of Pipeline Safety. ``We have not run into anything to cause concern about its integrity.'' The 48-inch-diameter pipeline was completed in 1977 at a cost of about $8 billion and carries 1.9 million barrels of crude oil daily from sprawling North Slope oil fields to a terminal in Valdez, 800 miles to the south. It is operated by the Alyeska Pipeline Service Co. for a consortium of the seven oil companies that own the line. There are no known leaks in the trans-Alaska oil pipeline, Overly said. Nearly all of the corrosion is located on the outside of the half-inch thick pipe wall, and nearly all of it occurs on buried pipe. Overly said corrosion is common on buried pipelines. ``I've seen them cause leaks, but I don't know of any that you'd say failed because of corrosion,'' he said. Most of the serious corrosion was found in a nine-mile stretch of pipeline buried in the Atigun flood plain, about 160 miles south of Prudhoe Bay, Marnie Isaacs, spokeswoman for Alyeska, said Monday. ``That is quite an active flood plain,'' she said. ``There is a lot of flowing water. There is a constant supply of oxygen. But corrosion is always to be expected in buried pipe.'' The pipeline generally operates about 1,100 pounds per square inch, Isaacs said, but that's been reduced by about 17 percent in the Atigun flood plain. The repair tab on the pipeline for this year alone is expected to total $150 million, with expenditures over the next five years estimated at just short of $1 billion. Partly because of the corrosion expenses, Alyeska has asked the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Alaska Public Utilities Commission for permission to sharply increase the tariff it charges to move oil through the line. Increased tariffs mean less income for the state, and Alaska officials filed an objection with the federal agency. About 85 percent of the revenue received by Alaska's treasury comes from oil. Isaacs said the corrosion was discovered last year by a mechanical ``pig,'' a device that moves through the line and measures pipe wall thickness with ultrasound. So far, 800 anomalies in thickness have been pinpointed, Isaacs said. The corrosion found has been given priorities based on its possible effects on the line's operation. There are 116 Priority One anomalies which could affect pipeline pressure, Isaacs said. ``We've investigated all of those. We finished last week,'' she said. She said wrapping designed to protect the line has failed in several spots, ``but most of them are in the nine-mile stretch at Atigun. More than 75 percent are in a 13-mile stretch, with most of that in the Atigun flood plain,'' she said. She said the outer wrapping in the Atigun area may have failed because the installation was difficult.``That section of pipe was installed in extremely adverse conditions. It was a winter installation, in the bitter cold and wind. There is some thought that may have compromised some of the wrap.'' Alyeska plans to replace the troublesome nine-mile segment in 1991, Isaacs said. A new pipe will be buried next to the old line, she said, and the pipeline should be shut down no more than about two days.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Leaders Ask Bush To Help In Settling Soviet Refugees
DOC.TEXT: American Jewish leaders asked President Bush on Monday to appeal to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to speak out against what they said was a resurgence of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union. Two dozen Jewish leaders, at a White House meeting, also appealed to Bush for U.S. help to resettle the Soviet Jewish refugees now flooding into Israel by the thousands. Seymour D. Reich, chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, praised Bush's own denunciation of ``racism, anti-Semitism, bigotry and hate'' in last week's State of the Union address. ``It would be helpful for (Gorbachev) to share those same concerns with the Soviet people,'' said Reich, a New York lawyer who is also president of B'nai B'rith, the Jewish fraternal organization. ``I had a sense that he would clearly encourage President Gorbachev to speak out, to still the fears of Soviet Jews and others who are torn by ethnic strife,'' said Reich. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said later ``I suspect (Bush) probably will'' communicate the Jewish leaders' concerns to Gorbachev. Reich said the issue ``may very well be on the agenda'' of Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who arrives in Moscow later this week for talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Reich said Jews in Eastern Europe have been ``haunted'' for centuries by fears of pogroms, such as the organized persecution and massacres of Jews that occurred in Czarist Russia. Gorbachev's policy of ``glasnost,'' in loosening state controls on everyday life in the Soviet Union, has also opened the lid on old ethnic rivalries in Azerbaijan and elsewhere and triggered an upsurge of anti-Semitism, Soviet refugees say. Nearly 4,600 Soviet Jews emigrated to Israel last month and Israeli officials are preparing for as many as 100,000 refugeees this year. Israel will welcome them ``with open arms,'' said Reich, but he added, ``The United States may be called upon to give assistance to that settlement process.'' On foreign aid, Reich said the Jewish leaders ``acknowledged that the United States will be called upon to assist the blossoming democracies in Europe. But that aid to those countries should stand on their own.'' ``Aid to Israel has to be measured against the fact that glasnost has not come to the Middle East. There are still 20 Arab countries still in a state of war and belligerency with Israel, armed to the teeth, ready to destroy Israel if they had the opportunity,'' said Reich. He said the Israeli government has not adopted a policy of resettling Soviet Jews in the occupied territories. But he said Israeli Prime Minister Yithzak Shamir last week told him that ``that Israel cannot pass a law to prevent that. Jews have a right to live anyplace in the world, in any Arab country. ... Clearly Jews should be permitted to live wherever they want.'' Earlier Monday, Bush called Shamir and expressed condolences over the deaths of Isreali tourists in a terrorist attack Sunday in Egypt. At least nine Israelis were killed. ``This horrible act of terrorism should be condemned by civilized people everywhere,'' presidential spokesman Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: entire nation.
DOC.TEXT: Regrettably, we could not escape miscalculations and mistakes during perestroika and this, too, has complicated the situation. Social tension and anxiety are typical of it now. Elements of apathy and disappointment have emerged. Such is the contradictory but real situation. There is the danger, and the party should be mindful of this, that adventurists will try to exploit the arisen difficulties and speculate on real problems and the working people's dissatisfaction. The signs of this danger are obvious, including in recent days.

We have already heard some allege that we have adopted an overly steep course, threatening the very foundations of the socialist system, and that there is no way out of the difficulties except by a return to the former order. Others, on the contrary, allege that reforms aiming to bring out the potential of the socialist system are doomed to failure and the country can be rescued only through capitalization. We might not speak about this if these were only abstract theoretical disputes or debates in political circles. But such destructive judgments, penetrating into society, befuddle quite a few people, adversely affect the political atmosphere and stop people seeing the restructuring process in the right perspective.

We remain committed to the choice made in October 1917, the socialist idea. But we move away from its dogmatic interpretation, refuse to sacrifice the people's real interests for schematic constructions. We set the task to translate into life step by step the principle of social justice without the slightest illusions in a speedy miracle. We intend to do this by rejecting the prejudices of the past and various ideological taboos, using everything valuable that is available in other societies, in their economies and social sphere, political life, the organization of production and everyday life, science and technology, culture and intellectual creativity.

The platform begins with setting out the political and socio-economic rights of the Soviet man, freedoms of the individual. I think that comrades have also noticed that, after human rights in the draft, the need is stressed to adopt a range of measures to enrich the spiritual world of people, to raise society's education and cultural level.

Along with long-term matters, the draft platform puts forward urgent tasks connected with the modern situation in the country. This has paramount importance. We hoped to mount the peak of the crisis in 1989, but recent events have shown that there has been no change for the better. The recently published results of economic performance of the past year revealed once again the contradictory nature of processes in the economy. On one hand, a number of indices posted slight growth despite considerable losses caused by strikes, ethnic conflicts, lax discipline and mismanagement. More foodstuffs and consumer goods have been produced. On the other hand, we can see further disruption of the consumer market, a growth in shortages and queues, and a fall in the purchasing power of the ruble. The situation is being worsened by the activity of shadow economy dealers and criminal elements. People are especially dissatisfied with the food situation. The question should be posed squarely. We worked out an innovative agrarian policy and voted for it at the March plenary meeting. We assess it as progressive and pointing to real ways out of the food crisis.

Nevertheless, on the scale of the country, no fundamental improvement has taken place. The reason is that many people in localities are still in the sway of old attitudes and methods of management. Yes, there are shortages of resources and technology. Yes, social transformations must be conducted on a different scale and at different rates. All this is true. But primary importance should be assigned to restructuring relations of production in the village. And the crux of the matter now is the position of our cadre at the center and localities. This is a political rather than an economic question. All obstacles should be removed in the way of the farmer, he should be given a free hand.

I think that until now we have lacked resolve and this should be overcome. This, particularly, concerns the main missing link that caused the entire economic reform to stall _ the pricing system. It is necessary to speed up the solution of this problem. The party continues to stand on the principled position: The price reform should not affect the standard of living, especially that of low-income strata. We can no longer reconcile ourselves with the glaring manifestations of mismanagement. Can we expect any effect from credits that draw ridiculously small interest? Our interest is found nowhere in the world. It is such that no one cares to return credits because this interest does not change much, after all. This explains why neither credit nor ruble work. This won't do at all.

At a time when the country is rumbling, there is a shortage of resources. Moreover, there is a shortage of basic goods on the market. This means that a mechanism is again lacking that would stimulate enterprises to have as much resources as they need and to get rid of the surplus.

We can get rid of these old ailments of our economy only by moving ahead, by introducing cost-accounting relations as part of the economic reform. All attempts to somehow spur on through commands were doomed long ago, comrades. They have not worked for decades. They certainly would not work today.

Comrades, our society is concerned, no less than with the situation in the economy, with a number of complex problems that arose in the inter-ethnic field, which affect the future of the Soviet federation. ... We think that the platform on inter-ethnic issues can serve as a departure for transforming our federation.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Modrow Says Neutrality of United Germany Open to Discussion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to include outlawing of Republican Party, appearance of Republicans at rally; picks up 8th `The eight'
DOC.TEXT: Premier Hans Modrow of East Germany said Monday his proposal that a reunited Germany be neutral was open to discussion, and indicated he wants fewer Soviet soldiers stationed in his country. Economics Minister Christa Luft said monetary union with West Germany must be approached with care. Rapid introduction of the West German mark would solve some immediate problems but create others, she said. Parliament added eight representatives of pro-democracy groups to the government, giving the opposition Cabinet seats for the first time in East Germanty's 40-year history. It formally approved March 18 for the first free elections and outlawed West Germany's ultra-right Republican Party. Modrow's remarks in the televised Parliament session appeared to soften his stance on neutrality. The reform-minded Communist said his proposal last week was meant as a basis for discussing ways to achieve German unity. About 100,000 people rallied in Leipzig Monday and speakers called for quick reunification, the official news agency ADN reported. One sign said ``Unity Now.'' West German flags waved in the crowd and many deomonstrators carried anti-Communist signs. Leipzig has been at the heart of the pro-democracy movement, and regular Monday rallies in the southern industrial city contributed to the downfall of the Communist old guard in October. In recent weeks, the rallies have become a focal point of support for reunification. ADN said a group of Republicans distributed leaflets, carried signs and used bullhorns to publicize the West German party's goals. It said they also marched and raised their arms in the Nazi salute. Republicans have attended recent Leipzig rallies. The party has said it wanted to run in the East Germany elections. The eight new ministers will have no portfolios in the interim Cabinet that is governing the until the elections. With 17 seats, the Communists became a minority in the 36-member government for the first time. Government and opposition officials spoke out against West German politicians making campaign appearances for East German parties during the campaign. West German party leaders said, however, that they would continue campaigning for sister parties in the East. Modrow said Monday his proposal of a neutral united Germany meant military neutrality, which appeared to leave open the possibility of political ties with the Western alliance. Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany has rejected the concept of neutrality for a united Germany, as have the United States and other kmembers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the West German foreign minister, has suggested the united country remain in the alliance, but that NATO military structures not extend to what is now East Germany. In Parliament on Monday, Modrow said: ``There is opposition to the idea of a military, I repeat, military neutralization of the future joint Germany. Well, then, we should discuss this point of contention so that we can come to an acceptable solution that would respect security needs of all those involved.'' ``Why not, for example, start with a reduction of reciprocal military presence on the territory of the present two German sttes?'' The premier said his proposal last week that a united Germany be neutral was not meant to be the final word on the matter. ``I never believed all points of my proposals would be accepted by everyone,'' he said. ``I made my proposals ... to create conditions for the inevitable process of unification of the German states. The German nation, despite all attempts to dismantle it, has never been lost,'' he added. He said several obstacles must be overcome because the two Germanys have vastly different legal and financial structures. Mrs. Luft said at the weekly talks between the government and opposition that quick introduction of the West Germany mark would ease some supply problems, broaden the possibilities for travel and force companies to become more competitive. She cautioned, however, that the flight of East Germans would not stop because pay would remain below that in the Westm, unprofitable enterprises would have to close, workers would be laid off and savings would be threatened. East Germans should decide the issue in a referendum, Mrs. Luft said. Theo Weigel, the West German finance minister, has recommended introduction of the currency. More than 50,000 East Germans went to West Germany in January alone, following 340,000 who resettled there last year. The East Germans leaving because of the slow progress of reforms and the prospect of being paid in valuable West German marks instead of East German currency, which is not convertible. West Germany also wants to stem the flow because of the strain placed on social services by the new arrivals. Mrs. Luft said West Germany should provide East Germany with immediate, interest-free aid of $5.8 billion to $8.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Key Points of Gorbachev's Address to Central Committee
With AM-Soviet-Party
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief look at some key points included in Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech Monday to the Communist Party Central Committee, in which he asked the party to give up its monopoly on power.

POLITICAL POWER _ The Soviet Communist Party, now given exclusive political power by the country's constitution, must prove its worthiness to remain the country's ruling party. It will reject any political or legal advantages and will struggle for people's support along with other political and public organizations.

MULTIPARTY SYSTEM _ Political changes fostered by Gorbachev's reforms already have begun to create political pluralism. That may lead to competing political parties being formed. The Communist Party is ready to work with any organizations that accept the Soviet Constitution and are not intent on destroying its socialist structure.

PARTY REFORMS _ The party must move up from October to summer its next congress, the meeting of its most powerful body that can elect a new leadeship. It should make its internal workings more democratic, and must review the key Leninist concept of democratic centralism that requires strict adherence once a decision is made at the top. The size of the policy-making Central Committee should be reduced.

GOVERNMENT AND ECONOMY _ The party must no longer dictate to the government or to economic managers. The Soviet economy was expected to turn the corner in 1989, but failed to show improvement. Soldiers were sent to the Azerbaijan republic on Jan. 20 because thousands of lives were at risk and the danger existed of nationalists' seizing power.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Bomber Crashes into Sea off England
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead, graf 3 to CORRECT to F-111 sted F1-11. Picks up 4th, `The aircraft...'
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Air Force F-111 bomber with a crew of two crashed into the sea off east England during a routine training missing Monday. The British Defense Ministry said one body was recovered and a search was under way for the second crew member. The coast guard at Great Yarmouth said two U.S. Air Force helicopters and two local rescue boats searched by the light of flares after nightfall. The F-111 plunged into the water over a sea firing range known as Wainfleet. ``The aircraft crashed ... in The Wash and a lot of debris has been found,'' said a coast guard spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Wash is a shallow bay of the North Sea. U.S. Air Force spokesman Sgt. Michael Devine said the bomber _ based at Upper Heyford, 50 miles northwest of London _ was on a run-of-the-mill training mission. Upper Heyford is one of two British bases for the U.S. bombers, which are capable of carrying nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: our federation.
DOC.TEXT: At the same time, we tried to take into account recent developments. The pre-congress platform points to the possibility of and the need for the further development of the treaty principle of the Soviet federation. This would involve the creation of legal conditions that would open the possibility for the existence of diverse forms of federative ties. We stand for the diversity of modes of ethnic life in an integral and united Soviet state.

People are becoming more and more aware as to where separatist nationalist, especially extremist, slogans may lead and what they can entail for people, nationalities and the whole country. We must display principled approaches in opposing nationalism, chauvinism and separatism and, at the same time, understand that ethnic problems are no fantasy, they are real and are waiting to be solved by perestroika. The sooner decisions are taken to delimit the competence of the union and that of republics, to actually strengthen their political and economic independence, to broaden the rights of ethnic autonomies and to achieve the harmonious development of all languages and cultures, the sooner people will see the enormous advantages of the new Soviet federation. Separatists, chauvinists and nationalists of all kinds understand this well and are trying to use the growth of peoples' national self-consciousness for their selfish aims. They evidently want to deliver a preventive strike at perestroika, which threatens to thwart their far-reaching plans. This has been patently manifest in the recent developments in Azerbaijan and Armenia.

I would like to draw your attention to the principled aspect of the problem. The conflict is centred round Nagorno-Karabakh. Serious problems accumulated in the economic and cultural development of this autonomous region and the central committee, and the government took major measures to solve them. There appeared hope that this tight knot could be undone and the situation could be improved, but such prospects did not suit certain forces in both republics and in Nagorno-Karabakh itself. Those for whom perestroika is a thorn in the side and who are afraid of democratization and glasnost, ignore laws. I am speaking about representatives of the shadow economy, a veritable mafia which is fanning the flames of ethnic strife and putting pressure on state bodies under the slogans of national revival. The conduct of the authorities and party bodies in both republics, which yielded one position after another under pressure, does them no credit. Unfortunately, many representatives of the intelligentsia in Azerbaijan and Armenia failed to correctly assess the situation, to find the real causes of the conflict and exert a positive influence on developments. Meanwhile, corrupted anti-perestroika forces managed to take the lead and direct misled people's actions into the destructive channel. I should say that there has been, perhaps, no other issue in the past two years that has been given so much attention in Moscow. The initial position of the center was that the Nagorno-Karabakh conflict should be settled in such a way that would leave no winners and no losers. Otherwise, new flare-ups of hostility and violence, new victims and losses would be inevitable. We continued to adhere to this position also at the height of the conflict. And still, we failed to check the aggravation of the situation. Late last year, in a difficult situation, the supreme bodies of power in both republics took decisions that aggravated the situation still more. The republics found themselves on the brink of all-out war. Armed groups from both sides began clashing, they began to seize weapons and attack troops and law enforcement bodies and tightened the blockade of railways and roads. Baku became the scene of brutal pogroms. If the state of emergency had not been introduced in Nagorno-Karabakh, in some border areas and then in Baku, the blood of not dozens, but of thousands upon thousands of people would have been shed.
The main lesson is that all issues connected with the development of nations and ethnic relations must be resolved on the road of perestroika, the renewal of society and democratic dialogue.

Attempts to use force and methods of terror intimidate the people and pressure authorities directly lead to chaos with all the ensuing consequences. Everything must be done to rule out the possibility of such developments in any part of the country.

It must be clear that those who depart from principled positions, follow in the wake of obsolete sentiments or fall under the influence of nationalist passions will find themselves outside political life.

We know how hard and painful perestroika processes are proceeding in these two republics. This is one of the reasons why nationalist forces have succeeded in winning over the people. ... The center has apparently failed to use all its capacities and authority in order to influence more effectively the course of perestroika in the republics and support its followers.

The key fact is that nationalist, anti-Soviet groups openly encroached on the constitutional system, strove for power and sought to establish a dictatorship _ not a democracy _ by naked force and through militant nationalism. This was in fact a coup attempt _ nothing more, nothing less. All structures, above all military ones, had been prepared for that. And the flirtation of some political forces with this wing of the Azerbaijani popular front only reveals their own goals.

It is now up to the peoples of the two republics and their party and state leaders. Their actions will determine how soon normal life will be restored and the state of emergency lifted. Surely, everything must be done to resolve as soon as possible the problems of Nagorno-Karabakh _ urgent, primary ones _ and those problems that have emerged around it _ given strict observance of constitutional principles, including Azerbaijan's integrity. Comrades, the logic of the struggle for perestroika has led to new major decisions. The U.S.S.R. Supreme Soviet will soon adopt laws on ownership, on land, on local self-government and local economy, on the tax system, on the delineation of the competence of the union as a whole and of the constituent republics, and other fundamental legislative acts. The second stage of political reform has been launched, encompassing the formation of governing bodies at republican and local levels.

Indeed, society is acquiring a new quality. But the processes that the party consciously activated, which will undoubtedly bring forth positive results, have not been insured, as we already see, against manifestations of instability, weakened management and centrifugal tendencies. The effect is making itself felt on society, causing misunderstanding of these phenomena and anxiety of the people. At present, from the viewpoint of strategic tasks and in view of current realities, it is necessary to realign forces in the upper echelons of power in order to give more dynamism to perestroika processes and ensure more firmly their irreversibility.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Most Customers of Check-Cashing Services Have Bank Accounts: Survey
DOC.TEXT: A survey released Monday of people who use check-cashing services said that two-thirds had bank or savings and loan accounts. The Consumer Bankers Association surveyed 505 customers in five cities _ Washington, New York, Miami, Chicago and Los Angeles. Even though check-cashing services are more expensive, most respondents said they used the services for convenience: they had longer hours, were eaiser to reach, had shorter lines or faster service. The survey was conducted by The Roper Organization Inc. in October and December. Customers were quizzed outside of five check-cashing outlets in each city. Consumer advocates are backing legislation by Sen. Henry B. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, to require banks and S&Ls to cash Social Security and other government checks and to offer so-called basic banking accounts with low fees. Joe Belew, president of the bankers group, said the poll suggests ``such legislation is unneccessary'' and indicates check-cashing services are not flourishing because banks have shunned poor customers. If high check-cashing fees are a problem, Congress should consider regulating check-cashing outlets, he said. Last month, consumer advocates released surveys saying that check-cashing fees continue to climb; that only 14 percent of banks quizzed in New York, New Jersey, Oregon and California offer low-cost checking accounts, and that most Americans support forcing banks to offer low-cost accounts.

DOC.HEAD: Iran-Contra Judge Orders Reagan Deposition on Videotape
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS pvs 8th graf bgng, Greene ruled, to add that Greene would allow Poindexter to ask Reagan almost all the 183 questions he requested.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Monday ordered former President Reagan to give a videotaped deposition for the Iran-Contra trial of John Poindexter, and to turn over 33 entries from his diary immediately to his former national security adviser. ``Former President Reagan's testimony will be taken by way of a videotaped deposition'' at ``an appropriate place and a date'' before the Feb. 20 start of Poindexter's trial, said U.S. District Judge Harold Greene. Reagan promptly invoked executive privilege to avoid turning portions of his diaries over to Poindexter. ``Former President Reagan hereby asserts his claim to the constitutionally protected privacy of his diaries,'' said Theodore Olson, one of Reagan's attorneys. The judge's order gave Reagan and the Bush administration until Friday to invoke executive privilege on the matter of videotaped testimony. In Los Angeles, Reagan spokesman Mark Weinberg refused comment on the order for a videotaped deposition, but said the former president was invoking executive privilege regarding the diary entries to give his lawyers time to ``evaluate the need'' for them. Invoking executive privilege will enable Reagan to gain access to a secret filing with Greene in which Pointdexter told why he needs the diaries. After examining Poindexter's document, Reagan will be able to determine whether the excerpts contain admissible evidence not available from other sources. ``If so, the former president may decide to waive his claim of privilege,'' Olson said. Greene ruled that he will allow Poindexter to question Reagan on a wide range of subjects in the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter gave the court a list of 183 questions he wants to ask Reagan, and the judge said he would be allowed to ask all but 30 of them. Specifically, Greene said: _Poindexter will be permitted to ask Reagan whether he approved Poindexter's denials to Congress that former White House national security staffer Oliver L. North was raising money and providing military advice to the Nicaraguan Contra rebels. Poindexter is charged with obstruction and conspiracy in connection with those denials. The responses sent to Congress by Poindexter embraced false denials about North's involvement which had been sent to Congress in 1985 by Poindexter's predecessor, Robert McFarlane. _Poindexter will be allowed to ask Reagan about ``the president's knowledge regarding the relationship of Oliver North with specific individuals involved in Iran-Contra activities.'' The president told the investigative Tower Board on Jan. 26, 1987, that he did not know the National Security Council staff was engaged in helping the Contras. ``The board is aware of no evidence to suggest that the president was aware of Lt. Col. North's activities,'' said the board's final report. ``Since he first told the American people about the diversion of funds from the Iran arms sale, President Reagan has cooperated fully with all of the legislative and judicial inquiries into this matter, including the Tower Commission which he appointed to conduct a thorough investigation,'' Reagan spokesman Weinberg said in a statement. Greene renewed his order that Reagan immediately furnish Poindexter with diary excerpts pertaining to U.S. arms sales to Iran and the Reagan administration's secret assistance to the Contras. The Justice Department's request to push back the deadline for surrendering the diary entries ``is nothing more than an attempt to delay'' and is ``out of the question,'' Greene said. The Justice Department had asked Greene to order Iran-Contra prosecutors and Poindexter to attempt to resume negotiations on a summary of the diary entries. Earlier negotiations broke down partly because Poindexter declined to tell prosecutors what he expected to prove through Reagan's testimony. Poindexter and Reagan had objected to having the former president give a videotaped deposition. Poindexter wants Reagan as a witness in the courtroom. Reagan is resisting giving testimony in any form, on the ground that compelling him to testify would have an adverse effect on the presidency. In ordering President Nixon to provide White House tape recordings to Watergate prosecutors, the Supreme Court ruled in 1974 that ``the general assertion of privilege must yield to the demonstrated, specific need for evidence in a pending criminal trial.'' In endorsing the videotape approach, Greene said: ``There is an absence of a direct precedent in 200 years of American history for the compelled testimony in a courtroom by an incumbent or former president.'' Greene said while that fact should not determine whether Reagan should testify, ``it does call for a sense of caution by this court.'' Videotaped testimony would protect the rights of the former president and the privileges of the presidency, Greene said. A videotaped deposition will allow evidence to be taken with recesses for consultations on invoking executive privilege ``or the handling of sensitive defense information,'' the judge said. ``Former President Ronald Reagan is claimed by Adm. Poindexter to have direct and important knowledge that will help to exonerate him from the criminal charges lodged against him,'' Greene said in a 54-page decision. ``In view of the prior professional relationship between the two men, ... that claim cannot be dismissed as fanciful or frivolous,'' the judge said. Greene said ``it would be inconceivable ... to exempt Mr. Reagan from the duty of every citizen to give evidence that will permit the reaching of a just outcome of this criminal prosecution.'' The judge rejected a suggestion by Reagan's lawyers that the former president be permitted to give written answers to written questions from Poindexter. Poindexter has said Reagan took notes at meetings focusing on congressional inquiries into North's activities to help the Contras. The former national security adviser also has said that his meetings with Reagan also dealt with the accuracy of a chronology prepared by North on a 1985 shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. North was convicted of aiding and abetting an obstruction of Congress because the chronology falsely stated that no official of the U.S. government learned before January 1986 that Hawk missiles had been shipped to Iran in the CIA-assisted delivery in November 1985.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agents Look Over Typewriters in Mail Bomb Investigation
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents looked over three typewriters Monday at a piano store in the hunt for a crucial piece of evidence in their mail bomb investigation. Store manager Dean Powers said FBI agents were interested in typewriters bought at an auction at nearby Fort Rucker Army Base. The agents examined one electric typewriter and two manual typewriters but did not remove them from the store, Powers said. A swarm of FBI agents has spent the last two weeks scouring southeast Alabama for the typewriter used to write letters linked to the December mail bomb killings of 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals Judge Robert Vance and Savannah, Ga., lawyer Robert Robinson. ``We are still searching for a typewriter,'' said Tom Moore, an FBI spokesman in Birmingham. No arrests have been made. In Atlanta, about 200 judges, lawyers, friends and relatives of Vance passed through tight security to attend a memorial service in a federal courtroom just a few feet from Vance's chambers. Among those who spoke at the service were U.S. Supreme Court Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who supervises the three states of the 11th Circuit: Alabama, Florida and Georgia. ``If we adhere to the law, civilized conduct and decent people _ people like Robert Vance _ will prevail,'' Kennedy said. ``So in the midst of grief and our sympathy ... we reaffirm the duty and dignity of the law.'' Two mail bombs were intercepted at the Jacksonville, Fla., NAACP office and the 11th Circuit courthouse in Atlanta. The threat to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People aroused fears that the bombings were racially motivated. That concern was heightened by a letter from an obscure group claiming responsibility for them. Ken Holder, a spokesman for Fort Rucker, said typewriters are sold at periodic auctions on the Army base. The FBI searches in Enterprise have focused on a salvage store owner, Robert Wayne O'Ferrell, and print shop operator Brian Joseph Fleming, who has been a member of the Coffee County NAACP chapter for three years. Holder said O'Ferrell was a registered bidder at the Fort Rucker auctions, but the spokesman said anyone who has a junk business probably would show up at the bidding. O'Ferrell has denied any knowledge of the bombings. He came under scrutiny because he had an employment compensation case that he lost on appeal before a three-judge panel of the 11th Circuit, including Vance, and because of alleged similarities in O'Ferrell's typed correspondence and typewritten material sent by the apparent mail bomber. ``I hope someone will pinch me and awaken me from this nightmare,'' O'Ferrell said Monday. O'Ferrell said he has been to at least three sales at Fort Rucker and has purchased typewriters. An attorney for Fleming said that his client's print shop and home were searched Friday probably because of Fleming's indictment on charges of conspiring to export weapons, reportedly to Northern Ireland. Fleming has pleaded innocent to the charges, and is free on $50,000 bond.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Governor Says U.S. In No Position To Seek Foreign Colldier Help
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department is in no position now to seek foreign funds to build the super collider and no one overseas is in a position to make such a commitment, Texas Gov. Bill Clements said Monday. Clements, whose state will be host to the 53-miles-around machine, said after meeting with Energy Secretary James Watkins the Energy Department is not prepared to request foreign help until Congress has ``completely endorsed'' the collider and foreign countries have been assured of its total costs and design. Rep. Tom Bevill, D-Ala., chairman of the House appropriations subcommittee with jurisdiction over the collider, however, was adamant last year that the department come up with a plan to share the cost of the collider with foreign countries. That plan is still being drafted but has been classified, said Department spokesman Jeff Sherwood. Sherwood said the draft had been classified because it represents the government's ``negotiating position'' with potential contributors. Clements said foreign participants, however, should not be sought ``until our plans are very definitive and until the Congress is totally on board with the whole project.'' ``We're not in a position to ask for (foreign help). Certainly no one overseas is in a position to make a commitment for `X' dollars until they know what `Y' cost is, and until Congress has completely endorsed the program. And so foreign participation, which everybody likes to talk about, is premature to talk about at this point,'' Clements said. Only India has publicly announced it was willing to contribute to the collider, up to $50 million. President Bush is seeking a $318 million appropriation for the collider in next year's budget. Bush last year requested $250 million and Congress voted $225 million for the current fiscal year. The collider, when completed late in the decade, will allow scientists to test theories about the fundamental nature of matter by smashing together beams of protons at 20 times the energy now possible. The original cost, estimate at $5.9 billion, will rise by $1 billion to $2 billion if the original design is maintained, a course Watkins has indicated he favors.

DOC.HEAD: Walker Family Back in Spotlight With Spy TV Miniseries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 11-13, `Last night's ...,' with 4 grafs to CORRECT `last night' to `Sunday night,' UPDATE with comment from co-executive producer.
DOC.TEXT: The former wife of convicted spy John A. Walker Jr. says her peace has been shattered by a television series about his spy ring, one of the most damaging espionage cases in the nation's history. The series, based loosely on two books about John A. Walker Jr.'s career as a spy for the Soviet Union, has reopened old wounds, Barbara Joy Crowley Walker said in a telephone interview with The Cape Cod Times on Saturday night. Mrs. Walker, 51, lives on Cape Cod but asked that the location of the house she shares with a daughter and grandson not be disclosed. CBS broadcast the first of two parts of ``Family of Spies: The Walker Spy Ring,'' on Sunday night. The second part is scheduled for Tuesday night. Mrs. Walker said she saw excerpts but did not plan to watch the series. Mrs. Walker said she is upset that she is being portrayed as weak and ineffectual, and as an alcoholic. She is hurt that her children will relive a time in their lives that was ``an absolute nightmare.'' Mrs. Walker and her husband were divorced in 1976, and she turned in her husband to authorities in 1984, unaware that her son was involved in the ring. Walker, a retired Navy communications specialist, had recruited his son, brother and a friend as members of the spy ring. He pleaded guilty in 1985 to spying for the Soviets for 17 years and was sentenced to life in prison. Mrs. Walker worries that the public will not understand that her son, Michael Lance Walker, 27, now serving a 25-year sentence in federal prison, ``did all he did because he so desperately loved his father.'' ``I know what happened was news and now it is one for the history books,'' she said. ``But now my life, or at least some screenwriter's version of it, is being shown on the television, not as news, not as history, but as entertainment for millions of people. ``Let me tell you, what my children suffered and what they continue to suffer has nothing to do with entertainment.'' Sunday night's program carried the following disclaimer: ``Certain events and characters portrayed herein have been fictionalized.'' Disclaimer or not, Mrs. Walker believes people will see the show and believe it. Gerry Abrams, the co-executive producer of the miniseries, said those affiliated with the project had been in touch with Mrs. Walker for the past four years. He said she had been paid a fee for the rights to her story, but would not give the amount. Mrs. Walker said the past five years have been spent ``trying to heal the wounds.'' She has sought to help her three daughters, all in their 30s, deal with the conflicts caused by loving their father while hating what he did. ``John Walker is not a horrible person. He is just a very sad man who took the path of least resistance,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Blast Hits Power Plant in Azerbaijan; Gorbachev Speaks on Unrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Gorbachev remarks, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An explosion blasted out the roof of a thermal power plant in Azerbaijan and disrupted electricity in the troubled republic, Tass reported Monday, without explaining if the damage was accidental. Ethnic and nationalist violence has wracked Azerbaijan for weeks. Soviet army troops, sent into Azerbaijan last month to restore calm after bloody attacks on ethnic Armenians, are supposed to be guarding key industrial points, including power plants. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev spoke of the unrest there at a meeting in Moscow Monday of the Communist Party Central Committee. He said the soldiers were sent to protect thousands of lives and prevent a seizure of political power. The official Soviet news agency said the blast occurred Sunday in one of the power plant's four generating units outside Mingechaur, 280 miles northwest of Baku. Tass said the unit was just going into operation when the explosion ripped off the roof and started a fire. Workers and firemen contained the blaze but shut down the other three units, it said. ``A special commission has been set up to investigate the causes of the incident,'' Tass said. It said the plant is one of the biggest in the southern Trancaucasus. It said two generators have been restarted, and a third is nearing operating condition. Each has a capacity of 300 megawatts. Baku, the capital of Azerbaijan, remained quiet Monday, Tass said. A general strike apparently continues, however. Tass said more than 50 percent of the workforce in light industry is showing up. A reduced curfew runs from midnight to 5 a.m., reported Interfax, a service of Radio Moscow. It said a stolen T-34 tank was recovered in Armenia's Artasat district on Saturday. Interfax quoted Ashot Manucharian, a spokesman for the Armenian National Movement, as saying talks with representatives of the Azerbaijani People's Front may resume after a situation in Azerbaijan is clarified. Negotiations being held in Riga, Latvia, between the two broad-based political movements broke off over the weekend when it was reported that Azerbaijani People's Front activists were forcing Armenians from their homes in two villages. Gorbachev, obviously stung by criticism of his handling of ethnic unrest in the Caucasus Mountain region, said Monday: ``The key fact is that nationalist, anti-Soviet groups openly encroached on the constitutional system, strove for power and sought to establish a dictatorship _ not a democracy _ by naked force and through militant nationalism.'' He said ``the blood of not dozens, but of thousands upon thousands of people would have been shed'' if the central government had not declared a state of emergency. In an address in which he told the party's policy-making body that Communists must yield their monopoly on political power, Gorbachev spent a surprising amount of time defending his actions to control an ethnic hotspot. Soldiers moved into Baku on Jan. 20, about a week after attacks began against ethnic Armenians. More than 100 people died after the army moved into Baku. The death toll in the latest outbreak of ethnic violence centered on control of the Nagorno-Karabakh region of Azerbaijan has reached at least 214. Azerbaijani nationalists accused Gorbachev of trying not to save lives but to break the People's Front political movement by sending in soldiers. Other critics said he should have reacted more decisively long ago to the Armenia-Azerbaijan dispute. ``I would say there has been, perhaps, no other issue in the past two years that has been given so much attention in Moscow,'' Gorbachev said. He said the Kremlin tried to solve Nagorno-Karabakh's problems by improving living conditions, but enemies of his reform program thwarted the effort. Gorbachev said party leaders in the area succumbed to extreme demands rather than resist them.

DOC.HEAD: European Foreign Ministers Give New Support to East Bloc Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with final statement. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: European Community foreign ministers lent support Monday to the channeling of economic and other aid to Eastern Europe as the nations there become more democratic. The ministers of the 12-nation trading bloc expressed willingness to include Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, East Germany, Romania and Yugoslavia in an aid program set up last summer for only Poland and Hungary. At the end of their meeting, the ministers issued a statement saying aid ``should be provided on the basis of commitments from the countries concerned to political and economic reform.'' ``In addition, the program of assistance should be adapted to each country's own situation,'' the ministers said. They supported plans of the European Commission, the community's executive body, to complete agreements by June to expand trade with East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria and Romania. The community already has broad trade agreements with Poland, Hungary and the Soviet Union that lift quotas and give their products greater access to West European markets. A smaller arrangement with Czechoslovakia is to be expanded, and bargaining is under way with East Germany and Bulgaria is under way. Foreign Minister Gerard Collins of Ireland said the community wants to treat Eastern Europe with a ``flexible and responsible attitude, so as to arrive at the solutions appropriate to the situations and problems and needs of each country concerned.'' Ireland now holds the rotating presidency of the community, which is at the center of the Western attempt to help the East European nations. Last summer, the trading bloc was put in charge of an effort by 24 Western nations to develop an economic aid program for Poland and Hungary. Western officials have indicated since that they wanted to expand help for other Eastern European countries moving toward democracy and free markets. Officials of the 24 nations will meet Feb. 16 Brussels for more discussions of aid. The foreign ministers discussed a European Commission plan to sign ``association'' agreements with some nations of the East bloc that would bring them closer to the European Community but stop short of full membership. Their statement said the ministers ``noted with interest the commission's views and suggestions,'' but did not commit them to the association concept. Commission officials told the ministers they would take a new look at the community budget for the next three years seeking sources of money for aid to Eastern Europe. Members of the European Community are Belgium, Britain, West Germany, Ireland, France, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, Denmark, Spain, Portugal, Italy and Greece. Monday's discussions were held at the regular Council of Ministers meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge's Trial Starts With Ruling Allowing Wiretaps
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge accused of using his office to do favors for convicted felons went on trial Monday after a ruling allowing the use of wiretape evidence vital to the goverment's case against him. U.S. District Judge Robert Aguilar, 58, is charged in eight felony counts of racketeering with using his office as a ``racketeering enterprise'' to obstruct justice. Among the charges are allegations that Aguilar approached two fellow judges to try to influence the outcomes of cases, that he helped his former secretary remain a fugitive, that he tipped off a co-defendant about wiretaps and that he told a witness to lie to the grand jury. As jury selection began, prosecutors unveiled a witness list that includes three other federal judges, Aguilar's former girlfriend, two of his brothers and a nephew. Lawyers expect the trial to last six weeks. Conviction carries maximum penalties of 55 years in prison and $2 million in fines. Aguilar, who has remained in office and is handling some cases, can be removed only by Congress. He is a 1980 appointee of President Carter and is based in San Jose. Defense lawyers, speaking before a gag order was imposed in the case, accused the Justice Department of targeting Aguilar as a liberal Hispanic who has ruled against the government in important cases. Aguilar is the fourth federal judge to be indicted in this decade. The others, Harry Claiborne of Nevada, Alcee Hastings of Florida and Walter Nixon of Mississippi, were all impeached and removed by Congress, although Hastings was acquitted of the criminal charge against him. Aguilar's co-defendants are Rudy Tham, 66, a former Teamster leader and convicted embezzler, and Abe Chapman, 83, a self-styled former mobster who is related to Aguilar by marriage. U.S. District Judge Louis Bechtle, a visiting judge from Philadelphia who is presiding over the trial, finished a series of pretrial rulings generally unfavorable to the defense by rejecting motions to prohibit wiretap evidence against Aguilar and his co-defendants. Aguilar's home and chambers were wiretapped for several months beginning in January 1988, and he was also tape-recorded by one of Tham's lawyers who was cooperating with the FBI. Aguilar is accused of approaching two other federal judges seeking favorable treatment for Tham and another man; of trying to help Tham get a new trial while Tham arranged a job for Aguilar's brother; and of tipping Chapman that his phone was being tapped. Bechtle also denied motions by Tham and Chapman for separate trials.

DOC.HEAD: Agriculture Secretary: Rural Electric Agency Will Survive
DOC.TEXT: A federal money-lending agency for rural electric cooperatives that serve about 25 million people will not be dismantled by the Bush administration, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Monday. He warned, however, that the Rural Electrification Administration, which is part of his department, is in for some changes in the way it operates. ``We need to make it a more-efficient administration,'' Yeutter told about 12,000 people at the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association's annual meeting. The association represents the nation's 1,000 non-profit, consumer-owned rural electric systems in 46 states. It is a major recipient of loans from the REA, which was created in 1935. During Ronald Reagan's administration, White House officials and some congressional leaders proposed a phaseout of the REA, contending it was unneeded and inefficient. ``There will be no more confrontational mode. ... That will never happen during the Bush administration,'' Yeutter said to cheers from the crowd of rural leaders from around the country. But because of current budget priorities, REA will ``not be able to afford the level of direct lending we've had in the past,'' he said. The REA's budget for the current fiscal year is about $1.4 billion, said association spokesman Thomas Hoy. The Bush administration proposes cutting the agency's budget in the next fiscal year to $200 million, an 86 percent reduction, Hoy said. Hoy called the proposed cut ``devastating.'' Bob Bergland, a former Agriculture secretary who heads the Washington, D.C.-based association, was scheduled to address the 48th annual meeting Tuesday to detail the potential impact of the reduction on rural electric programs. Officials of President Bush's administration said in a recently announced rural development plan that they want REA to take a strong role in rural economic development efforts. Yeutter said one of the future challenges for REA and rural leaders in general will be providing leadership in non-farm programs, such as clean air and groundwater protection and development of alternative fuels. The administration is setting up a president's council on rural America to advise federal officials. It also wants to set up state rural development councils and demonstration programs.

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: their irreversibility.
DOC.TEXT: People welcome what has been done to enhance the role of legislative bodies and divide the functions of party and state bodies. At the same time, they express clear dissatisfaction with the lack of decisive actions where they are needed. The question has been raised to form an institute of presidency with all necessary powers to implement the policy of perestroika. The draft platform naturally speaks about this concisely, stressing the need to act without delay.

Democratization and creating a law-based state and a self-governing socialist society remain the principal directions of our development. Comrades, naturally the draft platform speaks about the international aspect of perestroika, about the modern world outlook that defines our foreign policy strategy.

This policy meets our internal requirements, strengthens the international positions of the Soviet state, raises its prestige, favors forming civilized relations all over the world and brings mankind closer to a peaceful period in its development. The all-important thing for us now is to push forward the negotiating disarmament process, deepen dialogue and mutual understanding on crucial sections of international development, and facilitate in every way efforts to expand and strengthen the ground that was covered in building a common European home. It is important to upgrade within its framework allied relations with East European countries, which really need this.

The situation in the world did improve in recent years, but the danger of war is still preserved. The doctrines and concepts of the United States and NATO, which are far from being defensive, remain in force. Their armies and military budgets also exist. This is why we need well-trained and well-equipped armed forces. Certainly, they need improvement and restructuring. But there should be a more responsible approach to changing the principle of their staffing and their construction as a whole in the context of changes in the world situation. Some questions have arisen in view of the ongoing and possible reductions in troops and armaments. Specifically, apprehensions are expressed if this does not weaken the country's defense capability. Evidently, additional explanations are necessary here to show that the reduction and reorganization of the armed forces is being carried out strictly in conformity with the principle of reasonable sufficiency for defense, reliable defence.

And one more serious issue. It concerns mass media coverage of life in the army and the navy. It should be truthful and respectful to the Soviet army, to officers' and soldiers' military service. We cannot agree with anti-army propaganda. Our people will not allow this.

Comrades, I want to say for one more time that the pivotal idea of restructuring the party itself is in asserting the power of party masses. In this connection, we are to recomprehend, among others, the role of primary organizations in what concerns admission to the party and quitting it, using membership dues, and implementing the tasks related to the new role of the party as the political vanguard. The role of district and city organizations should be revised and their rights should be considerably broadened. We should change the system of forming party bodies at all levels. We need a new, effective election mechanism that should also be sealed in the rules.

The future rules should definitely say that all elective bodies, from top to bottom, must be under control of and accountable to Communists and that the apparatus must be under control of and accountable to elective bodies. We have long been concerned by the fact that inner-life of the party and its functioning do not give party members the possibility to participate regularly in the formation of its policy. Much has been said about it but still we have no mechanism to translate this idea into life.

We should call for the vigorous representation of the most active, advanced workers and farmers, who are well-known in the party, in all elective bodies of the party, including the Central Committee. Glasnost in the work of the party's leadership, including the Central Committee and bodies elected by it, should be ensured on a larger scale than before. Then Communists will know everything and will be able to make conscientious judgments, conclusions and proposals. We are increasing Communists' real participation in the formation of the policy also by giving party bodies the possibility to develop their own platforms on various problems of social development in the context of one or another region.

The draft platform includes a proposal on changing the structure of the upper party bodies. The meaning of this proposal is not just to rename them and thus show our readiness for renewal. They are intended to strengthen the factor of democratization in the party leadership and simultaneously to create the best conditions for its activity as a working collective. One may ask, why reduce the Central Committee? Let us discuss it. We proceeded from the need to turn the Central Committee into a body working on a permanent basis. We should also depart from the principle of electing to the Central Committee mainly people holding certain posts. This principle was actually an expression of the party-and-state system of power in the country. We think these changes will help strengthen the Central Committee's ties with party organizations, because these ties will be maintained not through the apparatus but mainly through elected members of the Central Committee. ... It would be appropriate to speak here also about the central party apparatus. It is clear that the change of the party's role should entail changes in the qualitative composition of the apparatus. It should become an assistant of the Central Committee and work strictly under its control.

DOC.HEAD: Three Suspected Collaborators Killed, Factions Fight
With AM-Bus Attack, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 4 grafs at end with report CBS stringer roughed up by troops; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A pregnant nurse and her husband were stabbed to death by masked Palestinians Monday on suspicion of collaborating with Israel, and doctors were unable to save their unborn child, Arab reports said. Army sources confirmed the deaths in the town of Khan Yunis in the occupied Gaza Strip and said police were investigating. The slayings of Jamil Rizik El-Bayouk, 45, and his wife, Intissar, 40, followed the weekend slayings of two other suspected collaborators in the Gaza Strip and the discovery of an alleged collaborator's body near the West Bank town of Tulkarem. Arab reports said the West Bank victim, Rafeek Shawahneh, 35, from the village of Kufr Thulth, was stabbed and beaten to death. He was kidnapped two days earlier, and the reports said he was suspected of collaborating and selling land to Israelis. The deaths raised to 181 the number of Palestinians killed by fellow Arabs during the nearly 26-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Most have been slain on suspicion of collaboration, but some were killed for alleged drug dealing or prostitution. Since the revolt began in December 1987, 651 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 43 Israelis have died. Collaborator killings have declined in the West Bank since an appeal issued in mid-December on behalf of PLO leader Yasser Arafat to show more caution in dealing with suspected traitors. But such killings have continued in the Gaza Strip, where Islamic fundamentalist groups operate alongside pro-PLO factions. Arab reports said Mrs. El-Bayouk was seven months pregnant and that doctors at Nasser Hospital performed an emergency Caesarian section but were unable to save her child. Mrs. El-Bayouk worked as a nurse at the hospital. On Oct. 26, a nurse was stabbed to death inside Nasser Hospital, and several weeks later another nurse from the same hospital survived an attack in her home. At the time, Arab reports said the two women accused of giving the names of Palestinians being treated in the hospital to Israeli authorities. Wounded Palestinians who come for treatment to hospitals often given false names to avoid later arrest. Also Monday, clashes were reported in the Tulkarem refugee camp between supporters of the Islamic fundamentalist group Hamas, or Zeal, and members of pro-PLO factions. At least 10 people, aged 9 to 35, were injured, Arab reports said. They were treated and released at the nearby Tulkarem Hospital, they said. The clash involved clubs, knives and stones, Arab reports said. They said army troops intervened with tear gas and rubber bullets to break up the melee. In another incident, a Palestinian stringer for CBS-TV was roughed up by Israeli troops, who damaged his camera and confiscated videotape of a demonstration he was covering in Gaza City, according to Arab reports. The correspondent, Taher Shriteh, was treated for bruises at Shifa Hospital and released, they said. He also works as a stringer for the London-based Reuters news agency. Michael Rosenbaum, CBS bureau chief in Tel Aviv, confirmed the incident and said a complaint will be filed with Israeli military authorities. ``He is an accredited journalist trying to do his job, and this is an outrageous incident,'' Rosenbaum said.

DOC.HEAD: Sihanouk Says He Will Return to Cambodia to Live
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's Prince Norodom Sihanouk said Monday he would return to live in one of Cambodia's ``liberated zones'' by the end of the month. ``As a patriotic Cambodian, my duty is to return to my much-loved country to live there in the midst of my people,'' Sihanouk said in a statement to the press. He said he planned to live in one of ``a certain number of liberated zones in the interior of Cambodia'' that are ``controlled and administered'' by his army. An assistant to Sihanouk's secretary, who identified himself only as Kim, said Sihanouk would live in an area ``liberated'' from Vietnam, but that an exact place had not been chosen. Vietnam, which invaded Cambodia in late 1978, said last fall that it had pulled out its last troops from Cambodia, but Sihanouk has charged most of Hanoi's troops remain in the country, disguised as Cambodian soldiers. Sihanouk, who was king of Cambodia from 1941-55 and head of state from 1960-70 after which he was deposed and formed a government-in-exile in Beijing, said he would ``install myself definitely in a liberated zone in Cambodia'' and ``occupy myself permanently with (the) well-being'' of his people. Two weeks ago, Sihanouk quit as president of a three-party coalition resistance fighting the Vietnamese occupation, but retained his title of president of the country. He said he would run for president if a political settlement is reached between the coalition and the Vietnam-backed Hun Sen government and general elections are held. Last week, Sihanouk changed the name, flag and anthem of the resistance coalition, which holds Cambodia's seat in the United Nations and is recognized as the legitimate government by most nations outside the Soviet-Vietnam bloc. Sihanouk said in his Monday statement that he would move by the end of the month, following brief, private visits to Thailand and Singapore. Sihanouk lives part-time in Beijing, as well as Paris and Pyongyang, North Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Frank Denies Allegation by Former Employee Gobie
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS new 4th graf: ``Frank's response,'' CORRECTS Gobie's 1st name in 2nd graf, Stephen sted Steven
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., denied Monday a report that he offered $10,000 to $12,000 to help a male prostitute get a new start in Florida after they quarreled about the man's activities in Frank's rented townhouse. ``It's totally bizarre,'' Frank said of the report attributed to Stephen Gobie in an article in the new issue of Penthouse magazine. ``It's the first time I ever heard of it.'' The House ethics committee is investigating an allegation that Frank, an acknowledged homosexual, knew Gobie was operating a prostitution business from Frank's Capitol Hill home. Frank has denied the allegation. Frank's response to the Penthouse article came the same day his office made public campaign finance figures for 1989 indicating that he raised $103,476 last year, most of it after Gobie's allegations were made public. Only a handful of the contributions came from constituents; the rest were from political action committees and individuals outside the district or the state. Frank, 49, has acknowledged paying $80 to Gobie for an initial sexual encounter. He says that after that they became friends and he gave Gobie a job as a personal aide, housekeeper and driver, firing him after learning Gobie was using the apartment as a business base. Gobie is quoted as saying in the Penthouse article that he and Frank argued after the congressman's landlord learned Gobie was operating a sex-for-hire business in the apartment. ``I told him I needed $2,000 or $3,000 to move to Florida,'' Gobie is quoted as saying. ``I thought Washington had tapped out for me. Barney offered me $10,000 to $12,000, but I said, `I don't need that much.''' The article does not say whether Gobie said he received any money. He has remained in Washington. Frank said the report was ``totally bizarre ... as is virtually all of the new information'' in the Penthouse article by Art Harris and Rudy Maxa. The congressman said there was ``partial truth to one story'' told by Gobie in the article ``even though he gets it wrong.'' Gobie is quoted as saying, ``One day, at a restaurant, Barney stood up to a bunch of Marines razzing a table of gays. They were sashaying around with limp wrists and laughing. So Barney says, `My name's Congressman Barney Frank. Do you guys have a problem? Were you harassing these men because they are gay?' He got their commanding officer's name and reported them.'' Frank said, ``Yeah, I was in Mr. Henry's on Capitol Hill when some Marines were hassling some guys and I went over and identified myself and told them to stop. But I never gave their names to the Marine Corps, because it was right after the Lebanon bombing and I figured they were upset and I'd give them a pass on it.'' A Marine Corps barracks in Lebanon was bombed on Oct. 23, 1983, and 241 servicemen were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Accuse Secord of Bad Faith
DOC.TEXT: Richard Secord is trying to circumvent his plea bargain by appealing his conviction, Iran-Contra prosecutors said Monday in asking a federal judge to delay dismissal of 11 felony charges or reinstate them against the retired Air Force major general. In a court filing, the prosecutors also said they may ask U.S. District Court Judge Aubrey Robinson to throw out Secord's plea agreement with the government and seek to put him on trial on all 12 of the charges he once faced. Secord filed a notice of appeal Jan. 25, one day after he was placed on two years' probation following a guilty plea to a charge of making a false statement to congressional investigators. As part of the plea agreement, the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh agreed not to prosecute Secord on eight counts of perjury and other counts alleging conspiracy to pay illegal gratuities to Oliver North, offering and paying North an illegal gratuity and obstruction of Congress. Prosecutors now are asking that ``the court delay final dismissal ... pending completiton'' of Secord's appeal or alternatively, ``reconsider dismissal of charges already dismissed.'' The decision to appeal is ``a clear violation of the spirit'' of the plea agreement and Iran-Contra prosecutors ``will oppose ... his attempt to reopen what should be a settled conviction,'' Walsh's office said. ``The government regards it as an act of bad faith to agree to plead guilty with the undisclosed intent to challenge the validity of the plea,'' said the prosecutors. The appeal is based on a contention by Secord's lawyers that Walsh lacks jurisdiction to prosecute for an offense arising out of Secord's testimony to Congress. Thomas Green, Secord's lawyer, said after Secord was sentenced Jan. 24 that if the appeals court were to uphold his position, ``that would result in a reversal and vacating'' of the conviction. Secord, who paid for a $13,800 security system at Oliver North's home, pleaded guilty to lying when he told investigators in a deposition in 1987 that he was unaware of any Iran-Contra proceeds going to North. The Enterprise was the network of offshore companies and secret accounts Secord and business partner Albert Hakim set up to handle money in the Iran-Contra affair raised by overcharging Iran for arms sold that country in secret.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect Arrested in Bus Attack, Shamir Criticizes Egypt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs with suspected attacker under arrest, INSERTS 2 grafs after 27th pvs to ADD details about car used in attack; pickup 28th pvs, `Authorities immediately...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CAI5, TLV5
DOC.TEXT: Egyptian authorities Monday arrested a suspect in the desert bus attack in which nine Israelis were killed and said the man was a Palestinian who went to Egypt two weeks ago with his accomplices. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir demanded that Egypt track down all of those involved in the Sunday attack and punish them, and Israelis mourned their dead with silence and screams of anguish. Egypt's state-owned Middle East New Agency quoted an unidentified police official as saying Monday night that one suspect had been arrested but gave no further details. Israeli leaders said the latest Middle East peace efforts should not be thwarted by public outrage over Sunday's attack _ the worst on Israelis in Egypt since the two countries signed a peace treaty in 1979. Newspaper editorials noted, however, that the incident would almost certainly boost support for hard-line views toward Arabs. Israeli victims flown home by military jet from Egypt's capital gave harrowing accounts of the several minutes during which two gunmen on a desert road raked their bus with gunfire and hurled grenades inside. ``Everyone saw his death,'' said Professor Yigal Barak, a passenger who was unhurt.``There was nobody who could protect us, nobody carried any weapons.'' ``I felt like a Jew who is facing the Nazis,'' said Judith Benjamini, 63, of Tel Aviv, describing the death of her 72-year-old husband, Ishachar. All the dead were Israelis, and there were 21 people wounded, including an Egyptian tour guide. In Washington, the State Department called the attack an ``outrageous act'' designed to halt efforts toward reconciliation and dialogue between Arabs and Israelis. President Bush called Shamir to express his sorrow and Secretary of State James A. Baker III relayed a similar message in calls to the Israeli and Egyptian foreign ministers, department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said. Shamir told Parliament: ``Our first demand from Egyptian leaders is to find the perpetrators of the crime and bring them to speedy trial and punish them severely.'' He said Israel would go ahead with its peace initiative calling for Palestinian elections but also would try to ``liquidate blood-thirsty'' terrorism. He noted that Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak had telephoned him at midnight Monday to apologize for the attack. ``I thanked him for his words, but I want to point out that we view Egypt as responsible for the safety and security of Israeli citizens who visit Egypt,'' Shamir said. ``It is inconceivable that Israelis will repeatedly be victims of attacks by murderers who exploit Egyptian soil for their evil and murderous plots.'' Mubarak denounced the attack as a ``monstrous aggression ... directed primarily'' against his efforts for Israeli-Palestinian talks as a step toward Shamir's election plan. An Israeli extremist group telephoned a bomb threat to an office of the national Itim News Agency, saying an explosive was planted at Islam's sacred Dome of the Rock mosque in Jerusalem. Police searched the area and found no bomb. While Israelis mourned the dead, some with silence and some with anguished screams, leaders on the left and right hardened their stands on whether it is time to move toward peace with the Palestinians. Trade Minister Ariel Sharon, a member of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc but a foe of the prime minister's plan for elections to choose Palestinian peace negotiators, said Egypt had no right to press on with efforts to start an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue. ``The positions of Egypt and the PLO are the same,'' he told Israel army radio. But Finance Minister Shimon Peres, leader of the center-left Labor Party, said on Israel radio ``that the peace process should not be stopped by a few mad terrorists.'' The attack gave Shamir a respite from challenges to his leadership of Likud by Sharon and other hard-liners. Sharon agreed to postpone for a week a showdown session on the government's peace plan that was scheduled for Wednesday. But Israeli newspaper editorials noted that the attack could could help the hardliners gain ground. ``This fearsome crime will no doubt also makes its mark on efforts to get the peace wagon moving again,'' wrote the mass-circulation Yediot Ahronot daily. ``Again there will be doubts about the value of a signature on a piece of paper in the face of deep hatreds that remained ingrained in the heart,'' the editorial said. Two unknown Moslem fundamentalist groups, meanwhile, claimed responsibility for the attack. In Cairo, an unidentified caller said the Organization for the Defense of Oppressed in Egyptian Prisons carried out the attack in retaliation for alleged torture in Egyptian jails. In the Jordanian capital of Amman, a handwritten message to the French news agency Agence France Presse claimed the assault was carried out by a group called the Islamic Jihad-Holy War Jerusalem group, but it was unclear if it was connected to any of several groups using that name. Egyptian investigators said they found the white Peugeot sedan used in the attack beside a road in the Nile River delta, and that they had clues to the attackers. The Egyptian news agency identified the owner of the car as Fat'hia Ahmed Abdel-Aal, and said she is an Egyptian citizen who rents her car to tourist companies. It quoted a police official as saying the attackers hired the car several days ago to use it in their attack. No further details were given. Authorities immediately tightened security in Cairo's southern suburb of Maadi, where many Israeli diplomats live. Police threw up barricades and checked cars in the suburb, where Egyptian gunmen attacked Israeli diplomats in 1984 and 1985. A state of alert was also declared in Egypt's sea ports and airports to prevent the gunmen from fleeing the country.

DOC.HEAD: Families of British Hostages Ask Rushdie Not to Publish Paperback
