DOC.TEXT: Relatives of British hostages held in Lebanon asked author Salman Rushdie on Monday not to publish a paperback edition of ``The Satanic Verses,'' which some Moslems consider slanderous. ``We believe the time has come to balance the principle of free speech against that of self restraint, which is also necessary in a civilized society,'' the families said in a statement. It was issued through the archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, and signed by Frances and David Waite, wife and brother of Runcie's envoy Terry Waite, and by close relatives of the three other missing Britons. Eight Americans also are held in Lebanon, including Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, who was abducted March 16, 1985, and is the captive held longest. Most of the hostages are believed in the hands of Shiite Moslems loyal to Iran. the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini pronounced a death sentence on Rushdie a year ago _ Feb. 14, 1989 _ and the novelist has been in hiding since. Monday's statement from the British families said his book had caused ``grave offense to Moslems throughout the world,'' and argued that free speech had been upheld by its large sales in hard cover. Rushdie, 42, a naturalized Briton born to a Moslem family in India, has been under police guard at an undisclosed location since Khomeini urged Moslems to kill him. The decree was not lifted when Khomeini died in June. ``Given the predictably grave damage likely to be caused, we believe that further publication on the grounds of upholding free speech would be both misconceived and irresponsible,'' the families said. Viking Penguin, Rushdie's publishers, reiterated Monday night that no decision had been made about a paperback edition. The relatives' made their appeal the day after a London newspaper published a 7,000-word essay by Rushdie defending his book and saying he regretted the offense caused. British Moslem leaders dismissed the essay, but members of London's literary establishment credited the author with a brilliant defense of free speech. Family members feel Rushdie has made matters worse for the captives. ``Is it worth it to publish a paperback for this notion of freedom of speech when freedom of individuals and indeed his own liberty is at stake?'' Waite's cousin, John Waite, asked in a television interview. ``If he thinks along those lines, I'm sure he will feel a spirit of compromise means: Don't publish the paperback.'' Novelist Martin Amis countered: ``Should we deprive ourselves of certain freedoms just to humor terrorists, to make them feel better? Stringing up Salman Rushdie would make them feel better still. It is not something we consider.'' Terry Waite disappeared in Beirut on Jan. 20, 1987, while trying to win the release of American captives. The other missing Britons are television journalist John McCarthy, and teacher Brian Keenan, both missing since April 1986, and retired pilot Jack Mann, who vanished last May. Keenan also has Irish nationality. They are among 18 Westerners missing in Lebanon, including the eight Americans.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Lawyers Ridicule Prosecution Evidence in Gotti Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with Gotti's comments on chances for acquittal, DELETE now-redundant first reference to prosecutor; picks up 12th graf, `Prosecutors say...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY33
DOC.TEXT: Defense lawyers at John Gotti's assault trial urged the jury Monday to reject ``Mafia hysteria'' and acquit the reputed mob boss of charges he ordered the revenge shooting of a union leader. Lawyers Bruce Cutler and Gerald Shargel, representing Gotti and a co-defendant, ridiculed the quality of the prosecution's key evidence _ poor quality audio tapes secretly recorded in 1986 at Gotti's hangout in the borough of Queens and in a visiting room at the Rikers Island jail. A prosecutor defended the state's evidence during his closing statement, saying, ``Gotti had the motivation and he ordered the shooting'' of John F. O'Connor, former vice president of Carpenters Union Local 608. After a three-hour closing argument from Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky, Gotti said of his chances for acquittal: ``There's no problem; there's never been a problem.'' The jury was expected to hear final instructions from Acting Justice Edward McLaughlin and begin deliberating Tuesday. The defense lawyers disparaged the truthfulness of criminals who were prosecution witnesses, saying they were lying to save themselves. They cited Vincent ``the Fish'' Cafaro, an admitted former Mafioso who is now a government informer and witness. Cafaro testified about the Mafia's structure but said he knew nothing about the case against Gotti. Cutler, Gotti's lawyer, told the jury that although Cafaro knew nothing about the case, ``he was put on to spread the poison, so you'll say, `Well, somebody's a gangster so we'll convict him anyway.''' ``We are in America,'' Cutler said. ``That's not how it's supposed to be. People are not supposed to be convicted because of who they are, who their friends are, what their background is.'' Shargel said prosecutors suffer from ``a disease that will cause them to do anything to get John Gotti.'' Gotti, 49, reputed head of the Gambino gang, and reputed mob associate Anthony Guerrieri, 61, are charged with ordering the May 7, 1986, shooting of O'Connor. Cherkasky asked the jury to study the daily court transcript of the trial. ``We truly believe that if you continue to look at the evidence, the evidence is overwhelming of guilt,'' he said. Prosecutors say Gotti had the Westies, a gang from Hell's Kitchen on Manhattan's West Side, shoot O'Connor because in February 1986 O'Connor allegedly ordered goons to trash Bankers and Brokers, a mob-run restaurant in lower Manhattan, for using non-union labor. Shargel, Guerrieri's lawyer, said there is absolutely no proof that Gotti and his client ordered the shooting of O'Connor. O'Connor, who has recovered from at least four shots in the buttocks, testified for the defense but he invoked his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination several times when cross-examined by Assistant District Attorney Michael Cherkasky. O'Connor has been charged in a 127-count indictment with extortion, perjury, larceny and labor racketeering. His case is supposed to start soon. The principal witness linking Gotti to the O'Connor shooting was James ``Studs'' McElroy, 45, a former Westies gang member who is serving a 60-year federal sentence. McElroy testified that he went to the funeral of reputed Gambino underboss Frank DeCicco and was introduced as the Westie who was going to ``whack'' O'Connor. Cutler called McElroy ``a psychopathic maniac'' who once cut a man's throat for $100 and lied on the stand to help his girlfriend get favorable treatment in a drug case and increase his own chances of getting out of jail. ``James McElroy is saying what he knows the prosecutors want to hear,'' Shargel said. ``When the smoke clears, you will realize one thing _ that there is no proof, let alone proof beyond a reasonable doubt, that John Gotti and Anthony Guerrieri had John O'Connor shot,'' Shargel said. ``The evidence they have put before you is riddled with doubt and infested with uncertainty.'' On the subject of the tape recordings, the defense pointed out that transcripts of the same conversations used in a federal court trial differed from transcripts in this trial in state Supreme Court, a trial level court in New York state. ``You've seen time and again that they misinterpreted on the tapes,'' Shargel said. The defense lawyers say a key sentence on tape, in which Gotti allegedly says, ``We're gonna, gonna bust him up,'' is inaudible. ``They (prosecutors) know full well that the tapes don't prove the case. If they did, John Gotti and Anthony Guerrieri would have been arrested in 1986, not in 1989,'' Shargel said.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Department Proposes Further Limits on Cancer-Causing Agent
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Department proposed Monday that permissible workplace exposure to cadmium, a potential cancer-causing substance used in batteries, paint and plastics, be reduced by at least 95 percent. The new standard would affect 512,000 workers in a variety of industries, according to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Cadmium is a soft metal found in lead, copper and zinc sulfide ores and is used, among other things, as an anti-corrosive and in batteries. Plastics, ceramic and paint manufacturers also use it, as do metal machining and welding firms. Permissible exposure limits currently are 100 micrograms per cubic meter of air for cadmium fumes, 200 micrograms for cadmium dust, averaged over an eight-hour shift. OSHA proposed to reduce those limits to 5 micrograms or 1 microgram for all cadmium compounds and asked for comment on which limit should be chosen. The agency said the lower limit could prevent 14 cancer deaths and as many as 189 cases of kidney damage each year. A short-term exposure limit was proposed to guard against heavy exposure to cadmium for short periods that would not violate the eight-hour standard. The short-term standard would limit 15-minute exposures to five times the concentration specified in the eight-hour standard. The agency estimated a 95 percent reduction would cost businesses nearly $57 million a year while the 99 percent reduction would cost about $160 million. Most of the difference includes additional costs for engineering controls, respirators and hygiene facilities necessary to achieve the lower limit. About half of the affected workers are already below the lower limit, said assistant secretary Gerard Scannell, who heads OSHA. The agency will hold hearings on the proposal in Washington in June and Denver in July. A decision is expected by around the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Asks Party to Give Up Right to Exclusive Power
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with speech details, quotes, background. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev told the Communist Party on Monday it must give up its unchallenged right to rule the Soviet Union to the tide of democratic reform he let loose five years ago. In a historic speech to the party's Central Committee in the Kremlin, he tacitly acknowledged the growing power of the pro-democracy movement that has toppled Communist regimes in Eastern Europe, set several Soviet republics on the road to multiparty politics, and on Sunday drew huge protests in Moscow. But his move was unlikely to bring about the disintegration of the Communist Party, and Gorbachev, who is both party chief and head of government, did not address the possibility of the party losing power. The Communist Party's leading role in society, a tenet of Soviet socialism that excluded any other political forces since Vladimir I. Lenin founded the Soviet Union during World War I, was formalized in the Soviet Constitution in 1977. The party wants to remain the leading force in society but must prove its worthiness, earning the right to govern instead of taking it for granted, Gorbachev said. In the future the party ``intends to struggle for the role of ruling party, but do it strictly in the framework of the democratic process, rejecting any kind of legal or political advantage,'' Gorbachev said. Political reform that has strengthened the Soviet government at the expense of an all-controling party apparatus, ``has been accompanied by a growth in political pluralism,'' Gorbachev said, presenting a draft platform to the 249-member Central Committee. ``This process can lead to the creation of parties at some stage.'' Central Committee sources said Gorbachev told the closed meeting that political changes he has pushed through since taking power in March 1985 have in effect created a multiparty system already. In his speech, Gorbachev called into question another tenet of Leninism _ democratic centralism, the theory that requires strict adherance by the party's 20 million members to decisions once they have been made at the top. ``The party's renewal presupposes its thorough, comprehensive democratization and rethinking the principle of democratic centralism with emphasis on democracy and power of the party masses,'' Gorbachev said. He proposed the Central Committee meet again in about three weeks to consider new party rules. It will reconvene its present session on Tuesday. The sources said that in contrast to usual practice, there was no applause for Politburo members when they entered the hall at the beginning of the day, nor any applause for any of the 28 speeches during the session. Gorbachev interrupted the proceedings to give his opinions only once or twice after he spoke, unlike previous Central Committee meetings, they said. The Soviet leader used strong terms to defend himself, his policies and actions. He named as some enemies of his reform policies ``representatives of the shadow economy, a veritable mafia that is fanning the flames of ethnic strife and putting pressure on state bodies under the slogans of national revival.'' He said soldiers had to be sent to the Azerbaijan republic because ``a coup attempt _ nothing more, nothing less'' was being attempted. Gorbachev said power changes were needed to get things done. ``At present, from the viewpoint of strategic tasks and in view of current realities, it is necessary to realign forces in the upper echelons of power in order to give more dynamism to perestroika processes and ensure more firmly their irreversibility,'' he declared. He also cautioned that while the world situation has improved, the danger of war remains _ ``The doctrines and concepts of the United States and NATO, which are far from being defensive, remain in force.'' Gorbachev indicated that he did not foresee the reform overturning the country's socialist system as well as the communists' assurance of power. The party was ``ready to act with due account for these new circumstances, cooperate and conduct a dialogue with all organizations honoring the Soviet Constitution and the social system it endorses,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: MOSCOW: to power.
DOC.TEXT: The two-day Central Committee meeting had shaped up as a major struggle between reformers and conservatives over the party's future. Rumors emerged that conservatives would accuse Gorbachev of bringing on economic collapse and ethnic unrest with his reforms. The Soviet president said he had hoped 1989 would be the turning point for his economic reforms, but acknowledged that ``recent events have shown there has been no change for the better.'' Gorbachev's address Monday granted the basic demands of the hundreds of thousands of people who swept 60 abreast through the streets of the capital on Sunday. Communist reformers and non-Communists demanded the party give up its exclusive claim to power. Reformer Boris N. Yeltsin, a leader of the rally, told the Central Committee the new platform did not go far enough. ``In general, the impression is formed that it was written by two hands _ both the left and the right,'' he said. Small political parties already are forming in the Baltic republics, where Communist leaders are leading the drive to eliminate the party's guaranteed role. Gorbachev said in Lithuania last month it would be ``no tragedy'' if a multiparty system evolved, but that such a system was not a panacea. Transcripts released by the Tass news agency indicated Gorbachev underwent immediate, stinging criticism at the Central Committee meeting for a lack of decisiveness. ``Is it not time for you, Mikhail Sergeyevich, and the leadership of the country as a whole to seriously think about the fate of the socialist government, over the fate of honest laboring people, and take the most direct radical measures before it's too late?'' asked the first speaker, Kiev party chief A.I. Kornienko. The ambassador to Poland, Vladimir I. Borovikov, also gave a strong speech urging faster reforms, said several Central Committee sources. One Central Committee source said Leningrad party chief Boris Gidaspov, who has become a lightning rod for conservatives, demanded the establishment of strict law and order in the country. Despite the criticism, Gorbachev was in firm control of the meeting and there was no organized effort to oust him or limit his power, the source said. The source said many of the 27 speakers who followed Gorbachev criticized his proposed platform for being too general, and that a commission of about 60 members was formed to rework it overnight. Gorbachev was appointed head of the commission, he said. There was little criticism in the meeting of Gorbachev's proposal to strike the party's constitutional claim to exclusive power, Central Committee members said. They predicted it would be approved handily. More than 1,000 people, including 240 Central Committee members, 100 non-voting members, military district commanders and local party and government officials attended the meeting, the source said. But only full Central Committee members will be allowed to vote on the platform Tuesday, he said. Gorbachev also said the Communist Party's views on managing the economy and the government no longer should be pressed on Soviet society as a whole. The Soviet leader called on the Central Committee to move up to late June the next party Congress, theoretically the party's most powerful body, which would be charged with electing a new Central Committee and leadership. Congresses normally are held every five years, and the next would have been regularly scheduled for spring 1991. But Gorbachev last year moved up the date of the Congress to this fall, and in his speech Monday called for it to be moved up again. Central Committee members interviewed outside the Kremlin at the end of the day's session also said Gorbachev proposed structural changes in the party and the government. Svyatoslav Fyodorov, a well-known eye surgeon and participant in the meeting, said the platform included creation of a stronger presidency with powers like that of the French or U.S. president. Vladimir Gusev, chairman of the Gorno-Altai regional party, said the Soviet leader proposed creating posts of two deputy chairmen of the Communist Party. Gorbachev also proposed reducing the size of the Central Committee, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: Calderon Says He's `Great Friend of United States'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Newspaper projections ... making number of minor party seats indefinite; SUBS 16th graf, Costa Rica ... INCLUDING name of Calderon's father.
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Rafael Angel Calderon said Monday he is ``a great friend of the United States'' and told a cheering crowd he hopes to turn his election victory into ``a triumph for all Costa Ricans.'' On May 8, Calderon will succeed Oscar Arias, who won the 1987 Nobel Peace Prize for developing and promoting the Central American peace plan. He attended Mass on Monday at the Roman Catholic Basilica de Los Angeles in Cartago, the colonial capital 15 miles east of here. ``I asked God to help me give the people of Costa Rica what the people deserve: a better future,'' he told 3,000 supporters gathered in downtown San Jose. Calderon, 40-year-old founder of the Social Christian Party, repeated campaign pledges to fight crime, poverty and poor housing, but got the biggest cheer when he asked for unity against drug trafficking and corruption. The festive crowd waved Costa Rican and red-and-blue Social Christian flags. People gave loud, good-natured jeers when a partisan of Carlos Manuel Castillo, candidate of the incumbent National Liberation Party, waved a green-and-white party flag from a balcony. By Monday afternoon, the official count showed Calderon leading Castillo by 656,282 votes to 604,396, with about 90 percent of precincts reporting. Castillo broke even in San Jose, the National Liberation Party stronghold. Calderon's Social Christians were sweeping most of the countryside. ``Today, we have elected liberty and democracy to the presidency of Costa Rica,'' Castillo said in a graceful concession speech Sunday night. Newspaper projections showed Calderon's party winning 29 or 30 of the 57 National Assembly seats, with National Liberation taking 25 and minor parties the remainder. Calderon, who visited Panama shortly after the Dec. 20 U.S. invasion, is a strong supporter of U.S. policy in the region. ``Costa Rica has elected a great friend of the people and government of the United States,'' he said in answer to a question Monday. ``I've always said Costa Rica and the United States are two countries very different in size and power, but very much alike in their battle for peace and democracy.'' He delivered his broadcast address of thanks to the nation from a balcony overlooking San Jose's central pedestrian mall, where even curious tourists joined the spirit of the occasion. The president-elect has expressed disappointment over U.S. aid for Costa Rica, set at about $90 million for 1990 and due to fall about 30 percent in 1991. Thousands of Calderon supporters celebrated into the early hours Monday, honking car horns and waving red-and-blue flags; the streets and the morning rush hour were quieter than normal as celebrants stayed home. Costa Rica celebrated 100 years of democracy in October; Calderon's victory marks the 10th straight peaceful election in Costa Rica since 1948, when his own father, Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia, tried to overturn the result. Calderon said he owed his victory to party organization and desire for change _ National Liberation candidates won the last two elections, beating Calderon both times. Calderon, generally seen as a conservative despite his populist rhetoric, has promised a new housing program for the poor while at the same time saying he would reduce the government's deficit spending. He proposal to require large companies to establish profit-sharing plans, something that has made some businessmen nervous.

DOC.HEAD: Helicopter Airlift from Cargo Ship; Two Die in Flood
With AM-France-Storm
DOC.TEXT: A helicopter Monday night plucked 10 people from a damaged British cargo ship drifting in a gale in the Atlantic, and flew them to Ireland, the coast guard reported. In northeastern England, police said the bodies of a man and his 13-year-old nephew, washed out of their van on Sunday as they tried to drive across a bridge on a flooded river, were found several miles away. Their dog was alive in the van. With gales and flooding hitting parts of Britain for a second week, the government announced emergency funds for damage in one of the hardest-hit areas, the Severn Valley in southwestern England. Ferry services between Wales and Ireland were disrupted Monday, and in Scotland there were landslides. A helicopter was sent to the stricken freighter, the Tribulus, after the captain asked that the wives of three crewmen and seven other people be taken off when the ship began taking on water 250 miles off the English coast. The captain said the 128,000-ton ship's iron ore cargo had expanded after the freighter began taking on water and ruptured the hull. The coast guard said 15 of the crew members, all Britons, remained on the vessel, which is owned by the Shell oil company. It was heading slowly toward Ireland Monday night.

DOC.HEAD: Dianne Feinstein, Andy Young Launch Campaigns for Governor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-11, `In his ...,' to UPDATE with speech given, edit quote to conform with delivery; picks up 12th graf, `An Atlanta ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA7
DOC.TEXT: Two former mayors _ San Franciso's Dianne Feinstein and Atlanta's Andrew Young _ launched campaigns Monday for the Democratic nomination for governor of their home states, California and Georgia. In other announcements Monday, Sen. Jim Exon, D-Neb., launched his bid for a third term and four-term Indianapolis Mayor William H. Hudnut said he was accepting the pleas of Republican leaders to run for secretary of state. Feinstein, 56, calling her campaign an historic step for women, said she would be a problem-solving governor who would improve California schools, provide health insurance to the uninsured and end the auto insurance crisis. Young, 57, also a former civil rights leader, ambassador, and congressman, sounded traditional campaign themes _ progress, education and holding down taxes _ in his bid to become Georgia's first black governor. Feinstein enters the race as an underdog both in polls and fund-raising to Democratic state Attorney General John Van de Kamp and Republican U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson. The incumbent, Republican George Deukmejian, is not seeking re-election this fall. She stressed her administrative experience as mayor of San Francisco for nine years, ending in 1988, saying she has the experience to ``be a governor who convinces, cajoles and, yes, even knocks heads to get the job done.'' Feinstein traveled to Los Angeles, Sacramento and San Francisco to announce her candidacy Monday. Young, who left office last month after eight years as Atlanta's mayor, has worked for months planning his Democratic campaign. After his kickoff Monday, he planned to begin a four-day driving tour of the state Tuesday. In his announcement, Young touched on two controversial topics, vowing to protect abortion rights and calling for a statewide vote on a lottery _ something that's been bottled up in the Georgia Legislature for years. Young spoke in his kickoff speech of a coalition campaign, with ``young and old, rural and suburban folks.'' He has traditionally eschewed direct racial messages, and he continued that strategy in his first official campaign speech. An Atlanta Journal-Constitution poll last fall showed Young with 38 percent of the Democratic vote. Four-term Lieutenant Gov. Zell Miller was second at 30 percent. Other Democratic challengers are state Sen. Roy E. Barnes and state Rep. Lauren W. McDonald Jr., and former Gov. Lester Maddox. The incumbent, Democrat Joe Frank Harris, is barred by the state constitution from seeking a third consecutive term. Georgia's Democratic primary is July 17 and if no candidate receives 50 per cent of the vote, a runoff is held Aug. 7 for the November election. Young, a key player in the civil rights movement, represented Atlanta in Congress from 1973-77. He was ambassador to the United Nations under President Carter and served as mayor of Atlanta beginning in 1982. Feinstein, who would be California's first woman governor if elected, also touched on the abortion issue in her speech and put special emphasis on seeking support of women voters. The primary is June 5 and general election is Nov. 6. ``And if I am elected, women can be sure that their governor not only supports their legal right to choice but personally believes in it too,'' she said. In Indianapolis, Hudnut, 57, will likely face Democratic incumbent Joseph H. Hogsett. Hogsett, 33, was appointed after Evan Bayh left that office to become governor.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes in Southern Colombia, All 15 Aboard Die
DOC.TEXT: A light aircraft slammed into a cloud-covered hillside early Monday in southern Colombia, killing all 15 people aboard, Red Cross officials said. The Grumman aircraft belonging to Helicol, a subsidiary of Avianca Airlines, crashed as it approached the airport in Ibague, a city 60 miles south of the capital Bogota. The plane had taken off from Neiva, 155 miles south of Bogota, at 9:05 a.m. Most of the passengers worked for the Colombian petroleum firm Hocol or Shell Oil Co., the radio network RCN reported. It added that the victims were all Colombians. A Red Cross spokesman, Ramiro Lozano, said in a radio interview that rescue workers located the plane and the bodies of the 11 passengers and four crew members on the slopes of a hill outside Ibague. Lozano quoted witnesses as saying they had seen fire engulfing the engines of the low-flying plane just before it crashed. The Red Cross worker said the plane had been flying just below a dense cloud cover. Helicol provides charter flights, primarily for executives of foreign oil companies operating in southern Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: President Extends Amnesty for Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos has extended for another year an amnesty for rebels trying to topple the government, the Angolan Embassy in Lisbon said Monday. The announcement came as government troops and rebels battled for control of the strategic Mavinga airstrip in southeastern Angola, which is on the way to the rebels' Jamba stronghold. According to an embassy statement, dos Santos said Sunday that the amnesty, which covers common crimes and crimes against state security, would be extended for a year from Sunday. Government sources in the Angolan capital, Luanda, said about 40,000 rebels have turned themselves in so far. The amnesty went into effect in December 1988 as an incentive for the rebels to end the 15-year-old civil war. But rebel leader Jonas Savimbi's National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) wants the Marxist, one-party state to hold free elections as a precondition for peace. The Portuguese news agency Lusa quoted an unidentified military source in Luanda as saying the rebels had launched a counterattack on Mavinga. Government forces were hampered by low supplies and could not consolidate their positions, Lusa quoted the source as saying. A military source had said Friday that two government columns had taken control of the airstrip and most of the town, 700 miles southeast of Luanda. The rebels denied the claims and Savimbi called for an all-out attack nationwide. According to Lusa, the rebels sabotaged Luanda's electricity supply lines Monday, depriving the capital of power for most the day. Earlier, the Angolan state news agency ANGOP reported that two members of the government's ruling party, the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), congratulated troops on Mavinga's capture but had differing views on how the civil war should end. Defense Minister Pedro Maria Tonha Sunday urged youngsters and soldiers in the southeastern garrison town of Cuito Cuanavale to fight until they defeat the rebels, the news agency said. It said former Interior Minister Alexandre Rodrigues called for a peaceful solution during ceremonies in the northern town of N'dalatando commemorating the 29th anniversary of the start of independence wars against former colonial power Portugal. Rodrigues spoke as a representative of dos Santos, and it was his first official appearance since he fell into disgrace in December 1988, accused of forming secret combat units without the president's knowledge. Rodrigues was fired as interior minister but remained in control of a key commission of MPLA and reportedly received support from hard-line party members. The rebels have fought to force the government to share power since Angola gained independence from Portugal in 1975. Savimbi and dos Santos agree to a truce in June, but it collapsed within weeks and efforts by U.S., Soviet, Portuguese and African diplomats have failed to persuade the two sides to resume negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: IMF Approves Credit for Poland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops with four grafs IMF action; two grafs edited for transition; picks up last graf pvs
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund said Monday it had approved standby credits for Poland equivalent to $723 million to support that country's economic stabilization program. Poland is trying to bring down an inflation rate that reached 650 percent last year while it moves to a market-based economy and balance its budget. Poland has arranged loans from the U.S. Treasury, the Bank for International Settlements and a fund from other western countries to stabilize the zloty on foreign exchange markets. It is the first time it has made use of IMF resources since it joined the fund in 1986. The IMF uses funds provided by member countries _ which include almost all the western nations _ to help member countries in economic trouble. became a member in 1986. The action was announced the same day that the Agriculture Department said it would send seven experts to Poland to help develop a private farm economy. The U.S. agricultural team, which will be in Poland from Tuesday through Feb. 15, will focus on Poland's needs in agricultural education and technical assistance for private farm production and marketing, said Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said. The mission will be headed by Myron D. Johnsrud, administrator of the Agriculture Department's extension service.

DOC.HEAD: News Photographer Killed in Lebanon Fighting
With AM-Lebanon, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Veteran Lebanese news photographer George Samerejian has died of wounds suffered during the weeklong fighting between rival Christian factions, authorities said. He was 42. Samerejian, an Armenian Christian, worked for Beirut's independent An-Nahar daily and was elected chairman of Lebanon's News Photographers Syndicate in December. He was hit in the head last Wednesday by a stray bullet and died Saturday. The photographer was one of the handful of journalists to have covered the civil war since it began in April 1975. He survived countless battles and two Israeli invasions and had the reputation of leading a charmed life, though he was wounded once before and was twice kidnapped by Moslems. Samerejian was among more than 150,000 people who have died in nearly 15 years of war here and the 12th journalist to be killed in the conflict. He was wounded fatally while covering street battles in east Beirut between rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's troops and the Lebanese Forces militia led by Samir Geagea. Samerejian was taken to a hospital but no surgeon could get there to operate on him because of fierce house-to-house fighting. The Red Cross got him to the American University Hospital in the western Moslem sector on Thursday. Surgeons removed the bullet that shattered his brain, but he died Saturday without regaining consciousness. An-Nahar Editor Francois Akl wrote of Samerejian: ``Throughout his outstanding career, George was noted for his fearless determination to be on the scene regardless of the risks involved. ``He was the ideal example of the news photographer, whose eye instantly catches what his camera should record.'' Mohammed Baalbaki, chairman of Lebanon's Press Syndicate, said in a eulogy: ``Journalism in Lebanon has become a profession of death and George Samerejian is one of its esteemed martyrs.'' A sniper shot Samerejian in the left leg in west Beirut on Dec. 9, 1975, early in the civil war, but after 35 days in a hospital bed, Samerejian was back shooting pictures of the fighting. An-Nahar said he was kidnapped twice by different Moslem factions, but in both instances emerged less than a week later, ``and when he came out his captors had become close friends.'' Samerejian was in south Lebanon in 1978, when the Israeli army invaded to drive out Palestinian guerrillas. An old Lebanese woman hid him in her cellar for three days and helped him sneak through the Israeli forces to safety. ``I was in agony when Israeli tanks rumbled over my hideout and I couldn't take pictures of them,'' Samerejian wrote. He covered the second Israeli invasion in 1982, including the 28-day bombardment of west Beirut. Samerejian is survived by his wife and two daughters.

DOC.HEAD: Two Soldiers Killed by Land Mine; Maoist Rebels Slay 4 Civilians
DOC.TEXT: An army captain and a sergeant were killed and seven soldiers wounded when a land mine set by Shining Path insurgents exploded under their passing truck, the military said Monday. Police in Ayacucho said Shining Path assassins also killed four residents in two shantytowns last weekend. The attack on the military truck occurred Sunday, 30 miles north of this state capital, which is in the Andes 235 miles southeast of Lima. The army said the truck was the first in a convoy of three military vehicles. The other two trucks were not damaged. Police said Shining Path rebels dragged four men from their homes Saturday in Ayacucho and shot them to death. According to the report, the guerrillas accused the four of posing as Shining Path members to extract ``protection money'' from local storekeepers. Ayacucho is the birthplace and stronghold of the Shining Path movement, which launched its insurgency in 1980 to topple Peru's government. Since then, the violence has spread through most of the country, and more than 17,500 people have been killed, including soldiers, police, rebels and civilians.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Tanks Reported Inside Militia Stronghold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT one graf after 18th, Casualties in ... to UPDATE with photographer killed. Picks up 19th, `Aoun's forces ... with minor editing to conform
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BEI2,3
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's tanks broke into a stronghold of his Christian militia rivals Monday, after aweek of battle, and advanced toward the command post of Lebanese Forces chief Samir Geagea, police said. They said the tanks, with cannons blazing, drove to within 300 yards of the Kassardjian militia base in Ein Rummaneh, a working-class district of Christian east Beirut. Witnesses in hills above the Christian sector, reached by telephone from Cyprus, reported heavy fighting in Ein Rummaneh south of the Karantina quarter, where Geagea has his headquarters. Explosions echoed across the city as militiamen crouching in alleyways fired armor-piercing rockets at the tanks and their comrades hurled grenades from rooftops. Shells hit hospitals, schools, and churches. They set fuel tanks, power plants, factories and apartment houses ablaze. Fires burned out of control because pumping stations were knocked out and no water ws available to fight them. Several hospitals said they they could not function for more than two or three days because water, blood, plasma and oxygen supplies were virtually exhausted. Shellfire slackened in some districts at dawn Monday, allowing tens of thousands of civilians to leave basements and underground bomb shelters where some had lived for six days. Youssef Khazen, 35, said his electrical tools store in east Beirut residential district of Ashrafiyeh was destroyed. ``You can't believe what those monsters have done to us,'' he said. ``They've ruined us. Ashrafiyeh looks like it was hit by a hurricane.'' In Geneva, the International Committee of the Red Cross asked for an immediate truce so it could help civilians. Geagea has said the 6,000 regulars and 30,000 reservists of the Lebanese Forces, the largest Christian militia, would ``resist unto death ... to end the dictator's reign of terror'' in Christian territory north and east of Beirut. Aoun, who has been dismissed as army commander but refuses to step aside, commands nearly 20,000 Christian troopers and is trying to gain complete control over the 310-square-milie enclave, where 1 million Christians live. On Monday, his paratroopers secured the key coastal town of Dbaye, 5 miles north of Beirut. They seized it Sunday in a fierce hand-to-hand battle. The Lebanese Forces conceded its 80-man Dbaye garrison had been overrun and made a ``tactical retreat.'' Police said 59 soldiers and militiamen were killed in Dbaye, including nine of Aoun's officers, and 70 were wounded. At least 277 people have been killed and 1,037 wounded since the fighting began Jan. 30, the police said. Casualties in the week-old war for military supremacy among the Christians have included 30 people killed and 117 wounded by shells that strayed into Moslem west Beirut, outside the combat zone. News photographer George Samerejian of Beirut's independent An-Nahar was hit in the head by a stray bullet Wednesday and died in a hospital Saturday, the newspaper said. He had covered the civil war since it began in 1975 and was elected chairman of Lebanon's News Photographers Syndicate in December. Aoun's forces appeared poised Monday for a final, two-pronged assault on Geagea's headquarters at Karantina, from the north and through Ein Rummaneh. Police said Aoun has regrouped his armor on the northern and northeastern flanks of east Beirut. His forces apparently broke through the militia defenses in Ein Rummaneh after two days of battle on the fringes of the district, which lies along the line between Beirut's Christian and Moslem sectors. Edward Djerjian, the U.S. ambassador to Syria, blamed Aoun for the carnage, criticizing the general's ``personal quest for power.'' He is responsible for Lebanon since American diplomats were withdrawn from Beirut in September, after Aoun's supporters surrounded the embassy. A three-man committee representing Maronite Catholic patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir called a cease-fire for 2:15 p.m. Monday, but it was as ineffective as the six before it. At 9:30 p.m., the mediators said Aoun and Geagea had agreed to observe the cease-fire and a committee of officers from both sides had been formed to oversee it, but radio stations reported continued fighting an hour later. A Lebanese Forces statement claimed Aoun's forces attacked in Ein Rummaneh ``at the very moment the cease-fire was slated to start,'' and declared: ``Pitched batles are raging.'' Aoun's command said the Lebanese Forces broke the truce. The capture of Dbaye was Aoun's first significant victory in the battle with the Lebanese Forces. He already holds the highway linking Karantina to militia bases in the northern ports of Jounieh and Byblos, and now can disrupt supplies arriving by sea. ``By taking Dbaye, a major Lebanese Forces armor base, the general has destroyed the militia's rear lines before turning for a frontal assault,'' on Karantina, An-Nahar reported. Ghassan Tueini, the publisher, denounced Aoun and Geagea in a front-page editorial as ``madmen dancing around the fire ... to build a republic of graves.''

DOC.HEAD: Aircraft to Fly Through Hole in Ozone over South Pole
DOC.TEXT: Scientists are building a remote-controlled aircraft to fly through the hole in the ozone layer over the South Pole, Harvard University said Monday. The craft will fly up to 85,000 feet above Antarctica, where temperatures plunge to minus 135 degrees, said Professor James Anderson, who teaches atmospheric chemistry. The aircraft will seek information about the ozone layer over the South Pole, 60 percent of which has been depleted, Anderson said. Some experts believe the protective ozone layer has been damaged by chlorofluorocarbons from air conditioners, refrigerators, some aerosol sprays and other sources. Because ozone blocks ultraviolet radiation, damage to the ozone layer could lead to higher levels of skin cancer, eye problems and damaged food crops, Anderson said. The craft will have a 60-foot wingspan and be built of graphite, hydrocarbons and other strong, lightweight materials. Anderson's team at Harvard is designing the aircraft's instrumentation. John Langford of Aurora Flight Sciences in Virginia is heading the team that will build the aircraft's body. The unmanned craft's flight over the South Pole will be battery powered and controlled by a computer program monitored from McMurdo Station in Victoria Land, Antarctica, Langford said. Anderson and Langford said they expect the aircraft to make its first flight this fall.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Glassware Recalled by Massachusetts Firm
DOC.TEXT: The importer of Italian-made OroFolio glass tableware has recalled the line because of dangerous concentrations of lead, the Food and Drug Administration announced Monday. Long-term use of the glassware could result in damage to the central nervous system of children by lead that leached into food, the agency said. The importer, Mariposa, a Gloucester, Mass., firm, distributed more than 3,000 piece to 166 stores in the United States and Canada since last August, the agency said. The FDA said Mariposa has advised the stores to post notices asking customers to return any items they have. The OroFolio line carries a gold band in the clear glass. The recalled pieces and item numbers are wine glass, 701; individual bowl, 710; salad plate, 711; dinner plate, 712; small round platter, 720; large round platter, 721; serving bowl, 722; small oval platter, 723 and large oval platter, 724. The pieces were manufactured by SI-AN di Cioni & Busoni of Florence.

DOC.HEAD: Virtually All Media Retrictions Lifted
With AM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk, in his speech last week announcing major political reforms, lifted virtually all the media restrictions imposed under the 3-year-old national state of emergency. The only emergency media restriction still in force prohibits photographic or television coverage of political unrest unless police permission is obtained. Many of the restrictions repealed by de Klerk had been ignored with increasing frequency by South African and foreign journalists. These regulations either prohibited or restricted reports about unrest, security force action, general strikes or consumer boycotts, and political statements the government deemed subversive. In addition to scrapping these regulations, de Klerk on Friday lifted bans that had prohibited the local media from quoting militant government opponents. Even before the emergency was declared in June 1986, South Africa's media was subject to an array of restictive laws that remain in effect. These restrict reporting about such topics as mational security, energy supplies and incidents in prisons. During the emergency, several foreign journalists were expelled and several anti-apartheid newspapers were ordered to close for months because of alleged violations of the restrictions. In the past year, such actions have become rare, and the government has been approving hundreds of visas for foreign journalists to come on temporary visits to cover the expected release of jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela.

DOC.HEAD: Report Troops Capture Strategic Town from Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers have captured a strategic eastern town from rebels in heavy fighting that left seven troops wounded, an army commander said Monday. ``We have suppressed the rebels to a point but we cannot be sure that the war has ended,'' Brig. Gen. Moses Craig told reporters. Craig, the army commander in eastern Nimba county, said his troops on Friday pushed rebels out of Kahnplay town, 200 miles northeast of Monrovia. He said no soldiers were killed in the battle. Craig said there were rebel casualties but that he did not know the number. Another Liberian officer, Lt. Col. David Vlayee, admitted soldiers under his command killed a civilian boy, but he said it was an accident. At least 500 civilians have been reported killed by troops sent to the eastern border to hunt rebels who infiltrated from neighboring Ivory Coast in a Dec. 24 invasion aimed at ousting President Samuel Doe, according to Western diplomats in Abidjan, the Ivorian capital. The rebels, led by former civil servant Charles Taylor, are from the Gio and Manno tribes that long have felt oppressed by Doe's Krahn tribe. Rebels have retaliated by moving south into Krahn territory and killing civilians there, diplomats reported. About 60,000 Liberians caught in the ethnic conflict have fled to Ivory Coast and about 12,000 have taken refuge in Guinea, according to officials of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees. Vlayee said a soldier shot and killed teen-ager Paul Duo in Yekepa, a town near the border with Guinea, as the youth ran to hide in bushes when troops approached him. Doe has admitted his soldiers have killed some civilians. He said it is difficult for them to differentiate between civilians and rebels who wear no uniforms. U.S. military advisers were sent to the area in January to help discipline soldiers, and several officers were relieved of their duties, according to U.S. State Department officials. Washington is a staunch supporter of Doe, who seized power in a bloody 1980 coup from the descendants of freed U.S. slaves who founded Liberia in 1847. Col. David Staley, chief of the U.S. military in Liberia, said Monday that U.S. soldiers in Nimba ``are assessing the situation and making sure that no Americans get hurt.'' About 700 Americans are in the war zone, Staley said in an interview. They include Peace Corps volunteers, missionaries and employees of mining companies. ``At the moment, the rebels are now scattered in the bushes and are being pursued by my men,'' Craig said. ``We also have to use guerrilla tactics to get rid of them.'' He said palm nuts found in the pockets of a dead rebel field commander were an indication the guerrillas have little food. The dead rebel ``had been surviving on palm nuts for days,'' Craig said. He said the guerrillas are heavily armed and well-trained. Rocket-propelled grenade launchers and heavy machine guns manufactured in East bloc countries were among captured weapons, Craig said. Liberia has accused Burkina Faso, Ivory Coast and Libya of supporting the rebels, an allegation denied by those countries.

DOC.HEAD: Member of German Minority Vies for Polish Senate Seat
DOC.TEXT: An ethnic German polled more votes than three other hopefuls Monday in the first round of voting to fill a vacant seat in the Polish Senate. Henryk Krol, a veterinarian who with his father is a leader of the ethnic German community in the Silesian province of Opole, will face Solidarity-endorsed candidate Dorota Symonides, a professor specializing in Silesian folklore, in a Feb. 18 runoff. In a field of four candidates, according to the state's PAP news agency, Krol obtained 39.4 percent of the votes to 35.7 percent for Mrs. Symonides. A runoff of the top two candidates is required when no candidate polls 50 percent or more. Eliminated during the first round of voting Sunday were Jozef Pietrzykowski, from the communist-aligned OPZZ trade union, and Jerzy Bobrowski, an independent businessman, according to PAP. There were 214,796 valid ballots, and the turnout was 31.4 percent of the electorate, PAP said. The election is to fill the seat left vacant by the recent death of Sen. Edmund Osmanczyk. If elected to represent Opole Province, Krol would become the first member of the ethnic German minority group to serve in either Poland's 100-member freely elected Senate or its 460-member lower parliament house, the Sejm. Communist officials for decades had denied that any German minority remained in the nearly one-third of present-day Poland that belonged to Germany before World War II. Heavily industrialized Silesia is a region that has been historically contested by both Germans and Poles. Part of Silesia was incorporated into Poland when Poland regained independence following World War I. The remainder of Silesia was awarded Poland at the end of World War II to compensate for land in the east taken away from Poland by the Soviet Union. Opole province, 190 miles southwest of Warsaw, has the highest concentration of ethnic Germans in the country, and Krol and his father Jan Krol were founders of the area's German Minority Cultural-Social Society. The province's population is about 1 million people.

DOC.HEAD: Man Kills Himself After Three Left Dead
DOC.TEXT: A man shot himself to death as he negotiated with police on the telephone after killing his two grown sons, a female visitor and wounding his wife with a kitchen knife Monday, authorities said. James W. Breen, 47, kept police at bay for more than two hours during his pre-dawn rampage, which left the walls of a house in a quiet subdivision splattered with blood. Breen's 48-year-old wife, Virginia, was in fair condition at St. Joseph's Medical Center in Joliet. Mrs. Breen, who suffered knife wounds and was beaten, escaped from the house near Wilmington about 15 miles south of this northeastern Illinois town. Investigators said they have no motive for the killings, and neighbors expressed disbelief at the violence. ``I would guess anybody else but Breen,'' neighbor Fanny Butler said. ``They just are not that type of people.'' The other dead were identified as James M. Breen, 27, Eric T. Breen, 20; and Victoria Pasinski, 18, of Lockport, who was a girlfriend of Eric Breen, said Will County sheriff's Lt. Steve Rathbun. The three apparently died without resistance, probably as they slept, Rathbun said. Mrs. Breen alerted neighbors after escaping from the house, where Eric Breen apparently lived. Authorities said they were unsure whether the other son also lived there. Police were summoned to the house shortly before 3 a.m. They established telephone contact with the eldest Breen, who talked periodically with negotiators until about 5:30 a.m., when police heard what sounded like a gunshot, Rathbun said. Police entered the house at 6:05 a.m. The father's body was found lying in a bathroom, a .32-caliber pistol and a portable telephone beside him, the sheriff's spokesman said. A .22-caliber pistol also was found in the one-story house. Eric Breen and Ms. Paskinski were found in a bedroom and the other son was found lying next to a couch in the living room, Rathbun said. All were casually dressed but were not wearing pajamas. Based on physical evidence and statements from Mrs. Breen, investigators believe the father shot Eric Breen and Ms. Pasinski first with the .22-caliber pistol, then shot his other son, the lieutenant said. Mrs. Breen, apparently roused by the shots, suffered a superficial gunshot wound. She struggled with her husband through the living room, kitchen and out to the back porch, where she was slashed with a kitchen knife but managed to escape, Rathbun said.

DOC.HEAD: New York Senate Approves Death Penalty Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The action ...,' to CORRECT number of senators to 61, sted 63.
DOC.TEXT: The state Senate on Monday approved a bill to restore the death penalty in New York state, a measure Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo has vowed to veto for the eighth straight year. The 40-20 vote followed a 2{-hour debate in which the chief Senate sponsor, Republican Dale Volker, asked his colleagues in the GOP-controlled chamber ``to send a really dramatic message out to the streets.'' But state Sen. Howard Nolan, a Democrat, argued that the death penalty would have no effect on crime rampant in many sections of the state. The legislation would permit the death penalty for the most heinous murders, such as contract killings and the slaying of witnesses. The action by the 61-member Senate began what's become an annual ritual at the state Capitol. Both houses of the Legislature annually pass the death penalty bill, Cuomo vetoes it, and legislators then count noses to see if they've got the votes for an override. Thus far, they have come up short. The measure now goes to the Assembly, where a vote isn't expected on the bill until late February or March, at the earliest. Only after that would it go to the governor for his promised veto. ``I'm confident that we have a better than even shot of overriding,'' said Volker. The 1990 death penalty battle has taken on additional meaning because the governor's job and all 211 seats in the Legislature go before the voters in November. As in the past, Republicans are expected to make Cuomo's opposition to the death penalty a major campaign issue. The governor, who has said he expects to seek re-election to a third term this year, is considered a potential 1992 presidential contender. Cuomo, arguing that the death penalty is debasing and not a deterrent, has called instead for life-without-parole sentences for some murderers. The state Senate has refused to go along with that proposal. New York state's electric chair hasn't been used since Aug. 15, 1963, when Eddie Lee Mays, convicted of murder in a New York City bar shooting, became its 695th victim. Since then, the state's death penalty law has been gutted by court decisions. The state Legislature has been unable to put one back on the books because of the gubernatorial vetoes. New York is the largest state without capital punishment. Thirty-seven states, including California, have death penalty laws.

DOC.HEAD: Writers Guild East Approves Three-Year Contract
DOC.TEXT: Members of the Writers Guild of America, East, in New York City and Washington D.C., overwhelmingly approved a three-year contract with Capital Cities-ABC Monday, the union said. The contract for ABC network and local television and radio employees covers 160 editors, desk assistants, researchers, production assistants, promotion writers, graphic artists and newswriters, some of whom also work as producers, according to union spokesman Martin G. Waldman. The agreement, retroactive to Feb. 2, provides wage increases and other benefits. The new pact succeeds a three-year contract signed in 1987 following a bitter seven-week strike against ABC by the Guild. The agreement provides for an immediate wage increase of 5 percent and another increase of 5 percent on Aug. 1, 1991, with additional increases for graphic artists. Waldman said the increases would raise the average newswriters' salary from $863 to $949 a week. The agreement also provides for new fees for newswriters in network radio who assume additional technical duties and additional vacation time for union members who have been with ABC for more than 15 years. The Writers Guild begins negotiating a contract on behalf of employees at CBS network and local television and radio Tuesday in New York. That contract expires on March 1, 1990. When the ABC agreement was reached last Friday, Jeffrey Ruthizer, Cap Cities vice president for labor relations, commended the union for being ``sensitive to the company's need for increased flexibility.'' ``... We were able to respond to its concerns with wage increases and protections important to them,'' he said. ABC spokeswoman Julie Hoover declined to add any comment Monday. Mona Mangan, executive director of the Writers Guild of America, East, chief negotiator in the contract talks, said in a statement the union was ``especially happy that we were once again able to prevent the network from gutting our contract, this time without being forced by ABC into a strike situation.'' Waldman said the union had succeeded in restoring fees for special duties, such as newswriters doing editing work, that ABC had planned on ending. He said the Guild had also fought off management's efforts to have non-Guild members do work normally done by union members at ``Good Morning America'' and ``News One,'' a television news service for affiliates.

DOC.HEAD: Observers Say Campaign Intimidation, Violence Threaten Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Violence by rebels and threats against candidates campaigning for the Feb. 25 elections pose serious obstacles to the democratic process in Nicaragua, according to a U.N. report. The report released Monday by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said the U.N. observer mission in Nicaragua also expressed concerns over attempts by opposition groups to discredit the nation's electoral authority and the international observers themselves. The report said that during December and January there was ``constant military activity, attributed to groups of the Nicaraguan resistance, which has taken a tragic toll of life and has undoubtedly hampered the electoral process.'' Rebel leaders have denied any involvement, U.N. observers say. There also was a considerable increase in the number of reports of intimidation against candidates during the same period, the report said. ``In the cases reported, pressures range from damage to property to death threats. Complaints usually involve members of the State Security Department,'' the report said. Elliot Richardson, the U.N. chief's personal representative monitoring political developments in Nicaragua, discussed the intimidation with Nicaraguan President Daniel Ortega during a January visit to the Central American nation. Richardson said such incidents could undermine the credibility of the vote. The U.N. observers said Ortega pledged to encourage members of his ruling party to refrain from any forms of intimidation against opposition candidates. Most of the intimidation appeared to come from local party members, indicating it did not result from a nationwide effort to subvert the political process, the U.N. observers said. During the past two months there have been substantial improvements in access to the media for opposition candidates and groups, according to the U.N. report. Bias observed in the mass media posed a serious concern in the initial stages of the campaigns. The U.N. observers also said violence at political demonstrations does not appear to be a cause for concern going into the final weeks of campaigning for the presidential and national assembly elections. Since violence erupted Dec. 10 at a rally sponsored by the National Opposition Union, a coalition of 14 parties, there have been more than 200 public demonstrations with no reports of serious injuries, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Analyst Says Mexican Domestic Debt More Serious Than Foreign
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with AP interview. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The president of a private economics institute on Monday called Mexico's domestic debt a ``time bomb'' that could do more damage than the foreign debt. Jorge Alberto Perez Zogbi of the Mexican International Foreign Debt Studies Institute spoke in an interview with The Associated Press the day after President Carlos Salinas de Gortari signed a widely acclaimed agreement with foreign commercial banks. ``They're paying a lot of attention right now to the foreign debt, but the domestic debt is causing more harm,'' Perez said. The accord cuts $7 billion from the $48.5 billion Mexico owes the banks and reduces interest payments by around $1.6 billion annually. With the agreement, Mexico now owes all foreign lenders a total of $93.6 billion. Brazil's foreign debt is the highest in the developing world, at about $114 billion. Mexico also owes an additional $48.2 billion to Mexican lenders. Perez said the Salinas administration should turn its attention to the internal debt. Although the internal debt is smaller than the foreign debt, payments are nearly three times as large because of high interest rates. Perez said Mexico will pour $17.4 billion of the $72 billion federal budget into the coffers of domestic creditors, compared with $5.56 billion destined for foreign lenders. ``Despite the signing of the foreign debt renegotiation, the internal debt makes adequate health and welfare impossible,'' he said. Perez said the domestic debt has increased 6,000 percent since 1982 and will stand at $57 billion by the end of the year, since Congress has authorized borrowing of up to $8.8 billion in 1990. The internal debt will absorb 7.9 percent of the gross national product and 24 cents of every taxpayer's dollar this year and the foreign debt will absorb 2.5 percent, or eight cents of every tax dollar, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sues Martin Luther King Jr. Associate for Libel
DOC.TEXT: A woman filed a $10 million libel lawsuit Monday against the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy and his memoirs' publisher, claiming she is the woman he implied slept with the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. the night before he was slain. The U.S. District Court lawsuit names Abernathy, who was an aide to King; Harper & Row, which published his book, ``And the Walls Came Tumbling Down;'' and a Harper & Row editor, Daniel Bial. The plaintiff, Adjuda Abi Naantaabuu, said the defendants ``falsely and maliciously charge, and caused the readers of this book to believe, that she had engaged in adulterous behavior and sexual relations with Dr. Martin Luther King on the last night of his life.'' Naantaabuu, who was identified as a beautician who also works in the civil rights movement, claimed she has suffered great mental anguish because she has been ridiculed and her reputation has been injured. In the book, Abernathy wrote that he awoke for a nap in a woman's living room after a late-night dinner on April 3, 1968, to see King and the woman emerge from a bedroom. The book drew criticism from many of Abernathy's comrades in the civil rights movement of the 1960s. Naantaabuu did not give her version of the story in the lawsuit, but in earlier interviews has said she was the host of the dinner and that she and her sister talked with King and another aide in the living room while Abernathy slept on her bed. ``Everyone in Memphis knew that Dr. King had been at my house the night before his assassination,'' Naantaabuu said in a statement released by her attorney. ``Dr. Abernathy's book has cast shadows on my character. Even my own granddaughter asked me whether I had had an affair with Dr. King.'' A call to Abernathy's office in Atlanta was unanswered Monday evening. A spokesman at Harper & Row also could not be reached for comment.

DOC.HEAD: Prostitute Who Claims Swaggart Was Client Settles With Agents
DOC.TEXT: The former prostitute who described assignations with evangelist Jimmy Swaggart to Penthouse Magazine got to keep about $54,000 of the $210,000 paid her by Penthouse, her attorney said Monday. ``She's happy. I talked with her on the telephone,'' Louis H. Schultz said in an interview after announcing settlements with Murphree's agents and the Internal Revenue Service. ``I don't think anybody's happy when they've lost a large amount of money,'' he said. ``But I'm glad we were able to salvage some.'' Agents and the IRS had claimed they were owed $428,000 by Murphree, a major player in the scandal that rocked Swaggart's religious empire in 1988. However, Schultz said their figures were based on inflated estimates of the amount Penthouse owed for the article and a promotional tour and _ in the IRS' $217,000 claim _ for income from prostitution. Murphree told Penthouse that Swaggart paid her $20 a visit to strike prurient poses and perform sexual acts. ``The IRS ... figured she was a full-time, 12-hour-a-day working girl, six days a week, 52 weeks a year on a rather regular basis,'' said Stephen P. High, who handled that claim for Schultz. ``On the promotional tour, someone asked about her income as a prostitute. They put words in her mouth. The IRS took that figure,'' added Schultz. He said the IRS will take $28,000 as taxes owed for 1977 through 1979 and for penalties and interest on those taxes. Schultz said last month that, based on a report that 4 million copies of the July 1988 issue were sold, Penthouse might owe Murphree $437,000. However, he said Monday that further research indicated Penthouse's lower figures and payment to Murphree were correct. The contract, for $75,000 up front plus 25 cents for each issue above 2.25 million sold, covered only the 2.8 million or so issues sold in the United States and Canada, he said, though another million may have been sold overseas. He said Murphree got $18,000 of the first $75,000 and will get about $36,000 from money in dispute until Monday. Most of the money has gone or will go to agents, attorneys and the IRS, he said. He said five agents and attorneys had convinced Murphree to let them represent her in contract talks with firms willing to pay for her story. ``She got herself into a mess of contracts,'' he said. With today's settlement, the agencies and one who settled Friday divide about $52,000, Schultz said. He said he and his associates get about $25,000 in fees and expenses. Schultz said Murphree is ``just a housewife in the Midwest'' but wouldn't say where she is living. Murphree married Samuel W. Travis, whom she met while doing time for prostitution, in December 1988. In February of that year, she was a prostitute working seedy motels in suburban New Orleans. She claimed that Swaggart, the Baton Rouge-based television evangelist, was a regular customer in 1987. Swaggart tearfully confessed to an unspecified ``moral failure'' and was subsequently defrocked by the fundamentalist Assemblies of God. Layoffs and cutbacks followed at his multimillion-dollar Jimmy Swaggart Ministries.

DOC.HEAD: Droppings, Fistfight Bring Relief to Boring Nicaragua Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Doves that misbehaved over a crowd of President Daniel Ortega's supporters and a fistfight between two opposition organizers brought comic relief last weekend to Nicaragua's electoral campaign. It all happened Sunday here and at another small town near the Honduran border. A crowd of 10,000 was giving Ortega a cold reception when he showed up at the Somoto bullring for a campaign rally organized by his leftist Sandinista party. When cheerleaders failed to work up the people, Ortega took over. ``I see you sunburned, I see you bored, I see you tired,'' he chided the crowd, then proceded to release one-by-one six doves _ the symbol of peace. The birds took off and, after a short flight, two dove straight into the crowd. The other four flew a circular course and bombarded the gathering with more than a few droppings, drawing squeals, screams and laughter. Things went smoother for Ortega after that. Ortega and running mate, Vice President Sergio Ramirez, are seeking a second six-year term in Feb. 25 elections, against Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and Virgilio Godoy of the United National Opposition, a coalition of 14 anti-Sandinista parties. The president told the rally how the Sandinistas in their 10 years in power had made sure the banks never foreclosed a farm mortgage when a landowner was too poor to pay. The only time a farm mortgage was foreclosed was in 1979 when Alfredo Cesar was Central Bank president, Ortega said in what was an obvious dig at Mrs. Chamorro's campaign. Cesar is now a top UNO adviser. ``Is there anyone here whose farm has been seized by the bank because of an unpaid loan?'' Ortega asked. One peasant raised his hand and Ortega asked him to come onstage. ``When did this happen?'' Ortega asked the man. ``About 20 or 18 years ago,'' said the peasant, provoking laughter. ``Oh,'' Ortega exclaimed, smiling. Meanwhile, in the town of Posoltega west of here, a fistfight broke out on the podium while a crowd of about 3,000 UNO supporters waited for Mrs. Chamorro and running mate Godoy to appear and say their campaign pieces. One contender in the brawl was Antonio Lacayo, Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law and campaign manager. Another was Jaime Bonilla, a member of UNO's top political council. Bonilla nearly fell off the stage before onlookers managed to separate them. The cause of the fight was not made public. But the Sandinista party newspaper Barricada had a field day on Page 1 with the story, and Sandinista-controlled television aired it on its Sunday night national newshour. Mrs. Chamorro, publisher of the opposition newspaper La Prensa, has become famous for her occasional absent-mindedness. Addressing supporters on one occasion, she mistook the election date, saying said she was sure she would win the Sept. 25 elections. During another speech, she left a crowd puzzled when she promised that, when she is elected, hunger will end ``because the corn will grow in your stomachs.'' During Sunday's rally, Mrs. Chamorro made no faux pas.

DOC.HEAD: Key Alliance Threatens to Pull Out of Elections
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A key political alliance Monday threatened to pull out of Haiti's elections unless the military government allows the return of exiled leaders and moves up the presidential balloting from October to July. The National Alliance for Democracy and Progress is the only political group left in the campaigning for this year's general elections and its announcement came as a surprise. Marc Bazin, the only officially declared presidential candidate and leader of the alliance, also gave four other conditions to participate in the balloting. It would be the first since the 1987 voting was canceled following a massacre at the polls in which armed thugs shot or hacked to death at least 34 people. An alliance statement said the military government's recent crackdown and state of siege in which political activists were jailed, beaten or forced into exile cast doubt on whether free and fair elections could be held. All other parties have refused to take part as long as Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril remains in power. But many candidates have also been jailed or deported. Avril declared a state of siege on Jan. 20, one day after the assassination of Army Col. Andre Neptune, his wife and their maid. More than 50 opposition politicians and militants were arrested and beaten at the time; six are still being held and seven were sent into forced exile. The alliance's position was unexpected because last week it welcomed the lifting of the state of siege on Jan. 29. In a controversial announcement, it called the move ``an important first step toward the necessary normalization of the political climate.'' Avril lifted the declaration after an international outcry. He came to power in a 1988 coup but has repeatedly promised to hold elections. The nine-member independent electoral council has set local and municipal elections for April 29, legislative elections for July 22 and Aug. 5, and presidential elections for Oct. 28, with a runoff on Nov. 25. The alliance said legislative and presidential elections should be held on the same date in July ahead of local elections. ``Our position is clear. If the electoral council does not modify the timetable, we will not participate in elections,'' Bazin said at a news conference. In addition to allowing the return of exiled leaders, other conditions set by the alliance for its participation were that the government respect the constitution, release uncharged political prisoners and give others a fair trial, and allow the United Nations to monitor the vote. Avril said last Thursday that the exiles could return and that he hoped they had learned ``a lesson.'' The new president would be be sworn in Feb. 7, 1991, on the fifth anniversary of the ouster of dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier, who fled to a exile in France. Avril, a close aide of the Duvalier regime, gained power in September 1988 when a soldier's rebellion ousted Lt. Gen. Henri Namphy, who took over after a popular uprising forced Duvalier into exile in France.

DOC.HEAD: Sailors Convicted of Raping Italian Woman
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. Navy enlisted men were convicted Monday of raping a Naples woman during a shore leave, and sentenced to more than four years in jail each, officials said. Patrick R. McCoy, 22, a fireman from Portsmouth, Va., and Brian T. Vaughn, 20, a petty officer from Los Angeles were found guilty by a Naples criminal court of rape, breaking and entering, assault with injuries and causing damage to property, said Lt. Paul Weishaupt, a spokesman for the Navy's Commander Fleet Air Mediterranean in Naples. The sailors planned to appeal the convictions, the U.S. official said. News reports said the pair allegedly raped a 44-year-old woman in September 1988 while their ship, the USS Yellowstone, was at port in Naples, used by the U.S. Sixth Fleet. They each were ordered to pay $60,000 in damages, Weishaupt said. Vaughn received a sentence of four years and six months, while McCoy was sentenced to four years and 10 months, Weishaupt said. McCoy was additionally convicted of resisting arrest, he said. They would continue to be held under house arrest at the U.S. base in Naples until the end of the judicial process, Weishaupt said.

DOC.HEAD: Meese, Soviet Minister Debate at Oxford
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. Attorney General Edwin Meese III and Andre Gratchev, Soviet deputy minister for international affairs, debated at Oxford Monday night on the relative values of the U.S. Constitution and socialism. The motion proposed by Meese at Oxford University's venerable debating society that ``this house believes that the values of the American Constitution, not of socialism, will shape the world in the coming century'' was carried by 351 votes to 235. About 1,000 students packed Oxford Union to hear the speeches. The debating society is a training ground for politicians and a hotbed of talk, wit and showing-off. Opposing the motion, Gratchev urged: ``Do not bury socialism. Perestroika is being tried by us to allow socialism to win. Socialism is capable of providing answers to human problems.'' He said many Western writers had predicted perestroika would fail because, they said, it was impossible to reform socialism. But Gratchev said perestroika involved irreversible change. ``It will continue to alter the world and profoundly change the nature of socialism,'' he said. ``The purpose of perestroika is to subject socialism to historical change. The 21st century will be the century of change. Right now the change is coming from the East, from the Soviet countries, from Moscow. But it is not anti-capitalist.'' Meese said socialism had not worked, could not be defended and was being cast aside. He said the value of the U.S. Constitution lay in giving to people the ability to bring about change through democratic processes. ``We recognize the Constitution will not solve all the problems of mankind, but it allows the process whereby people can attempt to solve problems through their elected representatives,'' Meese said. He said this was a potential recognized by more and more oppressed people. ``That is why a copy of the Statue of Liberty was raised in Tiananmen Square,'' he said, referring to the pro-democracy demonstrations crushed by Chinese troops in Beijing last year.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th item on Frankel to CORRECT first name to Eliot, sted Elliott, change dateline to New Brunswick, N.J.; UPDATE with day he died, age.
DOC.TEXT: Eliot Frankel, an NBC television network producer for at least 30 years, died of cancer Sunday night. He was 67. Frankel worked with NBC in the early 1950s and was with ``The Today Show'' on its first broadcast. He was senior producer of the Huntley-Brinkley evening newscast from 1956-1963, then moved to London to work as a European producer until 1966. He worked for news and documentary programs until 1984, when he was a political consultant to NBC during the presidential elections. Frankel later taught at Vanderbilt University and Rutgers University.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Businessman Refuses to Enter Federal Plea
DOC.TEXT: A Honduran businessman already sentenced to life in prison on federal drug trafficking charges refused Monday to enter a plea to a conspiracy charge in the killing of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena. Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros appeared in court under heavy security with three other men, including Ruben Zuno Arce, the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria. The three other men pleaded innocent to the 1985 torture-slaying of Camarena and his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie entered an innocent plea on behalf of Matta. Matta's attorney argued that a plea was not appropriate because his client was brought to the United States illegally to face charges. ``He was kidnapped by agents of the United States from his homeland in Honduras in violation of the extradition treaty and the United States Constitution and was tortured by those agents,'' said Matta's attorney, Martin Stolar. Matta's extradition to the United States from Honduras in 1988 sparked riots that left five people dead and the U.S. Embassy annex burned. Three federal judges have ruled the extradition was legal. Stolar also said the case has received ``highly prejudicial publicity'' since last month's airing on NBC-TV of ``Drug Wars,'' a miniseries about Camarena's slaying. Matta, 45, was sentenced last month to life in prison without the possibility of parole following his conviction on seven charges, including conspiracy, possession and distribution of narcotics, and running a criminal enterprise. The judge scheduled trial on the latest charges for April 10. If convicted, all four defendants could receive life sentences.
