DOC.TEXT: Sexy and outspoken, Taylor Dayne is a hybrid as is her music. At once warm and passionate, it is driven by a beat, just as she is driven. It has helped her avoid the pitfalls of alcohol and drugs, so often associated with musical success. She knew what she wanted and got it.

No shrinking violet, this lady. Her debut record album produced four top 10 singles. Now she's on her second hit single from her second record album. ``I don't believe in overnight stardom,'' Taylor Dayne says bluntly. ``That's garbage.'' She and her version of rock 'n' roll obviously is not. Nor her sense of what she looks like. Her hair, red and bushy when the first album came out, is now blonde and less full. For photographers she pouts full lips for a sultry look. From the time she was a child she says she knew she was going to sing. ``I was an obnoxious kid wanting to sing solos in school and doing it.'' She chooses decolletage for public appearances, like when she presented the dance and rap awards at January's televised American Music Awards. ``I like to be photographed,'' she says. ``I have fun with it. I like to feel good about myself. ``Being sexy is something that didn't happen overnight. I'm thankful I take good photographs every now and then.'' But she never considered modeling. ``I didn't think I was pretty enough or tall enough ... a fool job. Singing pays better. And it's more satisfying.'' Her next tour, for which she's having a ``great outfit'' made, starts in March. Remembering advice from her voice teachers, Dayne always warms up her voice before she goes on stage. ``On the road I get really freaked. Ask anybody on the tour bus with me. I have a scarf wrapped around my neck. I have my tea and lemon and honey. ``I choose not to be involved in drugs. I don't preach to anybody. I have this path within me. I've fallen off a couple of times. I picked myself up and got back on. Always what I saw for myself is where I am now. I know what works for me. It's to keep myself safe, happy and healthy. '' If she drinks too much and feels lousy the next day, ``I know exactly what I did to make myself feel like that. So I avoid it. I don't avoid it altogether. Let's just say I don't abuse it.'' In her three college years she studied philosophy and psychology. She took voice lessons on the side. She rehearsed with a band three nights a week and performed weekends. ``People call it paying your dues.'' Sometimes the lead singer, sometimes switching off with others, sometimes the kid with the tambourine. But she was getting restless, wanted out of the Long Island scene and she wanted to front a band. She joined one in White Plains, N.Y. ``I was schlepping up there three times a week, rehearsing. It was five people and with everybody having their own ideas and enormous egos. The songwriter was very gifted but he had a major attitude problem. I knew it wouldn't take him far, and I don't mind saying that because I hate him.'' In Manhattan, he told her to copy other singers. ``It was a bitter time in my life. All I could do was pray I would meet somebody who would respect me for my vocal sound and for myself. Three weeks later I met Ric.'' Ric Wake, a producer of dance records, heard her first on tape. He was struggling himself, making 12-inch singles, hoping they'd get picked up by a major label. ``I started singing and writing dance stuff with him. I could feel the pulse of the music.'' Then she began to think that melodic songs would intrigue more people _ both dance and pop fans. So, almost an unknown, she got from a music publisher a song that was danceable and she thought had crossover appeal, ``Tell it to My Heart.'' She cut a single and tried to shop it around. But, impatient to pay her father back money she had borrowed, she was willing for a small-time, independent release of the record if a major record company didn't pick it up. Arista Records signed her three days after she got out of a previous independent production deal. Born Lesley Wunderman, she changed her name, so single records she'd made wouldn't be re-issued to haunt her. ``I thought Taylor was different. I like guys' names.'' Dayne came out of a baby-name book. Arista released ``Tell it to My Heart'' and it flew up the charts, in America and abroad. ``I was making an album four months later,'' Dayne says. She'd never sung a ballad when Clive Davis, Arista's president, said that ``I'll Always Love You,'' a passionate ballad, should be on the album. She didn't want to sing it. ``Clive obviously had a lot more confidence in my voice than I did ... Now I'm comfortable with ballads. I knock them out constantly. It's cool.'' Dayne grew up in Long Island, middle child of an engineer who also deals in rare coins and a mother who had operatic training. One brother does record company promotion and the other produces corporate parties and ``weddings on a grand scale.'' A ballad, ``Love Will Lead You Back,'' is her current single, following ``With Every Beat of My Heart.'' Wake produced the ``Tell It to My Heart'' album and the new one, called appropriately ``Can't Fight Fate.''
DOC.NOTE: END ADV

DOC.TEXT: The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent for the eighth straight month in January but the economy still produced 275,000 new jobs, the government said. The Labor Department also said Friday factory jobs dropped 112,000 last month, with 90,000 of the losses suffered by the struggling auto industry. But many laid off auto workers have been recalled since last month. Large gains were posted in construction and service industries. The jobless rate in Michigan jumped to 8.4 percent in January, up from 7.2 percent in December. That was the largest unemployment increase in the 11 large industrial states surveyed by the government.

Orders to factories for manufactured goods slowed to a 6.4 percent increase during 1989, the government said. The Commerce Department said Friday orders for both durable and non-durable manufactured goods gained 1.9 percent to a seasonally adjusted $244.2 billion in December after rising 2.4 percent in November. Analysts said the manufacturing sector apparently hit a trough in the fourth quarter and should rebound slowly this year.

Federal regulators seized Florida's largest thrift association, CenTrust Bank, charging it with lavish spending on museum-quality art, a company yacht and high salaries. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision on Friday declared the Miami-based S&L operating in an unsafe and unsound condition and turned it over to the Resolution Trust Corp. for sale or liquidation. With $8.2 billion in assets, CenTrust is Florida's largest and the nation's 23rd-largest savings institution.

Roche Holding Ltd. of Switzerland will become the majority shareholder of Genentech Inc., the world's leading biotechnology company, in a $2.1 billion deal. Under the agreement announced Friday, Roche will invest $492 million in Genentech, buying half its 82 million shares of outstanding stock for $36 a share _ 65 percent above Thursday's closing stock price.

Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said it narrowed its losses sharply last year and expected to return to profitability in 1990 after spending two years at the center of the nation's biggest securities fraud case. The securities firm said it lost about $40 million after taxes in 1989 on $4.1 billion in revenue. That compared with a loss of $167 million on revenue of $4.4 billion in 1988, a year in which it took a charge of $650 million to cover a settlement of the fraud charges. As recently as December, Drexel Chief Executive Frederick H. Joseph predicted the firm would break even or show a modest profit for the full year.

The acting chairman of Bank of New England, which is trying to rebound from the $1 billion loss projected for 1989, said the bank probably wouldn't turn a profit this year but should come out ahead in the long run. Interim Chairman H. Ridgely Bullock, named by the board of directors last week, also said Friday the bank continues experiencing deposit outflows sparked by the recent disclosure of the extent of its financial problems. He said it would have to keep borrowing from the federal government to meet the demands of depositors.

McGraw-Hill Inc. has pulled the plug on its electronic business news services, saying the market for them was developing more slowly than expected. The unexpected decision to close its McGraw-Hill News and Standard & Poor's News services at the close of business Friday came only a day after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $98.3 million, due mainly to the impact of a corporate restructuring.

President Bush, citing ``credible confidential information,'' has ordered a Chinese-owned corporation to sell its interests in a Seattle aircraft parts company. Bush on Friday ordered the divestiture, on national security grounds, of Mamco Manufacturing Co. of Seattle by the China National Aero-Technology Import and Export Corp. In ordering the action, Bush invoked for the first time a provision of a 1988 trade law that gives the president the power to restrict foreign investment in the United States if the nation's security is affected.

General Electric Co. and two employees were convicted on several charges of bilking the government of $10 million for a battlefield computer system. A U.S. District Court jury returned the verdict Friday against GE, James Badolato and Gerald A. Leo, both former employees of Management and Technical Services Co., a GE subsidiary. GE, the nation's second-biggest defense contractor, could face a fine of $71.9 million.

The stock market rallied Friday after a government report on January employment boosted investor confidence about the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average ended 16.44 points higher at 2,602.70. The dollar finished mostly higher. Bond prices fell sharply. Expectations of strong gasoline demand early this summer prompted a strong rally in oil futures prices; copper and precious metal futures rose; livestock and meat futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Investment House Reports Sharply Reduced Loss; Sees Profit in 1990
DOC.TEXT: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said it narrowed its losses sharply last year and expected to return to profitability in 1990 after spending two years at the center of the nation's biggest securities fraud case. The securities firm said it lost about $40 million after taxes in 1989 on $4.1 billion in revenues. That compared with a loss of $167 million on revenues of $4.4 billion in 1988, a year in which it took a charge of $650 million to cover a settlement of the fraud charges. As recently as December, Drexel Chief Executive Frederick H. Joseph predicted the firm would break even or show a modest profit for the full year. Although the results announced Sunday fell short of that forecast, Drexel said cutbacks in the past year had effectively halved the firm's break-even point and leave it poised to turn a profit this year. Last year's loss included $75 million in expenses related to investigations of the firm for securities abuses. Those expenses should drop nearly in half this year, Drexel said. In September, Drexel pleaded guilty to six felonies and agreed to pay a record of more than $650 million in fines and restitution to settle criminal fraud charges that stemmed from the Ivan Boesky insider trading scandal. The firm also reached an agreement on civil charges with the Securities and Exchange Commission last year that placed Drexel under unprecedented government supervision for three years and revamps its management. The loss last year also included an undisclosed amount of charges related to discontinued operations. The firm unloaded its retail brokerage network last year and has reduced employment to about 5,300 today from 9,700 at the start of 1989, Drexel spokesman Steven S. Anreder said. He suggested that the charges for discontinued operations was fairly small but declined to give details. Drexel is a closely held firm and does not release detailed earnings figures. Before tax and interest payments and the special charges, Drexel said it had an operating profit of $67 million in 1989. That profit came after provisions to mark down the value of the firm's holdings of high-yield bonds to reflect the steep fall in the market for so-called junk bonds in recent months, Drexel said. The profit figure also included over $200 million in other charges that aren't expected to recur, the firm said. Anreder declined to say what the $200 million-plus charge covered or give details about the size of the junk bond writedown. ``We never indicate the size of our position for competitive reasons,'' he said of the junk bond portfolio. Drexel virtually created the junk bond market and rode it to prominence in the 1980s, posting a record pretax profit of $1.1 billion at its peak in 1986. Drexel said it would benefit from a sharp reduction in costs this year. In addition to reduced personnel and legal costs, the firm announced plans in October to cut its New York City office space to about 700,000 square feet by 1991 from 1.5 million square feet. Anreder said Drexel didn't anticipate any further job cuts despite a wave of reductions on Wall Street. In the most dramatic move, industry leader Merrill Lynch & Co. in January announced a $470 million charge to cover the elimination of some businesses, the dismissal of some 3,000 employees and a consolidation of office space. ``I think we recognized the cycles a lot sooner than other people in the industry,'' Anreder said. Drexel's equity capital stood at more than $800 million at the end of 1989, down from $1.1 billion a year earlier but up from about $750 million late in the year. Part of the reduction in capital reflected the firm's withdrawal from retail brokerage, Anreder said. Drexel boosted capital late in the year with contributions from high-salary employees, and employees should provide another $50 million to $100 million in fresh equity capital this year, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Fluctuates, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fluctuated in a narrow range in calm European trading late this morning as markets awaited news from a key meeting of the Soviet Communist Party. Gold prices rose. Traders said they expected little movement in the dollar until there were political developments in the Soviet Union and U.S. markets opened. The Communist Party's Central Committee is meeting today and Tuesday to debate a proposal, endorsed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, to give up its exclusive claim to power. News of further Soviet democratization could fuel some dollar buying, dealers said. But the U.S. currency generally remains on a downward trend, traders said. ``The dollar is currently a sick currency,'' one Milan trader said. The huge U.S. budget and trade deficits, lackluster economic growth, persistent inflation and the prospect of lower interest rates are all weighing on the dollar, he said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.64 yen to a closing 145.60 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 145.70 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning, compared with late Friday's prices, included: 1.6786 West German marks, down from 1.6860; 1.4868 Swiss francs, down from 1.4964; 5.7015 French francs, down from 5.7360; 1.8930 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9010; 1,246.50 Italian lire, down from 1,252.00; and 1.1875 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1884. In London, the dollar fell against the British pound. It cost $1.6915 to buy one pound, compared with $1.6820 late Friday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $418.50 a troy ounce, up from $417.25 bid late Friday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $418.75. In Zurich, the bid price was $418.40, up from $417.75 bid late Friday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $1.10 to close at a bid $416.86. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.31 a troy ounce, up from Friday's $5.29.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Dip
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued its climb against the Japanese yen and Tokyo prices fell marginally today as investors reacted to better-than-expected U.S. employment figures and uncertainties about Soviet developments. The dollar closed at 145.60 yen, up 0.65 yen from last Friday's close of 144.95 yen. After opening at 145.59 yen, it stayed in a narrow range of 145.40-145.60 yen. The dollar now has gained 2.38 yen in the last five trading days. Currency dealers said the dollar's firmness today carried over from its strong showing Friday in New York, where it closed at 145.50 yen. Investors bought dollars in New York after the U.S. Labor Department reported that the nation's unemployment rate held steady at 5.3 percent in January. Economists say a steady jobless rate will keep the U.S. Federal Reserve from easing interest rates. Higher interest rates tend to make a country's currency more attractive to investors. Dealers added, however, that uncertainty over the situation in the Soviet Union was keeping participants from taking large positions. ``Now the market is looking to whether Soviet leader Gorbachev's position will be consolidated'' in a meeting of the Soviet Communist Party Central Committee today and Tuesday, said a Bank of Tokyo dealer, speaking on condition of anonymity. The Tokyo market has fluctuated erratically in past weeks on rumors that Gorbachev might resign as party secretary. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues, which gained 443.73 points last Friday, fell back 18.74 points, or 0.05 percent, today, closing at 37,631.41 yen. Securities dealers said that after a strong opening, uncertainty about the direction of currency rates and falling government bond prices sent investors to the sidelines, causing large-capital issues to decline. ``Investors were watching the development of the Soviet situation from the sidelines so anxiously that they remained reluctant to take part all day,'' said a dealer with Nikko Securities Co., also speaking on condition of anonymity. Volume traded on the exchange's first section was estimated at 400 million shares.

DOC.HEAD: Study Lists Top Cars, Worst Cars In Number of Deaths

DOC.HEAD: Honda Motor Considering Selling Chrysler Cars in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Honda Motor Co. is considering a request by Chrysler Corp. to market the American manufacturer's automobiles in Japan, a Honda spokesman said Monday. Honda spokesman Hitoshi Dewa said Chrysler suggested the two companies set up a joint venture. All other details, including the Chrysler models, number of sales and distribution channels in Japan have yet to be finalized, Dewa said. Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's largest business journal, said Honda will concentrate on selling 5,000-6,000 Chrysler Jeeps and Cherokees a year through one of Honda's three distribution networks in Japan. The newspaper said an agreement was expected later this year. Honda's move is reportedly aimed at supplementing sales of the troubled U.S. manufacturer, whose profits have been suffering from a slump in the U.S. auto market, the newspaper said. Last November and December, Honda outsold Chrysler in the United States, the first time the American automaker was beaten by a foreign manufacturer, Dewa said. Chrysler's sales in Japan have remained negligible. Chrysler Japan Sales Co., the joint venture set up 1988 by Chrysler and J. Osawa, sold 440 Chrysler cars that year and 970 cars last year, accounting for 0.5 percent of foreign auto sales in Japan, according to company sales figures. Until recently, the U.S. company has had a close relationship with one of Honda's rivals, Mitsubishi Motors Corp. The two companies have a joint production facility in Illinois. Last September, however, Chrysler announced it would sell 45 percent of its share in the Japanese automaker for $592 million, reducing its share in Mitsubishi from 21.8 percent to 12.1 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Rhetoric Aside, Democrats Will Merely Trim Edges of Bush's Budget
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS 6th graf pvs, ``The side ... to restore dropped word ``cuts'' in quote
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats are gearing up to rework the defense, domestic and tax priorities in President Bush's 1991 budget, but they acknowledge they dare not even tinker with the widest gulf between the two sides. It's no secret that the majority Democrats in the House and Senate want to cut defense spending beyond Bush's proposal, beef up favorite domestic programs and change the president's mix of taxes. But the differences on those issues amount to just a fraction of the gap that separates the White House and Democrats on a larger question: how much deficit reduction will be needed next year. Democrats say the real figure is double the $37 billion Bush claims is necessary. Yet they concede they will use the president's number for a simple reason: if Congress decides that $74 billion in savings are needed, Congress must find them. ``Without the executive branch, Congress simply can't assemble the political support to make the hard, unpopular decisions that would have to be made,'' Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said last week. ``The side that goes for the higher numbers has to come up with more spending cuts or taxes,'' says Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of the House Budget Committee. ``It's one of the most awful political dynamics I've seen.'' The White House, relying on expectations of a healthy economy next year, based its $1.23 trillion budget on the assumption that healthy economic growth would shrink the 1991 shortfall to about $101 billion. Hence, just $37 billion in taxes or savings would be needed to reach the $64 billion Gramm-Rudman deficit target. Many analysts believe the economy will be less robust. That means lower revenue collections and, they say, a $138 billion budget gap _ or $74 billion in savings needed to hit the $64 billion target. The reality gulf between the two sides gets wider still. The Democratic staff of the Senate Budget Committee last week claimed the president's budget hid at least $100 billion in legitimate budget costs by relying on ``big lies and budget gimmicks.'' These ranged from carrying the federal costs of insolvent savings and loans associations off the budget _ a $50 billion to $100 billion expense over the next two years _ to assuming $2.5 billion in savings by running the Internal Revenue Service more efficiently. Administration officials say they have done nothing misleading. Democrats disagree, but will not discount those savings for fear of the consequences: having to replace them with cuts or taxes elsewhere. ``Going with those higher numbers now would be political suicide'' for the Democrats, says Stanley Collender, who follows the budget process for Touche, Ross and Co., the accounting firm. What Democrats will focus on is Bush's defense proposal. He wants to spend $303.3 billion for military programs next year, above this year's $296.3 billion but 2.6 percent below what is needed to stay abreast of inflation. Democrats say that with the easing of Cold War tensions, those cuts will have to go lower, perhaps $12 billion to $15 billion less than Bush's figure. ``We've got to cut more there,'' says Sen. J. James Exon, D-Neb., a member of the Senate budget and armed services committees. ``But the problem is you get where everybody says, `Don't close my base, close his base.' Therein lies the problem, that local pork barrel takes the place of rational decisions.'' Democrats will be eager to use any defense savings to protect domestic programs against cuts proposed by Bush. Democratic aides to the House Budget Committee said Friday that they had found 46 programs that Bush wants to eliminate, including several student loan programs and subsidies to Amtrak, the passenger railroad. Forty-three others were targeted for major cuts, including Medicare, farm assistance and federal prison construction. Majority lawmakers also are likely to try to change Bush's plans to raise nearly $22 billion next year in new taxes, fees and other government collections. Their main target is the president's proposal to cut the capital gains tax rate, which he insists brings the Treasury $4.9 billion. ``I don't see any quick resolutions here,'' House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., said Friday. ``The budget could very well be the focus of confrontation for the next few months.''

DOC.HEAD: Economists Predict Bush Administration-Fed Clash on Monetary Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's hopes of getting the federal deficit under control could be on a collision course with the Federal Reserve's efforts to get control of inflation, many economists believe. The Fed has been resisting a variety of signals from the administration that it would like to see a more aggressive easing of interest rates from the central bank in order to keep the economy from dipping into a recession. Private economists said recent comments from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan leave the unmistakable impression that the Fed's inflation-fighting efforts are not about to slacken as a result of the administration's comments. As a result, many private economists predict that a variety of short-term business and consumer interest rates are likely to remain unchanged over coming weeks, including banks' prime lending rate, which stands at 10 percent. They said mortgage rates, which have been rising, should stabilize although they conceded this forecast depends heavily on the financial markets. The Fed's main policymaking group, composed of Fed governors and regional Fed bank presidents, was scheduled to hold closed-door discussions on Tuesday and Wednesday to set monetary goals for the rest of the year. While the outcome of those deliberations will not be known until Feb. 20 when Greenspan testifies to Congress, many economists predict that the central bank will not loosen further and will instead adopt a wait-and-see attitude. ``I think the Fed is going to sit on its hands. The employment and inflation numbers are coming in too high to permit further easing,'' said David Wyss, chief financial forecaster for DRI-McGraw Hill. That could spell bad news for the administration, which last week sent Congress a budget projecting that the federal deficit will be slashed in half to $63.1 billion next year. That projection was based on an optimistic economic forecast which called for growth to be higher and interest rates to be lower than many private analysts believe is possible given the Fed's current course. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady on Friday conceded that the administration and Fed policymakers don't always see eye to eye. He said these ``differences of point of view are openly expressed'' during his weekly meetings with Greenspan. Since June the central bank has engaged in a series of small credit easing efforts as the Fed tried to keep the economy from slipping into a recession. But last week, Greenspan told a congressional committee he believed the chance of an imminent recession had diminished markedly since last spring and the current slowdown is likely to turn out to be only a ``temporary hesitation.'' Allen Sinai, chief economist for the Boston Co., said Greenspan's comment showed that the Fed was willing to risk lower growth because of renewed concerns about the need to lower the inflation rate, which last year jumped to a seven-year high of 4.6 percent. ``The central bank is toughing it out, letting economic growth dip quite low in an effort to get inflation down,'' Sinai said. Lyle Gramley, a former Fed governor and now chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers Association, said the central bank also is being forced to keep an eye on the turbulence in financial markets, especially the bond market, where interest rates have been rising out of fears that foreign investors may be abandoning the American market in favor of higher returns overseas. ``Even if the Fed wanted to ease, they could hardly do so with sentiment in the bond market so sour. Any easing could well be counterproductive, sending interest rates up and not down,'' Gramley said. Mortgage rates have been headed higher in recent weeks, now at 10.17 percent, the highest level since early September, according to a nationwide survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Rates dipped to 9.69 percent in late December.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Study Rates Car Death Rates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6-9th grafs, `Twelve of...', with 7 grafs to add background, quotes on prevalence of high-performance cars on high-death-rate list.
DOC.TEXT: The Chevrolet Corvette has the highest death rate in crashes, while a four-door Volvo has the lowest, according to a study released today. The study shows that 5.2 drivers and passengers die in car wrecks for every 10,000 1985-87 Corvettes registered in the United States. It also found the Volvo 740-760 four-door had the lowest rate, 0.6 deaths per 10,000 vehicles. The figures from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety were released by the Michigan Association of Professional Insurance Agents. ``Without question the consumer has a better chance of survival when driving a larger vehicle,'' said James Alexander, president of the Michigan association. Of the 10 vehicles with the lowest death rates, three were large, six were midsize and only one was a small car _ the Volkswagen Jetta with 1.1 deaths per 10,000 vehicles. Twelve of the 15 cars with the highest death rates are small, and the other three are midsize. Several, including the Corvette at the top of the list, are high-performance cars. Gary Mitchell, a spokesman for the association, said while the auto industry was making more small, fuel-efficient cars, they weren't as safe as the larger models. ``What we've seen in recent years is that the industry has placed such a great emphasis on fuel economy that safety has been compromised,'' he said. ``They're lighter so they're more fuel efficient and that's commendable, but I don't think fuel efficiency should take a front seat over safety.'' High-performance cars tend to have higher death rates because of the type of drivers they attract, Mitchell said. ``The study shows there's a direct correlation between high performance sports models and a higher accident death rate,'' he said. ``The Corvette, Camaro, Mustang, Firebird, and Dodge Daytona were all in the top 10 in terms of highest overall death rate. ``The average driver in those cars is a man under 30 years old,'' he said. ``Industry figures show there cars with a higher percentage of female drivers tend to have lower death rates. There's a direct correlation.'' Debra Barclay, a spokeswoman for the Washington, D.C.-based Center for Auto Safety, agreed the the study's finding that smaller cars were less safe, but said that doesn't have to be the case. ``We have continued to say that you can make fuel efficient cars that are safe. The technology is available. It's not being used to the extent that it can be,'' she said. ``With airbags, consumers have to pay a few extra hundred dollars, but they get an opportunity to save their life. People are thrilled to have that choice,'' she said. Barclay added that at least 14 insurance companies were offering discounts to customers who buy cars equipped with airbags. Mitchell and Barclay also said Congress should toughen safety standards for smaller cars. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration declined to comment on the study.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Drops Six to 931, Still Above Same Period Last Year
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and gas rigs continued to decline this week, dropping by six to 931, Baker Hughes Inc. reported. But the number of working rigs still was higher than the 780 total posted for the same week last year, Baker Hughes said Monday. In the two previous weeks, the count plunged by 55 and then 27 to 937. Experts blamed the decline on bad weather in some states and a general seasonal decline. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Ike Kerridge, a Baker Hughes vice president and economist, said the rig count generally declines during the first quarter. The count probably will bottom out in March or April, he said. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil producing states, Pennsylvania had the greatest weekly plunge, having lost six rigs, while New Mexico lost five, Kansas lost three, North Dakota lost two, and Oklahoma and Wyoming each lost one. Texas had the largest gain with seven, while Louisiana added four, Colorado increased by three and California gained two. The number of working rigs in both Michigan and Ohio were unchanged for the week.

DOC.HEAD: Conference Committee to Begin Work on Oil Spill Liability Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 6th graf, The House ... to show that in House legislation, hazardous materials category also will include oil
DOC.TEXT: Congress is expected this week to start working out differences in oil spill liability legislation so it can send a bill to President Bush by the March 24 anniversary of the Exxon Valdez accident. The biggest remaining problem is a dispute over whether tankers should be required to have double hulls and double bottoms. The legislation _ 15 years in the making _ would set comprehensive requirements for financing and managing oil spill cleanups. The issue was thrust to the forefront last year by the Exxon Valdez disaster. The tanker, which did not have a double hull or double bottom, dumped 11 million gallons of crude oil into Prince William Sound, Alaska, when it ran aground. Staff members say the House wants the legislation ready for the president's signature by the Valdez accident anniversary. The Senate already has chosen its members for the conference committee, while the House is expected to announce conference committee members on Wednesday or Thursday. The House bill would put oil into the hazardous material category by requiring that tankers calling on U.S. ports with petroleum products, like those carrying other dangerous substances, have double bottoms within seven years and double hulls within 15 years of the bill's enactment. All new tankers constructed in the United States would have to be built with double hulls. Such requirements already exist for tankers carrying other hazardous materials. The Senate version calls for a study to determine if any other technology would give better protection against spills. ``People have argued this thing over the years and nobody can really say precisely what would happen if a double hull or double bottom vessel was grounded,'' said Joe Lastelic, spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, which opposes that provision. A double-bottomed ship could be more difficult to salvage because water could accumulate between the two bottoms and cause the ship to sink or capsize faster, he said. There also is concern that vapors would accumulate between the two layers in an accident and cause an explosion, he added. International shippers lobbied against such a requirement since it would mean foreign tankers would have to be refitted to do business in American ports. The White House also opposes the provision. Rep. Dean Gallo, R-N.J., plans to offer a motion to instruct House conferees to support the hull-bottom requirement when they meet with the Senate. The motion would be non-binding, but it would lead to a House roll call vote and give congressional negotiators a sense of how strongly the House feels about the provision. Environmental groups like the National Wildlife Federation and the Sierra Club are lobbying in favor of double hulls and double bottoms. In past congressional sessions, the House-Senate dispute has centered on whether states should be allowed to enact stricter liability laws than the federal government. The Senate favored such a provision while the House was opposed. Many House members put up a fight over the issue again last year, but eventually the states' rights faction won. Twenty-eight states have their own oil spill liability statutes, and 19 require unlimited liability for the oil companies or carriers to clean up damage to the environment. The oil industry wants a federal law that would pre-empt the state laws and set limits on the amount a company would have to pay for cleanup, saying insurance costs could put reputable shippers out of business.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Reports Weekly Production
DOC.TEXT: Domestic coal production totaled 20.6 million tons during the week ending Jan. 27, down from the 20.8 million tons produced in the previous week, the Department of Energy reported Monday. The U.S. coal industry produced 19.6 million tons in the same week last year, according to the department's Energy Information Administration. Wyoming ranked first among the 27 coal-producing states with 3.47 million tons produced. Kentucky was second at 3.43 million tons and West Virginia was third at 3 million tons, the agency said. Domestic coal production so far this year is 78.7 million tons, 4 percent ahead of last year's production at this time. The week's production accounts for bituminous and lignite coal.

DOC.HEAD: Sears Reports Gains In Quarterly, Annual Net
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. today reported more than a five-fold increase in fourth-quarter profit after the previous year's expensive restructuring charge and said its annual earnings rose 4 percent. Despite the gains, Sears said results for both the fourth quarter and the full year were adversely affected by insurance claims stemming from the San Francisco area earthquake, Hurricane Hugo and severe cold weather in the South. Sears reported net income of $602.1 million, or $1.76 per common share, for the three months ended Dec. 31 compared with $117.4 million, or 32 cents a share, for the corresponding 1988 quarter. Revenue for the quarter rose 4.2 percent to $15.18 billion from $14.56 billion, Sears said in a statement. Results for the fourth quarter of 1988 included an after-tax charge of $442 million, or $1.17 per share, for restructuring the company's retailing business and a loss of $78.9 million, or 16 cents per share from the sale of the life and health insurance operations of the Allstate Insurance Co., a Sears subsidiary. Sears said claims of more than $250 million resulting from the September storm known as Hurricane Hugo contributed to the steepest losses in Allstate's history. For all of 1989, Sears reported net income of $1.51 billion, or $4.30 per share, up from $1.45 billion, or $3.84 per share, in 1988. Annual revenue rose 7.1 percent to a record $53.8 billion from $50.3 billion in 1988, Sears said. In a statement accompanying the results, Sears Chairman Edward A. Brennan said 1989 was ``a year of transition.'' ``The company is well-positioned as it enters the 1990s,'' Brennan said, ``and we expect momentum to build as the year progresses.''

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Gains On China Sale
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices rose modestly this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade following news of government approval for a subsidized sale of U.S. wheat to China. Soybean futures were slightly higher in early trading while corn futures were mixed. The Agriculture Department said it had accepted China's bid for 300,000 metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices. The bid was revealed Friday. Under a government program designed to increase export sales, the grain exporters from whom China buys the wheat will receive grain or grain credits from the government. The wheat market also was supported this morning by indications Egypt is seeking to buy 250,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat. But the gains were limited by last week's National Weather Service forecast for wetter-than-normal conditions later this week over a widespread area of the nation's midsection. Slight early gains in the soybean market reflected slack farmer sales, analysts said. In early trading, wheat futures were \ cent to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.81 a bushel; corn futures were { cent lower to { cent higher with March at $2.37 a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $1.35\ a bushel; soybeans were { cent to 1\ cents higher with March at $5.61\ a bushel. Livestock and meat futures rallied in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .15 cent to .53 cent higher with February at 79.72 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent to .60 cent higher with March at 83.30 cents a pound; live hogs were .08 cent to .50 cent higher with February at 48.92 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .33 cent to .70 cent higher with February at 49.50 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled higher on Friday while most pork futures retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Kelly Services Acquires Dutch, New Zealand Businesses
DOC.TEXT: Kelly Services Inc., the largest U.S. temporary help company, has acquired companies in the Netherlands and New Zealand, Kelly said Monday. The acquisitions bring to eight the number of overseas temporary services companies Kelly has acquired since January 1988. A Kelly subsidiary, Kelly Temporary Services BV, acquired Free-lance Uitzendburo, which operates six offices in the Netherlands, and Adstaff Associates Ltd., which has operations in Auckland, New Zealand. Amounts of the transactions were undisclosed. There will be no changes in staffs or duties stemming from either acquisition, Kelly said in a news release. Kelly Services employs more than 560,000 temporary workers annually through more than 950 offices in eight countries, including the Netherlands and New Zealand. It reported revenue of $1.27 billion and earnings of $60.3 million in 1988, the latest annual figure available.

DOC.HEAD: RCA Fined $2.5 Million in Pentagon Contractors Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS byline, UPDATES throughout with court hearing. No pickup. Moved on general news wires as PM-RCA-Pentagon Probe.
DOC.HEAD: Precede FAIRFIELD, CONN.
DOC.TEXT: RCA Corp. pleaded guilty in federal court today to two felony charges and was fined $2.5 million as part of the continuing probe of contractors who acquired and passed along secret Defense Department plans for weapons systems. One former and one current RCA employee also entered guilty pleas to charges of illegally conveying government property. The government told U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris that in the years 1978-1985, RCA acquired copies of a wide range of Department of Defense documents dealing with program objectives, internal decisions and budget estimates. ``Both counts of the information to which RCA plead guilty concrned RCA's unauthorized acquisition of secret editions of the Department of Defense's five-year defense program,'' said the U.S. attorney's office. One count charged that RCA, through former employee Leonard Kampf, gave others within the company a copy of the five-year program for 1985. The other count made a similar charge for 1986, involving Ronald Stevens. Stevens, 49, manager of marketing services at RCA's Aerospace and Defense Division at Cherry Hill, N.J. and Kampf, 69, former manager of marketing information and communications in Cherry Hill, face possible sentences of up to 10 years in prison and fines of $10,000. As part of their plea agreement, the two agreed to cooperate with the investigation. Stevens has been suspended from his duties, said George Jamison, a spokesman for General Electric Co., which purchased RCA in 1986. RCA agreed to enter the guilty plea when it learned the two planned to plead guilty to charges of conveying government documents without proper authority, according to a statement from GE. ``This unfortunate chapter in RCA history is now closed,'' GE said in a statement. The settlement is the second in three months. The Boeing Co. recently paid $5.2 million to settle civil and criminal charges involving similar violations.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico & Commercial Banks Sign Debt Reduction Agreement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after the 7th graf and ADDS 1 graf at the end with opposition comment.
DOC.TEXT: Mexico and its commercial bank creditors signed a debt reduction agreement that was praised as an example for other indebted nations and the result of the government's economic reforms. ``Mexico stands as a beacon of hope for other debtor nations,'' Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said at Sunday's signing ceremony. Brady laid the groundwork for the agreement a year ago by offering debt forgiveness in exchange for economic reforms in developing countries. Previously, banks had managed the debt crisis mainly by lending countries money to cover their interest payments, a process that merely increased the total debt burden. ``It is very important to have the first transaction completed but we do see it as only the beginning,'' Brady said. Mexico's agreement will cut the country's $48.5 billion bank debt by a little more than $7 billion and reduce annual interest payments by about $1.6 billion. Mexico estimates the full impact of the agreement will save it more than $4 billion a year. ``The renegotiation of the debt is sufficient for Mexico'' and will lead to growth and better living conditions for Mexicans, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari said. Salinas said faster growth is ``a social imperative to respond to the demands of the more than 85 million Mexicans of today and the 10 million more'' who are expected to swell the nation's population during the remainder of his six-year term. Opposition leaders criticized the agreement, predicting it would bring even greater austerity and hardship to the majority of Mexicans. ``It's not a solution, in the end,'' Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, leader of the leftist Revolutionary Democratic Party said, adding that it will lead to a prolonged period of austerity for Mexico's lower income wage earners. Treasury Secretary Pedro Aspe said the country's total debt, including loans from governments, will total $93.6 billion after the accord. That is the second highest in the developing world after Brazil's $114 billion. Officials of the 15 banks that negotiated the agreement on behalf of Mexico's 450 creditor banks signed the accord in the ceremony at the National Palace. The other banks will sign in New York. Salinas took office Dec. 1, 1988, six years into an economic crisis provoked by overborrowing and plunging prices for crude oil, the country's main export. In a sweeping program to reform the heavily-protected economy, Salinas has opened the country to competition from imports, encouraged foreign and domestic investment, begun selling a wide array of state-owned companies to the private sector and started slashing subsidies. Under the agreement, banks could choose from three options: reducing the principal amount of their loans by 35 percent, reducing interest to a fixed rate of 6.25 percent, or offering new loans equal to 25 percent of the debt they already held. Banks opted to reduce principal on $20 billion of the debt, reduce interest on a further $22.5 billion and extend new loans for $6 billion in existing debt. The banks that chose the first two options will exchange their debt for Mexican government bonds backed by U.S. Treasury bonds. Mexico will buy the U.S. bonds as collateral with a $7 billion package of credits from multilateral agencies and Japan, as well as the Mexican government's own funds. Aspe said the agreement will save Mexico an average $4.1 billion annually in net transfers abroad in the next four years. The figure includes $1.6 billion in reduced interest payments; an average influx of $288 million a year in new credits, and the deferment of prinicpal payments of $2.2 billion a year. The country has been paying about $12 billion a year in interest and principal. The agreement ``will serve as an example for the other countries affected by the problem of debt,'' said Michel Camdessus, director of the International Monetary Fund, which is lending money to Mexico as part of the agreement. Other countries in line for Brady plan renegotiations have not made as drastic reforms as Mexico. Venezuela has begun a program, but renegotiations of about $21 billion of its $34.6 billion foreign debt have made little headway. Argentina, which owes about $64 billion to commercial banks, is in a ``very difficult situation,'' but President Carlos Menem has said he will undertake reforms, Brady said. Brazil was $4.4 billion behind in interest payments to private foreign creditors in December and Argentina has about $4 billion in interest overdue. Brazil is refusing to pay, saying it wants President-elect Fernando Collor de Mello to assume office in March with a safe level of reserves. Cardenas said that if Mexico had joined other debtor nations to negotiate in a block, ``a real attitude of responsibility would have been obtained from the creditor banks.''

DOC.HEAD: International Paper To Close Phila. Container Plant
DOC.TEXT: International Paper Co. said Monday it would close its Philadelphia-area container plant by April 6, affecting about 100 employees. Benny R. Smith, general manager of IP's northern container division, said a review of plant operations made it ``clear that closing the Philadelphia plant was unavoidable due to the continued unprofitable nature of the operation.'' IP has other container plants in the Northeast that can serve the Philadelphia plant's customers, Smith said. Smith said IP will provide job severance and job placement services to affected employees. The plant employs an average 70 hourly and 28 salaried workers, but a company announcement did not specify what services or transfer rights would be available to them. A company spokesman did not immediately return a phone call seeking further details. IP bought the plant, which makes corrugated containers, in 1958.

DOC.HEAD: Capital Cities-ABC, Tribune Post Earnings Gains for 4th Qtr
DOC.TEXT: Capital Cities-ABC Inc. said Monday its earnings climbed 30 percent in the fourth quarter while another large media company, Tribune Co., reported a 7 percent increase in its profit for the same period. Capital Cities-ABC, the New York-based operator of the ABC Television Network, said it earned $182 million, or $10.33 a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31 compared with $140.2 million, or $7.76 a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 14.4 percent to $1.51 billion from $1.32 billion in 1988. For the year, Capital Cities earned $485.7 million, or $27.25 a share, up 25.6 percent from $387.1 million, or $22.31 a share, a year earlier. Annual revenue rose 4 percent to $4.96 billion from $4.77 billion in 1988. The company said operating income rose 13 percent for the year to $922.5 million, including a 16 percent increase from broadcasting. The ABC Television Network had significantly improved results compared with a slight loss in 1988, the company said. Revenue at the network was up slightly for the year as strong advertising demand in the second half of 1989 offset the impact of the Winter Olympics and Super Bowl telecasts on 1988 results. Operating results at its 80 percent-owned ESPN cable network were well ahead of last year, while the company's eight television stations and 21 radio stations and radio networks reported moderate increases. Publishing earnings improved slightly with gains for its newspapers offset by declines at several specialized publications. Chicago-based Tribune Co. said it earned $$67.6 million, or 90 cents a share, in the three months ended Dec. 31 compared with $62.9 million, or 84 cents a share, a year earlier. Fourth-quarter revenue rose 7 percent to $668 million from $624.7 million a year earlier. The company cited improved newspaper results, a reduction in net interest expense and a lower effective tax rate for the increase. For the year, Tribune said it earned $242.4 million, or $3.17 a share, up 15 percent from $210.4 million, or $2.78 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the year rose 5 percent to $2.45 billion from $2.33 billion in 1988. The operating profit at the newspaper group rose 13 percent for the year to $297.1 million, as improved results at the Chicago, Ft. Lauderdale and Orlando newspapers more than offset an operating loss at the New York Daily News. Advertising revenue rose 5 percent for the year while circulation revenue rose 4 percent. The company's broadcasting and entertainment group posted a 24 percent increase in operating profit for the year to $96.8 million despite a $10 million writedown of television programming assets in the second quarter. Tribune owns six TV stations and four radio stations and its entertainment group is involved with TV programs including ``At the Movies,'' ``Geraldo'' and ``The Joan Rivers Show.'' Its newsprint business had an operating profit of $61.3 million for the year, down 38 percent from a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Falls in Europe, Gold Rises
DOC.NOTE: Eds: An AMs version planned by 5:30 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar declined Monday against other major currencies, particularly the West German mark, in quiet European trading. Gold prices rose. Foreign exchange dealers said trading was generally dull and uneventful. But they said a late burst of dollar selling against the West German mark helped push the U.S. currency nearly 2 pfennigs lower than levels quoted late Friday in London. The dollar fell on the belief that Soviet Leader Mikhail Gorbachev will succeed in persuading the Communist Party to give up its exclusive claim to power, said a senior dealer at Barclays Bank PLC. The directorate of the Communist Party's Central Committee was meeting Monday and Tuesday to debate Gorbachev's proposal. ``There was a return of some sentiment that Gorbachev will stamp his mark on the Politburo,'' the dealer said. There have been fears that Gorbachev would run into severe opposition at the party conference in Moscow. The dollar often benefits from political turmoil abroad. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar closed up 0.64 yen to 145.60 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 145.30 yen. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6980 from $1.6820 late Friday. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $423.25 a troy ounce, up from $417.25 late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to $423.00 an ounce from $417.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.10 to close at a bid $416.86 an ounce. Silver rose in London to a late bid price of $5.37 a troy ounce from late Friday's $5.29.

DOC.HEAD: EC Leader Says Britain Meets Conditions for Eurocurrency Membership
DOC.TEXT: European Community Competition Commissioner Sir Leon Brittan said Monday that Britain's conditions for becoming a full member of the European Monetary System have been met. ``The way is now open for the government to start looking for an early date for full EMS membership,'' Sir Leon told the Overseas Banking Club in London. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, under pressure to link the pound to the system's currency-stabilizing Exchange Rate Mechanism, laid down stringent conditions last June. These included that France and Italy abolish controls on the movement of capital and that Britain's high inflation rate, now nearly 8 percent, fall. Sir Leon said France and Italy were removing exchange controls, rules for a single market in banking were agreed upon, the commission was taking a more ``rigorous'' approach to state subsidies of industry and the British government was trying to reduce inflation. ``Once the downward trend is clear, joining the ERM would actually help the continuing battle against inflation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Company Breaks Off Talks About Planned Defense Subsidiary Sales
DOC.TEXT: Daimler-Benz AG said Monday it has broken off talks with a consortium of several West German engineering companies about the sale of its navy and missile technology lines. The sale is required as part of a government agreement that allowed Daimler-Benz to take over the aerospace concern Messerschmitt-Boelker-Blohm GmbH. It was the largest merger in West German history. Daimler-Benz said its Deutsche Aerospace AG aircraft and defense subsidiary has ended negotiations with Systemtechnik Nord, a group of companies led by the steel and machinery company Fried. Krupp GmbH. In November, Daimler-Benz signed a memorandum of understanding with Systemtechnik Nord to sell the navy and missile activities. The consortium was formed under pressure from the governments of Hamburg and Bremen, where most of the navy and missile operations are located, to prevent a loss of jobs. A spokesman for Deutsche Aerospace said the company has ``gained the impression that not all partners of the consortium intend to stick to the memorandum of understanding.'' He did not elaborate. But the spokesman did not rule out an agreement with the group once the talks have been put on a new basis. Besides Krupp, which holds 35 percent of Systemtechnik Nord, Preussag-Salzgitter and Bremer Vulkan own 30 percent each, while Matra SA of France and two smaller shipbuilding companies have a joint 5 percent. Under the terms set by Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann last September, Daimler-Benz has two years to sell the two divisions. Hausmann approved the merger against the recommendation of the Federal Cartel Office and strong political forces, but set certain conditions to help maintain competition in the nation's defense industry. The purchase of MBB made Daimler-Benz the country's largest aerospace and defense company. Daimler-Benz also makes Mercedes-Benz automobiles. A spokesman for the city government of Bremen said Daimler-Benz and the consortium have not agreed on the price of the transaction.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mostly Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade, although near-term wheat contracts rose amid news of a wheat sale to China and a call for more wheat sales to the Soviet Union. The Agriculture Department said Monday morning it had accepted China's bid for 300,000 metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in April and May. Under a government program designed to increase export sales, the grain exporters who sell China the wheat will receive grain or grain credits from the government. The wheat market got a further boost from the National Association of Wheat Growers' call to increase offers of subsidized wheat to the Soviet Union. In a letter to Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, the association requested the USDA offer another 2 million metric tons of wheat to the Soviets. Other grain and soybean futures finished slightly lower, pressured by forecasts for beneficial precipitation this week in the nation's midsection. At the close, wheat futures were 2 cents lower to 4 cents higher with the contract for delivery in March at $3.83 a bushel; corn futures were { cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $2.36\ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1{ cents lower with March at $1.35 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2 cents lower with March at $5.58\ a bushel.

The stock market pushed higher this afternoon with the size of the advance gaining strength toward the close. DOC.HEAD: Former Paramount Exec Named to Development Post at Time Warner
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. said Monday it had selected Arthur Barron, a retired executive from entertainment industry rival Paramount Communications Inc., to head its new business development operation. Barron, 55, will be chairman of Time Warner Enterprises, which oversees the company's new ventures and its minority equity holdings. In his new post, Barron will be involved primarily in the development of Time Warner's strategies and ventures abroad, the company said. Barron retired last July from Paramount, where he had been president of the entertainment group, which includes Paramount Pictures, Madison Square Garden, the New York Knicks basketball team and the New York Rangers hockey team and theater operations. Ironically, Paramount tried to halt Time Inc.'s merger with Warner Communications Inc. last year by mounting a bid for Time, which Time management rejected. Barron said he was ``on the sidelines'' for that episode. He announced in 1987 that he planned to retire from Paramount when he reached age 55 after 26 years service. In the six months following his departure from Paramount, Barron said he had a chance to ``take inventory and see what I wanted to do next.'' He decided he wanted to get back into the business and began talking a month or so ago about the possibility of joining Time Warner. In addition to serving as president of the Paramount entertainment group for five years, Barron served at various times as chief financial officer and executive vice president at Paramount Pictures, the movie division, and as vice president and general sales manager for worldwide syndication at Desilu Productions Inc., which makes television shows. He and his wife Joan live in Beach Haven, N.J.

DOC.HEAD: Schlumberger Reports Slightly Lower 4Qtr. Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Schlumberger Ltd.'s fourth-quarter net income slipped to $118.1 million, or 50 cents a share, from $118.9 million, or 49 cents a share, a year earlier, the company said Monday. Revenue in the three-month period totaled $1.2 billion, down about 3 percent from $1.24 billion in the comparable 1988 period. For the year, the New York-based oil drilling and oilfield service company had net income of $441.5 million, or $1.86 a share, down from $476.2 million, or $1.80 a share, in 1988. Revenue totaled $4.7 billion, down about 5 percent from $4.9 billion in the previous year. Schlumberger said the previous year's stock buyback reduced the company's interest income in 1989. ``Decreased interest income of $63 million primarily resulted from spending $1.2 billion in 1988 to repurchase 34.5 million shares,'' said Chairman Euan Baird. The increase in earnings per share on lower income also was the result of fewer average shares outstanding, Baird said. Higher oil prices in late 1989 helped the company's oilfield businesses recover from a slump in 1988, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sears 4th Qtr. Net Up From Depressed Year-Ago; Hugo Hits Allstate Results
DOC.TEXT: Sears, Roebuck and Co. on Monday reported its fourth-quarter earnings rose sharply from a year earlier, when it undertook a costly restructuring, and said Hurricane Hugo and the Bay Quake made 1989 the costliest year ever for its Allstate insurance subsidiary. Results from Sears' merchandise group, its biggest business, rose sharply in a performance that several retailing analysts said was better than they had expected. Sears reported net income of $602.1 million, or $1.76 per common share, for the three months ended Dec. 31 compared with $117.4 million, or 32 cents per share, for the same period a year earlier. Sales for the quarter rose 4.2 percent to $15.2 billion from $14.6 billion, Chicago-based Sears said in a statement. Results for the fourth quarter of 1988 included an after-tax charge of $442 million for restructuring of the company's retailing business and a loss of $78.9 million from the sale of Allstate Insurance Co.'s life and health insurance operations. For all of 1989, Sears reported net income of $1.51 billion, or $4.30 per share, compared with $1.45 billion, or $3.84 per share, in 1988. Annual revenue rose 7.1 percent to a record $53.8 billion from $50.3 billion in 1988, Sears said. ``The company is well-positioned as it enters the 1990s and we expect momentum to build as the year progresses,'' Chairman Edward A. Brennan said in a statement accompanying the earnings. Last year, Sears overhauled its retailing operation, the world's largest, by cutting costs and introducing ``everyday low pricing'' in hopes of reversing slippage in its market share to both general merchandise discounters such as K mart and Wal-Mart and to ``superstores'' specializing in appliances, electronics or automotive products. The effectiveness of the strategy has been questioned since its debut last March but analysts said the fourth-quarter results indicated the retailing unit may be shaping up after a shakeout. The merchandise group reported fourth-quarter income of $368.6 million on sales of $9.6 billion compared with a loss of $113.5 million on sales of $9.5 billion in 1988. The 1988 period included a $442 million after-tax restructuring charge. The fourth quarter 1989 results included a $26 million after-tax gain from an accounting change, compared with a $26.4 million after-tax charge in 1988 for the same accounting change. ``Generally speaking, they are making progress,'' said retail analyst Monroe Greenstein, of the investment firm Bear, Stearns & Co. He said the merchandise unit was getting a better grip on expenses and that its gross profit margin was wider than many observers had expected, due partly to the mix of goods Sears is offering. Retail analyst Edward Weller of Montgomery Securities Inc. also said the results of the merchandise group were better than he had expected. Allstate reported fourth-quarter income of $245.4 million on revenue of $4.2 billion, compared with $206.3 million on revenue of $3.8 billion in fourth quarter 1988. Sears said natural disasters last year, including Hurricane Hugo, the northern California quake and severe cold weather in the South, resulted in historically high catastrophic damage claims against Allstate but would not reveal the dollar amount of the claims. Sears earlier had pegged claims stemming from Hurricane Hugo alone at more than $250 million. The Dean Witter financial services group reported fourth-quarter income of $48.4 million on revenue of $1.1 billion, compared with operating profit of $26.3 million on revenue of $958.7 million a year earlier. The Coldwell Banker real estate group reported fourth-quarter income of $15.3 million on revenue of $362.6 million compared with income of $61.9 million on revenue of $377.4 million a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Sales Fall 4.6 Percent in Late January
With BC-Auto Sales-Table
DOC.TEXT: Sales of cars and trucks made in North America by the nation's Big Three automakers fell 4.6 percent in late January from last year, with an increase in truck sales offsetting falling car sales, the companies said Monday. The sales pace last year was among the highest during any 10-day period of 1989, skewing the comparison with this year. During the period this year, the Big Three, especially Chrysler Corp., were offering incentives, and these inducements seemed to be boosting truck sales. Car sales for the three companies fell 12.9 percent while truck sales jumped 10.2 percent. General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler said they sold cars and trucks at an average daily rate of 36,537 during Jan. 21-31, compared with a rate of 38,284 during the same time last year. Chrysler announced a new incentive program Dec. 15, 1989, that, for the first time, offered cash rebates or low-interest financing on its popular minivans: the Dodge Caravan, Plymouth Voyager and Chrysler Town and Country. In January, Chrysler extended the incentives on all models but the minivans until the end of February. Chrysler guarantees that if it boosts the rebates before Sept. 30, the automaker will make up the difference to those that bought the vehicles during the current incentive period. Chrysler, which has made liberal use of incentives in the past, said its late-January car sales fell 4.1 percent while its truck sales, including the company's popular minivans and Jeeps, rose 42.7 percent. Those figures combined for a sales rate 20.3 percent higher than during the period last year. For the whole month, Chrysler's car and trucks sales were 19.9 percent higher than in January 1989. Ford said its combined car and truck sales fell 14.2 percent during late January compared with the same time last year, with car sales dropping 17.8 percent and light truck sales falling 8.2 percent. For the entire month, Ford's vehicle sales were down 5.2 percent. GM said its car and truck sales fell 6.5 percent during late January as car sales declined 11.8 percent and truck sales rose 6.8 percent. For all of January, GM's car and truck sales were 5.1 percent higher than in January of last year.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LONDON BC
Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished lower against major currencies in quiet trading Monday as the West German mark took center stage in foreign exchange. Gold prices rose in domestic and overseas trading. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $422.40 a troy ounce, $4.20 higher than Friday's close. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $422.75 an ounce, up $4.25. Gabriele Schmitt, a corporate trader for the Bank of New York, said the dollar's decline both here and abroad was ``mainly due to the mark's strength as opposed to the dollar's weakness.'' She said the mark gained on the belief that Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev will persuade his nation's Communist Party to give up its exclusive claim to power, thereby further fueling speculation that East and West Germany could some day be reunited. ``Even if it doesn't become a reunified Germany right away ... the belief is that West Germany has the potential to serve this huge market,'' Schmitt said. ``A lot of people are investing in German corporations.'' The dollar closed at 1.6590 marks in New York, down from 1.6830 Friday, and at 1.6670 marks in Europe, down from 1.6860. In Tokyo, where trading ends before Europe's business day begins, the dollar closed up 0.64 yen at 145.60 yen. It was quoted at 145.30 yen in London, and at 144.70 yen in New York, down from 145.50 yen Friday. Traders said the dollar's fall against the yen reflected concern the Japanese might keep a lower profile in the U.S. Treasury Department's quarterly bond auction this week. Reduced Japanese purchases would mean less demand for dollars to buy the bonds. The dollar was weaker against the British pound. Sterling rose to $1.6980 from $1.6820 late Friday in London, and to $1.7000 from $1.6840 in New York. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.47275 Swiss francs, down from 1.4920; 5.6370 French francs, down from 5.7160; 1,231.00 Italian lire, down from 1,251.00; and 1.18735 Canadian dollars, down from 1.18845. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Friday: 1.4780 Swiss francs, down from 1.4964; 5.6573 French francs, down from 5.7360; 1.8880 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9010; 1,236.00 Italian lire, down from 1,252.00; and 1.1891 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1884. Gold gained in London to $423.25 an ounce from $417.25 late Friday. In Zurich, gold rose to $423 an ounce from $417.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $1.10 to close at a bid $416.86 an ounce. Silver prices also headed higher. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.329 a troy ounce, up 2.2 cents from Friday. Silver rose in London to $5.37 an ounce from $5.29.
