DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures End Lower
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices sagged Monday mainly on technical factors with little news to buoy the market, analysts said. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the March contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, dropped 63 cents to $22.39 a 42-gallon barrel after a gain of 32 cents Friday. Contracts for later delivery declined 58 cents to 51 cents a barrel. Among refined products traded on the exchange, the March contract for No. 2 heating oil, which jumped 1.52 cents Friday, tumbled 2.31 cents to end at 55.95 cents a gallon. Contracts for delivery through 1990 closed down from 2 cents to 1.24 cents. Wholesale unleaded gasoline for March delivery finished off 1.82 cents at 62.40 cents a gallon. Other contracts closed with losses of 2 cents to 1.65 cents. Analysts attributed the days losses mainly to technical factors and to selling ahead of Tuesday's inventory report by the American Petroleum Institute. ``There wasn't any news driving the market today,'' said Jack Unger, energy broker for Merrill Lynch Energy Futures. ``Some people might be getting out before the APIs.'' Unger said heavy waves of selling by large commodities brokers knocked prices lower in spurts throughout the trading session. ``It made buyers skittish,'' Unger said. Randall Rothenberg, futures trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said expectations of warmer weather also helped depress prices. ``Some poeple went long Friday hoping that cold weather in the Northeast would stimulate prices but those hopes were dashed today with forecasts of 50-degree temperatures by midweek,'' Rothenberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Post Modest Advance in Slow Trading
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, Volume on ... to CORRECT reference to previous lower trading volume. Picks up 5th graf pvs, Nationwide, consolidated ...
DOC.TEXT: The stock market gained more ground Monday, but its modest advance came in the slowest trading of the new year amid worries that interest rates are headed higher. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose 16.44 points on Friday, added another 19.82 points to close at 2,622.52. It was the third increase in the market's best-known indicator in the past four sessions. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 838 up, 646 down and 490 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 130.95 million shares, down from 164.40 million in the previous session. That was the lowest trading volume since 128.03 million shares on Dec. 28, 1989. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 174.12 million shares. Prices of blue-chip stocks moved into the plus column early in the session, and held onto tiny gains for most of the day, extending their advance with a spurt in the final hour of trading. The market has generally labored this year under the weight of lackluster corporate earnings reports and rising interest rates. Interest rates are of particular concern this week as the government plans to auction $30 billion in new securities over the next three days. Some credit market analysts say rates must rise to attract foreign investors, especially the Japanese. Higher rates hurt the stock market, however, by making yields on short-term securities more competitive and placing pressure on corporate earnings. ``No one is willing to go out and commit themselves,'' said Charles Jensen, chief technical analyst at MKI Securities Corp. ``It's going to take some time to build up confidence in this market.'' Newton D. Zinder, senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Hutton, said the late advance came from ``traders who were encouraged the market did not go down with bond prices as weak as they have been.'' Yields on short-term Treasury issues added between 2 and 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, on Monday, while the yield on 30-year Treasury bonds rose to 8.53 percent from 8.50 percent late Friday. Amax was the most active issue on the NYSE, rising } to 23}. Among other actively-traded stocks, Philip Morris gained | to 38~, Exxon rose [ to 48, Bank of New England added { to 5} and IBM advanced 2{ to 99|. Genentech, which soared 8[ on Friday, lost 1} to 28[. Roche Holding agreed last week to make an offer of $36 a share for half of the company's stock and invest nearly $500 million in the company. Pan Am rose } to 3}. A union official said Sunday that Pan American World Airways may announce a deal with Northwest Airlines later this week. Also in the airline group, UAL rose 5\ to 135} and AMR was up ~ at 54\. Precious metals stocks were higher. ASA gained 4] to 72|, Homestake Mining was up 1~ at 23{ and Newmont Gold was up 1{ at 56{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $12.12 billion, or 0.38 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.60 to 183.35. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.16 to 382.29, and S&P's 500-stock composite index gained 0.93 to 331.85. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 2.52 to 424.73. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 354.70, up 1.14.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Plunge As Supply-Demand Factors Come To Fore
DOC.TEXT: Petroleum futures prices fell sharply Monday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as traders frustrated by resistance in the crude oil market turned their sights to a bevy of bearish signals for gasoline and heating oil. On other commodity markets, orange juice futures plunged; precious metals advanced; livestock and meat futures were higher; and grains and soybeans were mostly lower. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 51 cents to 63 cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $22.39 a barrel; wholesale home heating oil finished 1.34 cents to 2.31 cents lower with March at 55.95 cents a gallon; wholesale unleaded gasoline was 1.65 cents to 2 cents lower with March at 62.40 cents a gallon. Energy futures prices rose across the board last week, largely due to technical strength in the crude oil market despite such negative fundamental factors as weak cash markets for petroleum products and growing U.S. inventories of gasoline and heating oil. Signs of an impending collapse first surfaced Friday when the March crude oil contract climbed to $23.05, then fell back. Market bulls tried again on Monday to bid the contract beyond its lifetime high of $23.18, but the rally failed at $23.06, setting the stage for a sell-off. And with plenty of negative supply-and-demand news around _ including weak cash markets, slack demand for heating oil and expanding inventories of refined products _ prices fell rapidly. ``The market just ran out of steam today,'' said Jim Fiedler, a vice president of E.D.& F. Man International Futures Inc. ``Crude had been carrying us for the last few days but I think the product fundamentals started coming through.'' Orange juice futures prices tumbled on the New York Cotton Exchange in a wave of selling inspired almost entirely by technical factors. Analysts said they expect the Agriculture Department, in a report scheduled for release Friday, to reduce by as much as 4 million boxes its estimate for the Florida orange crop, which was severely damaged by a Christmastime freeze. Last month, the USDA pegged the crop at 91 million boxes. Frozen concentrated orange juce settled 4.65 cents to 6.35 cents lower with March at $1.9065 a pound. Gold futures posted strong gains on New York's Commodity Exchange as concerns about political change in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe prompted new buying by investors. Gold futures finished $4.10 to $4.20 higher with February at $422.40 a troy ounce; silver was 2 cents to 2.4 cents higher with March at $5.358 a troy ounce. Pork belly futures rose sharply on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in a technical rebound from last week's steep losses. Most livestock futures also rose in line with strong cash markets. Live cattle ended .02 cent lower to .70 cent higher with February at 79.55 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .12 cent to .70 cent higher with March at 83.17 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent lower to .60 cent higher with February at 49.02 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.08 cent to 1.52 cent higher with February at 50.52 cents a pound. Grain and soybean futures settled mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade with the exception of near-term wheat contracts, which gained amid news of a wheat sale to China and a call for more wheat sales to the Soviet Union. The Agriculture Department said Monday morning it had accepted China's bid for 300,000 metric tons of wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in April and May. The wheat market got a further boost from a call by the National Association of Wheat Growers' call for the USDA to offer 2 million metric tons more wheat to the Soviet Union. Wheat futures settled 2 cents lower to 4{ cents higher with March at $3.83{ a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1\ cents lower with March at $2.36{ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1 cent lower with March at $1.35 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 2 cents lower with March at $5.58\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: General Electric's RCA Unit Fined $2.5 Million in Pentagon Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 12th graf, `Kampf, 69 ...,' to CORRECT RCA division to Government Systems. INSERTS 4 grafs after 13th graf pvs, `They obtained ...,' to UPDATE with investigator comment and background. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co.'s RCA division pleaded guilty Monday to illegally obtaining classified Pentagon planning documents and agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle charges in the continuing probe of contractors trading defense secrets. RCA Corp. pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court to two felony counts of ``conveying without authority'' two secret editions of a Pentagon five-year spending program. A current RCA marketing official and a former one also pleaded guilty to felony counts of unlawfully conveying the secret documents they obtained from other defense firms to other people in RCA. The two face possible 10-year prison sentences. RCA's guilty plea marked an acceleration in the government's contining investigation, dubbed ``Operation Uncover.'' Nearly three months ago, Boeing Co. admitted it had illegally obtained Defense Department budget documents and paid $5.2 million in fines and restitution. Former Boeing employee Richard Lee Fowler was sentenced last month to two years in prison for obtaining more than 100 secret Pentagon documents and passing them along to Boeing and other contractors. In pleading guilty, RCA conceded to a statement of facts filed by prosecutors that it had acquired a wide array of secret Pentagon planning budget documents between 1978 and 1985 from other defense contractors. These included copies of authoritative statements of overall defense policy and program memoranda that detailed weapon-system priorities for the Army, the Air Force and the Navy, according to the prosecution filing. U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris fined the company $20,000. RCA, which was bought by GE in 1986, also agreed to pay the government $2.48 million to settle civil claims. RCA admitted in one count that on Dec. 19, 1983, marketing official Leonard C. Kampf provided a five-year planning document that contained details of the Pentagon's fiscal 1985 budget. In the second count, it admitted obtaining on Nov. 28, 1984, a five-year defense program document containing details for the fiscal 1986 budget from Ronald B. Stevens. Kampf, 69, who left the company in 1984, and Stevens, 49, manager of marketing services at RCA's Government Systems Division in Cherry Hill, N.J., have agreed to cooperate in the continuing investigation. They obtained the documents from employees of other defense firms, according to the government's filing. According to court papers, Kampf obtained documents from Philip R. Jackson, RCA's marketing representative in Washington. Jackson, who has received immunity from prosecution in return for his cooperation, testified at Fowler's trial that he received 20 documents from Fowler. The probe of major defense firms is continuing, said Michael Costello, who heads the investigation for the Pentagon's inspector general. Costello declined to identify those companies specifically under investigation. But RCA, Boeing and seven other firms were alleged during the Fowler trial to be part of a ring of companies that swapped secret Pentagon documents. The others named in testimony were Honeywell, Bendix, IBM, Grumman, Raytheon, Rockwell and Martin Marietta. GE spokesman George Jamison said Stevens has been suspended from his job. GE said in a statement from its Fairfield, Conn., headquartgrs that RCA, a wholly-owned subsidiary, agreed to enter the guilty plea after learning that Kampf and Stevens had planned to plead guilty. ``This unfortunate chapter in RCA history is now closed,'' GE said in its statement. Jamison stressed that the allegations centered on RCA. ``There have never been any allegations about GE with regard to this,'' he said. RCA's guilty plea came just three days after GE was convicted in Philadelphia of bilking the Pentagon out of $10 million for a battlefield computer system. GE, the nation's third-largest defense contractor, could be fined up to $71.9 million and faces possible suspension from future contracts.

DOC.HEAD: Freddie Mac Quarterly Earnings Up 19 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp., or Freddie Mac, said Monday its earnings rose 19 percent to a record $115 million in 1989's fourth quarter, which it attributed to higher income on its mortgage-backed securities sales. The October-December earnings of $1.72 per share compare with $97 million, or $1.45 per share, in the same period a year earlier. For all of 1989, Freddie Mac reported net income of $437 million, or $6.57 per share, up 15 percent from $381 million, or $5.73 per share, in 1988. Freddie Mac is a congressionally chartered but stockholder-owned company that helps finance one in eight American homes, primarily by purchasing mortgages from lenders and repackaging them into securities for sale to investors. Chartered in 1970, it was originally owned by the nation's savings and loans. Its stock was publicly traded for the first time last year. David Glenn, chief executive officer, said the company in 1989 had record mortgage securities volume and purchased the second-highest amount of mortgages in its history.

DOC.HEAD: LTV Earnings Decline 24 Percent On Aerospace, Steel Problems
DOC.TEXT: LTV Corp.'s profit fell 24 percent in the fourth quarter, due partly to a slump in the domestic steel industry and depressed results in its commercial aerospace programs, the company said Monday. LTV, currently operating under bankruptcy court supervision, said that for the three months ended Dec. 31, net income was $72.3 million, or 50 cents a share, down from $95.3 million, or 67 cents, in the same 1988 quarter. Revenue declined about 6 percent to $1.58 billion from $1.67 billion. The defense and energy company attributed the lower sales to reductions in military aircraft programs and fewer deliveries of LTV's multiple launch rocket system. LTV said higher costs for raw materials and services had a negative impact on its steel businesses. An increase in steel export volume was partially offset by a slumping automotive market, the company said. Lower demand also helped reduce overall steel plant operating capacity to 76 percent in the quarter, compared with 87 percent a year earlier. For the year, LTV earned $264.9 million, or $1.82 a share, a sharp reversal from 1988, when the company lost $3.15 billion, or $30.94 a share. Sales totaled $6.36 billion, a 13 percent drop from $7.3 billion in the previous year. The loss included a $1.35 billion charge related to the company's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing and a one-time $2.26 billion non-cash charge to reflect a change in the way the company accounts for pension benefits. Last year's earnings included a $30 million write down of costs associated with the company's cancellation of plans to build a flexible composites center to make advanced aircraft components. LTV, which completed the sale its Warren, Ohio steel bar manufacturing plant in November, said exclusion of those results for 1989, accounted for a $71 million decline in 1989 operating income and for an $872 million decline in the steel group's sales for the year. The divestiture is part of LTV's plan to reorganize into a more streamlined company before emerging from bankruptcy. LTV said its results also benefited from the deferral of interest, pension and other costs while the company operates under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

DOC.HEAD: New Kids on The Block `Immortalized in Plastic' as Hasbro Dolls
DOC.TEXT: Hasbro Inc. on Monday unveiled dolls modeled after the five members of the New Kids on the Block in a push by the big toy manufacturer to spur sales by capitalizing on the popular singing group. The announcement of the line of dolls and accessories was made at a news conference in Manhattan's Hard Rock Cafe, which houses rock 'n' roll memorabilia ranging from an Elvis Presley costume to an Eric Clapton guitar. Outside, hundreds of screaming fans _ mostly young girls _ crowded the sidewalk eager for a glimpse of the group that has been spinning hits out of anti-drug and other wholesome messages. The teenagers started converging on the area in the early morning after being tipped off by a local radio station that their music idols would be appearing at the news conference, a policeman at the scene said. He estimated that hundreds, possibly as many as 1,000, young fans were on hand. ``What you saw out there is the reason why we're bringing out the line,'' said Wayne Charness, a Hasbro spokesman. ``We are grasping on to something that girls can't seem to get enough of.'' One girl pressed up against the police barricade flanking the cafe entrance, Geneive Kervandjian, said she was skipping classes at Russell Sage Junior High 190 in Queens in hopes of seeing the Kids. Why? ``Because they're talented and I like what they stand for _ and they're gorgeous!'' she chortled. Al Carosi, Hasbro's senior vice president of marketing, said it was the first time the company has entered into a licensing agreement with a major name in music to create a line of fashion figures. Word of the hookup with the Kids was timed to generate advance publicity for Hasbro ahead of the line's official debut at Toy Fair, the industry's annual trade show that begins next Monday. The Hasbro line will be on store shelves by August, Carosi said. A month later a new half-hour Saturday morning cartoon television show based on the Kids is scheduled to begin airing. A feature-lenth film starring the Kids will begin shooting in October. The centerpiece of the Hasbro line are bendable 12\-inch dolls made to resemble the five Kids _ Jonathan Knight, his brother Jordan, Joe McIntyre, Donnie Wahlberg and Danny Wood _ complete with earrings, ponytails, rings and bracelets. They come dressed in either casual street clothes or stage costumes. The ``street look'' dolls will sell for around $12.99. Each concert doll, which will sell for about $15.99, carries a pretend microphone and comes with a cassette of a taped interview in which a group member answers questions on hot teeny-bopper topics like dating and kissing. The rest of the line, sold separately, includes additional clothes to augment the dolls' wardrobes, a stage playset including make-believe instruments, a battery-operated microphone, puzzles and other items. Lawrence Bernstein, president of the Hasbro toy division, said the company thinks the Kids have a long time before their popularity peaks and the line should be a lucrative addition to Hasbro's products, including the G.I. Joe action figures and Cabbage Patch dolls. Hasbro is the country's biggest toy company. The New Kids on the Block, whose members range in age from 17 to 20 and do not play instruments, was assembled in 1984 by Boston producer Maurice Starr and started its first major tour last summer as an opening act for former teen-queen Tiffany. Donnie Walhberg, who oftens acts as the group's spokesman, said members were honored to be turned into toys by Hasbro and had no qualms about using their pop music success in the commercial venture. ``We are being immortalized in plastic,'' Wahlberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Tourists Post First U.S. Travel Surplus in History
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Wynegar said ...,' to CORRECT ``billion'' to ``million.'' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A record 38.3 million foreigners traveled to the United States last year, contributing to a $450 million travel surplus, the first in U.S. history, the Commerce Department announced Monday. ``For the first time, the U.S. will enjoy a travel surplus of half a billion dollars,'' Undersecretary Rockwell Schnabel tol a briefing.``This means that foreigners spent more money in the United States than U.S. ciitzens spent abroad.'' The department's U.S. Travel and Tourism Administration said American and foreign travelers spent an identical $8.7 billion in getting to their destinations. But foreign visitors spent $34.3 billion in the United States, while Americans spent $33.9 billion abroad. ``For 1990, the surplus is projected to be $1.5 billion,'' Don Wynegar, the administration's research director, said. The adminstration is forecasting a 6 percent increase to 40.7 million foreign visitors this year and a 7 percent gain to 43.4 million in 1991. By the year 2000, foreign tourists are expected to total 67 million visitors, spending a projected $89 billion, Schnabel said. Sixty-four percent of the foreign tourists came from U.S. neighbors _ 15.2 million from Canada and 9.3 million from Mexico. Wynegar said 3 million Japanese visited the United States, an 18 percent increase over 1988, followed by 2.2 million British tourists, a 23 percent increase. Schnabel said overseas markets with the largest potential for continued growth include Japan, Britain, Australia and Sweden. ``While arrivals from Japan and the United Kingdom seem to be slowing slightly, averaging 9 percent growth per year, growth from Australia and Sweden is expected to average 14 percent annually in 1990 and 1991,'' he said. Wynegar said 10.4 million tourists from Mexico are expected this year, an 11 percent increase over 1989, while 15.5 million are expected from Canada, a 2 percent increase.

DOC.HEAD: Company Announces Bankruptcy Plan Approval
DOC.TEXT: Allegheny International Inc. announced Monday it has received U.S. Bankruptcy Court approval to submit its latest plan of reorganization to shareholders and creditors for a vote. In a statement, Oliver S. Travers, the chairman, chief executive officer and president, called the court's action ``a major step in moving the bankruptcy process forward.'' Allegheny International, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in February 1988, said it expects to emerge from that status by July. The company said acceptance of its plan would ``pave the way'' for that process. The Pittsburgh-based company is a manufacturer of consumer products, including Sunbeam and Oster appliances. The company said it will mail ballots and a description of the plan to creditors and shareholders within the next two weeks. Voting is to be completed by March 30. The statement said Allegheny International has received a letter of support for the plan from its unsecured creditors committee. The company also said it believes the plan will have broad constituent support. Company spokesman Edward M. Romanoff said Allegheny International proceeded with the reorganization plan despite a recent takeover bid from New York-based Japonica Partners. The company's board of directors has ``concerns'' about the investment firm's ability to make good on its $650 million offer, Romanoff said.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Concern Plans To Seek Removal of Georgia Gulf Board
DOC.TEXT: Dallas billionaire Harold C. Simmons, who launched a $1.1 billion tender offer for Georgia Gulf Corp., said Monday he would seek to oust the chemical concern's board of directors. In a related development, Georgia Gulf asked a Delaware court to declare its shareholder rights plan _ known as a ``poison pill'' defense _ valid and enforceable. A Simmons-controlled company, NL Industries Inc., said it intends to seek shareholder approval ``to remove all the current members'' of Georgia Gulf's board. NL Industries of Houston already holds a 9.9 percent stake in Georgia Gulf. In the SEC filing, NL said it intends to solicit the written consents of other Georgia Gulf shareholders ``in support of the removal of the current directors and the election of the NL nominees to the company's board of directors.'' If elected, the NL nominees intend to increase the size of the board and to proceed with the consumation of the tender offer and proposed merger. GG Acquisition Corp., a wholly owned subsidiary of NL Industries, launched a $45 per share tender offer for the outstanding shares of Georgia Gulf. NL said it was seeking to dump the current Georgia Gulf board because on Jan. 15 the company announced it had formulated a recapitalization plan that would provide shareholders with a special cash dividend, making a hostile takeover prohibitively expensive. Meanwhile, Georgia Gulf, which is incorporated in Delaware, asked Delaware Chancery Court to declare the recapitalization plan valid and enforceable under state law. NL said it had no comment on the request, which is in the form of a lawsuit against the company by Georgia Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Investor and Company Settle SEC Charges for $2 Million
DOC.TEXT: A New York investor and his company agreed Monday to pay $2 million to settle civil charges that alleged the investor made lucrative securities trades using inside information from his live-in girlfriend, who worked for an investment partnership. The settlement was announced by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which had charged the defendants _ Charles R. Hack, 43, of Manhattan, and Bentham International Ltd., a Cayman Islands corporation of which Hack is a 50 percent owner _ with securities law violations. The transactions took place from February 1985 to September 1986 and involved the trading of stocks or stock options in NL Industries Inc., Time Inc. and Viacom International Inc. Hack and the company did not admit guilt in settling the charges. Hack agreed to pay $1 million in penalties and Bentham agreed to repay $1 million, or the amount of the alleged profit. According to the SEC complaint, Hack ``directly or indirectly'' received confidential information about the companies from his girlfriend, Angella Hearn, with whom he lived from October 1975 to February 1989. Ms. Hearn, who was not charged, is employed by Gollust, Tierney & Olliver, an investment banking partnership that is a general partner in an umbrella investment firm, Coniston Partners. The complaint said that GTO, through Coniston, was involved in a type of trading called strategic block investing, in which it would buy large blocks of stock to try to force the company to take certain steps like restructuring or the liquidation of assets. Ms. Hearn maintained all the records of the firm's trading activity and knew which companies were to be targets of GTO's strategic block investing, the complaint said. After Hack obtained the confidential information, he instructed his partner in Bentham, Anthony In der Reiden, to have the company open a securities trading account in the Bahamas and to follow his instructions on trades. In der Reiden, a Dutch citizen living in the Bahamas, was not charged in the SEC complaint. The SEC said that Hearn caused Bentham to buy 10,000 shares and 1,523 call options of NL stock, 275 call options of Time stock and 1,150 call options of Viacom. They were sold at a profit of $1 million, the complaint said. A statement released by Hack's attorney, Minna Schrag, said: ``Mr. Hack cooperated with the SEC's investigation from its inception and none of the profits from the alleged insider trading were ever distributed or spent.'' Schrag said the alleged profits had been held in an escrow account pending the outcome of the SEC's investigation. Hack also owns Parkview Associates, a Manhattan real estate development firm.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Proposed To Help Protect Pension Funds
DOC.TEXT: Legislation to temporarily block companies from terminating employee pension funds for the purpose of gaining access to surplus assets was proposed Monday in the Senate. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., introduced the bill, saying an 18-month moratorium was needed to give Congress time to review pension fund changes that affect ``the lives and retirement security of millions of Americans.'' At issue is a pratice known as ``reversions,'' in which companies terminate overfunded pension plans, establish a new retirement program often through annunities with insurance companies and take surplus cash for their own use. Surplus pension assets have become a popular target for corporate raiders who acquire a company and use its retirement programs as a source of cash for other purposes. Since 1980, according to a Senate committee, at least 2,000 pension funds have been terminated to provide corporate owners with access to $20 billion in surplus assets. ``I tend to believe that pension fund surpluses belong right where they are _ in the pension fund,'' Kassebaum said in a speech on the Senate floor. ``Terminating these funds and stripping out the `surplus' is but one more way to realize short-term gain at potentially long-term cost.'' The legislation would block only those terminations in which companies seek to use assets of a retirement fund for non-pension purposes. A company could cash in a pension plan to create a new retirement program with better benefits and to make lump sum payments to workers with accumulated benefits of less than $3,500. Kassebaum introduced the legislation in response to what critics called a ``junk pensions'' proposal involving the Coleman Co. The Kansas-based manufacturer of outdoor recreation equipment was acquired last year by MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., which is controlled by takeover specialist Ronald O. Perelman. MacAndrews & Forbes had proposed terminating two Coleman retirement funds valued at $83 million and investing the monies in annunities with an insurance company with a large share of its assets in high-risk ``junk'' bonds. Under the proposal, MacAndrews & Forbes would be able to take more than $32 million in surplus cash for its own use. In response to complaints about the proposal, MacAndrews & Forbes announced last week that it would revamp the proposal and buy annunities only from a company with the highest financial ratings. Also Monday, Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., introduced legislation in the House to provide more protections for pension benefits when federally insured retirement funds are terminated.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with refund program, examiner's comments; edits to conform
DOC.TEXT: The court-appointed bankruptcy examiner overseeing Eastern Airlines said Monday he will fight liquidation of the carrier and called on creditors and management to start looking for compromises. The comments by examiner David Shapiro were contained in a statement announcing court approval of a $105 million ticket refund program for passengers and travel agents. Shapiro said it is ``totally irresponsible'' to presume liquidation or sale are the only alternatives for the Miami-based airline, which he termed ``eminently reorganizable.'' ``There's got to be some give and take on both sides,'' said Shapiro from his Washington, D.C., office. ``If the parties put the public interest first and their own selfish interests second, then Eastern is a viable airline.'' Recently, rumors have circulated that Texas Air Corp. Chairman Frank Lorenzo, Eastern's owner, would opt for a Chapter 7 liquidation. The ticket refund program approved Monday would cover ticketholders and travel agents who made purchases since Eastern filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization last March 9. Those who bought tickets issued before the filing remain under bankruptcy court jurisdiction. Meanwhile, Eastern has agreed to hire back 215 flight attendants by April 1 in a back-to-work accord in which the union agreed to drop a lawsuit challenging the jobs of 215 recruits hired during the strike. ``Both sides had to compromise, but this was something we could live with,'' said Mary Jane Barry, president of Local 553 of the Transport Workers Union, which represents flight attendants at Eastern. The union walked out March 4 in sympathy with the Machinists union, which remains on strike. The flight attendants called off their strike on Nov. 23. Ms. Barry said terms of the agreement with Eastern were described in a letter sent Friday to the carrier's flight attendants. Under the accord, the union agreed to drop a lawsuit challenging the jobs of 215 recruits who were in training when the flight attendants' strike ended, in exchange for Eastern rehiring 215 senior attendants by April 1. Also under the agreement: _Eastern agreed the union will continue to represent all Eastern flight attendants and that all future hiring will come from a seniority list. _Eastern will turn over to the union some $340,000 in dues collected from flight attendants working since the strike began. _The union will drop around $215,000 in claims from a longstanding dispute over pay to union representatives while on union business. Of the 3,600 flight attendants now working for Eastern, about half were hired after the strike began. The others are veterans who crossed the picket lines. The union and Eastern still must agree on a new contract to replace the previous one, which expired in 1988. Ms. Barry refused to comment on whether the agreement marked any change in the hostility between Eastern and its unions. But she said the contract talks will mark ``the real test of whether we can get anywhere.'' Eastern Vice President J. Michael Jones said Eastern was pleased with the agreement. ``We are delighted to have reached a settlement that protects the jobs of those who assisted in the rebuilding of Eastern,'' he said in a letter. Negotiations are continuing with the pilots union, which ended its sympathy walkout just before the flight attendants. Because of Eastern's downsizing as it strives to emerge from Chapter 11, the number of former strikers who will get their jobs back is in doubt. ``The company blackmailed the flight attendants,'' said Frank Ortis, president of the Machinists' local. ``There are still 3,000 of them out of work, and it looks like they are pretty well broke.''

DOC.HEAD: RJR Reports Quarterly, Annual Losses
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT to 1.15 billion sted 1.5 billion
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Earns-Sears, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp. on Monday reported losses for the fourth quarter and all of 1989, reflecting the cost of its record $24.5 billion buyout by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. a year ago. The consumer products giant, the former RJR Nabisco Inc. that was taken private in a deal finalized in February 1989, said it lost $144 million during the three months ended Dec. 31, compared with a $411 million profit in the 1988 quarter. Quarterly sales totaled $3.54 billion, unchanged from a year ago. For the year, RJR Nabisco lost $1.15 billion and had sales of $12.76 billion. That compared with a $1.4 billion profit the previous year on $12.64 billion in sales. RJR Nabisco blamed the negative results on significantly higher net interest expenses, its decision to eliminate excess tobacco trade inventories and costs related to the KKR acquisition. Despite the losses, which were expected, Chairman Louis V. Gerstner Jr. said the company was making fundamental improvements and had steady operating results in its tobacco and food units. ``Our tobacco and food businesses exceeded their goals, despite the extraordinary organizational changes and restructuring we undertook to strengthen the company's long-term prospects,'' Gerstner said in a statement. ``We're off to a very strong start.'' He said the company has substantially completed a divestiture program spurred by the buyout that has allowed it to repay about $5 billion of the debt it took on in the transaction. The company said annual cash flow from operations totaled $647 million after interest payments, exceeding initial expectations. The strength of the company's business, and in turn, its cash flow, is crucial for the success of the buyout, which was accomplished partly through the sale of $4 billion in high-yield, high-risk junk bonds. Interest and debt expenses shot up to $3.38 billion in 1989 from $549 million the previous year. RJR Nabisco's bonds have fallen sharply in recent days after Moody's Investors Service Inc. lowered its rating of the company's debt, and that could mean higher future borrowing costs. Moody's said it downgraded the debt due to uncertainties about the cash flow of RJR Nabisco's tobacco business over the long term as the company faces the problem of fewer smokers and possibly lower profits in the years ahead. For the full year, the company's worldwide tobacco businesses had sales of $6.98 billion, a slight drop from $7.07 bilion in sales in 1988. But excluding the impact of required acquisition-related accounting adjustments and the trade inventory decision, sales would have been up 27 percent, the company said. Food businesses reported 1989 sales of $5.78 billion, up 4 percent from $5.57 billion in 1988. The gains occurred despite record expenses for marketing, research and development of new products, the company said. RJR Nabisco's products include Oreo cookies, Ritz crackers and Winston cigarettes. Its major subsidiaries are R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co., R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc., Nabisco Brands Inc. and Planters LifeSavers Co.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Japan Queries Investors on Their Interest in U.S. T-Bills
DOC.TEXT: The Bank of Japan has probed life insurance companies, securities firms and other institutional investors to guage their interest in buying U.S. Treasury bonds being auctioned this week, news reports said Tuesday. The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's premier financial journal, reported that the country's central bank asked investors whether their investing stance had changed since the previous auction of U.S. government securities late last year. The report said some institutions viewed the bank's inquiry as informal pressure on investors to continue buying U.S. bonds. ``It reflects how the Bank of Japan is concerned about the outcome of the auctions. It's a virtual request for us to purchase the U.S. bonds actively,'' Kyodo News Service quoted an official from a life insurance company as saying. But Takashi Watanabe, a spokesman for the Bank of Japan, said the reports were ``groundless.'' From Tuesday through Thursday, the U.S. Federal Reserve will auction $30 billion of three-, 10- and 30-year securities. In recent years, Japanese investors are estimated to have purchased as much as one third of all U.S. bonds auctioned. If they don't bid actively for U.S. bonds at this week's auctions, that could force American interests rates up and put the brakes on the economy. Kyodo reported that officials at some life insurance companies called the queries ``unusual'' because Bank of Japan officials directly visited investors to solicit their responses. Fears of higher inflation and political uncertainties have driven Japanese interest rates up sharply in recent months. As a result, Japanese rates now are closer to U.S. interest rates than they have been in years. That fact has raised concerns in the U.S. that Japanese investors will no longer find U.S. bonds as attractive as in the past. On Wednesday, Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno will leave Tokyo for Washington to confer with U.S. monetary authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor Says Tanker Captain Drank Vodka; Defense Says He Wasn't Drunk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 10 grafs to UPDATE with testimony by pilot; no pickup. Also moved on general news wires
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AG1
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood was in a bar for seven hours, ordering glasses of vodka, the day before his tanker Exxon Valdez caused the nation's worst oil spill, and he left the bridge before a tricky part of the voyage, a prosecutor said Monday. But a defense attorney for Hazelwood told jurors the skipper's judgment was never impaired, that he showed no signs of drunkenness and was ``calm, cool and collected as a captain should be'' throughout the night and day of the accident. Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole accused the fired Exxon captain of leaving control of his ship in the hands of inexperienced crewmembers who were not certified to pilot the vessel through treacherous Prince William Sound, where the tanker ripped its hull open on a reef outside normal shipping channels. ``The ultimate responsibility for the tanker is with the captain,'' Cole said in his opening statement at Hazelwood's trial. ``The most dangerous part of the journey was after Hazelwood absented himself from the bridge.'' Defense attorney Dick Madson, however, told jurors that Hazelwood left the ship in the hands of qualifed crewmen who may not have had the proper licenses, but knew the territory and took appropriate actions when it appeared the Exxon Valdez was in trouble. Cole also alleged that the 43-year-old captain responded wrongly after the March 24, 1989, accident, frantically trying to move the ship off the rocks _ a maneuver which he said Hazelwood later admitted was the wrong thing to do. Madson insisted that Hazelwood never put the ship in reverse and did not try to move it off the rocks. He insisted that Hazelwood actually was trying to stabilize the ship on the reef in an effort to prevent further damage. Cole said that if Hazelwood had succeeded in moving the ship, it would have capsized, spilling all of its oil. He noted that at least some of the tanker's cargo of Alaska crude oil was saved, although nearly 11 million gallons spilled, killing wildlife and blackening miles of rocky shoreline. Exxon has said it has spent $2 billion on the cleanup. Some state officials say the work is not over and should continue this spring and summer. Hazelwood is charged with a felony charge of criminal mischief, and misdemeanor charges of reckless endangerment, negligent discharge of oil and operating a vessel while intoxicated. Maximum penalty for conviction on all counts is seven years, three months in prison and $61,000 in fines. Cole said that by the time the Coast Guard reached the tanker, officers could see the extent of the disaster. ``They could see the oil bubbling out of the tanker. By some descriptions, it was 12 to 15 inches thick,'' he recounted. Cole reconstructed Hazelwood's actions during the day before the ship left the oil terminal at Valdez, alleging the captain spent some seven hours in a bar called the Pipeline Club where patrons saw him ordering glasses of vodka. When he returned to the ship, Cole said, other crewmembers saw that he was intoxicated and one of them smelled liquor on his breath. Madson said he would dispute that Hazelwood spent the day drinking before he boarded the ship, although he conceded the captain had one or two drinks about four hours before he returned to the tanker. Hazelwood's attorney said the captain was in control throughout the ordeal. ``He did not stagger. He did not slur his words. He was cool, calm and collected as a captain should be,'' Madson said. Many hours after the accident, the prosecutor said, two investigators arrived and found Hazelwood sitting off in a corner by himself. ``It became apparent to both of them that Captain Hazelwood had been drinking. Both of them asked each other, `Did you smell what I smelled?' and they both said `Yes.''' By the time a state trooper arrived to investigate, Cole said the man was told ``they had a wild man on board.'' Later in the day, the ship's pilot, William E. Murphy, testified that he had lunch with Hazelwood and two other crewmembers on the day they stopped in Valdez to pick up their cargo of oil. He said Hazelwood drank iced tea, and that afterward Murphy dropped him off near the Pipeline Club. About eight hours later, they met again on the bridge of the Exxon Valdez, Murphy said. ``While on the bridge did you notice any signs that he had been drinking?'' asked Cole. ``No,'' said Murphy. ``Except I smelled something I associated with alcohol on his breath.'' Within a half hour, he said, Hazelwood had left the bridge, disappearing for about an hour. ``It's not unusual for masters to leave the bridge,'' said Murphy. ``It wasn't typical to be gone for that long in the narrows.'' ``Would you have rather had him there?'' asked Cole. ``Yes,'' Murphy said. Murphy acknowledged he is testifying under a grant of immunity from prosecution, an agreement reached at the request of his attorney. Murphy was not on board the tanker when it ran aground. At the time, pilots _ local boat handlers familiar with coastal waters _ were required to guide outbound ships to a point just short of Bligh Reef. The rules since have been changed to require pilots to remain on board past the reef.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Chain Sues to Depreciate Subscriber Lists
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper subscription lists are depreciable assets, attorneys for a newspaper company argued Monday in a case that could affect how publications pay their taxes. Lawyers made opening statements in a lawsuit brought by the Morning Ledger Co., a Newhouse family company that owns The Star-Ledger of Newark. Morning Ledger sued the Internal Revenue Service after the agency refused to allow the company to depreciate subscriber lists for eight Michigan papers it acquired in 1987. The company would decrease its taxable income by depreciating the lists. Morning Ledger paid $305 million for the papers, which had a combined circulation of 460,000, the company's lawyers said. ``The issue in this case is whether the Morning Ledger can depreciate, for tax purposes, certain assets of its business, and those are the paid subscribers of the Booth Newspapers as of May 31st, 1977,'' said an attorney for Morning Ledger, Albert Turkus. The case is being heard by U.S. District Judge H. Lee Sarokin in a non-jury trial. Subscriber lists can be treated like tangible _ and hence depreciable _ assets because they are used in the taxpayer's business for a limited period of time and because they have ``ascertainable values separate and apart from goodwill,'' said Turkus. But, countered a government attorney, the company ``has no proprietary interest in the subscribers. ``These are at-will paying customers,'' said Gregory Hrebiniak, a lawyer with the Justice Department's tax division. If the newspaper company is given the depreciation allowance, any concern with paying customers could claim depreciation if they isolate some and say they have a ``limited useful life,'' he said. A paper and its subscribers have a ``customer business relationship, just as if they were selling peas.'' The Michigan newspapers involved, formerly known as the Booth Newspapers, are the Ann Arbor News, Bay City Times, Flint Journal, Grand Rapids Press, Jackson Citizen, Jackson Citizen Patriot, Kalamazoo Gazette, Muskegon Chronicle and Saginaw News. The trial is expected to end late this week.

DOC.HEAD: P&O Offers to Buy Rest of Laing Properties
DOC.TEXT: Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Co. PLC on Monday offered to pay 441 million pounds ($745 million) for the 78.2 percent of Laing Properties PLC it doesn't already own. Laing rejected the offer, saying it significantly undervalued Laing's assets and longer-term growth potential. P&O, which has interests in passenger and cargo shipping, said its offer for the remainder of the property investment and development company came to 650 pence ($10.99) a share. Laing shares surged 89 pence ($1.50) to finish at 653 pence ($11.04) on London's Stock Exchange, still below P&O's offer price. Chairman Sir Jeffrey Sterling said P&O's board was seeking discussions with the board of Laing Properties ``with a view to obtaining their recommendation for the offer.'' P&O already holds 13.2 million Laing ordinary shares, a 21.8 percent stake. Sterling said the offer would give Laing shareholders the opportunity to ``unlock value.'' ``In common with most quoted property investment companies, shareholders in Laing have generally seen their investment valued in the market at a discount to the value of the underlying asset,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: EC Looking For Compromise With Japan On Car Trade
DOC.TEXT: European Community countries failed to agree Monday on a proposal to Japan over the contentious issue of phasing out restrictions on auto imports, officials said. Foreign ministers of the 12 EC nations met here to discuss the issue, together with other foreign trade and policy problems. A spokesman for the European Commission, the community's executive body, said, the discussions were ``encouraging'' and an ``undertstanding was found among all parties that a compromise must be reached.'' The foreign ministers have widely diverging views on the troublesome issue. Some car-producing countries, like France, Italy and Spain, have strict limitations on Japanese cars imports and want them maintained. Others, like West Germany and Britain, have taken a more liberal attitude. The European Commission recently proposed abolishing national import quotas imposed by some countries and replacing them with a community-wide quota over a transitional period, leading eventually to the elimination of all import restrictions. The spokesman, who requested anonymity, said countries disagreed on the length of the transitional period. Countries suggested maintaining quotas for periods ranging from three to 10 years, he said. The community wants to do away with the quotas as part of efforts to create a single European market by the end of 1992. By that date, the 12 nations have agreed to get rid of the many trade barriers preventing the free flow of money, people, goods and services. The EC would represent the world's single largest market for cars while Japan is the world's biggest auto exporter. Frans Andriessen, the EC official in charge of negotiating with Japan, asked the ministers for a clear position on the transitional period and import restrictions. The countries have not yet agreed on whether trade negotiations with Japan should be limited to cars or expanded to wide-ranging discussions. The spokesman said the Commission was in favor of a broad discussion. Andriessen told the ministers that Japan has a trade strategy with the Common Market but the community has none in return. The foreign ministers will resume their discussions on Japanese cars in March. A meeting with Japanese officials is scheduled in June.

DOC.HEAD: Rosenberg Named Clausen Successor at BankAmerica
DOC.TEXT: BankAmerica Corp. on Monday named its vice chairman, Richard M. Rosenberg, president and heir apparent of the giant banking company. In another indication of its sharp improvement in recent years, BankAmerica also announced it was increasing its dividend 67 percent to 25 cents a share from 15 cents. Rosenberg, 59, will succeed A.W. ``Tom'' Clausen when he retires as chairman and chief exectuive officer May 24 after heading a healthy turnaround for the once-ailing company, the company said. ``The job I was called back to do, and which I came back to do, is done,'' Clausen said in a statement. ``The recovery has been accomplished. The turnaround has been completed.'' The statement described Rosenberg as the architect of the bank's profit resurgence in retail banking, real estate and commercial banking in California. BankAmerica, parent of Bank of America, earned $1.1 billion in 1989, or $5.19 a share, the highest in its history. Fourth quarter earnings of $270 million represented the 10th consecutive quarter of improvement in the bank's operating income. ``Dick Rosenberg's record as a banker, a manager, and a leader speaks so strongly for itself that little else needs to be said,'' Clausen said. ``He gives BankAmerica the unique combination of strength, experience, innovation and inspiration that is critical to its success in the constantly changing and increasingly competitive marketplaces of the '90s.'' Rosenberg was recruited by Clausen in 1987 from a job as president of Seafirst Corp., Washington state's largest bank and a wholly owned subsidiary of BankAmerica. The imminent departure by Clausen, 66, will mark the end of his second tour as bank boss. He ended a 32-year career at the bank by serving as president from 1970 to 1981. After a stint as head of the World Bank in Washington, D.C., he returned to BankAmerica in 1986 at a time of big losses.
